fields.headline: Brute force
fields.standfirst:
Ronan Bennett explains why the Unionists must not be allowed to minimise the reform of the RUC

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Ronan Bennett explains why the Unionists must not be allowed to minimise the reform of the RUC
fields.body:
Put yourself in this position: you come home to find your house has been burgled (again) and the television and video stolen. You have a pretty good idea who's responsible. You're a law-abiding citizen, all you want is your property back and to feel secure in your own home. But this home happens to be in Ardoyne in north Belfast, a strongly republican area, and one of your neighbours suggests you go to the IRA. You're fed up, you want something done, but you don't approve of punishment beatings.

What do you do? The obvious course is to go to the police, to the RUC. Not an easy decision. Here are some things you will be thinking of as you mull over your predicament.

You will be aware, for example, of the slaughter that took place in Kinnaird Terrace, a mile or so away, and which has come down to you as folk memory. One March night in 1922, at a time of bitter IRA and loyalist fighting, a band of masked policemen led by John Nixon, a district inspector in the RIC (shortly to be reorganised as the RUC), sledgehammered their way into the house of Owen McMahon, a prosperous Catholic publican, moderately nationalist in politics. The policemen roused the family from their beds and herded the men into the parlour, where Nixon ordered McMahon, his five sons and his bar manager, Edward McKinney, to say their prayers. Then the policemen opened fire. When the shooting stopped, McKinney, McMahon and three of his sons were dead; two others were seriously wounded.

A few days later, Nixon visited Arnon Street with some of his men. Here they found a Catholic man, Joseph Walsh, in bed with his seven-year-old son Michael and two-year-old daughter Brigid. Dragging Walsh from the bed, they smashed his head in with a sledgehammer. They then shot the two children, killing the boy. Before leaving, they also shot 14-year-old Frank Walsh.

There's much more - Nixon's men using bayonets to finish the job, murdering a Catholic policeman - but none of it led to Nixon's arrest, though his activities were known to both Lloyd George and Churchill. Nixon remained a policeman, helped found the Sir Robert Peel Memorial Orange Lodge, was later elected to Stormont as an independent Unionist MP, and went on to be awarded an MBE. As Catholics at the time were not slow to grasp, the murder gangs were intent on terrorising the Catholic population into political quiescence and acceptance of the newly created state.

There are those who say there is too much history in Ireland, too much remembering and casting up of the past. But the point about the Nixon murders of 80 years ago is that they established what turned out to be a consistent pattern. And they serve to illustrate that the overwhelmingly Protestant RUC was, from the moment of its creation, whether acting illegally or otherwise, understood by Catholics and Protestants, nationalists and unionists, as existing to serve the interests of the ruling party.

The RUC acted as the Unionist party's enforcers when, in 1964, it used water cannon and batons to snatch a tricolour from the election offices of a republican candidate in Divis, sparking the worst riots Belfast had seen for many years. It was acting in the same spirit in 1968 when in Derry, in front of the world's cameras, it beat civil rights marchers - protesting about the abuses of the Unionist-run Derry city council - off the streets with such violence that it triggered the outbreak of the Troubles. When Unionists express outrage at the proposed reform of the RUC, it looks very much to non-Unionists as if they are doing so because they see the RUC as theirs.

It is a point made by Max Hastings, no lover of Irish republicanism, who recalls in his recently published memoirs being in Belfast in August 1969 and is explicit in attributing to the RUC the deaths of innocent Catholic civilians during the loyalist attack on the Falls Road. He asks the obvious question: how do you expect Catholics to trust a force which was responsible for machine-gunning their co-religionists?

Or for killing children with plastic bullets? Or for colluding with loyalist assassins? Or for brutalising prisoners in the infamous interrogation centre at Castlereagh? Or - in a less dramatic, everyday kind of incident - for beating up a Catholic teenager outside a chip shop, falsely arresting him, throwing him in a van and calling him a "fenian bastard" (the RUC officer in this case was, unusually, sent to prison a few weeks ago)?

It would take much more than the space available here to complete the indictment of the RUC. But let's consider one more count, chillingly reminiscent of the activities of Nixon. In the 80s, in the vicious sectarian murder triangle of mid-Ulster, a serving RUC sergeant who was also a member of the UVF, the loyalist paramilitary group responsible for hundreds of sectarian murders, called at the shop of a local Catholic, like Owen McMahon unconnected with the IRA, and shot him dead. The sergeant was not alone. Six of the 10-strong special RUC squad based in Armagh of which he was a member were later arrested and convicted of assassinating Catholics and carrying out bombing attacks on Catholic homes and property.

The present RUC chief constable, Sir Ronnie Flanagan, routinely dismisses allegations of anti-Catholic, anti-nationalist prejudice in his force by insisting that such episodes are neither "tolerated" nor "systemic". But if, say, half a dozen white Metropolitan police officers had been convicted of moonlighting as racist assassins; if others were handing over weapons to white supremacist murderers in order to kill black people; if yet more were passing on confidential information about prominent members of the black community - their movements, their cars, their telephone numbers, their addresses - and this information was then used to kill them; if they conspired to pervert the course of justice by destroying evidence of their activities; if they had fired plastic bullets that resulted in the killing and maiming of black children on the streets of London; and if all of this had gone on for over 30 years, would the Metropolitan commissioner dare to make a statement as palpably risible as Flanagan's? Would his force have gone unreformed for so long?

There are many who thought Chris Patten's report on the future of policing did not go far enough, and that the case for disbanding the RUC and starting afresh was unanswerable. But, for the sake of something more important, they reluctantly went along with Patten's recommendations, only to see them watered down by Peter Mandelson. If the Unionists succeed in minimising reform, the party may have reason to feel pleased, but it will be to the ultimate detriment of the north. All it will have achieved is the alienation of our burglary victim. Until he can go to the police, the law and order vacuum will continue to be filled by the men with baseball bats and pistols.

 Ronan Bennett is author of His Rebel Heart, a four-part drama set in Ireland between 1916 and 1922 to be screened on BBC1 later this year

fields.headline: FSA fears pensions scandal
fields.standfirst:
Davies warns life firms to cut out the 'risky stuff'
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The City's regulator is scrutinising life and pensions firms to try to head off another "misselling" fiasco.
fields.body:
The City's regulator is scrutinising life and pensions firms to try to head off another "misselling" fiasco.

In an environment where insurance and life companies' profits are coming under pressure, particularly as a result of the introduction of stakeholder pensions, the financial services authority is keeping a close watch on how the firms react to maintain their profitability.

Howard Davies, the chairman of the FSA, warned in an interview with the Guardian that he would be watching out for financial companies which resort to selling customers "fancy stuff which may be more risky".

The government has restricted the fee that pension companies can charge customers for stakeholder pensions to 1% when they are introduced next April, a level which some providers have claimed is not sustainable.

At the same time, Cat (charges, access and terms) standards, which also keep a lid on fees, are being introduced on a number of products, including individual savings accounts.

"There are a lot of pressures on margins in that sector, [through] ISAs and stakeholder pensions, and one thing that we will have to watch very carefully is how will [firms] adjust their cost base to cope with these reduced margins," said Mr Davies.

"Will they be able to do that quickly enough so as not to put their overall financial soundness under risk or will they seek to try to compensate for these lower margins on these basic products by trying to sell more fancy stuff which may be more risky."

"We are watching the displacement effect. Will it push people into trying to sell more fancy products if the core routine business comes under pressure of government Cat marks, and less profitable? What will actually happen as a result?" Mr Davies added.

Leading insurance companies such as Prudential are already taking steps to cut costs. The Pru, for instance, is to axe a third of its salesforce over three years.

Mr Davies said such cost-cutting efforts were a "perfectly appropriate response" to the situation. "What we have to watch for is if there are any companies who are not taking that response and who are instead trying to push through [sales]," he said.

Referring to the pensions misselling scandal, which firms are still trying to compensate customers for, Mr Davies said "we know about the incentive effect".

"These are risks which may be to some degree theoretical... but we think it is our job to try to look for trouble," he said.

As well as keeping a close watch on the providers of pension products, the regulator this week issued proposals for a "decision tree" to help customers decide whether to buy a stakeholder pension.

He hoped the decision trees would help to "avoid misbuying of stakeholder pensions," as he suspected this was more likely to occur than misselling because the low fee meant sales staff would have little incentive to push the products.

The FSA is being formed through the amalgamation of nine former regulatory bodies and will receive its powers though the financial services and markets bill which risks being delayed in parliament by a series of amendments. The most recent was a defeat in the house of lords over its power to police takeovers and mergers.

While the government has pledged to reintroduce that rule, the London Investment Banking Association, in its annual report, points to concerns that undermining the authority of the takeover panel, which currently polices bids, is potentially damaging to the marketplace.

fields.headline: 2002: Britain and a cyberspace odyssey
fields.standfirst:
The government has this week asked Alex Allan to revolutionise Britain's relationship with the net and IT. Here, he outlines his strategy
E-finance: special report
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government has this week asked Alex Allan to revolutionise Britain's relationship with the net and IT. Here, he outlines his strategy.
fields.body:
At a time when technology has dominated the media and set the stock market spinning, the Prime Minister has set up a team to define the role of government in the e-commerce revolution. I offer here thoughts on the approach. My website sets out the action in more detail.

E-commerce. E-business. E-government. Even an E-Envoy! The fifth letter of the alphabet seems to be springing up in front of everything. The original stock market euphoria for dot.coms caught the public imagination. Tiny start-ups bursting with energy and ideas and finding new ways of meeting consumer needs sparked enthusiasm for a "new economy".

But as the shine fades from dot.com stocks, many are asking whether it has all been just another South Sea Bubble about to burst. There is no doubt that we are still in the first flush of a new gold rush. Many of the valuations we have seen over recent months have been highly speculative, and the events of recent days are a healthy correction.

Though I, for one, am convinced that the fundamental premise remains true: the internet is capable of driving wealth creation on a scale, and at a pace, unprecedented by previous technological advances.

It is clear that the internet is not just the preserve of the so-called new economy. It is transforming business across the entire economy: driving cost out of supply chains, lowering barriers to entry, giving smallest firms the sort of global reach previously enjoyed only by the largest. This is what we need to hold on to when the stock markets finally settle. And this is where the government fits in.

What does e mean for government? It wants the UK to be the best place in the world for e-commerce; 2002 is the target date for this; to create an environment in which British businesses and consumers can seize the opportunities which e-commerce is opening up and to make today's prediliction for the letter e a quaint reminder of the time when the internet was not embedded in every aspect of British life.

But what role can government hope to play in the face of such rapid change? Although it may be too early to predict the final shape of our future environment, we can start demonstrating the opportunities, tackling the problems and moulding our new environment.

There is a key role for government to play here. Not trying to second-guess market and technological developments, but helping ensure everyone benefits fully and fast.

I see three sides to this role: markets, people and government. First, markets. Setting the legal and regulatory framework in which businesses and consumers operate is government's traditional role. It remains so in the e-commerce world. But we face new challenges which mean many of the old approaches need rethinking. The pace of change is relentless, so we need light-touch, flexible approaches, encouraging industry to develop effective self-regulation. We need to build global, not national solutions. Rules which might have made sense in the off-line world may be nonsense in cyberspace - so we need to uproot barriers to e-commerce, as we are doing through our Electronic Communications Bill.

Second, helping people get ready for the latest technologies - giving everyone, access to the skills they need to make a success of new opportunities. The Prime Minister has committed the government to achieving universal access to the internet for all by 2005. That is why the government is wiring up all schools and libraries and building Information and Communication Technology Learning Centres to give everyone access to free taster sessions, and launching the University for Industry.

We are helping businesses get on-line too. There is the Small Business Service online portal offering advice and support and in his latest Budget the chancellor announced a £60m package of support to help SMEs get on line, alongside new capital tax allowances for investment by small enterprises in Information and Communication Technologies. And we are working with industry on a long-term strategy to ensure that the skill needs of the technology supply sector itself are met, including relaxing visa restrictions on skilled IT professionals to help counter skills shortages.

Finally, we are reforming the way government conducts its business. New technologies mean government services can be delivered to those affected, immediately and efficiently. We are working hard to take advantage of this. The e-Government Strategy, published last month, sets out how government services will all be conveniently available online.

Links:
e-Envoy site: www.e-envoy.gov.uk/
University for Industry www.ufiltd.co.uk/
Small Business Online: www.business.dfee.gov.uk

webTitle: The holiday cover to pack with your bags

fields.headline: The holiday cover to pack with your bags
fields.standfirst:
Unexpected problems can undermine the best-planned trips. Jessica McCallin looks at the range of insurance on offer
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Unexpected problems can undermine the best-planned trips. Jessica McCallin looks at the range of insurance on offer
fields.body:
If figures from the insurance industry are anything to go by, UK holidaymakers are a pretty responsible bunch. Of the 21m adults who go abroad every summer, 19.3m take out holiday insurance. That's the good news. The bad news is that many unwittingly take out inappropriate cover or even buy too much insurance.

If you've got all risks home contents insurance your possessions should be covered against theft or damage while you are away. If you buy your holiday on certain credit cards, it is automatically insured, which means you don't need extra cover. In addition, some private medical insurance companies include foreign travel in their cover. In fact, depending on what kind of insurance you have in the UK, it's possible that just about every holiday eventuality is already covered.

It's hardly surprising that confusion arises. Having a plethora of insurance companies all competing for your custom may lead to cheaper premiums, but it also means companies are constantly having to develop new products, each with slightly different clauses and cover, to gain an edge over their competitors.

Only last week, Direct Line moved to leapfrog the competition by adding, at no extra charge, up to £25,000-worth of cover for legal fees for customers who want to take their holiday company to court for misleading them. And Primary Direct is hoping to solve the problem of being overinsured by giving policyholders the option of leaving their baggage off their holiday insurance.

So, what is the hapless holidaymaker to do? First and foremost, check your existing insurance policies and the terms and conditions on any credit or debit card which you used to pay for the holiday. You may be happily surprised.

If, once you've gone through these with a fine-tooth comb, you find you need extra cover then think very carefully about the kind of cover you need. Many travel policies will exclude certain risky activities like scuba diving or bungee jumping. Unless you're quite sure that you will not want to engage in some of the more hare-brained holiday activities then it's worth being safe rather than sorry and getting the additional cover.

Valuable items like expensive jewellery or a camera may be excluded from cover. Insurers assume there is no need to take a £10,000 diamond necklace to the beach and if you make a claim for something like it, will probably think you are trying to defraud them.

So if you don't think you can live without the necklace or any other particularly valuable items, you should consider getting them insured independently.

It's also worth remembering that some companies will charge extra to insure money and documents.

Your insurance needs will also vary depending on where you are travelling to. In the litigation-obsessed US, third party liability is vital. But if you're trekking through the Amazon, it's probably more important to make sure you can be airlifted out in an emergency.

The moral of the story is, of course, to check the small print and if you're in doubt about any aspect of the cover, to talk it over with one of the insurance company's employees.

Once you've established what kind of cover you need, start thinking about price. Boring though it may be, shopping around is the only way of making sure you get the best deal. It has been made easier in recent times with online brokers such as www.screentrade.co.uk offering to do the work for you. Just remember these broking services send your information to only around five insurers, so it may still be worth doing a bit of phoning around yourself.

Similarly, the online brokers don't always have the facilities to deal with any special insurance needs.

There has been a huge increase in the popularity of weekend breaks. More than three million people a year go on such holidays without insurance.

If you're prone to taking last minute citybreaks, go abroad more than once a year and/or have a family then you might find that annual travel cover will work out much cheaper.

You can get all sorts of different policies these days. Some will include a one week winter holiday, while others will not. Some will work out cheaper if you intend to travel only in Europe. And others will cover you all over the globe for any possible activity or eventuality you care to imagine.

Whatever you do, don't book your insurance through your tour operator. Travel companies are breaking the law if they try to force you to buy their cover which, in any case, is almost always significantly pricier and often provides less cover than that offered by a travel insurer.

Finally, a few words of advice. Only a die-hard pessimist will go on holiday expecting the worst, but accidents do happen so some sensible precautions should help minimise the amount of disruption you suffer.

Take a note of your policy number and insurer's telephone number.

Keep copies of receipts and anything else you may want to claim on. And if your possessions get damaged or stolen, report it to the local police immediately.

It's also worth remembering that insurers expect you to behave within the bounds of reason when on holiday.

You wouldn't leave your Rolex by the side of the pool in the UK, so don't do it on holiday and then expect the insurer to pay up.
fields.bodyText: If figures from the insurance industry are anything to go by, UK holidaymakers are a pretty responsible bunch. Of the 21m adults who go abroad every summer, 19.3m take out holiday insurance. That's the good news. The bad news is that many unwittingly take out inappropriate cover or even buy too much insurance. If you've got all risks home contents insurance your possessions should be covered against theft or damage while you are away. If you buy your holiday on certain credit cards, it is automatically insured, which means you don't need extra cover. In addition, some private medical insurance companies include foreign travel in their cover. In fact, depending on what kind of insurance you have in the UK, it's possible that just about every holiday eventuality is already covered. It's hardly surprising that confusion arises. Having a plethora of insurance companies all competing for your custom may lead to cheaper premiums, but it also means companies are constantly having to develop new products, each with slightly different clauses and cover, to gain an edge over their competitors. Only last week, Direct Line moved to leapfrog the competition by adding, at no extra charge, up to £25,000-worth of cover for legal fees for customers who want to take their holiday company to court for misleading them. And Primary Direct is hoping to solve the problem of being overinsured by giving policyholders the option of leaving their baggage off their holiday insurance. So, what is the hapless holidaymaker to do? First and foremost, check your existing insurance policies and the terms and conditions on any credit or debit card which you used to pay for the holiday. You may be happily surprised. If, once you've gone through these with a fine-tooth comb, you find you need extra cover then think very carefully about the kind of cover you need. Many travel policies will exclude certain risky activities like scuba diving or bungee jumping. Unless you're quite sure that you will not want to engage in some of the more hare-brained holiday activities then it's worth being safe rather than sorry and getting the additional cover. Valuable items like expensive jewellery or a camera may be excluded from cover. Insurers assume there is no need to take a £10,000 diamond necklace to the beach and if you make a claim for something like it, will probably think you are trying to defraud them. So if you don't think you can live without the necklace or any other particularly valuable items, you should consider getting them insured independently. It's also worth remembering that some companies will charge extra to insure money and documents. Your insurance needs will also vary depending on where you are travelling to. In the litigation-obsessed US, third party liability is vital. But if you're trekking through the Amazon, it's probably more important to make sure you can be airlifted out in an emergency. The moral of the story is, of course, to check the small print and if you're in doubt about any aspect of the cover, to talk it over with one of the insurance company's employees. Once you've established what kind of cover you need, start thinking about price. Boring though it may be, shopping around is the only way of making sure you get the best deal. It has been made easier in recent times with online brokers such as www.screentrade.co.uk offering to do the work for you. Just remember these broking services send your information to only around five insurers, so it may still be worth doing a bit of phoning around yourself. Similarly, the online brokers don't always have the facilities to deal with any special insurance needs. There has been a huge increase in the popularity of weekend breaks. More than three million people a year go on such holidays without insurance. If you're prone to taking last minute citybreaks, go abroad more than once a year and/or have a family then you might find that annual travel cover will work out much cheaper. You can get all sorts of different policies these days. Some will include a one week winter holiday, while others will not. Some will work out cheaper if you intend to travel only in Europe. And others will cover you all over the globe for any possible activity or eventuality you care to imagine. Whatever you do, don't book your insurance through your tour operator. Travel companies are breaking the law if they try to force you to buy their cover which, in any case, is almost always significantly pricier and often provides less cover than that offered by a travel insurer. Finally, a few words of advice. Only a die-hard pessimist will go on holiday expecting the worst, but accidents do happen so some sensible precautions should help minimise the amount of disruption you suffer. Take a note of your policy number and insurer's telephone number. Keep copies of receipts and anything else you may want to claim on. And if your possessions get damaged or stolen, report it to the local police immediately. It's also worth remembering that insurers expect you to behave within the bounds of reason when on holiday. You wouldn't leave your Rolex by the side of the pool in the UK, so don't do it on holiday and then expect the insurer to pay up.

webTitle: Oftel orders BT: open lines to 'flat rate' net rivals

fields.headline: Oftel orders BT: open lines to 'flat rate' net rivals
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Telecommunications regulator Oftel yesterday ordered BT to allow its competitors to use its network to sell unmetered net access in direct competition to its forthcoming Surftime service.
fields.body:
Telecommunications regulartor Oftel yesterday ordered BT to allow its competitors to use its network to sell unmetered net access in direct competition to its forthcoming Surftime service.

The ruling follows a complaint by MCI Worldcom; BT had rejected the American company's request for a wholesale unmetered internet access service and was only prepared to offer a metered service instead.

Oftel said its decision meant that other operators would be able to provide unmetered internet access to consumers in competition to Surftime - the BT unmetered internet access service which is due to be launched at the beginning of next month.

A spokesman for AOL UK, the British arm of the American service provider, said Oftel's ruling effectively ended BT's role as "gatekeeper to the internet in the UK" and opened the way for providing British consumers with the most affordable flat rate online access in the world.

He said that internet service providers would probably be able to offer unmetered access at less than half the cost of BT's Surftime service.

David Edmonds, the Oftel director general, said: "Although the UK has some of the cheapest internet access for residential consumers, Oftel wants to see more low cost access available, with a choice of tariff packages.

"We have been working to encourage a range of tariffs - including unmetered access for heavy users of the internet.

"We have welcomed BT's plans to launch Surftime, which will offer consumers both low cost pay as you go internet access and unmetered, or flat rate, tariffs.

"It is vital for the UK's vibrant internet market that other operators and internet service providers can compete fairly and offer similar products to their own customers."

The services covered by the ruling are based on narrow band access and do not involve broadband technology.

An Oftel survey published yesterday shows that Britain has some of the lowest telephone charges in Europe or the US.

The survey, which covers charges in five European countries and a selection of American states, shows the UK has the lowest prices for off-peak net use in the home. British residential customers also enjoy the cheapest peak-rate voice call prices.

fields.headline: Architect of delusion
fields.standfirst:
Albert Speer
Royal National Theatre, London ***
fields.trailText: Did he know or didn't he? Was he aware of the Final Solution? That is the question that haunts any discussion of Albert Speer. But David Edgar's new play, based on Gitta Sereny's biography, only gets to grips with the big moral issues in the second half, after what often seems an impersonal recital of recorded events.
fields.body:
Did he know or didn't he? Was he aware of the Final Solution? That is the question that haunts any discussion of Albert Speer. But David Edgar's new play, based on Gitta Sereny's biography, only gets to grips with the big moral issues in the second half, after what often seems an impersonal recital of recorded events.

Edgar's purpose becomes clear only as the evening progresses. In the first half he presents us with Speer's version of himself. We see the young architect Speer plucked from relative obscurity in the 30s, becoming a friend of Hitler and preparing grandiose plans for the rebuilding of Berlin as the capital of a new world empire. But Speer's monumental vision is accompanied by an awareness, at the start of the war, of Germany's failure to arm and supply its troops.

In 1942 he becomes armaments minister and is responsible for the use of slave labour to increase production, but his conscience finally rebels against Hitler's scorched-earth policy as the war reaches its conclusion. Challenged on his involvement with the elimination of the Jews, he cries: "I should have known, I could have known, I didn't know."

Up to the interval I felt moodily dissatisfied. Where was the challenge to Speer's presumed ignorance and post-war reinvention of himself? But it comes in the vastly superior second half, in which Speer is constantly arraigned. Rudolf Wolters, his architect colleague and faithful ally, tells him at a literary party: "You flagellate yourself in hindsight to justify your sins at the time." And, in a scene where Speer gives a university lecture based on his memoirs, he is confronted by students who ask the questions that haunt Sereny's book: in particular, how Speer could not have been at a meeting in Posen in 1943 where Himmler spelled out extermination policies?

Even more than Sereny's book, Edgar's play leaves you with the impression that Speer was fully aware at the time of what was going on. Edgar also gives Hitler a powerful climactic speech in which he turns on his followers and asks why he was never taken literally when he talked of destruction and elimination, as he says to Speer, "You realised my vision." The final impression of Speer is of a man who lied to himself and others in order to live with his conscience.

As drama, it is full of slow-gathering power. And Trevor Nunn's panoramic production contains an overwhelming performance from Alex Jennings that combines Speer's ambition and guilt, and a no less fine one from Roger Allam as a Hitler who is Mephistopheles to Speer's Faust.

By the end of a long evening the play has also given us insight into the strange, truth-evading soul of the articulately evasive Albert Speer.

In rep. Box office: 020-7452 3000.

webTitle: Who will join the charge of the heavy brigade?

fields.headline: Who will join the charge of the heavy brigade?
fields.standfirst:
As another high street bank breaks ranks over cash machines, Jessica McCallin looks at the consequences for them and their customers
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: As another high street bank breaks ranks over cash machines, Jessica McCallin looks at the consequences for them and their customers.
fields.body:
Halifax gathered brownie points this week with its decision not to impose charges on people using its cash machines. The move, which was applauded by consumer groups and financial services watchdogs, ups the ante for other high street banks who still intend to levy charges come January 2001.

As the table (right) shows, widespread criticism and anger from customers has not made the big consumer banks change their mind on charging. Most intend to impose some sort of charge, ranging from disloyalty charges, when its customers use another bank's machines, to surplus charges, levied when a rival bank's customer uses its machine.

But developments suggest the tide is turning against them. Supermarkets are urging customers to use their cashback services instead of the cash machines and some, including Tesco and Sainsbury, are threatening not to renew licences for banks with in-store cash machines if they push ahead with the charges.

They have approached banks to try to increase from £50 to £100 the maximum amount of cashback they can offer shoppers, although any increase in the limit will be at the banks' discretion and it is not clear if they will agree.

In addition, the high street banks will soon face competition. Following a critical report from Don Cruickshank, chair of the govern ment's inquiry into banking, which said they had a monopoly over the distribution of cash and the payments system, Link, the company which connects banks to the ATM or automatic teller machine network, this week decided to let up to 15 non-bank providers of cash machines join the system.

This is expected to lead to 1,000 new cash dispensing machines in outlets like shops and garages over the next year. But many of the companies which hope to join Link, such as NetCash, Euronet and Moneybox, say they plan to install many more over the coming years which could push the figure up to 12,000 new machines. The companies say they are unlikely to charge customers for using their machines, especially in well-serviced areas, and will rely on the 40p interchange fee paid by the bank to the ATM owner.

This is unlikely to be the case in the more remote, predominantly rural areas where the cash dispensing companies say they may make a £1 charge for each withdrawal to cover their costs. This is a double-whammy for local residents who are facing widespread bank branch closures. It also means some communities may have no charge-free cash machines in their area.

Meanwhile, the 15% to 20% of pubs and bars which can offer up to £50 cashback are looking at increasing awareness among customers that the facility is available. A spokesperson for the industry said pub owners are asking their staff to publicise the facility, while others are looking at ways of offering cashback themselves.

It is also possible to get cashback from other retailers including, in some instances, the local butcher or village shop. But, again, take-up is low because the public do not know it is available.

Following Mr Cruickshank's recommendations the government has said it will set up a regulator, Paycom, to oversee the cash dispensing industry.

webTitle: A bit runny, but Egg finally gets to market

fields.headline: A bit runny, but Egg finally gets to market
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Egg, the Prudential internet bank, is finally coming to the stock market after months of will it or won't it rumours. But only existing Egg customers on the books before February 22 and with e-mail access will be able to apply. It will be the first totally online share offer.
fields.body:
Egg, the Prudential internet bank, is finally coming to the stock market after months of will it or won't it rumours. But only existing Egg customers on the books before February 22 and with e-mail access will be able to apply. It will be the first totally online share offer.

The 800,000 plus savings account, credit card and mortgage customers will have to decide whether the shares are bargain basement priced or whether they represent an opportunistic move by the parent Prudential to cash in before new competitors come to the market.

They will be offered shares in parcels costing £200, £500 or £1,000, although they will not know the price per share when they apply.

The shares are set to be priced at between 130p and 175p - a quarter to a third of the value they were set to command at the height of dotcom mania two months ago. This would value Egg at between £1.1bn and £1.4bn - at one time analysts gave it a £4bn plus price tag.

The Prudential will sell at least 18% of the company, keeping the rest for itself.

Analysts now say the new price is realistic. And financial bookmakers predict the shares will rise in early trading to around 190p. "The price range seems realistic in these adverse market conditions and I expect it to be succ- essful," said Charles Landa, insurance analyst at SG Securities. The company, which began in October 1998 as a phone bank, was "well established by dotcom standards."

But other analysts fear that while Egg has first-mover advantage and the biggest online customer base, it has had to pay over the odds to sign them up and retain them.

Egg started off paying uneconomic rates for savings and offering credit cards at low interest levels. But that resulted in a £150m loss for the Prudential in 1999.

Egg management must decide whether to continue to pay the best rates or to push up earnings and risk losing the best accountholders. "Stickiness" - the ability to hold customers - is notoriously difficult on the internet. And Egg faces stiff competition from Halifax's Intelligent Finance with its all-in-one account offering 0% credit card interest to some and the as-yet unveiled Cahoot from Abbey National.

The float could yet sink. The Pru will pull the offering if the tech market moves into total meltdown. Qualifying Egg customers can view the mini-prospectus at http://share.egg.com.

webTitle: It's your money ... or your Life

fields.headline: It's your money ... or your Life
fields.standfirst:
After a fierce offensive by the pro-flotation campaigners, Standard Life policyholders must soon decide whether the giant insurer should remain a mutual. Rupert Jones reports on the state of play
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: After a fierce offensive by the pro-flotation campaigners, Standard Life policyholders must soon decide whether the giant insurer should remain a mutual. Rupert Jones reports on the state of play.
fields.body:
Judgment day is approaching fast. Voting forms start going out to 2.3m Standard Life policy-holders on Wednesday, and in a month's time we will know whether the insurance giant is converting to a plc and dishing out windfalls, or staying a mutual.

However, the various claims, counter-claims and accusations that have been flying between the two sides in the battle may have left some policyholders feeling like they've been whacked round the head with a carpetbag.

Last week, in response to the original attack from a group of rebel members, Standard Life issued its defence document which urged policyholders to vote to keep the company member-owned. "The future of Standard Life is in your hands - don't let all you've planned for slip through your fingers," it screamed in bold letters.

This week, the policyholders pushing for the insurer to convert hit back with their own document, entitled It's Time To Stop Misleading The Members, which highlights the reasons they say people should vote for demutualisation. Hours later, the Scottish insurer fired off a six-page statement rebutting the claims by Fred Woollard, the Australia-born, Monaco-based leader of the rebels.

It's quite clear there will be plenty more harsh words exchanged before the result of the vote is announced on June 27. For some policyholders, this will probably be irrelevant - they've already made up their minds. But what about those who have yet to decide which way they will vote? In order to help them, here we attempt to pick through some of the arguments put by the two sides.

The most hotly debated aspect of the row is, of course, windfalls, and what they might be worth. Mr Woollard claims the flotation of the company could see it valued at £12bn-£15bn, which he says would spell average payouts of £5,000-£6,300 to qualifying with-profits policyholders.

Standard Life says that, assuming a flotation value of £12bn and a minimum payout of £250, a 26% of policyholders could be looking at windfalls of £250-£1,000, another 24% might get £1,000-£2,500, while 30% could receive £2,500-£6,000. Around 256,000 policyholders (11%) might get £6,000-£10,000, another 200,000 (9%) could receive £10,000-£99,999, with a lucky 2,000 policyholders set for £100,000-plus each.

In truth, no one can say for sure what the payouts would be worth. There are a number of different ways Standard Life could decide to divide up the cash and the company is right when it says the actual amounts would depend on its market value, which in turn would depend on stock market conditions at the time of the float.

However, many commentators say Standard Life has gone for a very conservative potential flotation value. Ned Cazalet, a respected independent life insurance analyst, believes the company is likely to be worth around £16bn, and predicts average windfalls of £7,000 - even higher than Mr Woollard is forecasting.

But it's fair to say that quoting an average windfall figure of any size is misleading because any payouts are likely to vary wildly, from a few hundred pounds to six-figure sums depending on the type of policy, its size and how long it has been held for.

So how will the vote go? Well, we can assume that a sizeable chunk of the policyholders - probably at least half - will vote to take the cash. However, the rebels face a substantial challenge in getting 75% of policyholders to vote for demutualisation (the amount needed for the proposal to succeed).

Some observers say the most likely result is a vote of between 50% and 75% for demutualisation. This could be the worst result of all for Standard Life's boardmembers: technically they would have won, but this would be a very hollow victory as it means the majority of policyholders voted against them.

It's hard to disagree with Mr Woollard's assertion that a result of, say, 66% would put the board in a very awkward position and leave the company vulnerable to a takeover bid from a predator. However, for the policyholders, a takeover battle could be great news as it would drive up the potential windfalls.

One of the other crucial areas is to what extent policyholders would be affected by a demutualisation because of the need to pay dividends to shareholders. Mr Woollard seized on remarks made by Standard Life group managing director Scott Bell in an interview which quoted him saying that "existing policyholders would not lose out [from demutualisation]". Mr Woollard says this shows that no existing policyholder will suffer, and adds there are legal procedures in place to ensure this is the case.

But Standard Life says this is wrong. While steps are taken to protect existing policies from future bonus reductions caused by the need to pay dividends to shareholders, people who increase their pension contributions could be worse off, as would anyone taking out a new policy.

 Standard Life's website: www.standardlife.com. Mr Woollard's website: www.slmag.co.uk.

Around 256,000 policyholders (11%) might get £6,000-£10,000, another 200,000 (9%) could receive £10,000-£99,999, with a lucky 2,000 policyholders set for £100,000-plus each. In truth, no one can say for sure what the payouts would be worth. There are a number of different ways Standard Life could decide to divide up the cash and the company is right when it says the actual amounts would depend on its market value, which in turn would depend on stock market conditions at the time of the float. However, many commentators say Standard Life has gone for a very conservative potential flotation value. Ned Cazalet, a respected independent life insurance analyst, believes the company is likely to be worth around £16bn, and predicts average windfalls of £7,000 - even higher than Mr Woollard is forecasting. But it's fair to say that quoting an average windfall figure of any size is misleading because any payouts are likely to vary wildly, from a few hundred pounds to six-figure sums depending on the type of policy, its size and how long it has been held for. So how will the vote go? Well, we can assume that a sizeable chunk of the policyholders - probably at least half - will vote to take the cash. However, the rebels face a substantial challenge in getting 75% of policyholders to vote for demutualisation (the amount needed for the proposal to succeed). Some observers say the most likely result is a vote of between 50% and 75% for demutualisation. This could be the worst result of all for Standard Life's boardmembers: technically they would have won, but this would be a very hollow victory as it means the majority of policyholders voted against them. It's hard to disagree with Mr Woollard's assertion that a result of, say, 66% would put the board in a very awkward position and leave the company vulnerable to a takeover bid from a predator. However, for the policyholders, a takeover battle could be great news as it would drive up the potential windfalls. One of the other crucial areas is to what extent policyholders would be affected by a demutualisation because of the need to pay dividends to shareholders. Mr Woollard seized on remarks made by Standard Life group managing director Scott Bell in an interview which quoted him saying that "existing policyholders would not lose out [from demutualisation]". Mr Woollard says this shows that no existing policyholder will suffer, and adds there are legal procedures in place to ensure this is the case. But Standard Life says this is wrong. While steps are taken to protect existing policies from future bonus reductions caused by the need to pay dividends to shareholders, people who increase their pension contributions could be worse off, as would anyone taking out a new policy.  Standard Life's website: www.standardlife.com. webTitle: Motorists pay price as fraud moves up a gear

fields.headline: Motorists pay price as fraud moves up a gear
fields.standfirst:
A US-style crime wave is sweeping Britain. with staged road accidents and bogus claims for personal injuries and written-off cars. What's more, insurers admit they are practically powerless to prevent it, reports Patrick Collinson
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: A US-style crime wave is sweeping Britain. with staged road accidents and bogus claims for personal injuries and written-off cars. What's more, insurers admit they are practically powerless to prevent it.
fields.body:
A new form of motor insurance fraud, involving staged and contrived car accidents plus multiple personal injury claims, is sweeping the UK after swamping US insurers over the past few years.

Some major insurers and investigators now speak openly of systematic criminal activity and corruption, but admit that they are almost powerless to prevent paying out millions of pounds even to known fraudsters.

This week Direct Line, the UK's biggest motor insurer, broke ranks with other insurers which prefer to pretend' that sophisticated computer systems and information sharing is beating the fraudsters. Bill Trueman, who runs Direct Line's anti-fraud division, says the industry is wide open to fraud. "The industry shares hardly any data. Where they do, it's on an ad hoc basis. The Association of British Insurers says the total fraud figure is around £650m a year, but I believe it is much higher than that." His own estimate of how much Direct Line pays out every year on fraudulent claims is "anywhere between £40m to £70m".

This is not a "victimless" crime. On a £400 motor insurance premium, it can add up to as much as £30-£40.

Fake claims for staged and contrived motor accidents began in the US and have, in recent years, spread across the Atlantic. The scam works by faking accidents which allow the insured to make multiple claims, involving as many as 12 fictitious passengers, and which include assistance from bogus witnesses, bent solicitors, doctors and engineers and car repair yards. The big prize is personal injury and criminal injury compensation board payouts, which boost a £20,000 claim for a fraudulent "written-off" car into cheques for hundreds of thousands of pounds.

Bob Barnett set up Ravenstone, a motor fraud investi gation company, eight years ago. Now, with the spiralling of bogus claims, he employs 150 investigators, largely ex-police officers.

He explains how the frauds work: "Mr Smith gets his mate, Mr Brown, to run into the back of his car. Mr Smith, the non-fault driver, makes a claim for the car damage. The vehicle, of course, will have been full of passengers, who will all have suffered severe whiplash, if not worse. The advent of people carriers is a godsend to them - we see a remarkable number of fake claims for Renault Espaces and Ford Galaxys - because it allows you to claim for six or seven passengers.

"As they've got cleverer, they've realised the passen gers of the at-fault driver, Mr Brown, can sue him for negligence. That allows you to add another six fake personal injury claims, so now you have 12 claimants.

"The cars are taken to a friendly accident management company - you can find them in the Yellow Pages - and within minutes the non-fault driver has a free hire car. Miraculously, the damaged car becomes a write-off. We know damn well that they are writing the car off in the garage. Everybody involved in these claims is on the take."

It is not only insurers and honest policyholders who lose out. The fake injured parties extract disability, income support, housing and incapacity benefits from the taxpayer.

Bogus car insurance claims are hardly new, but their volume and sophistication is. "We're currently investigating 20,000 claims in total, and we've seen the incidence of contrived accidents go through the roof. It's grown out of all proportion because it is such easy money," says Mr Barnett.

Part of the reason why the problem has ballooned is that insurers run into a brick wall when dealing with the police or Crown Prosecution Service.

Last year Royal & SunAlliance says that it received 750,000 insurance claims across all classes of business, the vast majority of which were perfectly genuine, but it estimates that it paid out about £80m in fraudulent claims.

Yet it succeeded in prosecuting only 15 cases. RSA's fraud manager Peter Jackson says: "A lot of police forces simply won't take on the case, and the CPS says that it is not in the public interest, so we don't invest much time or money in getting people prosecuted."

Without prosecutions and criminal records, the fraudsters are free to reapply for insurance policies again and again, such is the paucity of information sharing among insurers. Not that a record will deter many from taking out future policies; bogus identities are rife on insurance policies.

Ravenstone says it is tackling the "marked reluctance" of the police in the past to prosecute by putting an entire case together before going to the police. "We give them such a fait accompli that they can't and don't want to ignore it," says Mr Barnett.

Ravenstone assisted another anti-fraud company, Dave Dawson Investigations, in compiling one of the few major cases of motor fraud to reach court in recent times.

Last year nine members of a Preston family were found guilty of raking in £3m from an insurance and benefits conspiracy. The family, led by their father, Mohammed Sharif, staged a total of seven fake car crashes, with family members throwing themselves on to the bonnets of stationary cars. Relatives who gave false names made up the "independent" witnesses. One family member even pretended to be in a persistent vegetative state to claim £1.7m, yet he was seen driving a car shortly afterwards.

"The family would stop at nothing to deceive and manipulate the insurance companies, benefit agencies and the criminal injuries compensation board," said the judge, jailing members of the family for a total of 22 years.

Motor insurers such as Direct Line are only now disclosing the scale of fraud because they believe they have come up with at least a partial solution - by weeding out potential fraudsters at the policy application stage rather than waiting for a dodgy claim. It's called Hunter and is a system that checks applicants on a wide range of criteria to detect if they may be using fake identities and made-up addresses as well as other more sophisticated ways of profiling potentially bogus applicants.

Direct Line wants the entire insurance industry to adopt Hunter so that, within the constraints of the Data Protection Act, fraudulent claims can be reduced. Already another major motor insurer, Churchill, says it is joining Hunter, and R&SA says it is considering installing it later this year.

On a typical Saturday, Direct Line sells around 7,000-8,000 motor insurance policies. In a batch of 1,500 policies, the Hunter system will identify around 30 to 40 that are potentially suspect. Take date of birth, for example."December 25 is the most common birthdate given for Direct Line policies," says Mr Trueman. Why? Because when giving false identities, fraudsters have to give a birthdate, and usually choose the most memorable date of the year. Not that a birthdate of December 25 will automatically disqualify you from a motor policy, but it will get you examined more closely.

Of the 30-40 suspect applications from Saturday's batch being studied by Direct Line on Monday morning last week, many will remain precisely that. Like other companies, Direct Line may be 99% certain a policy is fraudulent but still leave it "on risk" because it cannot be sure.

Insurers would like to see greater anti-fraud action by the DSS and other government departments.

Unless the government takes a lead in tackling fraud - by investing in new IT systems and possibly overhauling the Data Protection Act - the insurers feel they will continue to face an uphill struggle in reducing fake claims and keeping down premium levels for the vast majority of genuine customers.

webTitle: Techniques and technology to carpet the cheats

fields.headline: Techniques and technology to carpet the cheats
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Staging a car accident to make a fraudulent car insurance claim is beyond the pale for most people. But bumping up an insurance claim after a burglary or a holiday is almost a national pastime.
fields.body:
Staging a car accident to make a fraudulent car insurance claim is beyond the pale for most people. But bumping up an insurance claim after a burglary or a holiday is almost a national pastime.

Two thirds of the population think that people exaggerate insurance claims, according to a survey last week by Royal & SunAlliance. Most of us believe insurance claims are inflated by around 30%, and a third of us believe that inflating claims is justifiable in return for years of paying insurance premiums.

The mostly commonly exaggerated claim is for the humble household carpet. Homeowners, it seems, are constantly "knocking over" a pot of paint or "accidentally" dropping cigarettes on to a worn-out carpet, then claiming a new one on their contents policy.

In one village, six familes claimed for the same burned carpet. They were only caught when an insurance agent recognised it from a previous claim.

Exaggerated holiday insurance claims are rife:

One regular traveller claimed for the loss of 33 suitcases in 18 months. Her luggage included designer suits, jewellery, expensive shoes and laptop computers, totalling £85,000 in value. She got 18 months in jail.

A man made eight separate claims at different times for the same operation when on holiday - the removal of his appendix.

A holiday hire car was "broken into", but the small hatchback was not big enough to hold the items listed as stolen.

Another man claimed £14,000 for treatment and convalescence following a dose of malaria -but his "convalescence home" turned out to be a brothel.

A woman claimed to have lost her bag containing £5,000 worth of jewellery on a flight. Shortly after, she reported a burglary at home with the very same jewellery listed as stolen.

The insurers are aware of the scams, but know they walk a tightrope between rejecting fake claims and clamping down too hard on genuine ones.

Royal & SunAlliance says it uses a number of indicators to detect if a claim has been inflated. Fraud manager Peter Jackson says: "We are on the lookout for things that are not consistent with someone's lifestyle. We check that receipts and documents are not fictitious or altered, and we find that the most aggressive customers are often the most likely to be inflating a claim. Claims that are made soon after a policy is taken out are also checked more thoroughly."

Because insurers now nearly always demand proof of purchase on lost or stolen items, and prefer to replace the items rather than send a cheque to cover the loss, they thought they had the amount of fraud on home and travel policies under control.

But last year R&SA picked Peterborough and Ipswich as the pilot sites for a special anti-fraud initiative, and found exaggerated claims were rampant. "We were quite staggered by the amount of inflated claims we picked up on - it was around four or five times the level we expected." The pilot programme will this year be extended to Bristol, Maidstone, Leeds, Oldham, Halifax and Glasgow before going national.

Like Direct Line in motor insurance, R&SA is also introducing technology which will profile applicants when they take out insurance to detect would-be fraudsters.

"The profiles cover such things as socio/economic group, salary levels, and the sum insured. For example, we seem to have a higher level of fraud on lower sums insured."

But Mr Jackson admits the practice of adding an excess to a policy to deter small claims is not necessarily working. It appears that the majority of claims now include around £50-£100 for the value "lost" by the excess element on an insurance policy.

Favourite fiddles

The top 10 inflated insurance claims involve:

1. New carpets

2. High value items of jewellery

3. Tag Heuer/Rolex watches

4. Computers

5. Three-piece suites

6. Widescreen/28in TVs

7. Games consoles

8. Laptops

9. Digital cameras/camcorders

10. Designer clothes

 Source: Royal & SunAlliance

fields.headline: A gilt-edged designer
fields.standfirst:
Leslie Kinsey came from South Africa with just an A level in art and became one of the country's top restorers. Anne McHardy talked to her
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Leslie Kinsey came from South Africa with just an A level in art and became one of the country's top restorers. Anne McHardy talked to her.
fields.body:
Leslie Kinsey agreed with barely a thought when asked if she would help an undergraduate restore a white paint-covered gilded table.

Nine months later, two days before last Christmas, as she touched the last of the gilding, she realised: "The table hijacked my life." She had spent the summer and winter terms and holidays on it at London Guildhall University, where she is a technician, working every free moment, 8am to 8.30pm. She felt that she had abandoned the two of her four children who still lived at home.

The table, now gleamingly restored to the entrance hall at Firle Place, Sussex, an independent stately home and ancestral home of owners the Gage family, repays her by its beauty, she says. That it revealed itself under the paint as a rare piece of 18th century craftsmanship worth around £400,000, is irrelevant. What matters is fulfilling a passion for restoration that she discovered after she left her first career, nursing.

It was this passion that took her into freelance restoration, brought her to London Guildhall and persuaded her to work tirelessly building the link between her university and the Worshipful Company of Painter Stainers, the ancient City of London craft guild that resulted in a Millennium Saloon exhibition in February.

The undergraduate student who brought her the Firle table, Paul Cadman, a former broker, had written to Lord Gage after visiting Firle, which, he said, felt lived in, unlike more pristine National Trust-run houses. He asked to borrow a piece as his degree project.

Lord Gage's art dealer cousin, Deborah Gage, offered a selection. "I had a feeling about this table but I had no idea just how good it was," she says. It had been painted over in the 30s, probably after the carving was damaged. As the paint came off Cadman realised he had a project too big to handle alone. Miss Gage went hunting for provenance.

The Gage family had lived in Arlington Street, Piccadilly, in the 18th century and she thought the table had been commissioned for that house. She asked experts from Christie's and the Royal Collection for advice. So far no certain attribution has been made but a similar table is in the Royal Collection.

Ms Kinsey, called in to help, felt that there would be little gilding left, but, unusually, the gilding was water-and not oil-based and much was intact. "It would have been quicker and cheaper if it had all come off. But when we realised how much was there I tried to consolidate."

"This was such a stunning piece it just consumed me. I went right to the wood and worked out. I tried to find the right colour gold. I bought six different colours, then I found it, Rose Noble." Each day would start with speculation over breakfast. The table had last been worked on 250 years earlier. What had that craftsman eaten?

She started her career as a nurse in her native Cape Town. She considered art school but "all my family were medics". She followed her boyfriend to London, married and started private nursing. "It was so disheartening. I was on relief so I did not get to know my patients." Then she saw an advert for "somebody with a knowledge of interior design" to design open-plan offices. She only had an A level in renaissance art but applied. The firm interviewed 23 architects, then appointed and trained her. It was five years before wanderlust struck again.

She started a degree at Surrey University, but four months from the end she had a baby, "an unexpected and happy surprise". Her second son arrived within 17 months. Turning her talent into producing Montessori toys, she ran a thriving business from her kitchen table until the kids were grown up. In 1989 she decided to formalise her skills and enrolled on a conservation and restoration course at De Montfort University. She established a reputation. "After I qualified dealers kept on giving me work. I had a nice business." Then she saw the London job advertised. She went to London Guildhall. She prefers being a technician because a lecturer spends one hour with students where she spends three.

She still runs a freelance business and her ambitions now include a working retirement. "I want to build an eco house and grow organic carrots. There is painting I would like to do. I would like to learn to carve and, of course, carry on gilding."

"I want to build an eco house and grow organic carrots. There is painting I would like to do. I would like to learn to carve and, of course, carry on gilding."

webTitle: End of the line looming for red braces brigade

fields.headline: End of the line looming for red braces brigade
fields.standfirst:
The advent of online selling is sowing fear in the ranks of estate agents, writes Elizabeth Langton
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Estate agencies are throwing away the red braces in an attempt to reinvent themselves for the new millennium. They are using the internet to target customers via their sexuality, lifestyle or where they live.
fields.body:
Estate agencies are throwing away the red braces in an attempt to reinvent themselves for the new millennium. They are using the internet to target customers via their sexuality, lifestyle or where they live.

Traditional estate agencies that market properties via their shop windows and local newspapers have recently come under threat from the growing number of property internet sites. The new-style agencies, which post property details on the web, have low overheads. They offer to sell homes free or for a small fee to cover the cost of a sale board. Estate agents who used to cover a defined area now have to compete for business in cyberspace.

In some areas competition has forced agents to stoop to new lows, according to Peter White, managing director of Betweenthecommons.com. Mr White believes one leading London agent has been tearing down for sale boards put up by his company, an internet-based rival.

This month a survey from the National Association of Estate Agents found that piracy was a growing problem for agents who use the internet. In London and the south-east, rivals are lifting details from one site and posting them on their own.

Internet property sites have sprouted so rapidly it seems a new one is launched every week. Mr White is taking the concept further and targeting a niche with a website for home owners buying and selling property in an area known as Between the Commons in London's SW11.

It won't be long before office based agents are forced out of the market completely, he says. The idea came about at a dinner party when he was chewing over the usual conversational fodder of house prices. Guests began to complain about the "outrageous" sums estate agents charge for selling homes. "In an area where property is in high demand agents are getting paid £10,000-15,000 for doing little more than trading phone numbers," he says.

That night the idea of a property site dedicated to one hotspot was born. The enclave sits between the green spaces of Wandsworth and Clapham. The streets of large, Victorian homes are beloved of moneyed families, many of whom work in the media, says Mr White.

For £50 home owners can post the details of the property they want to sell or let. When the site has reached a "critical mass" of 30-40 properties, Mr White plans to introduce pages featuring restaurant reviews and free classified ads.

The site has been running for six weeks and has 13 homes for sale and two for rental, all in the Between the Commons area. Those on the fringes can also advertise, he says. While his clients want to save money, Ray Woolford, sales director of Housemartins estate agents, says: "Sellers are earning so much from London homes that estate agents fees (he charges 2%) are almost immaterial." Instead, what Mr Woolford's customers want is service. Something that Housemartins, which bills itself as London's only gay estate agency, believes it can offer. The company has three of fices covering homes in Docklands, south and central London. All calls to Housemartins are dealt with centrally via a freephone number. "We only view each property once a week to prevent the owners being stood up by people who don't turn up." Mass viewings are conducted in groups in the company's own black cabs.

Gazumping is banned at Housemartins, says Mr Woolford. Gay buyers and sellers need agents sensitive to their needs. "Gay clients are often interested in more unusual properties, that might otherwise be hard to sell."

Mr White predicts that tailor-made estate agency will grow. Meanwhile, he is busily registering domain names for other websites: Tonsleys.com for those living in SW18 and NightingaleTriangle.com for the area where Battersea and Clapham meet are in the pipeline.

www.betweenthecommons.com
www.homes-on-line.com

webTitle: Ask yourself: could you be talked into a new career?

fields.headline: Ask yourself: could you be talked into a new career?
fields.standfirst:
Leading research organisation Gallup has launched a recruitment drive to bolster its telephone survey team. So, have you got what it takes to persuade someone to turn off the TV and give you their thoughts on instant coffee? David White investigates
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Leading research organisation Gallup has launched a recruitment drive to bolster its telephone survey team. So, have you got what it takes to persuade someone to turn off the TV and give you their thoughts on instant coffee?
fields.body:
Everyone has opinions, but persuading someone to reveal them to a total stranger telephoning out of the blue requires special skills. Jobs beckon for those who can master this particular version of the cold-call: business is booming for opinion pollsters as political parties seeking votes and companies chasing customers join the rush to discover our likes and dislikes and look for clues about how to win our support.

One of the world's leading research companies, the Gallup Organisation, is recruiting interviewers for its telephone survey team based at Kingston upon Thames. Flexible work patterns of 15, 25 or 35 hours a week are offered with pay ranging from £4.50 to £7.20 an hour, plus the prospect of higher rates and promotion for those with a burning talent for teasing out our views.

"It's a job that offers unique variety and challenges and can be tremendously satisfying," says Gallup's Dominic James, who is handling the latest batch of recruitment. "It requires patience, persistence and persuasion to obtain the opinions of people on topics ranging from politics to brand awareness when they would probably much rather be doing something else such as enjoying a cup of tea or watching TV."

So what is the magic form of words that can persuade a committed fan of Coronation Street or The Bill to switch off their favourite soap in order to be quizzed on the merits or otherwise of New Labour or a particular brand of coffee or car?

"The key is empathy," says Mr James. "The approach must be based on the understanding that no one is obliged to give their views and sensing that, even if they are willing, it might be an inconvenient time for them to do so. Most people will listen to a polite request to take part in a survey - the challenge is to overcome the common temptation to give a polite refusal. When someone appears hesitant, asking for a convenient time to ring back can be effective. It is the talent to establish a rapport that we look for. Our training programmes can de velop this, but are not a substitute for it."

The recruitment process begins, appropriately enough, with a telephone conversation. Applicants are asked to call Mr James or a colleague for a "general chat" about what the job involves. If this goes well from Gallup's point of view - it will be looking for a "good telephone manner" which includes clarity of speech and listening skills - applicants will be asked to take part in an "automated interview".

This involves telephoning a freephone number and listening to a recorded voice (that of Mr James) asking applicants to agree or disagree with 50 statements. Answers are given via the telephone key-pad on a scale of one to five to denote strength of feeling about the statement.

Gallup was reluctant to give examples, saying the effectiveness of the process depended on applicants giving an instant response to statements they had not considered before. However, using the organisation's own guiding mantra of "patience, persistence and persuasion", I did obtain an example of the type of statement used.

This was: "Are you a good loser?" Gallup stressed that there was no "right or wrong" response to this or any other statement, but did indicate that a "good" interviewer would see being turned down for a survey as a stimulus to greater efforts when asking the next person.

"The automated-interviews are aimed at detecting the particular talents Gallup believes are necessary to do the best possible job for our clients," says Mr James. "It is not a reflection on the individuals we do not select - someone we decide is not suitable may have exactly the qualities that another firm is looking for."

Gallup's last recruitment drive attracted 450 inquiries, with 220 people being invited to take the automated interview. Of these, just 19 made it through to the final selection stage, attending a three-hour assessment evening. Interviews confirm that applicants understand the demands and purpose of the job and the requirement to make a six-month commitment if selected. Candidates then conduct mock telephone surveys with experienced interviewers playing the part of the public.

"These are recorded and analysed so that we can be really sure that candidates do have the depth of talent required," says Mr James. Making it through to this final stage usually bodes well for applicants; last time, all but three were offered contracts.

Training for those selected begins with courses on interview techniques, the principles behind polling and the reasons why clients use surveys. "The use of the 'third ear' is one of the skills taught," says Mr James. "This means listening for clues that will help an interviewer win co-operation through empathy. Hearing a door-bell, for example, is a cue for suggesting a pause in the conversation or offering to call back at a later time." Two weeks are then spent in the call-centre working alongside a nominated "buddy" who acts as a mentor. The first "live" surveys will be done with the buddy on hand to offer instant advice. Further classroom sessions follow to review progress.

"The development process never really stops," says Mr James. "We operate an open-door policy to offer staff easy access to more experienced colleagues to discuss training and any other issues."

Calls made by interviewers are monitored by senior staff (the term "manager" is not used in the Gallup culture), but it is stressed that the aim is to ensure high professional standards are maintained and any need for further training identified.

"Performance targets are used, but no one is set unrealistic numbers of interviews to complete and staff have control over when they work to complete their chosen number of hours duty per week," says Mr James.

Those on 35 hours can select start times between 1.30pm and 9pm on week-days; 25-hour people work within a 3pm to 9pm slot; with those doing 15 hours choosing times between 4pm and 9pm. Saturday hours for all groups are anywhere between 10am and 4pm; Sunday slots are between 4pm and 9pm.

The interviewers come from a wide range of ages and work backgrounds. Professors in their 60s have found themselves working next to trainee hairdressers, with each being equally adept at the job. "Talent for the task is not linked to age, background or previous training," says Mr James. "Our selection process is rigorous, but passing it means you have every chance of doing the job well and will want to stay with us. The flexibility on hours makes the work particularly suitable for parents, the early retired and students."

How Nigel Kennedy got the vote for best politcal leader

Karen Cook, 28, joined Gallup's first telephone call centre in Britain when it was set up in 1995 at Weybridge, Surrey, with just 10 interviewers. She now works with the soon-to-be increased 80 interviewers at Kingston.

"I studied psychology, which can be a useful background for market research," she says, "But there is a view that successful telephone interviewers tend to be born and not made. Training can help, but you do need a natural ability for winning the confidence of all sorts of people very quickly."

Her tips include remaining polite at all times and never becoming disheartened. "When five or more people in succession don't want to take part in a survey, always remember that the next five may all say 'yes'. Persistence and never allowing your efforts to persuade to slacken usually succeeds in the end.

"The rewards of the job include feeling that the information you obtain can make a difference for the good - surveys carried out for charities, for example, can help them target fund-raising more effectively. There is also a real feeling of excitement compiling surveys in the run-up to a general election - it's like having a glimpse into the future."

Mind you, questions about politics can produce bizarre replies. Ms Cook says that asking which party leader - Tony Blair, William Hague or Charles Kennedy - was best suited to be prime minister, produced an unshakeable answer from one respondent. "It was along the lines of 'it has to be Nigel Kennedy - what a musical talent!'"

Fellow interviewer Christina Carlsson, also 28, describes the Kingston call centre as the most family-friendly place she has worked. "There is great flexibility allowed in the hours, while the work is absorbing,challenging and very motivating. If you enjoy talking on the telephone and are keen to play a part in finding out what people from all walks of life are thinking about all sorts of issues and subjects, it's a fascinating job."

 Recruitment inquiries can be made to Dominic James at Gallup on 0208-939-7622.
