webTitle: What happens after don't buy dot.com

fields.headline: What happens after don't buy dot.com
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Just like a market for fruit and vegetables, the price of shares is determined by supply and demand. The collapse in hi-tech stocks was precipitated by a slump in demand while supply remained plentiful. The price falls have choked off supply, encouraging hope that stability might be restored.
fields.body:
Just like a market for fruit and vegetables, the price of shares is determined by supply and demand. The collapse in hi-tech stocks was precipitated by a slump in demand while supply remained plentiful. The price falls have choked off supply, encouraging hope that stability might be restored.

Herd behaviour is typical of participants in financial markets. Only a few weeks ago bankers raced to bring hi-tech companies to market, and investors - particularly private punters - were only too delighted to furnish them with cash. Now the rush towards the exit by investors has forced bankers to issue a string of cancellation notices.

Among the most high profile new issues that have been postponed or cancelled this week are those of Yes TV and Letsbuyit.com. Earlier in the year there seems little doubt that such flotations would have been roaring successes. Now, although nothing has changed within the businesses, the fundraising vital for their future expansion has proved impossible.

One can only guess at the full extent of new equity supply that has been cancelled, but it can be said to tot up to billions of dollars.

For every new issue pulled at the last minute when investor roadshows proved unsuccessful, there are many more that were almost on the blocks but will not now take place.

For the companies concerned the closing of the new issue door could have dramatic consequences. Who knows how many more dot.coms could follow Boo.com into liquidation, now investors have traded in credulity for scepticism. Flotations have often been matters of urgency as aggressive building programmes burn up existing cash.

The fine line drawn by the market's fickle finger is well illustrated by Letsbuyit.com. Rarely has a soap opera ad break come around without a troop of cartoon ants marching across our TV screens to drum up interest in Letsbuyit's e-tailing concept. Now the company appears likely to have to cut its aggressive marketing spend.

One can only speculate about the impact this will have on Letsbuyit's attempts to create a viable business. Without fresh funds it will be lucky to see out the year. There but for the grace of God go many of the earlier dot.coms with Lastminute.com top of the list. One can only hope they realise their luck and deploy their cash effectively.

The withdrawal of putative new issues is part of the normal healing process in the equity market in which supply and demand are restored to balance. Companies jilted at or close to the altar invariably ask when the new issue window will reopen. The answer must always be: only when secondary market investment interest has been re-established.

A flotation might represent a wonderful investment opportunity, but it does have risks over and above those associated with any foray into the stock market. A company coming fresh to the market will have been pored over by its advisers and some third party analysts. But this cannot be as testing as the daily scrutiny all publicly quoted companies are subjected to. Time exposes risks.

It is no surprise, then, that professional investors typically restore their confidence through investment in companies they know well and have followed for some time, rather than in unproven new issues. Only when this rehabilitation is complete - and demand is restored - does the new issue window open once again.

The traditional cycles within the equity market are increasingly compressed into shorter time periods.

This is bound up in the greatly increased volatility of share prices. Thus the severity of the fall in hi-tech stocks holds out hope that investor interest will be rekindled by the reappearance of value.

The consensus in the market is that investor interest in hi-tech shares will be restored in the autumn and that the pipeline of flotations will begin to fill again towards the end of the year. But I would not be surprised if the hi-tech indices recover before the summer. If so, good quality companies should be floatable once more in September.

Whether hi-tech stocks recapture market leadership will depend in part on the fortunes of the old economy. While they have resumed leadership by default, the suspicion exists that they might yet fall short on profit delivery.

Sterling's strength against the euro has given a bear hug to the profit margins of UK manufacturers and exporters. The full effect of that has yet to be revealed to investors, and faced with a choice between old economy disappointments and discounted new economy dreams, many are simply sitting on their hands and wishing for summer.

Edmond Warner is chief executive of Albert E Sharpe Securities

fields.headline: Worldly music
fields.standfirst:
Kronos Quartet / Dawn Upshaw
Barbican, London **
fields.trailText: Dawn Upshaw's first entrance could not have been less auspicious. In a real-life enactment of every singer's worst nightmare, she sang a few tentative phrases of Osvaldo Golijov's Lua Descolorida before stopping mid-flow and announcing that she had lost her voice just minutes before coming on stage, thanks to a nasty cold. But although Upshaw had to curtail her programme, her singing, which sounded almost as full-toned and expressive as her unafflicted voice, was the highlight of the evening.
fields.body:
Dawn Upshaw's first entrance could not have been less auspicious. In a real-life enactment of every singer's worst nightmare, she sang a few tentative phrases of Osvaldo Golijov's Lua Descolorida before stopping mid-flow and announcing that she had lost her voice just minutes before coming on stage, thanks to a nasty cold. But although Upshaw had to curtail her programme, her singing, which sounded almost as full-toned and expressive as her unafflicted voice, was the highlight of the evening.

Tonight Is the Night is a collaboration between the Kronos Quartet and Upshaw, designed as an aural journey around the world, presenting the music, poetry and singing styles of everywhere from Azerbaijan to the US, India to Yugoslavia.

Gabriela Ortiz's five-movement song cycle Baalkah, which sets texts in a Mayan dialect and was specially commissioned for this tour, was the most substantial and involving of the new works and arrangements.

Baalkah veered from slowly evolving, almost static textures, to violent, motor-like rhythms. Upshaw's voice was treated as another instrumental part, as the richness of the Mayan dialect inspired melismatic meditations on individual words and obsessive repetitions of others. In the final movement, which was framed by Upshaw's declamatory, wordless monologue, the Kronos players bowed suspended cymbals and left Upshaw alone on stage in a mesmerising trance.

Replacing the numbers Upshaw could not sing, the Kronos played a typically wide-ranging selection of music, from Hildegard von Bingen to John Cage. The historical and cultural diversity of the concert was laudable. But the quartet's approach treads a fine line between a genuine revelation of many kinds of music and a multicultural glibness.

Their playing, and their style of presentation, tends to flatten out the differences between musics and cultures into a blandly trendy stew of lighting effects and a succession of short, easily digestible cultural chunks.

fields.headline: Great movie soundtrack
fields.standfirst:
Saint Etienne
School of Art, Glasgow **
fields.trailText: Saint Etienne may be victims of their own success. So brilliant are they at producing music akin to the soundtrack of an imaginary movie - all 70s London with heroes in tank tops - that the tunes on their latest album, The Sound of Water, sound like incidental music. This is not a good thing when playing that music live.
fields.body:
Saint Etienne may be victims of their own success. So brilliant are they at producing music akin to the soundtrack of an imaginary movie - all 70s London with heroes in tank tops - that the tunes on their latest album, The Sound of Water, sound like incidental music. This is not a good thing when playing that music live.

From Heart Failed, their next single, through to A Little Overcome, this gig was a monotonous meander through backstreets, rather than a joyous ride in a softtop sports car on the autoroute. Even Like a Motorway failed to get the engines revving.

There is no denying Saint Etienne's contribution to pop music. From their 1989 cover of Neil Young's Only Love Can Break Your Heart to their collaboration with DJ Paul Van Dyk, Tell Me Why, they have been at the forefront of experimentation with musical genres, sliding gracefully between easy listening, trip-hop and samples of old films.

Their blend of influences might be fine in the studio, but live, practically all the nuance of their layered, atmospheric, poised music was lost amid the din, as were many of the lyrics. This may have been just as well: 10 years of recalling the minutiae of everyday life sounds fake-naive.

While Sarah Cracknell could sing a phonebook and it would sound like candyfloss on a sunny day, this talent makes for soothing background Muzak, not a smashing live performance. Always retro before their time, Saint Etienne are now in danger of sounding old hat. Where there should have been swing, there was lacklustre swaying. Where there should have been melancholia, there was an arch smile and trumped-up basslines. Cracknell - who, surprisingly, had all the stage presence of a melting ice pole and was in danger of being upstaged by the backing singer - oscillated like an underwater frond caught in an eddy. Still, it was she, not the music, that provided the audience with a lasting impression of the evening. Sarah Cracknell: she's got lovely hair.

Saint Etienne play Bristol University (0870 444 4000) tonight, then tour.

webTitle: Rehman's life ban means little in the Ribblesdale League

fields.headline: Rehman's life ban means little in the Ribblesdale League
fields.standfirst: More about corruption in cricket
fields.trailText: One of the two Pakistan players banned for life from international cricket after being found guilty of match-fixing was given permission last night to while away his career in the relative calm of Lancashire club cricket.
fields.body:
One of the two Pakistan players banned for life from international cricket after being found guilty of match-fixing was given permission last night to while away his career in the relative calm of Lancashire club cricket.

After a day of mounting bewilderment, the England and Wales Cricket Board gained confirmation from their counterparts in Pakistan that Ata-ur-Rehman would be free to continue his career at club level. The 25-year-old fast bowler, who played two years for Pakistan as a teenager, will line up for Blackburn Northern against Whalley in the Ribblesdale League on Saturday.

The news came as a relief to the club's secretary Geoff Eccles. "If the authorities had asked us to ban him, we would have had to honour their request," he said. "But there is nothing in the league rules to say whether you can have a replacement overseas player for someone found guilty of match-fixing, so we could have faced a bit of a problem."

As the implications of the Qayyum report were sinking in around the world, Rehman was discovered completing a four-day coaching course in the Old Trafford indoor school. He will sit an exam today for his grade three coaching certificate and, if successful, will be officially entitled to coach Northern's players. Trips down to the local bookies are not expected to be on the agenda.

Rehman, in his first season as a Ribblesdale League professional, said: "I intend to talk to my solicitor to decide what to do next, and I wouldn't want to comment on whether the punishment is harsh. But I intend to keep playing for Blackburn Northern."

An ECB statement said the organisation had "no legal authority to prevent him from playing cricket in this country".

Claims that Rehman repeatedly changed his evidence because he was shaken by threats made against him - behaviour which irritated Justice Malik Mohammad Qayyum so much that he found him guilty of perjury - have already filtered through to the Lancashire leagues.

Channel 4 were also poring over the Qayyum report last night. They have enlisted Wasim Akram - a man whose reputation, according to Judge Qayyum, is too "sullied" for him to ever captain Pakistan again - as a commentator for England's forthcoming series against West Indies .

The official line from Channel 4 was that "no snap decision will be made. We will base our decision on the minutiae of the report".

Rehman told an earlier inquiry that Wasim gave him £1,100 to bowl badly in a one-day match in Christchurch in 1994. He maintained to the Qayyum commisssion that he changed his story under coercion after Wasim paid for his air ticket from Newcastle to Manchester: a ticket which Wasim's counsel accepted was paid for on Wasim's credit card.

But Rehman was recalled for cross-examination last September and categorically stated that he had lied to the commission. He was immediately issued with a notice for perjury. In a third appearance before the commisssion, he said he had been induced by team-mate Aamir Sohail to give evidence against Wasim.

Lord MacLaurin, the ECB chairman, said yesterday that the International Cricket Council had the power to press the Pakistan Cricket Board to increase the punishments on their players. "Watch this space, because this is not the end of it," he said. But the PCB director, Yawar Saeed, said he did not fear further sanctions.

Australia have appointed Greg Melick, a lawyer and former part-time army commando, as the country's first anti-corruption watchdog. He has been given sweeping powers to investigate claims of corruption and match-fixing.

fields.headline: Kapil vents fury at 'malicious' claims
fields.standfirst: More about corruption in cricket
fields.trailText: India's coach and former captain Kapil Dev yesterday dismissed as "baseless and malicious" fresh claims by his one-time team-mate Manoj Prabhakar that he had been guilty of match-fixing.
fields.body:
India's coach and former captain Kapil Dev yesterday dismissed as "baseless and malicious" fresh claims by his one-time team-mate Manoj Prabhakar that he had been guilty of match-fixing.

In a robust statement, Kapil said that there was "no truth whatsoever" in the allegation made by Prabhakar two days ago that he had offered him a bribe to "underperform" in a match against Pakistan back in 1994.

"I wish I could ignore these baseless and malicious allegations with the contempt they deserve, but I owe it to the nation to personally state that there is no truth whatsoever in these allegations," he declared.

"All I can say is that I am either being made the target of a deep-rooted conspiracy or personal jealousy or animosity," he added.

In a press conference on Wednesday, Prabhakar graphically described how Kapil allegedly offered him a £38,000 bribe during the Singer Cup in Sri Lanka six years ago. He was shaving in the bathroom at the time. "I asked him, 'Why should I sell my country to Pakistan? You can do that but I am not a traitor'," Prabhakar said he recalled.

The former all-rounder claimed five other Indian players knew about the approach. Prabhakar first alleged three years ago he had been offered a bribe by a team-mate, but had refused to identify him.

Prashant Vaidya, who was one of the five supposed to know of the approach, yesterday said he was baffled by Prabhakar's allegations. "I am shocked and surprised to be drawn into the controversy, about which I have no idea," he said. Ajit Wadekar, the team's coach at the time, yesterday refused to confirm or deny whether he knew about the offer.

Prabhakar's claims are unlikely to prevent Kapil from departing with his Indian squad to Dhaka for the Asia Cup, which begins on Sunday. The Board of Cricket Control in India has so far refused to comment on the row.

"The CBI [Central Bureau of Inquiry] is inquiring into the matter and I request everyone, especially the media, to hold their hands until the CBI completes its investigations, since publicity of reckless allegations can cause irreparable harm," Kapil added.

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: Groucho Marx's most oft-quoted one-liner was the one about never wanting to join a club that would have him as a member. Deep down, sadly, Mal Loye may well harbour similar misgivings.
fields.body:
Groucho Marx's most oft-quoted one-liner was the one about never wanting to join a club that would have him as a member. Deep down, sadly, Mal Loye may well harbour similar misgivings.

Loye made his highest championship score for more than a year yesterday, helping Northamptonshire overhaul Middlesex's 217 in the Second Division match, yet still failed to reach 50: the latest underachievement from a batsman whose fall from grace continues to baffle and dismay. One theory is that success, with all the attendant pressures and expectations, scares him. As it did Somerset's Mark Lathwell.

"That wouldn't be something I would think, or say," said Bob Carter, the county's coaching director, after watching Loye make 47 - more than his previous three four-day endeavours put together. "Then he came down the wicket to Phil Tufnell and got his feet mixed up. He's been working hard on moving into the ball, too, made progress."

A year ago Loye was standing where Vikram Solanki is now, on the fringe of the England team. That Solanki's lordly unbeaten 161 off 211 balls, adorned with 25 fours and a brace of sixes, has given Worcestershire a commanding lead over Gloucestershire rammed the point home.

Loye, after a coming-of-age 1998 campaign that saw him average 62, starred for the A team in southern Africa. A place in the England middle order was within grasp. Cue 302 runs in 18 championship innings, 20 fewer than that record-breaking assault of Glamorgan the previous summer. A threat to leave the club, though ultimately empty, must have weighed heavy.

He was one of three top-order men to fall to Tufnell as the hosts slid from 142 for one to 151 for four before Graeme Swann and David Ripley stiffened upper lips.

A splendid day all round for the thirtysomethings was confirmed by Phil DeFreitas, who helped the last two Leicestershire wickets double the total to 336 at Riverside with one of his more sedate efforts, 81 not out off 157 balls, then wobbled Durham with three wickets.

Then there was Tony Cottey, 34 next week, striking his first century in 12 months as Sussex comfortably outstripped Essex's 255. The sole blot on the visitors' landscape was the duck Ronnie Irani inflicted on Chelmsford's least favourite Repton old boy, Chris Adams.

The Zimbabweans enjoyed the most encouraging day, Pommie Mbangwa whipping out six men for a dozen runs as Yorkshire dissolved to 119 for nine, 116 behind. The Yorkshire Post apparently only just resisted the headline "Pommie B'stard".

fields.headline: Joanna lessons
fields.standfirst: Joanna MacGregor has a hectic schedule as a concert pianist. So why has she has added the task of writing books for young children learning the piano?
fields.trailText: Joanna MacGregor has a hectic schedule as a concert pianist. So why has she has added the task of writing books for young children learning the piano?
fields.body:
Even a member of that mythical species, the completely tone deaf, could not fail to be stirred by a Joanna MacGregor performance. Simply to see her zipping around a keyboard grabbing fistfuls of notes at the behest of some unfeasible contemporary score is to watch a pianist pushing the human frame to its limits.

But even her dazzling virtuosity was not enough to wow one small boy at a recent concert she gave for kids. Like the rest of the audience, he had been cascaded with bits and bobs of pieces in every style from her vast repertoire of classical, jazz, ragtime, blues, techno, African etc. He'd coolly watched her dive under the lid of the concert grand to pluck the wires - normally a surefire knockout for kids. Then as she drew breath and invited questions, he piped up:

"Can you play Match of the Day?"

How many veterans of the Wigmore Hall platform would be floored by such a request? For Joanna MacGregor, though, it was simply a hoot. "In his eyes, until I played Match of the Day, I hadn't passed the test. I wasn't a proper pianist." Needless to say, she sailed through and doubtless logged the experience for her next children's recital.

MacGregor is rare among top-flight concert pianists, for the interest she takes in how small children learn the instrument. She has just published her own piano tutor for children: Joanna MacGregor's PianoWorld. And she has managed it despite a crippling work schedule. This week, for instance, she was giving a lecture in London as Gresham professor of music. Then she was straight off to Bath for the first of three concerts at its festival - a recital that included a fiendishly hard piano transcription of Stravinsky's ballet Petrushka.

There hardly seems to be a festival this summer which she is not gracing. Tomorrow, as artistic director of the Society for the Promotion of New Music, she is in the thick of an all-day collaboration between nine young composers and artists at the Tate Gallery, Liverpool. She runs her own recording label: SoundCircus. And by her own admission she cannot meet an artist of any sort without being tempted to suggest a joint project. So, why on earth take on the extra burden of writing a book?

"Everyone asks me this. People are clearly surprised that I would concern myself with the very first lessons. It says a lot about the music profession that we tend to concentrate on the top end, on the BBC Young Musician competition, on this idea of the child as a nascent virtuoso.

"Most people's interest in music is much more ordinary and much more everyday. I find that much more interesting."

In producing the first three books of what she intends to be a continuing series, MacGregor is drawing on vivid experience. Between the age of 18 and 25, before she was getting concert engagements as a pianist, she taught a stream of beginners the piano. But most important in her make-up now as a musician who is unsurpassed in the breadth of her eclectic repertoire, was the endless procession of small boys and girls during the 1960s and 70s traipsing into her childhood home in Willesden, north London, where her mother taught the piano.

"Not only was I fiddling around at the keyboard but there were all these other children of all backgrounds wanting to play every sort of music - bits of classical, jazz, pop, improvisation."

Until she was 18, she had lessons from her mother, too. "I wasn't part of that hothouse thing. I didn't go to the Yehudi Menuhin school. I grew up with the idea of trying to make music available to people of all abilities."

Just as everyone should be able to learn how to swim, or to speak a smattering of French, so, in her view should everybody be able to make a stab at learning the piano. Some kids have a flair and make rapid progress. Such kids, she says, can take care of themselves. She is fascinated by the others: those who chug along at varying rates of progress, enjoying it for a while, but all too often giving up.

This falling off happens at any stage. Some kids find the beginning too frustrating. Others rebel at parental pressure driving them to "be like those children on the telly". A fair proportion bow out at Grade 5, the peak of the foothills, after which the going gets distinctly tougher.

"I worry that some people use music, like sport, as a way of making their children achieve things, rather than just saying: it's music, it's there to enjoy. I don't want to sound woolly, but the reason children fall by the wayside is because they feel they are not going to match up to their parents' high expectations."

The production of her own training manuals begs an obvious question. Does she have a poor opinion of the existing corpus of tutor books, or indeed of the general quality of piano teaching? "I'm very reluctant to criticise other people's teaching or others' tutor books," she says, shutting that avenue for discussion. What she does do is readily accept that her books, colourful and eye-catching though they are, are by no means the only books on the market designed to make the early years enjoyable.

Her wheeze for luring the fives, sixes and sevens through those bewildering early months is to weave a storyline into the books and their accompanying CDs, right from the that first fumbling for middle C. Ned, a crepe-soled rocker with an extravagant quiff, and Grumper, a cat in cool shades, live on top of an old upright piano. A note, signed Scherzo Sisters, arrives: "PianoWorld needs help today, Silent pianos get thrown away. To save the piano complete our tasks, That's all the Scherzo Sisters ask."

And so the odyssey begins. First task. Find the Cs - "they're always to the left of the two black keys". The challenge at this fragile stage is to make the work interesting.

"Kids want something that sounds exciting and good, even if they're playing just one note." And so, from lesson one, there are accompaniments in a variety of styles for teacher - or parent - to play beneath the child's line. For kids whose parents aren't pianists, the accompaniments are recorded on the CDs.

For five to seven year olds, learning the piano should be unadulterated fun, MacGregor insists. "You have to allow them to improvise and give them a reason to play at either end of the keyboard and on the black notes and use the pedals."

In Book 2, the characters fall inside the piano and open up opportunities for making a whole lot of weird noises. As progress is made, bigger obstacles loom. Children need to be coaxed quite hard to read the music rather than rely on ear. Having relied for so much of her own childhood on her very keen ear, MacGregor has considerable sympathy on this score.

But perhaps the biggest problem of all is practice. How can children be persuaded to play a passage even once again, let alone many times over. She admits not having practised rigorously until she went to the Royal Academy of Music, after graduating in music from Cambridge. As a teenager, she had simply played what she liked: hymns at school, keyboard with bands, and lots of Gershwin for dance classes.

At the Royal Academy and afterwards she began building up a contemporary repertoire whose formidable difficulties demanded practice. Now she loves practice. The eight hours a day that she gets through are the core of her musical life, she says, more important than performances.

"I have enormous sympathy with people who find it difficult to practise. I don't think people talk about practice enough."

The secret of any practice, whether for 20 minutes or five hours, is to work out beforehand exactly what it is you are aiming to do, she says. Other tips: treat yourself - play the whole piece through, however many wrong notes. And mix hard with easy.

"If I'm learning a Birtwistle, and gosh that's hard. It's nice to play a piece by Eric Satie afterwards."

But Birtwistle must wait for Book 4.

· PianoWorld Books 1-3, published by Faber Music, £4.95 each.

fields.headline: Schofield picks Warne bouncer
fields.standfirst:
Lancashire 215
Hampshire 175-4
fields.trailText: Shane Warne may have had a moral victory over Salim Malik to celebrate yesterday, but he was unable to add the scalp of England's new leg-spinning hope Chris Schofield.
fields.body:
Shane Warne may have had a moral victory over Salim Malik to celebrate yesterday, but he was unable to add the scalp of England's new leg-spinning hope Chris Schofield.

This was the first time the Lancastrian apprentice has tangled with his Australian hero, and it made for a fascinating contest. Schofield had started confidently late on Wednesday and resumed in the same vein, apparently picking Warne from the hand and moving his feet with purpose.

Warne indulged him for a while, but when Schofield swept him to the boundary it was clearly too much and the next delivery was a rapid bouncer. No matter, Schofield ducked it and, when Warne slipped in another short ball in his next over, hooked him casually to fine leg for a single.

An attempted reverse sweep brought a third Warne bouncer, again ducked, and Schofield ended Lancashire's innings unbeaten on 39 from 75 balls with five fours, having steered them beyond 200 to earn a batting bonus point.

His style may not be orthodox, but the fidgety left-hander has now scored 207 championship runs at an average of more than 50; he is developing into a handy all-rounder.

The second half of the Warne-Schofield duel may have to wait for another match, if today's miserable weather forecast is correct, which would also deprive Hampshire of the chance to add to the single batting point they have picked up this season.

They did not start well, losing the openers Derek Kenway and Jason Laney to Peter Martin's lively new-ball burst. But Robin Smith and Will Kendall put on 78 for the third wicket, Hampshire's highest partnership of the season, as the remainder of Lancashire's seamers struggled to find the right line.

Smith reached a routine, but valuable, half-century from 67 balls with nine fours but immediately lost his partner, Kendall pulling a Schofield long-hop straight to midwicket. Schofield bowled in tandem with Gary Keedy, making his first appearance of the season, either side of tea and the spinners claimed their second victim when Smith's firm push at Keedy was snapped up by Andy Flintoff in the gully.

But Giles White, after a nervous start against Schofield, grew in confidence to reach 45 before yet more rain forced an early close.

Lancashire need five more wickets to claim the bowling points they need to pull level with the First Division leaders Yorkshire, although it was not those dizzy heights which caused Graham Lloyd to slump to his knees just before lunch with a nosebleed.

It turned out that Lloyd had been felled by the huge figure of Flintoff, who for some reason wanted to practise his left-arm bowling action in the slips, and Bumble Jr was forced off for 10 minutes' treatment from the Lancashire physio Lawrie Brown.

Hampshire have lost Peter Hartley with a more serious injury, a calf tear, although Dmitri Mascarenhas compensated with four for 52.

webTitle: Football's summer sale sparks air-mile bonanza

fields.headline: Football's summer sale sparks air-mile bonanza
fields.trailText: Clubs like Newcastle are well and truly lumbered with players with unpronounceable names with indescribably huge salaries and outrageous egos well beyond their abilities.
fields.body:
Football managers and agents are clocking up an astonishing number of air miles at the moment and no doubt Britain's favourite airline, which is going through a bit of financial turbulence just now, is grateful for the business.

But to suggest that this summer is going to see a frenzy of Premiership transfer activity may be misleading.

The arrival of a foreign player now has little impact. With over 300 imports plying their trade over here, we have become anaesthetised by the injection of endless sexy names, although Ronaldo joining Manchester United, Liverpool or Arsenal would cause a bit of a stir.

Too often they have turned out to be men past their prime who are prepared to get a tan in the English rain and swallow the early rounds of the League Cup in return for £30,000 a week.

I gather there is plenty of pan-European activity at the moment but there is a growing feeling that, apart from a handful of huge-money signings (most probably involving Chelsea), this summer could be relatively quiet.

Managers, or their representatives, are jetting to Scandinavia, Spain, Italy, Holland and Germany in a pre-Euro 2000 rush of activity in the hope of negotiating sensible deals. If a transfer target hits the spot too often during the forthcoming tournament in the Low Countries, fees will suddenly inflate beyond reason.

But outside the top four or five in the Premiership, the harsh truth is that clubs are not awash with cash and there are too many of them, like Newcastle, who are well and truly lumbered with players with unpronounceable names with indescribably huge salaries and outrageous egos well beyond their abilities.

There are three issues that will affect this summer's market. First, clubs (however healthy their balance sheets appear) are no longer pre pared to pay crazy wages, unless the player is a genuine guarantee of a place in next year's Champions League.

Second, the amount of money committed to new players will hinge on whether the men in the boardrooms are prepared to gamble their lump sums from the new TV deal, which will be announced before the start of the season.

And, third, there is a fear that Fifa, football's world governing body, could impose a limit on the number of imported players a club can have on the books. Nobody knows when it might happen, but the threat is proving to be a deterrent.

Football, though, is a daft business. As one top agent told me yesterday, "I reckon there could be a lot of activity after Euro 2000. All it takes is for two or three clubs to make a few moves and the rest of the clubs panic and pile into the market as well.

"They may not be signing big stars, but they'll pick up a few squad players. More and more clubs want to buy British, but they cost too much. Foreign players still represent value for money."

Like the savings to be had by importing your BMW or Merc, a quality defender like Michael Reiziger of Barcelona is apparently valued at something like £1.5m, which seems a snip.

Chelsea, Sunderland and Arsenal, for example, have made no secret of the fact that each is looking for three or four new players, and Charlton and Manchester City need to strengthen.

And as long as football needs new faces to ensure season-ticket sales, rumours will continue to abound.

The latest speculation suggests Emmanuel Petit will leave Arsenal for Internazionale, Real Madrid or Parma; Robert Pires will join Liverpool or Arsenal from Marseille and, if Marc Overmars leaves Highbury, Jesper Gronkjaer will join Arsenal from Ajax. Then, of course, Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink will join Chelsea from Atletico Madrid, while Nolberto Solano will quit Newcastle to join the European champions Real Madrid.

On the domestic front Wimbledon's Scotland goalkeeper Neil Sullivan is in danger of pricing himself out of the market; Chris Sutton might leave Chelsea for Spurs; and Paulo Wanchope will swap West Ham for Leicester.

So that's the gossip. The reality depends on how brave, or desperate, clubs are. There could also be a Steve McManaman effect on transfer policy. If a good rather than great English player can grab a European Cup winners' medal while playing for a Spanish club, then are we underestimating our homegrown talent?

fields.headline: Fulham eye £3m French recruits
fields.trailText: Fulham's French manager Jean Tigana is aiming to pay a total of £3m for two compatriots rejected by Newcastle but deemed to have the right stuff to help propel the ambitious west London club into the Premiership.
fields.body:
Fulham's French manager Jean Tigana is aiming to pay a total of £3m for two compatriots rejected by Newcastle but deemed to have the right stuff to help propel the ambitious west London club into the Premiership.

Tigana has lined up a £2.5m deal with Metz for the 21-year-old striker Louis Saha and is also seeking the defender Laurent Charvet, who is deemed surplus to Bobby Robson's requirements at St James' Park and likely to cost around £500,000.

Fulham hope to make Saha their first major signing under Tigana and the First Division club's interest in Saha was confirmed by Metz yesterday when their recruitment director Bernard Zenier said: "It's possible that a deal could be in place soon. We have been in contact with Fulham and Saha has told us he wants to leave.

"We know he has already tasted English football with Newcastle and he is keen to experience it again. It is not official yet but there is a good chance it will happen."

The Paris-born Saha spent five months on loan at St James' Park at the beginning of last year and scored twice in 12 appearances.

But his chances to impress were limited by injuries and he was devastated when Ruud Gullit, then Newcastle's manager, decided not to make the move permanent.

Charvet followed Gullit to Newcastle from Chelsea, joining for £500,000 in 1998, but has been told he can go by Robson after injury ruled the 27-year-old out of the final five months of last season.

Robson will want to recoup that fee for a player who can play at full-back or in central defence.

Fulham's intended French connection extends further with Tigana pursuing the Auxerre winger Bernard Diomede.

Chelsea have confirmed they are negotiating to bring Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink back to the Premiership but conceded they are facing strong competition abroad for the former Leeds striker.

Colin Hutchinson, Chelsea's managing director, said he was given permission by Atletico to talk to Hasselbaink's agent Humphry Nijmen. "It is true we have made an inquiry but other clubs are going down the same road," said Hutchinson "That's as far as it's gone although we hope to take the matter a little bit further.

"It's well known in Spain that he is being linked to Valencia and Deportivo [la Coruna], who have won the championship, while the talk in Italy is of him possibly joining Lazio."

Hasselbaink, sold to Atletico for £12million nine months ago, will command an even higher fee after has scoring 24 league goals for Atletico. The Dutchman plays his last game for the relegated club tomorrow when he faces Espanyol in the Spanish Cup final.

Chelsea are prepared to pay around £14m for Hasselbaink although it is understood that Atletico have been holding out for £17m given the widespread interest.

Leeds are selling their Austrian defender Martin Hiden to one of his former clubs, Salzburg, for £500,000. The 27-year-old has struggled with injuries since moving to Elland Road for £1.3m from Rapid Vienna in 1998.

 The £475million redevelopment of Wembley has been given the go-ahead by Brent planning officers. After months of wrangling, it has been decided to recommend that the borough council's planning committee approves the scheme at its meeting next Thursday.

webTitle: Liverpool gamble on McAllister as father figure

fields.headline: Liverpool gamble on McAllister as father figure
fields.trailText: Gary McAllister will be handed the dual role of father figure and midfield enforcer by Gérard Houllier after agreeing to move to Liverpool from Coventry on a free transfer yesterday.
fields.body:
Gary McAllister will be handed the dual role of father figure and midfield enforcer by Gérard Houllier after agreeing to move to Liverpool from Coventry on a free transfer yesterday.

Liverpool's manager has turned to the 35-year-old former Scotland captain in an attempt to add experience and guile to a team whose senior members, Patrik Berger and Dietmar Hamann, are only 26, and to ensure the continued development of youngsters such as Steven Gerrard, David Thompson, Jamie Carragher and Danny Murphy.

"The average age of their side last season was under 25, and that's very young indeed for a top-flight club," McAllister said. "The manager explained that there was a need for some experience around the squad, an old head in the side.

"It's too early to say just how many games I will play - maybe people will be surprised. But I aim to take this chance to pass on to the youngsters at Liverpool the experience I have gained."

This includes 57 caps for Scotland in a career spanning 19 years. He remains, though, in peak fitness and was Coventry's player of the year last season, scoring 13 goals, his best tally in the Premiership. He is sure he will be inspired and refreshed by working at Anfield.

"I'm feeling as fit as ever and I can't wait to get going. There are so many great young players at Liverpool. With that sort of quality around me maybe I can go on for a couple more seasons yet, you never know. If I can offer anything to help the younger players and their development, that's fine by me."

One player for whom McAllister has particular regard is the 19-year-old Gerrard, likely to be part of England's squad for Euro 2000. "He is already one of the best midfield players around and there's nothing he can't achieve in the game if he wants it. He's already a very special player.

"Obviously I'm there to help him. But he can help me too. Playing alongside him I will be able to bounce off him as much as he can bounce off me. I can't wait for it all to start."

Next season Liverpool face the rigours of three cup competitions, including the Uefa Cup, and attempting to qualify for the Champions League through a top-three finish in the Premiership, a feat they narrowly failed to achieve last season.

If they are successful next time round McAllister will get an extra year on top of the one season Houllier has already signed him for.

"This is fairytale stuff for someone at my stage of life," said McAllister, who will officially sign on July 1 when his Coventry contract expires. "It did surprise me when Liverpool came in for me, but I have talked through the specific role that Gérard Houllier wants me to have and I am more than happy with it.

"It's a tremendous challenge for me and something that I really didn't expect at this stage of my career. But I intend to grasp it and enjoy it. In fact, I wish the season could start straight away."

 John Toshack received a 40 million peseta (£136,400) bonus after his former employers Real Madrid beat Valencia in the Champions League final on Wednesday night. The Welshman was in charge for the club's six games in the first group phase of the competition and as such was entitled to a winner's bonus.

fields.headline: Referees' boss defends u-turn
fields.trailText: The Football Association yesterday denied the decision to scrap the practice of appointing Premiership referees for the entire season was a response to the increasing criticism of officials over the past two years.
fields.body:
The Football Association yesterday denied the decision to scrap the practice of appointing Premiership referees for the entire season was a response to the increasing criticism of officials over the past two years.

From August there will be a national list of 74 referees, similar to that used before the Premier League's advent in 1992.

There will still be a sub-list of 20 Premiership referees but this will be reviewed every three months, with relegation to the Nationwide League for poor performances and promotion for others an integral part of the new system.

Next season Paul Alcock and Uriah Rennie will start in the Nationwide League after their poor marks in the Premiership.

John Baker, the FA's head of refereeing, claimed yesterday the new system was not tantamount to accepting the widespread criticism that has been coming the way of referees.

"It would not be fair to say that," Baker said. "This is all about creating equal opportunities. All we've done is to go back to how it was before the Premier League, when referees had the opportunity to move up and down the divisions.

"The Premier League brought separation and we felt that the decision to make the list in May was too early. By going back to a national list, those referees who are performing best are more likely to be given the best matches."

Darlington's players have been feeling the pressure ahead of this evening's Third Division play-off with Peterborough at Wembley. Darlington's manager Dave Hodgson admitted that a training session was halted after two of his players nearly came to blows.

"It was the first time we've seen a little bit of aggravation," he said. "They're getting anxious and to be honest I'm glad it's like that. There's a fear factor there as well, and I think that's a good thing to have."

Hodgson's counterpart at Peterborough, Barry Fry, said: "Darlington were favourites to win promotion from day one, and rightly so. The reason they have not gone up is the terrible state of their pitch.

"It was 4-2 at our place and 2-0 up there. So it's 4-4 and Wembley is a wonderful place to decide it. It's a marvellous occasion for players, their families and the fans."

webTitle: Roberto Carlos flies out of Wembley date

fields.headline: Roberto Carlos flies out of Wembley date
fields.trailText: Roberto Carlos is frequently referred to as a flying left-back and yesterday he lived up to his reputation. After jetting in from Paris to show his face at Brazil's base in Hertfordshire, the 27-year-old headed for Spain. Ruled out of tomorrow's international against England because of injury, he was allowed to join Real Madrid's Champions League celebrations.
fields.body:
Roberto Carlos is frequently referred to as a flying left-back and yesterday he lived up to his reputation. After jetting in from Paris to show his face at Brazil's base in Hertfordshire, the 27-year-old headed for Spain. Ruled out of tomorrow's international against England because of injury, he was allowed to join Real Madrid's Champions League celebrations.

Tendonitis in his right knee means one of the few places Roberto Carlos will not be flying is down the flanks at Wembley. He will be named among the substitutes but the good news for England is that Brazil are intent on resting him until their World Cup qualifier in Peru next Sunday.

During his brief stay in England the player explained: "The president of Real Madrid asked me to come back for the party and since I am not able to train, the coach [Wanderley Luxemburgo] said it was no problem. But I will be back on Friday and will sit on the bench. This is Brazil's last game at the old Wembley and I would not miss it for the world."

Events could be a little hazy if the hangover has not worn off but Luxemburgo made it clear last night that he was treating the game seriously. Only in the last half-hour of their 3-0 win over Wales on Tuesday did Brazil come to life. This time it could be a different story.

fields.headline: Meet Keegan's secret weapon
fields.standfirst: Faceless Derek Fazackerley revels in his role as England's anonymous No2
fields.trailText: Martin Thorpe blows the cover of England's anonymous No2, faceless Derek Fazackerley.
fields.body:
In the England camp he is known as "Faz". To outsiders he is known as "Who?". When Kevin Keegan accepted the job of national coach just over a year ago, it was assumed someone so respected and charismatic would bring in a No2 of a similar stamp.

There was a severe sense of anti-climax, however, when Keegan announced that his main assistant would be Derek Fazackerley. It was neither a sexy nor a household name, sounding more like a character from Coronation Street than the man who was going to mastermind England's revival.

Apart from those he coached in fleeting spells at Blackburn Rovers and Newcastle, few knew who he was. Only those with good memories can recall his sterling service as a Preston-born workaday centre-half in the 70s at Ewood Park, where he is still their longest-serving player. But he had no international experience. And as for respected and charismatic. Well, quite frankly, no.

But nobody was more surprised than Fazackerley himself when the call to national colours came just seconds before his call to the tea table. "I'd been Kevin's first-team coach at Newcastle but we'd both gone our separate ways and I hadn't had much contact with him in 3 years," the 48-year-old remembers.

"Then one night just before tea-time I got a phone call and it was Kevin. It came completely out of the blue. He said he'd been approached for the England job and he was going to take it part-time for four games and would I like to come along for the ride? I was delighted and shocked, but you can't refuse that."

He was also relieved because he was out of a job, having just been released as Blackburn coach. But he had obviously made an impression on Keegan during their time together at St James' Park.

Tactical awareness is allegedly a chink in Keegan's armour but Fazackerley denies it is his job to fill it. "No. Kevin's very much his own man when it comes to the team and tactics," he says. "Obviously we do discuss things, as well as with Arthur Cox and Les Reed, the other coaches. But Kevin has the final say and I don't agree that he is not good tactically."

So was Fazackerley picked for the contribution he could make to the team spirit which plays such a huge part in Keegan's game-plan? "Well, I'm the worst teller of jokes you could ever meet in your life," he says. "And practical jokes are the things people play on me. I wouldn't say I'm the life and soul of the party."

He laughs at the suggestion that he is a sergeant-major on the training pitch. "Day to day my job is to formulate the coaching and training for the whole squad. That might mean we split the squad into various groups with the attackers with Kevin and the defenders with me."

But do not mistake Fazackerley for someone who just collects the balls and lays out the cones. He has scouted all England's first-phase opposition for the Euro 2000 finals, helped set up the training camp in Belgium and liaises regularly with Keegan.

He was bitten by the scouting bug in a unique way. "Within the first three months of joining Blackburn as an apprentice at 16, I picked up a thigh injury and I was told I could do absolutely nothing for 12 months.

"The manager of the time, Eddie Quigley, said to me 'We can't just have you sat around for 12 months picking up your £8 a week and doing nothing'. So even at that age he said, you go and watch the opposition.

"So I used to go off to Blackpool, Preston, Burnley and Bury and places like that on a Saturday and watch the opposition Blackburn were playing soon.

"That provoked an interest in it. He was quite complimentary to me and he let me continue until the end of the season when I was fit enough to start training again."

From Bury to Brazil on Saturday. That's life in the Faz lane.

webTitle: McManaman plays his way into free role

fields.headline: McManaman plays his way into free role
fields.trailText: The refloating of Steve McManaman has now become essential to England's chances of success in the European Championship following the former Liverpool player's outstanding performance for Real Madrid in Wednesday's European Cup final.
fields.body:
The refloating of Steve McManaman has now become essential to England's chances of success in the European Championship following the former Liverpool player's outstanding performance for Real Madrid in Wednesday's European Cup final.

Three years ago McManaman's international career was in doubt when, together with Robbie Fowler, he withdrew from Glenn Hoddle's squad for the pre-World Cup tournament in France. While McManaman did eventually go to France 98 his participation was limited to 17 minutes against Colombia.

Now, for Keegan, McManaman is rather more than an optional extra. The present England coach has always had the lanky, athletic 28-year-old at the back of his mind for Euro 2000 and if he ever had any doubts, these disappeared at the Stade de France.

Having played a major role in the removal of last year's finalists, Manchester United and Bayern Munich, McManaman was the prime influence behind the breathtaking 3-0 victory over Valencia which brought Real Madrid the trophy for the eighth time, capping his performance with a superb volley for the second goal.

McManaman's willingness to cover enormous amounts of ground, tackling back one moment, driving into the opposing penalty area the next, has all but persuaded Keegan to give the player a similar free role with England. But with the player joining the squad on Sunday, it will not be against Brazil at Wembley tomorrow.

Nevertheless Keegan will need to see if McManaman is likely to reproduce his rich vein of form, which means that the friendly against the Ukraine on Wednesday will almost certainly be a crucial test.

"It is now up to me to try to find a way within the England team of getting the very best out of Steve McManaman," Keegan said yesterday. "Whatever he is doing in Madrid is paying dividends.

"He has become the focal point of their play. Nearly everything seems to go through him and his role is not restricted, which is something some people might argue would happen if I ended up playing him on the left side."

With David Beckham so valuable to England on the right there is no question of asking McManaman to operate from that wing. But as Terry Venables, England's coach in Euro 96, pointed out this week, McManaman may have started on the left in that tournament but still proved to be effective when he drifted across to link up with Darren Anderton.

Keegan needs to find out whether allowing McManaman to float from the left would impede Paul Scholes, one of England's main scoring hopes, who tends to make his runs in the inside-left position. Yet the England coach remains confident.

"We have a lot of flexibility in the squad," he said, "people like Steve McManaman, Paul Scholes and two or three others who give you opportunities to try different things. But it is difficult to start massive experimentation when you are going to a major championship. Getting that right, I think, is the key to how well we do."

What Keegan does not have, compared to Real Madrid, are natural wing-backs like Michel Salgado and Roberto Carlos and a midfielder to compare with Fernando Redondo, all of whom have provided the platform for McManaman's willingness to roam.

For the moment McManaman's form, if he can retain it, will be sufficient bonus for an England side who have lacked a spark of inspiration since Paul Gascoigne's decline. "I can't believe that Steve McManaman has ever played better than this," Keegan enthused.

Paul Ince, McManaman's old team-mate at Liverpool, supported the idea of giving him his head. "Steve is playing with confidence, which he hasn't had at other times when he's played for England," he said. "Now I think you can afford to play Macca anywhere."

England's latest injury worry is Jamie Redknapp, who pulled out of training yesterday with a knee problem which will need an examination by a specialist. Injuries limited his participation in Euro 96 and forced him to miss the last World Cup.

Tony Adams (back) and Steven Gerrard (thigh) missed training and Andy Cole's damaged toe is to be checked by a specialist today. Keegan will announce his squad of 22 immediately after the Ukraine game.

fields.headline: Doctors on the front line
fields.standfirst: Those of us who treat cancer feel diminished and often angered by a system in which we must beg for cash
fields.trailText: Everyone involved in the treatment of cancer feel diminished and often angered by a system in which we must beg for cash, says leading ccancer doctor David Kerr.
fields.body:
Everyone who reads this will have been touched by cancer - whether personally or through friends and family. It remains a stigmatising illness and it is likely that the constant stream of worrying statistics or stories of missed and delayed diagnosis will amplify existing anxieties.

All of the nurses and doctors in my cancer centre detect an erosion of trust, or at least a heightened suspicion that many of our decisions not to treat might be underpinned by some economic sub-plot, rather than a rational response to the patient's needs. We are increasingly asked: "But if I was insured, could you treat me then?" So between which extremes does the truth lie?

It is apparent that our cancer survival figures fall short of those of our neighbours in Europe and the United States; however, closer inspection of the data suggests that they are open to misinterpretation. In this country we are especially skilled at collecting information on the dead, unlike France, say, where it is more difficult to derive death rates which reflect the whole population.

At a recent meeting of experts gathered to discuss the international survival disparity, it did seem as if patients in the UK presented with more advanced cancer - there is a rule of thumb that there is greater potential to cure a cancer the size of a grape rather than a grapefruit - which should lead us to promote strategies for greater health awareness.

There is also a strong inverse relationship between deprivation and cancer survival, with poorer sections of society surviving least well, which we need to understand more fully in order to develop corrective policies. Another factor which is likely to contribute to differential survival is inequity of access to quality cancer care.

It is useful to conceive a sequential pathway of care, starting with referral to hospital by the GP, followed by diagnosis, staging (how far has the cancer spread?) and treatment (which could be surgery, radiotherapy or chemotherapy, singly or in combination). A retrospective audit of waiting times (October, 1997) showed that it took six months for 90% of bowel cancer patients to proceed from the point of GP referral to surgery. This is far too long. There are patients whose cancer will grow, perhaps to the extent that their chance of cure or prolonged survival will be significantly reduced, while waiting for treatment.

Rather than singling out the initial bit of the cancer pathway - the push to get patients referred by GPs seen by hospital consultants within two weeks - I believe that we will see increasing focus on the time to first treatment as a target, which is likely to return greater health gain.

There is a consensus emerging that if we could streamline the system so that the majority of cancer patients were treated within two months from the point of GP referral, lives would be saved. What are the bottlenecks that are preventing us from achieving this goal? When we examined our process of referral from consultant surgeon to medical oncologist, it involved 26 steps and took seven weeks. By rearranging our appointment system we reduced this to 10 days. Hardly rocket science, but it saved time towards getting the patient treated promptly. We are also understaffed: there are 100 consultant chemotherapy experts in the UK compared to 7-8,000 in the US. In some centres, the waiting time for a CT scan (necessary to estimate tumour burden), is in excess of three months. The waiting time for a CT scan in the Mayo clinic is probably closer to three hours.

If there is a war on cancer and a front line, it often feels like wading through the mud of the Somme. Chemotherapy drugs are the tools of my trade and yet I am sometimes denied access to the latest drugs through the arbitrariness of post-code prescribing. If a cancer fails to respond to initial treatment, patients ask what else can be done, and if that involves a novel drug which is not "funded" I have to explain that I have to engage in a round of "begging" letters to health authorities to try to come up with the money (usually in the range of a couple of thousand pounds). It is impossible to imagine the feeling of worthlessness which my patients feel while waiting for funding to come through. The drug might buy them only an extra six months of life, but that could be a baby born or an anniversary realised. They say: "Am I not worth that few thousand pounds? Who would deny me that chance of extra time?"

I feel diminished by the system and often angered by the uncaring responses from the funding bodies.

We are currently writing a national cancer plan, which will take account of workforce planning and provide a kit to relieve bottlenecks in the process of care. The National Institute of Clinical Excellence should improve the flow of worthwhile drugs into the clinic. We also hope to make shorter-term gains through the DoH-funded Cancer Services Collaborative, which will redesign the care pathway to deliver timely treatment, by a multidisciplinary, site-specialised team.

 David Kerr is professor of clinical oncology at the CRC Institute for Cancer Studies, Birmingham university.

fields.headline: Bradford to play in Europe
fields.trailText: An Italian side has dropped out of the Intertoto Cup, giving the Bantam's a chance to qualify for the UEFA Cup.
fields.body:
Bradford's players, still savouring the prospect of another season in the Premiership, will be back at work earlier than expected after the club's shock decision to play in the Intertoto Cup.

There is every possibility too that they could face a trip to Turkey in their opening game. Bradford, who will join Aston Villa as the English representatives in the coming season's Intertoto, will come in at the second round.

They will meet the winners of a first-round game between an unnamed Turkish side and Atlantis of Lithuania with the prospect of a match against Waalwijk of Holland in the third round.

Two places were originally up for grabs for English clubs, but Bradford were the only other side who showed an interest in competing in the second round which takes place at the beginning of July.

With UEFA insisting back in April that they would not accept a relegated side into the competition, Bradford decided against entering. However, they retained their place in the Premiership on the last day of the season.

With an Italian team dropping out of the competition, Bradford are set to play their first game away on July 1 or 2, with the second leg a week later.

webTitle: Astronauts wrap up space station work

fields.headline: Astronauts wrap up space station work
fields.standfirst:
Nasa Human Spaceflight
International Space Station homepage
Space exploration: special report
fields.trailText: Astronauts from the space shuttle Atlantis delivered a final boost to the flagging orbit of the International Space Station on Thursday, and Nasa declared the orbiting outpost nearly as good as new.
fields.body:
Astronauts from the space shuttle Atlantis delivered a final boost to the flagging orbit of the International Space Station on Thursday, and Nasa declared the orbiting outpost nearly as good as new.

The 18-month-old science project was losing orbit, low on power and urgently in need of repairs when Atlantis arrived last Sunday.

Without the repairs and orbital boost courtesy of the shuttle, the station could not have been ready to receive its first live-aboard crew later this year.

"When we leave, we'll have a robust spacecraft," said the station's lead flight director, Paul Hill.

During their stay, the Atlantis crew raised the station's orbit about 30 miles in three separate boosts, using the shuttle's thrusters. Inside the station's power plant, they replaced four solar-charged batteries that had failed or were failing.

Outside the station, a pair of spacewalking astronauts fixed a wobbly crane, replaced a communications antenna, and assembled a Russian construction boom.

Indications of a power fluctuation from one of the batteries had Mission Control in Houston talking about extending the mission by a day at one point. Their concerns evaporated when engineers determined the problem was on the ground, not in space. The only job left for the astronauts was to close the maze of hatches aboard the station in preparation for Friday's departure.

The $60-billion project is a joint venture of the United States, Russia, Canada, Europe and Japan. In July, the two existing modules of the station are scheduled to dock with a Russian service module with the living quarters and life support needed to make the outpost fully habitable.

Atlantis commander James Halsell and pilot Scott Horowitz performed the day's most important task, firing the shuttle's thrusters 26 times and pushing the station into an orbit 238 miles above Earth's surface.

The station's orbit had been crumbling by about 1.5 miles a-week before Atlantis' arrival, putting it too low to intercept the Russian module in July.

With four of six storage batteries either failed or failing and the faltering orbit caused by atmospheric drag, the station would not have been able to make that rendezvous if Nasa had not planned this repair mission last February.

Most of the electrical work was performed by Russian Yuri Usachev and American Susan Helms. Usachev, who will command Helms and fellow Atlantis astronaut James Voss when the three return to the station as an expeditionary crew next year, had plenty of experience working with the Russian designed electrical systems aboard the station. His two tours on the Russian Mir space station totalled more than a year.

Earlier, Voss and crew mate Jeffrey Williams made repairs to the outside of the station during a 6 1/2-hour spacewalk. The crew also finished moving supplies from the shuttle's pressurised cargo hold to the space station's storage racks. The supplies - everything from an exercise treadmill to trash bags - are for long-duration crews.
fields.bodyText: Astronauts from the space shuttle Atlantis delivered a final boost to the flagging orbit of the International Space Station on Thursday, and Nasa declared the orbiting outpost nearly as good as new. The 18-month-old science project was losing orbit, low on power and urgently in need of repairs when Atlantis arrived last Sunday. Without the repairs and orbital boost courtesy of the shuttle, the station could not have been ready to receive its first live-aboard crew later this year. "When we leave, we'll have a robust spacecraft," said the station's lead flight director, Paul Hill. During their stay, the Atlantis crew raised the station's orbit about 30 miles in three separate boosts, using the shuttle's thrusters. Inside the station's power plant, they replaced four solar-charged batteries that had failed or were failing. Outside the station, a pair of spacewalking astronauts fixed a wobbly crane, replaced a communications antenna, and assembled a Russian construction boom. Indications of a power fluctuation from one of the batteries had Mission Control in Houston talking about extending the mission by a day at one point. Their concerns evaporated when engineers determined the problem was on the ground, not in space. The only job left for the astronauts was to close the maze of hatches aboard the station in preparation for Friday's departure. The $60-billion project is a joint venture of the United States, Russia, Canada, Europe and Japan. In July, the two existing modules of the station are scheduled to dock with a Russian service module with the living quarters and life support needed to make the outpost fully habitable. Atlantis commander James Halsell and pilot Scott Horowitz performed the day's most important task, firing the shuttle's thrusters 26 times and pushing the station into an orbit 238 miles above Earth's surface. The station's orbit had been crumbling by about 1.5 miles a-week before Atlantis' arrival, putting it too low to intercept the Russian module in July. With four of six storage batteries either failed or failing and the faltering orbit caused by atmospheric drag, the station would not have been able to make that rendezvous if Nasa had not planned this repair mission last February. Most of the electrical work was performed by Russian Yuri Usachev and American Susan Helms. Usachev, who will command Helms and fellow Atlantis astronaut James Voss when the three return to the station as an expeditionary crew next year, had plenty of experience working with the Russian designed electrical systems aboard the station. His two tours on the Russian Mir space station totalled more than a year. Earlier, Voss and crew mate Jeffrey Williams made repairs to the outside of the station during a 6 1/2-hour spacewalk. The crew also finished moving supplies from the shuttle's pressurised cargo hold to the space station's storage racks. The supplies - everything from an exercise treadmill to trash bags - are for long-duration crews.

webTitle: Dando suspect detained for 36 more hours

fields.headline: Dando suspect detained for 36 more hours
fields.standfirst: More on the Jill Dando case
fields.trailText: Detectives questioning a man over the murder of TV presenter Jill Dando have been granted an extra 36 hours to interview him, Scotland Yard said.
fields.body:
Detectives questioning a man over the murder of TV presenter Jill Dando have been granted an extra 36 hours to interview him, Scotland Yard said.

The man has already been held for 36 hours since his arrest early on Thursday morning in his west London flat, less than a mile from Dando's home where she was shot on April 26 last year.

The extension granted by magistrates allows police to detain the suspect until Sunday morning. Police may hold a suspect for up to 96 hours before either pressing charges or releasing him.

Scotland Yard has not revealed the identity of the suspect, but neighbours say he is Barry Bulsara, an unemployed musician, aged between 35 and 40.

Bulsara is said to be obsessed with the late Freddie Mercury, the lead singer of rock band Queen. He reportedly changed his name by deed poll to Bulsara, Mercury's real surname, and claimed to be his cousin.

The star's family vehemently denied that the arrested man is a relative Detectives said yesterday's arrest was a "highly significant" development in their 13-month hunt for Dando's killer.

They have spoken to thousands of people during their investigations and a £250,000 reward has been put up for information leading to the arrest and conviction of the killer.

On the first anniversary of Dando's murder, the detective leading the investigation said the fact that no one had come forward to claim the reward suggested the killer was probably a loner.

Detective Chief Inspector Hamish Campbell also said at the time he had identified 140 people with an unhealthy obsession with Dando.

webTitle: Why Oxbridge was right to refuse me special treatment

fields.headline: Why Oxbridge was right to refuse me special treatment
fields.standfirst: Gordon Brown suggests Oxbridge elitism excluded state school pupil Laura Spence. So what? Not all state pupils are underprivileged, says Patrick Barkham
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown suggests Oxbridge elitism excluded state school pupil Laura Spence. So what? Not all state pupils are underprivileged, says Patrick Barkham
fields.body:
Seven years before Laura Spence flunked her Oxford entry, I was directed to an absurdly low chair in a dimly lit oak-panelled room in Caius College, Cambridge, to face the interrogation of a grisly old history professor. Towering above me, in a massive, dilapidated armchair, he asked why he should let me in to Cambridge?

I tried the brazenly cheeky approach. I told him my background. Like Laura, I had 10 top GCSEs and hailed from a humble state school - one in rural Norfolk that had not managed to get anyone in to Oxbridge for something like a decade. I should be given the chance, I ventured, to provide a beacon of hope for poor state schools and help redress the elitist public school imbalance among Cambridge students.

Rubbish, he glowered through the gloom. He told me I was a snivellingly privileged, white, middle-class male with no need for any special favours, before proceeding to fire further provocative questions at me for the next 10 minutes. Chastened, I slunk out of the room. I had two further interviews that day, which went much better, with a friendly woman and an equally amenable elderly professor, but received a rejection in the post two weeks later. (Don't worry about popping round to see if I'm alright, Gordon: another Cambridge college, Fitzwilliam, got in touch and said they would take me instead.)

Every year there is an almighty fuss in the right-thinking newspapers about the irregularities of Oxbridge admissions. Two years ago, the Daily Mail went ballistic about the abrasive interview technique of a Cambridge English professor, who deployed a style very like the one I encountered with the fusty professor in Caius. This aggressive technique, straight out of a public school debating society, is rightly criticised.

But Laura and I were not victims of it. I later learned that I actually scored the highest points with the grisly professor who nailed my underprivileged lie. Similarly, Laura Spence performed best in the interview section of her admissions procedure, which accounted for a quarter of her marks. Anthony Smith, the president of Magdalen college, said: "She performed less well in the written test, the test of observational skills and the structured discussion. In the end we were not convinced that she had the necessary potential."

Oxbridge's admissions procedures are arbitrary and the privilege of the two universities remains featherbedded by big business and government. But lucky people like Laura are not convincing examples of its elitism. Rather, they show a class-fixated society still unable to realise that Oxbridge is not the only stamp of high achievement and that state school pupils from privileged backgrounds need no special treatment.

fields.headline: Getting a place at Oxbridge
fields.standfirst: Oxford and Cambridge universities are routinely accused of elitism because of the high proportion of entrants from fee-paying schools. We put their admissions procedure under the microscope
fields.trailText: How do universities choose who they should admit?
fields.body:
How do universities choose who they should admit?

That depends on the university and the course. If you want to go to a prestigious Russell Group university - such as Oxford, Cambridge or Warwick - the admissions tutors will read your Ucas form, which includes your GCSE grades and predicted A-level grades. They will either reject you or invite you for an interview and, in science subjects, aptitude tests. If those go well, the university makes a conditional offer. That means they will insist on, say, two A grades and a B, or a minimum of 26 points. An A grade counts as 10 points, a B eight, and so on. If you fail to meet any of their offers, you have to join the scramble for leftover places in clearing.

Didn't Oxford and Cambridge insist on entrance exams until recently?

Until 1996, candidates could choose to sit an entrance exam for Oxford in the December before their A-levels and then be called for interview. If they were accepted, they usually received a "two-E" offer because, as far as Oxford was concerned, they had already proved themselves. Cambridge also encouraged applicants to take special papers and enjoy the same advantages. But the system was unfair to schools which had no history of sending pupils to Oxbridge: private schools often laid on special tuition and tended to know what admissions tutors were looking for. Cambridge abolished it in 1987 and Oxford followed suit in 1996. But about 15% of Cambridge applicants, mainly in maths and the sciences, also sit special papers after their A-levels to help tutors decide whether to admit them. According to the university, these don't involve extra work.

What else have they done?

Both universities claim that they do not receive enough applications from state schools, ethnic minority groups and - to a lesser extent - women. If they don't apply, the argument goes, they can't get in. Each college recruits students separately, making it difficult for admissions tutors to influence admissions policy - but they do try. Cambridge, for example, runs summer schools aimed at state pupils and has formed a Group to Encourage Ethnic Minority Applicants. Oxford sent a video to every sixth-form and further education college in Britain and stresses its commitment to equal opportunities.

One Cambridge college, Clare, went further this year and positively discriminated in favour of state school and inner city applicants.

Is it working?

A little. At Oxford, 48% of the offers made during 1999 were to private school pupils, who made up 42% of applicants. This year, the offers have risen to 53%. But it's not quite that simple: a significant number of those accepted come from selective state schools rather than true comprehensives. At Cambridge, the situation is worse. Only 43% of the offers were made to state school pupils - but given that private school applications made up 64% of the total, that wasn't surprising.

So why was the Tyneside pupil Laura Spence rejected by Oxford but accepted by Harvard?

According to the leaked reports on her interview performance, she was "very nice" and had 10 A and A-starred grades at GCSE, but the tutors weren't sure enough of her potential and her aptitude tests didn't go particularly well. In other words, according to the warden of New College, Oxford, she was one of many perfectly-qualified students whom Oxford finds it difficult to discriminate between.

According to the warden, the interviews are an even worse criterion for selection than than the entrance exams and A-levels. "Unless interviewers are carefully trained, they are suckers for charm and liveliness. The process gives the students impolitely described by one researcher as "middle class bullshitters" a flying start," he claims.

So what else could be done?

Within a few years, A-levels will probably move to April, and admissions tutors will be able to make offers based on actual rather than conditional grades - something they don't have time to do now. Oxford and Cambridge could carry on encouraging state school pupils to apply. Or they could embrace positive discrimination and establish quotas. Eighteen percent of all university students are from private schools. Some would argue that 18% of Oxbridge students should be, too.

One thing is certain: while the country's political and media establishments are still dominated by Oxbridge graduates, the universities will continue to be seen as a symbol of all that is most unfair - and most alluring - about the way Britain's privileged institutions work.
