fields.headline: Brown scorns Oxford elitism
fields.standfirst:
Chancellor attacks Oxbridge elitism

Education Unlimited
Are our universities elitist?Talk about it
fields.trailText: The chancellor yesterday launched an outspoken attack on "old school tie" elitism at Oxford and Cambridge, which he claimed rewarded privilege instead of potential.
fields.body:
The chancellor yesterday launched an outspoken attack on "old school tie" elitism at Oxford and Cambridge, which he claimed rewarded privilege instead of potential.

To the dismay of academic leaders at Britain's two most prestigious universities, Gordon Brown used a speech to a TUC audience in London to berate Oxbridge in the wake of the much-publicised case of Laura Spence, the Tyneside comprehensive sixth-former rejected by Magdalen College, Oxford.

Denouncing the decision as "an absolute scandal", Mr Brown said the teenager with 10 A-starred GCSEs and the ambition to be a doctor - who later won a £65,000 medical scholarship to Harvard - had been the victim of "an interview system that is more reminiscent of the old boy network and the old school tie than genuine justice in our society".

The chancellor's speech was personally sanctioned by Tony Blair, it emerged last night, underlining Labour efforts to match the new Tory populism of William Hague. Cabinet sources are privately speaking of the need for the party to find "new enemies" in the run-up to the next general election, rather than simply try to fight on Labour's record.

Although Downing Street officials were not openly making the link, they had earlier detailed the cabinet's discussion of Mr Hague's aggressive new tactics on tax, pensions and asylum.

The chancellor told the TUC: "It is about time we had an end to that old Britain when what matters to some people is the privileges you were born with rather than the potential you actually have.

"I say it is now time that these old universities open their doors to women and to people from all backgrounds. And we are determined that in the next 10 years the majority of young people will be able to get higher education."

Labour has been rattled by its mid-term dip in the polls - 48% to 32% according to yesterday's Times/Mori poll compared with 51% to 27% a month ago - and by the new Tory effectiveness.

Ministers are now intent on meeting populist fire with populist fire - although Mr Blair, himself the kind of public school and Oxford graduate Mr Brown deplores, has always been more susceptible to elitist arguments than his grammar-school and Edinburgh University educated chancellor.

Ms Spence welcomed the chancellor's attack: "I think it's wonderful that Gordon Brown has decided to stick up for people all around Britain who are under-represented in places like Oxford. It's not quite so important to me because I have my place in a university abroad now. But I think it's very important for all of the other youngsters in the country - particularly those who aren't from typical Oxford backgrounds."

Last night the Liberal Democrats told Mr Brown to put his money where his mouth is by abolishing tuition fees, which, they said, reduced university access for poorer students.

Tory spokeswoman Theresa May said: "It's time this government delivered on its promises to spend a higher proportion of national income on higher education than we did, rather than telling Oxford University who should not be chosen as candidates."

Oxford's vice-chancellor, Colin Lucas, called the remarks "deeply disappointing", and insisted that while Oxford had "opened its doors" the university was not complacent and continued to redouble its efforts to widen access.

"I am dismayed that claims of this kind are made without knowledge of the real facts behind the headlines," he said. "Oxford University is constantly seeking out the most able students to come and study with us - whatever school they have been to, whatever their background, whatever their accent."

Oxford has this year made 53% of offers to UK students from the state sector, with a near exact gender balance. That compares with an average of 48% over the past 10 years.

However, while the proportion of state-educated students at Oxford has finally been hauled over the halfway mark, the share of state school pupils accepted is substantially below the proportion who apply, while the proportion of undergraduates from private schools - currently 49% - is dramatically higher than the 8% of the nation's children who go to independent schools.

Private lessons

In 1999 48% of people who won places at Oxford were from private schools, as were 42% of applicants. For Cambridge the figures were 43% and 36%.

18% of students at all British universities and higher education institutions are from private schools.

7% of school pupils and 18% of A level students are at private schools.

fields.headline: Monteverdi: The Coronation of Poppea
fields.trailText: In our series on building a classical library, Andrew Clements selects the definitive recording of Monteverdi's The Coronation of Poppea.
fields.body:
We have only a partial record of the beginnings of opera in Italy at the turn of the 17th century. The earliest known opera, Peri's Dafne, performed in Florence in 1598, survives as a few fragments (though his Euridice, two years later, exists as a complete score), and even for Monteverdi, the composer who first demonstrated the real potential of the genre, the documentary material is full of holes.

Though his first stage work, Orfeo (1607), has come down to us complete, all musical traces of at least a dozen pieces composed between that masterpiece and the next extant opera, The Return of Ulysses in 1640, have vanished, while of his Arianna, premiered in 1608, all that remains is the famous and tantalising Lament.

Even for his last opera, The Coronation of Poppea, performed at the Venice Carnival in 1643, the year of Monteverdi's death, there is no contemporary source material. The music exists in two later manuscripts, one from performances in Naples in 1651, the other from a Venice revival some time in the same decade.

There are significant differences between the two, and just how much of what we know as Poppea was written by Monteverdi and how much was the work of his assistants and pupils is unlikely ever to be established conclusively. But that only matters if you think that great art has to the product of a single, overarching creative mind. Whatever its provenance, The Coronation of Poppea is one of the milestones in operatic history, and the first work to be based on the lives of real historical figures rather than the gods and goddesses of mythology who peopled earlier scenarios.

Most recorded performances take the Venice manuscript as their starting point; only John Eliot Gardiner's version (Archiv) starts from Naples. But every conductor makes his own adjustments - Gardiner, for instance, commissioned new string accompaniments to the arias. There are two sets conducted by Nikolaus Harnoncourt (both on Teldec); the first, from 1974, is the more complete and the more tautly dramatic, but Monteverdi singing has moved on a lot since then, and for all its virtues the performance does not stand up against Gardiner's or René Jacobs'.

For Gardiner, Sylvia McNair and Anne Sofie von Otter are compelling in the roles of Poppea and Ottavia, though Dana Hanchard is a less interesting Nerone; Jacobs' trio of Danielle Borst, Jennifer Larmore and Guillemette Laurens is marginally finer and his pacing seems more natural. Even though he dolls up the ritornelli, this is the version to get.

Key Recording: Jacobs, Harmonia Mundi, HMC 901330.32, three CDs )

fields.trailText: WISE BEFORE THE EVENT
fields.body:
WISE BEFORE THE EVENT

Kelvin Koogan has named the team that will face Brazil tomorrow. It's called "Absolutely fizzing" and will take to the field in a rainbow of Day-Glo colours that will reflect the positive, outgoing nature of the side.

Yeah, all right, so he's named 11 names instead. But the Fiver is really disinclined to talk about a Koogan team that, given the available options, looks half-sensible. The most sensible decision of all is in midfield where the Koogmobile has picked cheeky chirpy Dennis Wise to play on the left wing. Dennis, you see, has actually played on the left before (for Wimbledon, Chelsea and even England, if our ravaged memory serves us correct), and what's more he can cross a ball. If Wise on the wing means we have to put up with Paul Ince for another international, then so be it.

Another vaguely encouraging decision has been taken up front, where Baron von Koogan has chosen to pair Alan Shearer with Michael Owen. If this pairing is to be Little Lord Koogleroy's first choice - as many predict - then they should be given as much time together on the field as possible. Same goes for the selection of Phil Neville, who despite his rubbishness, appears to be the only real option at left-back. All in all a vaguely decent team wethinks.

Now watch them go and get stuffed.

England team to face Brazil at Wembley tomorrow: Seaman, G Neville, P Neville, Ince, Campbell, Keown, Beckham, Scholes, Shearer, Owen, Wise.

HE IS OFF

A couple of weeks ago, the Fiver tried to build a He Is Emmanuel Petit robot. A tribute to the purring machine that is He Is, we had little difficulty constructing the thighs of steel, nor the ponytail of gold. However, the same could not be said of the gob of lead, because the open and shut mechanism got permanently stuck on "wider than the Mississippi". But like they say, as in animatronics, so in life ...

"I don't know if I'm going to be at Arsenal next season," He Is blathered on today, confirming what many back pages have been speculating for months. "The only thing that I will say is that I am soon going to be 30 and if Arsenal get the opportunity to get a good return on their investment in me they must accept the offer," he told a French website (football365.fr) with an honesty that would be admirable in any other profession.

Not so much admirable, as slightly weirdo were the remarks that followed (he's read the Celestine Prophecy, you know). "I want to be part of a club which fires the imagination, and you can count those on the fingers of one hand," He Is said. "When I say that, I include Arsenal, even though they might not be a 'mythical' club." He Is went on to list the number of mythical clubs on the fingers of one (severely mutated) hand. "Manchester, Bayern, Barcelona, Real Madrid, AC Milan and Juventus. To become a mythical club, Arsenal need to win more European trophies."

Now the cynics among you might point out that only last week, He Is played an integral part in failing to secure a European trophy for the Gunners. But He Is has not got where he is today by being blinkered to the truth, and he went on to observe: "I don't know how Arsenal can hope to win the Champions League next season if they play like they did last season." At least on our robot there was an "off" button.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

CROCK OF THE DAY

As one of the many who've watched that MPEG of his leg folding in two over and over, the Fiver would like to congratulate Henrik Larsson on his miraculous recovery from injury and selection in Sweden's Euro 2000 squad. We were going to offer the traditional theatrical wish of good luck, but decided against it.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

WINDASS IN EUROPE

Earlier this month, the campest chairman in football, Geoffrey Richmond, offered the world a wondrous vision of Bradford's future. "Maybe in a year or two we could even win the Worthington or FA Cup," he purred in his best George-from-Rainbow voice; "and I feel we could soon be challenging for a European place." Oh how the Fiver laughed at the prospect of the two Dean's (Fat-boy Windass and Boyo Saunders) going up belly to belly with the best in Europe! At the time, Bradford were odds-on for the drop, and Richmond seemed a worthy British contender for the title of world's craziest chairman (held for the past 17 years by Jesus "I am not Christ" Gil).

Then, earlier today, something surreal happened: Uefa announced that Bradford will be joining Aston Villa in next season's Intertoto Cup - thus making Geoffrey's dream of Europe a reality, (and the Fiver's plan to distil, bottle and sell the hippy-trippy effluents in his water supply a distinct non-starter). Apparently two places have always been up for grabs for English clubs - but nobody ever bothered taking the second spot for the second round because it starts at the beginning of July.

But now, an Italian team has dropped out of the competition, and Bradford are in. And they're as happy as whippet pie at the news. "The chairman is in the building and he's absolutely delighted," a spokesman told the Fiver. And the players? "They are blissfully unaware of the news because they're all on holiday." But won't they lose part of their summer break? "They were originally due back on July 6, but I don't think there'll be too many dissenting voices when they're called back early to play in Europe," we were told. Of course there won't be - especially when they hear they'll be playing either Atlantis from Lithuania or a mid-table Turkish side. It doesn't get much bigger than that.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

COMPETITION NEWS

The answer to yesterday's question was Graeme Le Saux (not Gary Lineker, you idiots). The winner was Dr Alastair Hudson, a professor of law at the University of London. He gets a pair of tickets to tomorrow's game (and a quick phone call the next time we find ourselves in Aldgate nick on a Saturday night).

THE RUMOUR MILL

Manchester United have been linked with a move for Barcelona star Figo. Sources close to the player say that the Nou Camp favourite will complete a move to Old Trafford within the next couple of weeks.

Arsenal have had a £5m bid for Barcelona playmaker Gabri turned down. The Catalan club have told Arsene Wenger he'll have to double his bid to sign the 20-year-old midfielder.

Liverpool and Parma are targeting Swedish international striker Marcus Allback, who looks set to leave Gamla Ullevi in the summer.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Both Rangers and Aberdeen are expected to be at full-strength for tomorrow's Scottish Cup final. Gers strikers Billy Dodds and Rod Wallace have recovered from their respective injuries. Likely line-ups: Aberdeen - Leighton, Lilley, Anderson, Solberg, McAllister, Rowson, Guntveit, Bernard, Dow, Jess, Stavrum. Rangers - Klos, Numan, Wilson, Vidmar, Porrini, Albertz, van Bronckhorst, Ferguson, Kanchelskis, Dodds, McCann.

Former Arsenal striker Nicolas Anelka has left the door open for a second season with Real Madrid. The 21-year-old Frenchman, infamously suspended for 22 days and heavily fined for refusing to train with the side, said: "There had been a few problems but they have been completely sorted out now. My future depends on the president of the club. We will have to discuss it. After that, we will see."

Euro 2000 tournament director Alain Courtois today rejected criticism of the venue for England's clash with Germany on June 17, insisting: "Charleroi is safe." He added: "To those who want to tell us what to do, I tell them, 'Take care of your own fans and we take care of the stadiums.'"

Mark Bosnich will not be playing in this year's Olympic Games. "I'm looking forward to more success with United next season," he said. "I intend to come back in great condition after having a good rest."

Dundee have completed the permanent signing of Javier Artero for a club record fee of £300,000.

Celtic's Henrik Larsson and Marcus Allback have been added to Sweden's final 22 for Euro 2000. "Henrik has shown a lot in practice," said manager Tommy Soderberg. "He lacks match fitness but he is on his way, and that will be no problem in the championships."

The Portugal squad for Euro 2000: Vitor Baia, Pedro Espinha, Joaquim Silva; Roberto Severo, Rui Jorge, Carlos Secretario, Jorge Costa, Abel Xavier, Fernando Couto, Dimas Teixeira; Paulo Sousa, Rui Costa, Luis Figo, Sergio Conceicao, Francisco Costa, Paulo Bento, Jose Vidigal; Joao Pinto, Nuno Gomes, Ricardo Sa Pinto, Pedro Resendes, Nuno Rocha.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Sky Sports 2: Third division football - Live! (7pm) Peterborough v Darlington. The gristly heart of football. And that's just Barry Fry.

Eurosport: Football - Live! (5pm) As Dr Frankenstein said to his spherical experiment.

Football - Live! (7pm) Ivory Coast under-21 v Italy under-21. At last some detail. But perhaps a little more than we needed.

Radio 5 Live: 5 Live Sport Live 5 (7pm) Live streaming audio of the Darlo Posh game.

webTitle: Defence loses as Brown draws up spending plans

fields.headline: Defence loses as Brown draws up spending plans
fields.standfirst:
Pledges on health and education restrict ministers' room for negotiation

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Defence, policing and transport spending are expected to be the biggest losers in the three year comprehensive spending review currently drawing to a close in Whitehall, ministers have revealed.
fields.body:
Defence, policing and transport spending are expected to be the biggest losers in the three year comprehensive spending review currently drawing to a close in Whitehall, ministers have revealed.

Cabinet ministers said yesterday the spending review is now the single biggest drain on ministerial time.

The room for manoeuvre in the spending review covering the three years from 2001-02 to 2003-4 has been restricted by the prime minister's decision to give an average cash boost for health of 5.6% per year.

Tony Blair has also committed himself to ensure education has "the first call" on government investment, suggesting schools and universities will receive comparable increases to those in health.

If this proves to be the case, Whitehall departments, with the exception of education and health, will only have enough cash left to take a modest 2.4% rise over three years, according to the Institute of Fiscal Studies. Overall public spending, capital and current, is due to rise over the three years by 3.3% in real terms.

Ministers insisted yesterday education is certain to get a further healthy above inflation increase, but the education secretary, David Blunkett, may struggle to receive as large an increase as health. According to the IFS, he is already on course to meeting the 1997 manifesto commitment to increase spending on education as a proportion of GDP.

The cabinet spending committee, chaired by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, has now met most ministers for initial negotiations. The second most senior minister present is Lord Irvine, the Lord Chancellor, seen as a deadly cross examiner.

In the current negotiations, defence is fighting hard to avoid suffering three more years of real terms cuts. Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, is proposing to use public/private finance initiative money as much as possible to reduce the immediate cost of capital spending.

Pensions, rapidly moving up the political agenda, may receive a surprise increase through proceeds from lower debt interest payments caused by the £20bn mobile phone sales. The chancellor may also draw on £16bn surpluses in the National Insurance Fund.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, will be pressing hard for extra cash to ensure that police numbers reach the levels the government inherited at the time of the election.

The trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, is seeking cash to fund paid parental leave worth up to £150 a week.

John Prescott, the environment, transport and regions secretary, is confident that he will be able to announce big increases in capital spending. Current spending is set to rise by 2.5%, but capital spending will rise by 32.4%, ensuring cash can be found to expand a big expansion in the rail network.

The Treasury has agreed that the spending increases will not be combined year on year to give misleadingly high total increases by the third year, of over £20bn in the case of health.

Treasury officals like a three year spending programme because it gives departments greater certainty and prevents wasteful end of year spending as ministers try to spend all the money in their budget.

webTitle: Blair warns NHS workers to be braced for change

fields.headline: Blair warns NHS workers to be braced for change
fields.trailText: The prime minister today warned health service staff that they must expect and accept changes in the way the NHS is run.
fields.body:
The prime minister today warned health service staff that they must expect and accept changes in the way the NHS is run.

In an interview published today, Tony Blair said that the modernisation plan for the NHS, to be unveiled in July, would end traditional working systems, change professional demarcations and introduce "incentives" for change. "What the plan will illustrate is the degree of change that is necessary," he said. "And I think the problem... will be making sure that those in the health service, who we need to work with in order to get these changes done, buy into the change."

"Really, I think that will be the biggest problem," he added.

The remarks are the strongest indication yet that the government's changes are likely to prove unpopular with NHS staff. But Mr Blair insisted that they were necessary. "The choice for the country is perfectly clear. We either rebuild the National Health Service, or we move to an American-style system," he said. " My vision is to rebuild the National health Service because I think it is, in the end, the best and most effective way of providing healthcare for the broad majority of the people."

He went on to suggest that if Labour was re-elected the NHS would benefit from continued investment which would see the service "rebuilt".

  • The government has published two new reports outlining plans to make the NHS more cost-efficient.

The Public Services Productivity Panel released Sold on Health, which recommends that the sale of spare land could be streamlined, saving up to £60m a year. The NHS owns surplus land and assets worth around £900m.

fields.headline: Courage under fire
fields.standfirst:
He was an athlete, a racing driver and a subway boss before, age 40, he abruptly decided that he wanted to be a reporter. But Kurt Schork, who was killed in Sierra Leone this week, soon came to be regarded as the greatest war correspondent since Vietnam. Julian Borger pays tribute to his friend while, below, Maggie O'Kane explains why reporters choose to go to war

Sierra Leone: special report
Interactive guide
fields.trailText:
He was an athlete, a racing driver and a subway boss before, age 40, he abruptly decided that he
wanted to be a reporter. But Kurt Schork, who was killed in Sierra Leone this week, soon came
to be regarded as the greatest war correspondent since Vietnam. Julian Borger pays tribute to his
friend while, below, Maggie O'Kane explains why reporters choose to go to war
fields.body:
You probably would not know his name. He did not give his news to a television camera. Unlike many star reporters, he wrote stories without an accompanying portrait. But Kurt Schork, who was killed in Sierra Leone on Wednesday, was widely considered to be the greatest war correspondent of the post-Vietnam era.

He wrote for Reuters, a news agency, which means that his perceptions of war in Bosnia, Kurdistan, Chechnya and Sierra Leone were customarily fed into the news machine that produces the articles you read in the newspapers and bulletins you see on television.

His writing was the gold standard against which other journalists judged whether or not they had got the story right. So if you paid any attention over the past decade to news of far-flung violence and human rights abuses, you would have benefited from Kurt Schork's accuracy, his tenacity and the courage it took to be where he had to be to find out the truth.

That's where he was on Wednesday with a small group of Reuters colleagues, at the edge of the known and unknown in a chaotic conflict, when they were ambushed by a group of rebels 50 miles from Freetown. Kurt was shot in the head and died instantly. His colleague, Miguel Gil Moreno, an Associated Press cameraman and producer who was also among the finest in his field, was killed too. Yannis Behrakis, a Reuters photographer, and Mark Chisholm, a Reuters cameramen, were both wounded.

All four knew each other from the Bosnian war. They were all brave, but aware of the risks involved in their work and alert to the need to reassess them and control them at all times. Any reporter who knew them would have felt confident to have accompanied them. But risks can never be calculated entirely. The ground can shift beneath your feet without warning, especially in as fluid an unpredictable place as the Sierra Leonian bush this week. They would have known that, too, as they set out to do their job.

I last saw Kurt a few days before he left for Sierra Leone. For such a perpetually energetic and restless person, he seemed extraordinarily rested and at ease. He had settled in Washington with his Bosnian girlfriend, Sabina Cosic, and had spent a few months renovating their flat. For someone who had lived out of a couple of suitcases for most of his journalistic career, it was a remarkable transformation. He was looking forward to reporting from behind the scenes at the Sydney Olympics. But there was just one more war. When the latest bout of violence erupted around Freetown I knew he would be there and, sure enough, the next time I tried to get in touch, he was gone.

"War junkie" is an epithet often used for war correspondents, and in certain cases it more or less fits. But Kurt's relationship with violence and human conflict was much more complicated and had far more depth.

Sean Maguire, a Reuters colleague, recalls Kurt explaining the fascination this way: "In extreme situations people behave in remarkable ways. Most journalists are students of human behaviour. Reporting on that in those kinds of situations and stretching yourself at the same time - those are the major challenges you can face."

In the course of his life, Kurt had posed himself all forms of human challenge - both mental and physical - and overcome them all with ease. Despite his modest height, he was a star American football player at school in the Washington suburbs, good enough to win a scholarship to university. His academic prowess then led to a Rhodes Scholarship to Oxford, at the same time as Bill Clinton.

He could never remember much about Clinton from that era, but yesterday Clinton remembered him, describing him as a good and a brave man. "He went to a lot of places, a lot of the troubled and dangerous places of the world, to bring the news to people. And I am very sad about it," the president said yesterday.

After university, Kurt worked for a string of democratic politicians, including Bill Bradley, for whom he was chief of staff but with whose indecisiveness and equivocation he eventually lost patience. For several years, he was chief of staff at New York's Mass Transit Authority, running the city's overburdened subway system. He also tried his hand at real estate development, and even as a racing driver, speeding Porsches around a New England racetrack. Then, at the age of 40, he suddenly declared he was going to become a war correspondent. "He was at a stage when he decided he just had to do it," says his brother, John Schork. "And if he was going to be a journalist he wouldn't do things by half-measure. He was into ice climbing and he was an avid and expert skier."

If it was extremity which drew Kurt to Kurdistan and Bosnia, it was the human and moral imperatives which made him stay. "He was not a religious person but for him honesty and morality were always absolutes, he had a sense of fairness," says his brother. Kurt arrived in Bosnia in the summer of 1992 and stayed for five years, the longest-serving foreign correspondent of the Bosnian war. He did not think it was right to take weekends off, or holidays, while the population had no way of leaving. He would wake up before dawn most days and run through the shell-scarred streets, and usually finish his morning round-up of the night's developments by the time most of the press corps were getting up.

But the mark of his superiority as a journalist was the fact that the story never came before the people. Joel Brand, a US journalist also in Sarajevo for most of the war, recalled eating pizza with Kurt one day when shells began to fall on a neighbourhood nearby. "My first reaction was to drive away from the shells, his first reaction was to drive towards the shells," he says. They came across a pile of wounded and bleeding civilians and Kurt immediately jumped out and started loading them into the car. A group of French soldiers arrived in an armoured vehicle, took one look and drove away, but Kurt - with no protection (he believed wearing a flak jacket was an insult to the Bosnians who had none) - insisted on getting everyone who could be helped to hospital.

"Above all else, he was a humanitarian. He knew better than most journalists how to walk the fine line between doing what he had to do to be a reporter and doing what he needed to do to help people," says Brand. "Kurt stood for everything that I wanted to stand for."

Malcolm Brabant, the award-winning BBC correspondent who also covered the Bosnian war, says simply: "Nobody compared to him in the slightest."

Before he left for Sierra Leone, Kurt said he was still tinkering with a much-delayed book about Bosnia, and there are efforts afoot now to get it published. It is far from being the first work on the subject, of course, and it will almost certainly not be the last. But there is no doubt whatsoever that it will be fair, accurate, funny and, quite simply, the best.

'We are driven by ego, insecurity and... sometimes, a desire to do some bit of good'

Through the fug of early morning waking the radio spat a few disjointed words at me - first there was "foreign correspondent", and, as I woke up, "American". And then "Reuters". I knew then that it was Kurt Schork. This wasn't supposed to happen to journalists like him. He was too experienced, too levelheaded, too sober. A non-smoker, a non-drinker, 5.30am riser. He was 53 but looked 40. I had been bumping into him since we both started this job 10 years ago.

Why he covered almost every single conflict of the last 10 years, I don't know. Partly, I think, because it challenged him hugely and he needed a challenge. I also suspect that he was a "believer". A believer that journalists can make a difference. Miguel Moreno, the Spanish cameraman who died with him, certainly made a difference when he provided the world with the only pictures of the suffering of the people in Grozny - playing Russian roulette with his own life to get them.

East Timor was a good place for believers, too. Max Staal, a freelance cameraman, stayed behind when the pack of journalists panicked and evacuated after a BBC correspondent was wounded. His pictures were the only ones coming out of the country and showed desperate people fleeing into the mountains. This was at a time when the United Nations was considering abandoning East Timor to the fate of the Indonesian military, in the same way it abandoned the city of Srebenica five years earlier.

The other believer in Timor was Marie Colvin of the Sunday Times, who stayed on in the UN compound in Dili with thousands of women and children who had fled there. Her reports of plans to abandon those people helped bring military intervention to Timor. I asked her about it afterwards - about how hard it was to stay behind when your colleagues are bailing out - and she said: "I looked at those women and children there - and they were all looking up at me to see what I would do. I just couldn't leave them."

Colvin and Staal survived Timor, but Sanders Thoenes, a reporter with the Financial Times, did not. His mutilated body was dumped down an alleyway after he ran into a crowd of hostile militia men.

At a rather sad memorial service in the garden of our hotel the next day, an Australian army chaplain who could not even pronounce Thoenes's name concluded the service with a short reminder not to put toilet rolls down the loo. It was a desperate end to a young man's life.

I have a good friend who said to me once that there is a certain logic in thinking that if you keep doing this for long enough you will get hurt. After hearing of Schork's death yesterday morning, I went for a long walk and asked myself why any of us do this. The answer probably lies in what an editor I know said after the Irish crime reporter Veronica Guerin was murdered three years ago. "We are driven by ego, insecurity and sometimes a desire to do some bit of good."

The "ego" is self-explanatory - it's a cool enough job description. The "insecurity", ditto. He missed out the fun, the adventure and the camaraderie. But the desire "to do some bit of good" should also be recognised. Moreno's pictures from Chechnya were the people of Grozny's only window to the world.

The belated intervention in Bosnia happened because of international public pressure to put an end to what they were seeing night after night on television. In Sierra Leone, the continued intervention of the British military is partly fuelled by press reports that acknowledge it to be a good thing that a fine army is stopping killers who cut off the limbs of children.

At the end of my little walk yesterday, the words of the late Martha Gellhorn, the grande dame of war correspondents, came into my mind. In the conclusion to her book The View From the Ground, she writes:

"All my reporting life, I have thrown small pebbles into a very large pond, and have no way of knowing whether any pebble caused the slightest ripple. I don't need to worry about that. My responsibility was the effort. I belong to a global fellowship, men and women, concerned with the welfare of the planet and its least protected inhabitants. I plan to spend my remaining years applauding that fellowship, cheering from the sidelines, shouting: 'Good for you, right on, that's the stuff, never give up. Never give up.' "

On Wednesday night, as Schork and Moreno drove out of Freetown, she would, I'm sure, have been cheering them too.

fields.headline: Most everywhere
fields.standfirst: Place names on T-shirts
fields.trailText: Place names on T-shirts
fields.body:
Palm Springs, Nashville, Brixton, Peckham, Dalston ... No, we're not listing fashion's latest hot spots and those London boroughs haven't (yet) reached the giddy heights of the party circuit. Instead, these are the words currently emblazoned on many a stylish chest about the land. The latest fad has sprung from the US student trend of wearing a place name on your T-shirt. But the Brit versions don't stipulate geographical interest as a prerequisite: you don't have to come from, or even have been to, the place you want to show off. (You're from Lincoln and want to wear La Concha? Go ahead.)

For spring/summer, the catwalks were awash with names of places on clothes (just to be different, Jeremy Scott spelt Paris backwards). On the high street, the new women's collection from Duffer of St George favours fraternity-style Ts with spring break destinations (from £30, 020-7920 7700); Savage London are sticking to their roots and promoting less salubrious (sorry, up-and-coming) areas of London; while Top Shop has gone for a mixture, including Las Vegas, London and Hollywood (from £12, 0800 731 8284). Location, location, location as they say. Just find out where it is on the map first.

webTitle: Pretend you know all about... Cacharel

fields.headline: Pretend you know all about... Cacharel
fields.trailText: For any women over the age of 25, the name Cacharel probably conjures up a pearly white bottle with a silver stopper, filled with sweet-smelling, rather sickly scent. In the 80s, Cacharel's bestseller was every 16-year-old's first perfume purchase: the school corridors reeked of it. A-neigh A-neigh, I used to call it: still did, in fact, until Meg Mathews' baby was born and someone grandly informed me that the umlaut on "Anaïs" meant it should actually be pronounced "Ana-ees". Daft name for a baby, maybe, but it proved a winning name for a perfume: since its launch in 1978, Anaïs Anaïs has never been out of the bestseller list. Along with other favourites such as Loulou, Noa and Eden, the scent has consolidated Cacharel as a big-money brand.
fields.body:
For any women over the age of 25, the name Cacharel probably conjures up a pearly white bottle with a silver stopper, filled with sweet-smelling, rather sickly scent. In the 80s, Cacharel's bestseller was every 16-year-old's first perfume purchase: the school corridors reeked of it. A-neigh A-neigh, I used to call it: still did, in fact, until Meg Mathews' baby was born and someone grandly informed me that the umlaut on "Anaïs" meant it should actually be pronounced "Ana-ees". Daft name for a baby, maybe, but it proved a winning name for a perfume: since its launch in 1978, Anaïs Anaïs has never been out of the bestseller list. Along with other favourites such as Loulou, Noa and Eden, the scent has consolidated Cacharel as a big-money brand.

Its clothes, however, have never been prominent on the designer fashion scene. Sporty verging on mumsy, their presence barely registers with the fasherati, who prefer to plump for the far more chic Chanel and Dior. Cacharel has no stand-alone stores in Paris, nor even a catwalk show to its name.

All this is about to change. The company has just appointed British-based design duo Clements Ribeiro to revamp Cacharel's image and if their own line is anything to go by, the liaison should be a resounding success. Suzanne Clements and Inacio Ribeiro's last catwalk show, held during London Fashion Week in February, was a full-on riot of colour and snappy disco references. If they can invest even a sliver of this glamour into Cacharel, it can only be an improvement.

The worst thing the Cacharel suits could do, though, is expect the duo to perform a Chloe-style turnaround in sales. Talented as they are, Clements Ribeiro do not have the pop star pull of Stella McCartney, whose glamorous persona has been as instrumental as her talent in reversing Chloe's fortunes. Cacharel has a turnover of £168m per year: with over a thousand outlets in Europe, Asia and America, its operation is on a far larger scale than anything Clements Ribeiro is used to. Let's hope too much pressure isn't applied too soon. Le tout Londres wishes them the best of luck. Up the Brits!

fields.headline: Most wanted
fields.standfirst: Urban Therapy
fields.trailText: Urban Therapy
fields.body:
You would think we were saturated to perming point with the mass of hair products on offer. Want sleek, shiny, volumised, de-frizzed, de-dandruffed locks? No problem. But for people from Mediterranean countries or of mixed race, it's a little more tricky; specialist products for more demanding hair types can usually be found only in individual hair salons.

This week, however, sees the launch of a range called Urban Therapy, available from Boots stores nationwide (from £1.29), which includes products for Thirsty Hair (for relaxed or highlighted hair), Curl Definition (for naturally curly hair) and Boost and Shine (for lacklustre locks). There's something for everyone, with no clichéd branding in sight.

fields.headline: Do the bright thing
fields.standfirst: Red and yellow and pink and green, orange and purple and blue: fashion editor  Laura Craik recommends a rainbow summer
fields.trailText: Red and yellow and pink and green, orange and purple and blue: fashion editor Laura Craik recommends a rainbow summer
fields.body:
Before you accuse us of pandering only to beautiful young things, we'd like to emphasise that this is not a trend that works solely on tanned skin. This season's brights work just as well with pale skin, if you know which colours to plump for and which to avoid.

While black skin can set off just about any vivid hue to its fullest advantage (Sudanese model Alek Wek stole many a spring/summer show in acid brights), the rest of us have to be more careful. For the pale and freckly, yellow is a disaster, while an Asian friend swears off green ("It makes me look like I've been up all night"). We all have colours we detest. Sadly, for Brits, these colours are often everything but black, navy, cream and beige. Neutral? We are the living embodiment.

This spring's hottest colours aren't just bright: they're positively neon. At the spring/summer collections, every designer threw cautionary black to the wind and embraced vivid hues. Of course, you'd expect emerald green at Versace ... but canary yellow at Prada? Antonio Berardi used fluorescent orange and pink to offset stark white and even Helmut Lang, best known for his 1001 Ways With A Black Suit, sent out neon pink slip dresses in fluted chiffon.

The high street has responded in kind. Never has there been more fuchsia, orange and turquoise in the shops. Top of the crop is Whistles: silk slips and tops aplenty. Chinese silk takes dye particularly well, resulting in a vibrant, lustrous finish.

It's a staple piece of advice, but never has it been truer: if brights scare you and you're worried about looking as grey as a chicken fillet, confine yourself to the shoe option. You'll be hard pressed to do anything else, anyway: black shoes are almost nonexistent this season, as shelves groan under the weight of jewel-encrusted lime mules and shiny pink stilettos. LK Bennett do every colour of the rainbow; a pricier option is Gina, but for evening elegance, their spindly-heeled sandals are hard to beat.

It's a staple piece of advice, but never has it been truer: if brights scare you and you're worried about looking as grey as a chicken fillet, confine yourself to the shoe option. You'll be hard pressed to do anything else, anyway: black shoes are almost nonexistent this season, as shelves groan under the weight of jewel-encrusted lime mules and shiny pink stilettos. LK Bennett do every colour of the rainbow; a pricier option is Gina, but for evening elegance, their spindly-heeled sandals are hard to beat.

fields.headline: Smarty pants
fields.standfirst: Wearable computers are no longer the stuff of science fiction, as  Hazel Curry found at a cutting edge exhibition this week. Welcome to the future of fashion
fields.trailText: Wearable computers are no longer the stuff of science fiction, as Hazel Curry found at a cutting edge exhibition this week. Welcome to the future of fashion
fields.body:
Fashion folk are notoriously computer phobic. Computers are big, square, ugly things that mostly come in grey. Why should the fasherati relinquish their gorgeous Smythson stationery and Mont Blanc pens to communicate via something so impersonal? And why shop on the net when there's Bond Street?

Perhaps this might interest them more. If a new exhibition is anything to go by, computers are set to revolutionise the way we dress. On Tuesday, US company Charmed Technology revealed its first collection of wearable computers - WCs, as they are unfortunately known. The show, Brave New Unwired World, took place at the Earls Court Internet World UK 2000 exhibition and will tour the world in the next few months. Its mission is to showcase smart clothes that think and perform.

"The body and technology will become one in the future. But people don't want to look like cyborgs when it happens," says Alex Lightman, CEO of Charmed. "Fashion is the answer. We aim to reduce technology in size so much that it can be worn on the body. We want to personalise it so it knows and helps the individual. And of course we're going to make it look good."

Lightman's company plans a vast range of WCs. In the future, a dress will be more than just a dress. It will monitor health, aid communication, provide instant access to information and more. "Originally, technology separated everybody. Charmed will connect people," says vice president Katrina Barillova.

So what are these wonderful gadgets and how do they work? First up, the Charmed Badge - a good stocking filler for the networker. In a room full of people wearing these, the badge will bleep when you pass someone with similar business interests or even sexual preference, depending on what sort of party you're at. Then there's the Charmed Communicator, a device that combines TV, video, radio, mobile phone, internet and email, and the Terrera, a camera and computer that recognises buildings and street names, thus helping travellers. There is something with bio-sensors that release medicinal mists around asthma sufferers and a device that delivers vitamins into the skin. Indulgent options included tubes that squirt essential oils while massaging the skin, as well as a gadget that plays soothing music.

Smart jewellery is an option, too. There are necklaces that pick up voice vibrations so the wearer can communicate quietly, for example if dictating something confidential, and mobile phone earrings. Cheesiest are matching "His and Hers" bracelets. Girls - feeling soppy? Just press a button on yours and no matter where your partner is, his bracelet will become warm or vibrate.

Another innovation is e-broidery, conductive thread that can be sewn into any fabric, in any way, and connected to a tiny computer. Barillova shows off a keyboard sewn into the fabric on your knees and a scarf version (how chic) that can be whipped from your neck and typed on anywhere.

These inventions might sound outlandish - not to say unnecessary - but they are here to stay. Charmed, a year-old spin-off from the Media Lab at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, was one of the first companies to make WCs, along with Nasa and Philips. The Media Lab spends $20m per year on research and development, and will be backing Charmed. The company already has seven offices worldwide. "The project is going to be huge," Barillova says. "It will completely change people's lives. We want to give six billion people instant access to the internet via WCs."

An ex-bodyguard to government officials all over the world, Barillova is one of the few to have used WCs in the course of her job. "It gave me a huge advantage over other people - instant information. Maps, statistics, everything. I used to sew the technology into whatever I was wearing. If I walked into a room, my camera would survey the crowd and tell me who everyone was and what they did."

Charmed's sensory designer, Jenny Tillotson, has another party trick: the Phero-mate. Spot a potential pull and your ruched top will automatically release a cloud of sexual scent. He won't be able to say no. Could this be the new way to make clothes appeal to men? New toys that get the girls? "There will be a whole new tribe of consumers who will be looking at the function rather than the label," Barillova reckons.

A fashionista could train her WC to do all sorts of useful things. It could store information from every style mag in the world, so it knows exactly where to buy the perfect pair of trousers. "Your WC will learn about you, taking messages or contacting the doctor if you need an appointment. It will become your best friend," Barillova insists. Best friend? Surely that's taking things a bit far.

How all this technology will gel with the fashion industry is hard to say. It's difficult to imagine Yves Saint Laurent or Balmain sewing keyboards into their haute couture creations, however discreet. But if WC technology should fall into the magical mitts of someone like Rei Kawakubo at Comme des Garçons, something quite beautiful could be born.

Let's hope WCs catch on with international designers soon because the actual clothes at Charmed were dreadful. Most looked like something Steps would wear on a world tour: silver PVC, tight Lycra, strappy body harnesses. "At the moment, the clothes are simple because we want to put the emphasis on gadgets like the jewellery," says Charmed's director of events, Megan Griffith. "But the possibilities are endless. All the designers I've spoken to are very excited about the creative potential."

"Designers want something new," Barillova says. "Fashion is stuck and whether it's the 30s or the 70s, they're all waiting for something to happen. This is it. With the convergence of technology and fashion, designers can really start to use their talents. Creating rather than rehashing."

"Design is about brands and we don't want to give ours away," Lightman adds. "We'll use in-house designers for the next few years, pulling talent from colleges."

So when will the Charmed collection hit the shop floor? "Sooner than you think," Barillova says. A third of the WCs in the show will be on sale early next year and the badge is already being leased to conference and trade show organisers. "In two to five years' time, everyone will wear WCs as often as they use cell phones." With a little more thought on the design front, she might be right. Designers, are you ready?

webTitle: Unionists square up for vital vote

fields.headline: Unionists square up for vital vote
fields.trailText: The battle lines are now drawn for tomorrow's crucial vote by the ruling council of the Ulster Unionist party. On that vote depends not only the unity of the party, but the prospects for peace in Northern Ireland.
fields.body:
The battle lines are now drawn for tomorrow's crucial vote by the ruling council of the Ulster Unionist party. On that vote depends not only the unity of the party, but the prospects for peace in Northern Ireland.

Leading dissident Jeffrey Donaldson has issued what is in effect an alternative manifesto, pledging the party to continue its veto on power-sharing until the IRA starts a "credible and verifiable" disarmament.

The Donaldson plan, which also calls on the party to defend the Royal Ulster Constabulary's name and insignia, was brusquely rejected by the party leader, David Trimble.

"There isn't anything new in this," he said. "On a number of occasions over [the] last year, proposals very like this were explored. From the response we got from other parties, there wasn't much mileage in them."

Mr Trimble wants the party to accept the IRA's ingenious proposal for a phased programme of putting its weapons "beyond use", after inspection by international observers. If he wins the vote, the short-lived devolved provincial government could be back at work as early as next week.

The vital vote should have been taken last weekend, but was postponed at the last moment when party managers sounded out ruling council members and found to their horror that there was a clear majority against returning to government.

The opposition is thought to have subsided in recent days, following frantic lobbying of council members by Mr Trimble's camp.

A key figure in the debate is the deputy leader, John Taylor, a shrewd and respected veteran of Unionist politics who has never concealed his distaste for power sharing, but who has taken a more pragmatic line on the new disarmament proposals. His endorsement of the Trimble line could be crucial in swinging the mood of the council meeting.

fields.headline: Winterson wins her name back
fields.trailText: "Cybersquatted" author Jeanette Winterson has won back her name in a court ruling against Cambridge academic Mark Hogarth, who had registered the domain names of 139 authors.
fields.body:
"Cybersquatted" author Jeanette Winterson has won back her name in a court ruling against Cambridge academic Mark Hogarth, who had registered the domain names of 139 authors.

Hogarth, who admitted registering the names to "make money, basically", was ruled to have acted in bad faith. He has been ordered to transfer three web addresses to the writer within 10 days. The ruling could have far-reaching implications for the practice of cybersquatting, with other disgruntled "names" following the author's example. Winterson took her complaint to the World Intellectual Property Organisation arbitration and mediation centre in Geneva, which has already received more than 100 similar complaints.

Hogarth, who registered 139 names of various authors, including Joanna Trollope, Louis de Bernières and Julian Barnes, had asked for 3% of gross book earnings in return for giving the names back. Winterson, who won the Whitbread Prize in 1985 for Oranges Are Not the Only Fruit, claimed that "a writer is his or her own trademark" and that she had "common law rights in her name".

Her solicitor said the ruling will enable Winterson to use the domain name "to create a web prescence for the purpose of marketing and developing sales of her work".

webTitle: Peru risks isolation over one-candidate election

fields.headline: Peru risks isolation over one-candidate election
fields.trailText: Peru today brushed aside the threat of international isolation by pressing ahead to hold a presidential election on Sunday in which the president, Alberto Fujimori, stands unopposed.
fields.body:
Peru today brushed aside the threat of international isolation by pressing ahead to hold a presidential election on Sunday in which the president, Alberto Fujimori, stands unopposed.

In a move which further threatens the international legitimacy of Sunday's vote, an Organisation of American States (OAS) mission said late yesterday that it would not perform ground-monitoring of an election process it deems "far from free and fair".

The OAS also said it will not carry out an independent vote count, a procedure intended to allay fears of fraud by verifying the official government count. The terse statement followed violent clashes between police and protesters opposed to Mr Fujimori, who is seeking a third five-year term.

Thousands of students and workers held running battles with police yesterday, throwing paving stones at the government palace. Police dispersed demonstrators with tear gas. At a late-night rally yesterday, Mr Fujimori's opposition rival, Alejandro Toledo, reiterated his promise to boycott the election and promised to continue campaigning until clean elections are held.

"Alejandro Toledo isn't leaving the campaigning because we still have a long road ahead," Mr Toledo bellowed to thousands of his supporters in central Lima. His concerns have been echoed by the US-based Carter centre and the OAS.

"According to international standards, Peru's election process is far from being considered free and fair," the OAS mission said in one of its strongest statements yet. It said the election campaign, marked by a biased media and the use of government funds to bolster Mr Fujimori's campaign, "do not uphold an election process which will represent the authentic will of the people". The OAS will keep only a core team in Peru to issue a final report on the vote.

Mr Toledo, a former World Bank economist whose mix of free-market talk tinged with populist promises has helped consolidate an anti-Fujimori vote, is urging his followers not to vote on Sunday or to spoil their ballots by scribbling "No to fraud". Voting is mandatory in Peru and punishable with a fine in a country where half the 25m population is poor.

Fears of vote-rigging have clouded the contest between Mr Fujimori, the son of poor Japanese immigrants who won popularity for reviving a moribund economy and defeating the Maoist Shining Path rebels, and Mr Toledo, the son of an Andean peasant. The first round of voting in April was marked by massive street protests after a slow count sparked suspicions of fraud.

Like many foreign election-monitors, the US government suspected Mr Fujimori of vote-rigging. The final count showed him with 49.9%, just 20,000 votes short of the majority he needed to avoid a runoff.

"I see isolation descending on Peru," said Arturo Porzecanski, chief economist for the Americas at the New York financial firm ING Barings. "I think the US government, European governments and many Latin American governments will distance themselves from Peru in various ways - diplomatically, in trade, in financial support."


Peru election 2000
fields.bodyText: Peru today brushed aside the threat of international isolation by pressing ahead to hold a presidential election on Sunday in which the president, Alberto Fujimori, stands unopposed. In a move which further threatens the international legitimacy of Sunday's vote, an Organisation of American States (OAS) mission said late yesterday that it would not perform ground-monitoring of an election process it deems "far from free and fair". The OAS also said it will not carry out an independent vote count, a procedure intended to allay fears of fraud by verifying the official government count. The terse statement followed violent clashes between police and protesters opposed to Mr Fujimori, who is seeking a third five-year term. Thousands of students and workers held running battles with police yesterday, throwing paving stones at the government palace. Police dispersed demonstrators with tear gas. At a late-night rally yesterday, Mr Fujimori's opposition rival, Alejandro Toledo, reiterated his promise to boycott the election and promised to continue campaigning until clean elections are held. "Alejandro Toledo isn't leaving the campaigning because we still have a long road ahead," Mr Toledo bellowed to thousands of his supporters in central Lima. His concerns have been echoed by the US-based Carter centre and the OAS. "According to international standards, Peru's election process is far from being considered free and fair," the OAS mission said in one of its strongest statements yet. It said the election campaign, marked by a biased media and the use of government funds to bolster Mr Fujimori's campaign, "do not uphold an election process which will represent the authentic will of the people". The OAS will keep only a core team in Peru to issue a final report on the vote. Mr Toledo, a former World Bank economist whose mix of free-market talk tinged with populist promises has helped consolidate an anti-Fujimori vote, is urging his followers not to vote on Sunday or to spoil their ballots by scribbling "No to fraud". Voting is mandatory in Peru and punishable with a fine in a country where half the 25m population is poor. Fears of vote-rigging have clouded the contest between Mr Fujimori, the son of poor Japanese immigrants who won popularity for reviving a moribund economy and defeating the Maoist Shining Path rebels, and Mr Toledo, the son of an Andean peasant. The first round of voting in April was marked by massive street protests after a slow count sparked suspicions of fraud. Like many foreign election-monitors, the US government suspected Mr Fujimori of vote-rigging. The final count showed him with 49.9%, just 20,000 votes short of the majority he needed to avoid a runoff. "I see isolation descending on Peru," said Arturo Porzecanski, chief economist for the Americas at the New York financial firm ING Barings. "I think the US government, European governments and many Latin American governments will distance themselves from Peru in various ways - diplomatically, in trade, in financial support." webTitle: China opens its arms to America

fields.headline: China opens its arms to America
fields.standfirst: Consumers craving western goods welcome US vote to normalise trade
fields.trailText: Chinese consumers with a growing taste for western goods welcomed the US house of representatives vote to normalise trade relations with China yesterday. The decision was also hailed by those hoping that foreign competition will speed up economic and perhaps even political reform.
fields.byline: John Gittings and Duncan Hewitt  in Beijing
fields.body:
Chinese consumers with a growing taste for western goods welcomed the US house of representatives vote to normalise trade relations with China yesterday. The decision was also hailed by those hoping that foreign competition will speed up economic and perhaps even political reform.

"It is definitely a good thing," said the manager of a photographic shop. "The US has Kodak, their products are famous around the world. Now China's companies will be able to join the world family."

Chinese officials in Beijing showed relief at the vote, saying it was a "wise move" which would benefit long-term relations with Washington. But the new move towards globalisation worries many Chinese workers and factory managers who fear it will lead to huge job losses in industries which were previously protected.

China's foreign ministry denounced the house of representatives' decision to set up a special panel to monitor its human rights situation - a concession to US critics of the vote for permanent normal trade relations (PNTR). Yet many younger officials in the Communist party express in private their hopes that economic liberalisation will promote domestic reform. "The more change in our economy," says a party activist in south-west China, "the sooner our politics will change too".

"If we enter the WTO [World Trade Organisation]," he predicts, "then there will be big changes in this country within five years".

The Chinese prime minister, Zhu Rongji, and senior leaders in Beijing believe, however, that the economic benefits of joining the world market will buy more time for the political system to survive.

Complaints from workers who may suffer from cheap foreign imports have been subdued: many are preoccupied with struggling to save their jobs.

The combined effect of recent trade deals will lower tariffs for many agricultural products, including meat, wheat, maize and soya beans. And the government will gradually eliminate preferential policies for Chinese medical, chemical, tobacco and alcoholic beverage products.

Many urban consumers hope that the influx of foreign products will expose lagging standards of service and supply. "In America we hear that the customer is king," says a Beijing taxi driver. "Here, the customer is still just a little person. Yes, we have new shop fronts here, but behind the counter it is the same."

China's emerging urban middle class hopes to see more stylish and desirable foreign goods on the counters. They also aspire to greater choice of cars and electronic goods as tariffs are reduced. "Chinese goods are still too high in price and low in quality," says a young Chinese working for a Beijing website. "Many of us have travelled in the west and we want to see more western products in our shops."

The trade agreement reached last week between the EU and China has already lifted limits on foreign joint ventures in department and chain stores. The logos of multinational giants such as Ikea and Carrefour, which already have a foothold on the mainland, will spread rapidly into provincial China. Indifferent Chinese wines will face increased European competition; the EU deal lowered tariffs on wines, as well as pasta, shoes, ceramics and another 150 major exports.

Market specialists predict that Chinese eating habits will continue to change, not only in sophisticated Shanghai but in remote provincial towns; the coffee-bar boom will be followed by the spaghetti-house revolution.

"The biggest impact will be a fundamental challenge to China's current economic and management systems," said a Chinese businessman. "But competition will push both sides. Chinese people will be thinking about how they can do things better than foreigners."

An announcement yesterday from Beijing on medical care gave a hint of the way foreign business may now penetrate areas previously reserved for the Chinese state. Officials in Beijing said that China will abolish its collective healthcare system in the next three years, letting hospitals and clinics fix their own prices.

Popular Chinese magazines which have blazoned the prospect of WTO entry on their front covers for many months are now doing the same with PNTR. Only one or two conservative journals warn that the forces of globalisation may undermine China's "socialist" society.

"Most ordinary people really are in favour, even though they do not understand the complexities," says an international aid official in Beijing. " Most reform-minded people see it as an inevitable step forward."

 200-year fight for a lucrative market

1793: Chinese emperor Qianlong gives brush-off to British mission; writes to George III that "we do not have the slightest need of your country's manufacturers"

1839-41: First Opium War. China forced to pay compensation for opium seized from foreign traders and allow free imports

1858-60: Second Opium War. Britain, US, France and Russia gain trade rights and treaty ports. Foreigners allowed to travel freely in China; import tariffs fixed at only 5%

1898-90: Western powers scramble for exclusive railway, mining and trade concessions. US calls for an "open door" - free access for everyone to China's markets

1945: Mao Zedong woos Washington with message that China is the ideal market for American goods and capital investment. But US backs Chiang Kai-shek against Chinese communists

1949-50: The US imposes embargo on new communist government; it becomes illegal even to buy used Chinese postage stamps

1954 - : After Korean war, Britain and other European powers try to keep trade door open to China without offending Washington.

1966-76: Chairman Mao's Cultural Revolution proclaims that China will "rely on its own resources" and avoid dependence on foreign technology

1979: Following US-China thaw, Washington gives Beijing Most Favoured Nation (MFN) trading status. Coca-Cola goes on sale in Chinese hotels

1990s: Annual renewal of MFN becomes a contentious issue after Tiananmen Square massacre

1997: Foreign trade passes US$300bn - compared with $20bn in 1978. But China sells seven times as much to the US as it imports

1999: 50th anniversary of Mao's China. Beijing proclaims: "China needs the world and vice-versa"

fields.headline: Hay Festival of Literature
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about the annual book-lovers' convention on the net
fields.trailText: 1. This is the 13th annual festival of language and literature in Hay-on-Wye, a market town on the Welsh side of the border with England. Hay is known in Welsh as Y Gelli.
fields.body:
1. This is the 13th annual festival of language and literature in Hay-on-Wye, a market town on the Welsh side of the border with England. Hay is known in Welsh as Y Gelli.

2. The festival, which was founded in 1988, attracts a who's-who of the British literary world. Politician and prolific diarist Tony Benn is full of praise: "In my mind it's replaced Christmas."

3. Among the many writers due to attend this year are Martin Amis, Booker winners Ian McEwan and Kazuo Ishiguro, as well as high-profile, younger stars Amy Jenkins and Zadie Smith.

4. Hay is mad about books. The town has a population of 1300 people and 39 bookshops. That's one shop for every 34 inhabitants.

5. Children can go along to their own book events. The Hay Children's Festival of the Arts runs May 27-30, with readings, performances and music aimed at different age groups.

6. TV cook and best-selling author Delia Smith has inspired a song which has been written especially for this year's Hay Festival. A band called Bad Habits from Worcester has recorded "Song For Delia", featuring the extraordinary line: "Delia, I'd like to peel ya... like an aubergine."

7. Don't think it's all about books and song. At last year's festival, it was reported that: "If you didn't have a pashmina, you were no one - and that included the boys."

8. Hay's long history dating back before medieval times has inspired some tall stories. According to one folk legend, a giant called Maud Walbee rebuilt the castle in Hay in one night after it was attacked. Maud was so strong she could hurl boulders more than a mile. But she met a grisly end: imprisoned by King John and left to starve to death in a dungeon.

9. Hay is one of the largest literary festivals in the world, ranking alongside the Toronto Harbourfront and the Adelaide Literary Festival.

10. If you can't make it to Hay over this week, try the Edinburgh International Book Festival, which runs from 12-28 August.

webTitle: The best hypnotism scene: Stir of Echoes

fields.headline: The best hypnotism scene: Stir of Echoes
fields.standfirst: Stir of Echoes
fields.trailText: After being hypnotised at a neighbourhood party by his sister-in-law Lisa (Ileana Douglas), aspiring musician Tom Witzky (Kevin Bacon) has experienced a disturbing vision. Covered in sweat, he comes to, gasping for air.
fields.body:
After being hypnotised at a neighbourhood party by his sister-in-law Lisa (Ileana Douglas), aspiring musician Tom Witzky (Kevin Bacon) has experienced a disturbing vision. Covered in sweat, he comes to, gasping for air.

"What the hell was that?"

Lisa, Tom's wife Maggie (Kathryn Erbe) and party guest Frank (Kevin Dunn) are doubled up with laughter.

"What? What happened?"

Maggie leans over her husband.

"Are you OK?"

"You had to be faking it," exclaims Frank.

"That was the weirdest goddamn thing I've ever seen in my life."

"Congratulations, Tom," smiles Lisa. "You're one of the lucky eight per cent."

"What do you mean," asks a still-disorientated Tom, "the lucky eight per cent?"

"There's only, like, eight per cent of the population that's highly hypnotisable. Almost anyone can go under a little, but not way under. Not freaky under like you did. How's your hand?"

"What do you mean?"

"Dude," Lisa explains, "I stuck a safety pin in your hand and told you to bleed on one side but not the other."

"Which," says Frank, "I can't believe, you did!"

"You were very co-operative," Lisa grins. "It was a side of you I hadn't seen before."

Tom turns to Maggie, still shaken and confused.

"What happened?"

"You said it didn't hurt."

See also: The Manchurian Candidate, The Cabinet Of Dr Caligari, Devil Doll, On Her Majesty's Secret Service

Don't see also: Dead Again

Pointless trivia: Ileana Douglas is the granddaughter of Melvyn Douglas, star of (among others) The Old Dark House, Ninotchka and Billy Budd.
