webTitle: Should we let children play with war toys?

fields.headline: Should we let children play with war toys?
fields.standfirst:
Does playing with guns encourage children to be violent? To Kids' Club Network director Anne Longfield, the answer is obvious. But lecturer Penny Holland's research has shown that this "zero tolerance" approach may be counter-productive, and she argues that any imaginative play should be encouraged and developed.
Have your say
fields.trailText: Does playing with guns encourage children to be violent?  To Kids' Club Network director Anne Longfield, the answer is obvious.   But lecturer Penny Holland's research has shown that this "zero tolerance" approach may be counter-productive, and she argues that any imaginative play should be encouraged and developed.
fields.body:
Dear Anne,
For the last 20-30 years the answer to this question has been a largely unquestioned and resounding no. Zero tolerance of any form of war, weapon and superhero play has held sway in the majority of early-years settings and has been adopted by many parents. This approach has an admirable pedigree, arising from both pacifist and feminist aspirations to intervene in the spiral of violence and stamp out male violence at an early age. This is a perspective to which I vigorously subscribed myself as a parent and teacher - until recently. The central difficulty is that a zero tolerance approach simply does not work. In addition, there is no conclusive research to implicate this area of play in the development of aggressive adult behaviour. In most early-years classrooms there will always be a small group of boys (rarely girls) for whom this area of play is a dominant interest, and they are not for turning. My experience has been that far from gently enticing these boys into more "worthy" areas of play, our constant negativity towards their interests only serves to erode their self-esteem, stunt their imaginative development and turn them into creative liars, as the weapons they construct become mobile phones, drills or hosepipes as soon as they see an adult approach. On the other hand, when we relax such stringent approaches and allow children to construct weapons and play out "superhero" scenarios, I have seen these same boys flourish imaginatively and emotionally. Their aggressive play diminishes. (I'm not talking about toy guns as purchased in toy shops ¾ these are single-purpose toys that can only be pointed and shot). They control the child's play). A general principle of early learning is that we start from where the child is. Why have we been making such a glaring exception for this area of play? I would suggest that while zero tolerance has a discernible moral rationale, it is lacking in pedagogical sense. With adult support, sensitive guidance and boundaries maintained around real aggression, I'd say the answer to this question should now be yes. Penny Holland,
Senior lecturer, School of Education, University of North London

Dear Penny,

The reason zero tolerance of war or weapon play has remained for so long is because it is right. It's important not simply to consider children as isolated individuals. You imply that any interest developed by a child should be encouraged rather than contained, but this ignores the fact that play with war toys can lead to behaviour that dominates or intrudes on the play of other children. Those who work in childcare have to balance the needs of all the children in their care.

I disagree with you that simply because we don*t always succeed in preventing children playing with guns we should abandon all our efforts. What is more important is that we, as parents and carers, help direct children towards more positive play opportunities. Zero tolerance of war toys will not by itself produce a less violent society - but there is no reason to give up one area where we can make a difference.

Best wishes,
Anne Longfield,
Director, Kids' Clubs Network

Dear Anne,

While I'm sure we would both agree that the original intent of zero tolerance - to minimise aggression and promote non-violence - is right, surely concerned and reflective practitioners must constantly challenge strategies conceived to achieve these aims if they are ineffective? I am not advocating that we should allow children to play with manufactured toy guns. My research is concerned with children being allowed to construct weapons from play materials as props for play, and to initiate war and superhero scenarios.

Concerns about the management of potentially disruptive play, which can intimidate and distract others, have been prominent in upholding zero tolerance. Far from advocating a laissez faire approach, which privileges one individual at the expense of others, I'm suggesting we engage with children*s interest in this area of play and support their imaginative development so that they can move beyond media-imposed scenarios, while maintaining clear boundaries around aggressive and intimidating behaviour. Children in my preliminary research were allowed to point weapons at the ceiling, walls and floor, but not at each other. For children with no other entry point into imaginative play, it seems crucial that we hold the door open for them. Once children have come through it, their imaginative play grows beyond their initial area of interest and aggressive play diminishes.

Since I first published this research, I've been inundated with requests to speak with early- years practitioners who are feeling uncomfortable and dissatisfied with the limitations of a zero tolerance approach and wish to develop new strategies. I'm not suggesting a blanket approach to replace zero tolerance, but I hope I am stimulating practitioners to become reflective about their approach. Over the next year, I will be evaluating this work, and the signs so far are that there is much positive work in progress. Like you, I have certainly not given up working towards a less violent society. It is precisely this which fuels my research.

Best wishes,
Penny

Dear Penny,

I'm pleased you agree with me that children should not be allowed to play with manufactured toy guns. But allowing a loophole, where they are allowed to make their own to play with, weakens the message that guns and violence are unacceptable. The central issue is the danger that children become accustomed to violent play and that this affects their development. In the wider culture of TV and computer games, violence is often linked to success. Violent play with toy guns should not reinforce this. Instead, there must be a consistent and universal message that guns and violence are unacceptable. Children like and need consistency from the adults who care for them. As research from the Girl Guides published this week shows, children's primary role models are parents. When parents set down consistent guidelines about war play, they send a very clear value judgment that will resonate through the years as children grow up.

Nurseries should reflect this consistent message from parents. To allow children to create and play with toy guns in a nursery, when they are not allowed to at home, can create doubt and uncertainty in a child's mind, muddying the development of their value system.

Regards,
Anne

Dear Anne,

I'm sorry that you do not seem to have taken on some of the central points I made. Over the last two years of my research it has become clear that significant numbers of practitioners, parents and carers feel that zero tolerance is no longer an adequate response to their experiences of war play. In fact, zero tolerance may have become an avoidance strategy for adults, whereby they do not have to deal in more complex ways with the experience of violence that very small children bring into our settings.

I would suggest that greater developmental damage is caused by leaving children alone with these frightening and disturbing influences, and that to do so is an abnegation of our responsibilities. By engaging with their starting points we can more effectively bring to them an understanding that violence is unacceptable, and develop a repertoire of approaches to conflict resolution. My preliminary research indicates that to relax zero tolerance in a managed way can lead to a reduction in aggression. That, surely, is an avenue of enquiry worth pursuing. Parents are a key feature in this debate. The most conclusive evidence available to us so far on the development of adult aggression shows that parental physical punishment of children and their attitudes to aggression are the most significant influences. Children are not receiving consistent messages from all parents and carers: quite the opposite.

Allowing war, weapon and superhero play does not have to lead to an escalation in violent play, nor does it prevent us from tackling real aggression in a clear and consistent way. Children are far more able to discriminate between fantasy and reality than generally assumed. Violence and conflict are realities. We can help children to face them, and develop their abilities to deal with them peacefully.

Yours
Penny

Dear Penny,

We both share the desire for children to grow up in an environment free from violence. We both want children to be free to develop their potential through play and learning. We also recognise that parents are the main influence on the development of a child's attitude to violence. But we must continue to differ fundamentally over the inclusion of war toys in play. I do not want to exclude play with war toys to satisfy my own attitude to guns - I do it because I want children to realise that violence is not a necessary or desirable part of life. Play is a child's way of coping with life and developing emotionally and intellectually - but the content of that play can sometimes reinforce harmful attitudes learnt or experienced elsewhere. Let us agree that the best childcare allows children to escape from parts of their lives that cause them emotional or physical pain. Instead it helps them develop their full potential in a reassuring, secure environment free from violence or representations of violence.

Best wishes,
Anne

My experience has been that far from gently enticing these boys into more "worthy" areas of play, our constant negativity towards their interests only serves to erode their self-esteem, stunt their imaginative development and turn them into creative liars, as the weapons they construct become mobile phones, drills or hosepipes as soon as they see an adult approach. On the other hand, when we relax such stringent approaches and allow children to construct weapons and play out "superhero" scenarios, I have seen these same boys flourish imaginatively and emotionally. Their aggressive play diminishes. (I'm not talking about toy guns as purchased in toy shops ¾ these are single-purpose toys that can only be pointed and shot). They control the child's play). A general principle of early learning is that we start from where the child is. Why have we been making such a glaring exception for this area of play? I would suggest that while zero tolerance has a discernible moral rationale, it is lacking in pedagogical sense. With adult support, sensitive guidance and boundaries maintained around real aggression, I'd say the answer to this question should now be yes. Penny Holland, Senior lecturer, School of Education, University of North London Dear Penny, The reason zero tolerance of war or weapon play has remained for so long is because it is right. It's important not simply to consider children as isolated individuals. You imply that any interest developed by a child should be encouraged rather than contained, but this ignores the fact that play with war toys can lead to behaviour that dominates or intrudes on the play of other children. Those who work in childcare have to balance the needs of all the children in their care. I disagree with you that simply because we don*t always succeed in preventing children playing with guns we should abandon all our efforts. What is more important is that we, as parents and carers, help direct children towards more positive play opportunities. Zero tolerance of war toys will not by itself produce a less violent society - but there is no reason to give up one area where we can make a difference. Best wishes, Anne Longfield, Director, Kids' Clubs Network Dear Anne, While I'm sure we would both agree that the original intent of zero tolerance - to minimise aggression and promote non-violence - is right, surely concerned and reflective practitioners must constantly challenge strategies conceived to achieve these aims if they are ineffective? I am not advocating that we should allow children to play with manufactured toy guns. My research is concerned with children being allowed to construct weapons from play materials as props for play, and to initiate war and superhero scenarios. Concerns about the management of potentially disruptive play, which can intimidate and distract others, have been prominent in upholding zero tolerance. Far from advocating a laissez faire approach, which privileges one individual at the expense of others, I'm suggesting we engage with children*s interest in this area of play and support their imaginative development so that they can move beyond media-imposed scenarios, while maintaining clear boundaries around aggressive and intimidating behaviour. Children in my preliminary research were allowed to point weapons at the ceiling, walls and floor, but not at each other. For children with no other entry point into imaginative play, it seems crucial that we hold the door open for them. Once children have come through it, their imaginative play grows beyond their initial area of interest and aggressive play diminishes. Since I first published this research, I've been inundated with requests to speak with early- years practitioners who are feeling uncomfortable and dissatisfied with the limitations of a zero tolerance approach and wish to develop new strategies. I'm not suggesting a blanket approach to replace zero tolerance, but I hope I am stimulating practitioners to become reflective about their approach. Over the next year, I will be evaluating this work, and the signs so far are that there is much positive work in progress. Like you, I have certainly not given up working towards a less violent society. It is precisely this which fuels my research. Best wishes, Penny Dear Penny, I'm pleased you agree with me that children should not be allowed to play with manufactured toy guns. But allowing a loophole, where they are allowed to make their own to play with, weakens the message that guns and violence are unacceptable. The central issue is the danger that children become accustomed to violent play and that this affects their development. In the wider culture of TV and computer games, violence is often linked to success. Violent play with toy guns should not reinforce this. Instead, there must be a consistent and universal message that guns and violence are unacceptable. Children like and need consistency from the adults who care for them. As research from the Girl Guides published this week shows, children's primary role models are parents. When parents set down consistent guidelines about war play, they send a very clear value judgment that will resonate through the years as children grow up. Nurseries should reflect this consistent message from parents. To allow children to create and play with toy guns in a nursery, when they are not allowed to at home, can create doubt and uncertainty in a child's mind, muddying the development of their value system. Regards, Anne Dear Anne, I'm sorry that you do not seem to have taken on some of the central points I made. Over the last two years of my research it has become clear that significant numbers of practitioners, parents and carers feel that zero tolerance is no longer an adequate response to their experiences of war play. In fact, zero tolerance may have become an avoidance strategy for adults, whereby they do not have to deal in more complex ways with the experience of violence that very small children bring into our settings. I would suggest that greater developmental damage is caused by leaving children alone with these frightening and disturbing influences, and that to do so is an abnegation of our responsibilities. By engaging with their starting points we can more effectively bring to them an understanding that violence is unacceptable, and develop a repertoire of approaches to conflict resolution. My preliminary research indicates that to relax zero tolerance in a managed way can lead to a reduction in aggression. That, surely, is an avenue of enquiry worth pursuing. Parents are a key feature in this debate. The most conclusive evidence available to us so far on the development of adult aggression shows that parental physical punishment of children and their attitudes to aggression are the most significant influences. Children are not receiving consistent messages from all parents and carers: quite the opposite. Allowing war, weapon and superhero play does not have to lead to an escalation in violent play, nor does it prevent us from tackling real aggression in a clear and consistent way. Children are far more able to discriminate between fantasy and reality than generally assumed. Violence and conflict are realities. We can help children to face them, and develop their abilities to deal with them peacefully. Yours Penny Dear Penny, We both share the desire for children to grow up in an environment free from violence. We both want children to be free to develop their potential through play and learning. We also recognise that parents are the main influence on the development of a child's attitude to violence. But we must continue to differ fundamentally over the inclusion of war toys in play. I do not want to exclude play with war toys to satisfy my own attitude to guns - I do it because I want children to realise that violence is not a necessary or desirable part of life. Play is a child's way of coping with life and developing emotionally and intellectually - but the content of that play can sometimes reinforce harmful attitudes learnt or experienced elsewhere. Let us agree that the best childcare allows children to escape from parts of their lives that cause them emotional or physical pain. Instead it helps them develop their full potential in a reassuring, secure environment free from violence or representations of violence. Best wishes, Anne

webTitle: UN calls on Lebanon to avert Hizbullah threat

fields.headline: UN calls on Lebanon to avert Hizbullah threat
fields.trailText: The UN envoy to the Middle East today called on the Lebanese government to quickly resume control of south Lebanon, as Hizbullah guerrillas threatened to attack Israel unless it withdrew from a disputed area in south Lebanon along the Syrian border.
fields.body:
The UN envoy to the Middle East today called on the Lebanese government to quickly resume control of south Lebanon, as Hizbullah guerrillas threatened to attack Israel unless it withdrew from a disputed area in south Lebanon along the Syrian border.

"[The disputed area] Shebaa Farms is Lebanese and the resistance is committed to returning it by force and fire," Mohammad Raad, chief of the political bureau of Hizbullah, said. "Israel should leave Shebaa today and not tomorrow."

He also warned Israel that Hizbullah guerrillas would hit Israeli settlements if Israel attacked Lebanon. "If Israel attacks Lebanon's infrastructure, Lebanon will hit Israel. We are on the edge of the borders now, the settlements are just in front of us and Israel should not play the game of firing at us because we will pay back and burn its body," he added.

With Hizbullah issuing bellicose statements, the UN is trying to fill the vacuum left by Israel's precipitous withdrawal after 22 years of occupation. UN envoy Terje Roed-Larsen said he expected all government and non-governmental bodies in Lebanon to abide by UN decisions on whether Israel had fully withdrawn.

In the past, Hizbullah, which is backed by Iran, has said it would keep fighting until Israel leaves all of Lebanon, including the Chebaa Farms, a strip of land Israel says it seized from Syria in the 1967 Middle East war and is not obliged to leave. The Lebanese government has demanded it be returned to Lebanon, a position supported by Syria.

But Mr Roed-Larsen said the UN has looked over about 25 Lebanese and Syrian government maps and considers the Chebaa Farms to belong to Syria. The decision means Israel's presence at the strip, along the foot of Mount Hermon, would not impede confirmation of the withdrawal.

Mr Larsen said countries supplying peacekeeping troops needed assurances that their soldiers will be welcomed in their role of confirming an Israeli withdrawal and restoring central government authority.

"One of the most important signs of this is the manner in which the government of a country assumes its responsibilities for ensuring safety and security within its national territory," Mr Roed-Larsen said. But Hizbullah's threatening language bodes ill for any UN force trying to restore stability in south Lebanon. The UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, plans to call for 3,500 more troops to secure peace along the Israeli-Lebanese border to boost the present force of 4,500.

UN teams fanned out in south Lebanon today, making sure Israel has withdrawn completely and that its allied militia has been dismantled - conditions that appear mere formalities to deploying a peacekeeping force along the Lebanon-Israel border. Lebanese police, meanwhile, were settling in at southern Christian villages to provide a small measure of security after reports of looting by armed Shiite Muslim guerrillas following the hasty departure of Israeli troops.

webTitle: Unionist hardliners demand decommissioning before devolution

fields.headline: Unionist hardliners demand decommissioning before devolution
fields.trailText: The IRA must disarm before Northern Ireland's power-sharing executive can be restarted, Ulster Unionists opposed to the Good Friday agreement said today in plans put to members of the party's ruling council ahead of tomorrow's crucial vote on the latest peace deal.
fields.body:
The IRA must disarm before Northern Ireland's power-sharing executive can be restarted, Ulster Unionists opposed to the Good Friday agreement said today in plans put to members of the party's ruling council ahead of tomorrow's crucial vote on the latest peace deal.

The proposals, drawn up by Jeffrey Donaldson MP, who is meeting the party leader, David Trimble, today, demands a "credible and verifiable" start to IRA disarmament.

Mr Donaldson said he had put forward the proposals because of the deep unease within the party over the IRA's unprecedented statement early this month that it would put its weapons beyond use.

"Our twin objectives are sustainable devolution and disarmament," he said. "But it has to be government based on democracy and committed to democracy."

His scheme suggests that a timetable should be agreed for the completion of total disarmament by paramilitaries in the province, also calls for the Royal Ulster Constabulary to retain its name and emblems despite reforms of policing in Northern Ireland.

Details of Mr Donaldson's proposals emerged as rival camps in the Ulster Unionist party entered the final 24 hours of their campaigns to persuade or deter council members from voting for the Hillsborough deal, which, if backed by the party, would restart devolved government in Northern Ireland.

Mr Donaldson said his alternative plan was a "genuine and sincere attempt" to avoid division in the party. But a supporter of Mr Trimble and his deputy, John Taylor, expressed scepticism about the ability of the plan to win support beyond the Ulster Unionist party.

"If these reports are reflecting what is in Jeffrey's proposals, then I don't think it is that realistic," he said. "It would appear to be something of a Unionist wish-list."

Later, Sinn Fein's chief negotiator, Martin McGuinness MP, said that a return to devolved government should not be attached to conditions and warned that rejection of the IRA's current proposals would be "a serious mistake".

"We want to see a very clear statement coming out of tomorrow's meeting from the Ulster Unionist council that they're going to move forward with the rest of us to build a new future for our people," he said.

"All the difficulties which are attached to this process can then be resolved, and resolved in a sensible way. The Hillsborough deal is the way forward. Any attempt to undermine it is a serious mistake at this time."

 A man was shot dead in Belfast today. The shooting occurred near the scene of Wednesday's assassination attempt in Old Park, north Belfast. The attack was believed to be part of a Loyalist paramilitary feud.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's transfer talk, trussed up like a turkey
fields.trailText: Teamtalk are today linking Manchester United with a move for Barcelona star Figo. They report sources close to the player as saying that the Nou Camp favourite will complete a move to Old Trafford within the next couple of weeks.
fields.body:
Teamtalk are today linking Manchester United with a move for Barcelona star Figo. They report sources close to the player as saying that the Nou Camp favourite will complete a move to Old Trafford within the next couple of weeks.

Emmanuel Petit wants to leave Arsenal this summer, according to a French football website (www.football365.fr). "I don't know if I'm going to be at Arsenal next season," he said. "The only thing that I will say is that I am soon going to be 30 years old and if Arsenal get the opportunity to get a good return on their investment in me they must accept the offer."

Spurs are ready to offer Chelsea £4m for Frank Leboeuf. The Daily Star reports that the impressive form of Emerson Thome is likely to mean that Leboeuf is surplus to requirements next season, and tentative talks with Spurs have already taken place.

Newcastle are set to sign Argentine midfielder Christian Bassedas next week, according to the Sun. The deal, which Newcastle could not afford earlier in the season, has been bankrolled by the Toon's new sponsors NTL.

The Daily Express reports that Spanish champions Deportivo La Coruna have made Tore Andre Flo their main transfer target this summer and are preparing a £16m bid.

Gianfranco Zola will definitely be leaving Chelsea this summer, according to the Daily Mail, after Gianluca Vialli told the 33-year-old he will no longer be guaranteed a first-team place next season.

Planetfootball reports that Arsenal have had a £5m bid for Barcelona midfielder Gabri rejected. The Catalan giants have told the Gunners to double their offer.

Bolton and Manchester City have reached a standoff over the proposed transfer of Eidur Gudjohnsen, says the Sun. Joe Royle has offered £2m for the Icelandic striker, but Bolton are holding out for £6m.

The Daily Mail reports that Sunderland are looking to strengthen their back line by signing Joachim Bjorklund from Valencia. A regular in the Swedish national side, Bjorklund made it only to the bench for Wednesday's Champions League final.

Celtic are to pinch Joe Kinnear from under the noses of Sheffield Wednesday after their vacant manager's post was turned down by Martin O'Neill. Kinnear is a lifelong Celtic fan and, says the Daily Star, would jump at the chance of working at Parkhead.

fields.headline: An excellent excursion
fields.trailText: An excellent excursion
fields.body:
'Dinosaur stomps Gladiator' was the big story at this week's box office, one which caused double-takes among those of us who think we know our history. After repressing images of Russell Crowe being eaten by a rampaging Megalosaurus, I was put in mind of the primitive, Roman-occupied Britain conceived by screenwriter Talbot Rothwell for the imperishably leery Carry On Cleo.

While Caesar and his invading cohorts luxuriate in civilised, well-appointed military camps and moan about Britannia's inclement weather - "Hail Caesar!" "Hail, snow, sleet, rain. Bloody country!" - the moronic Picts are trapped in some kind of anachronistic time-slip, still dressed like the cavemen in The Wacky Races, wielding cartoony cudgels and dragging their womenfolk about by the hair.

Meanwhile, here comes the summer! The schools here are about to discharge a tidal wave of hormonal teenagers into the nation's multiplexes. The studios are waiting outside the schoolyard like drug dealers, readying their cash-magnet youth-market movies to strip the kids of their allowances and the pay cheques they work hard to earn slinging hash and hawking loogies into bacon-double cheeseburgers.

Disney's animated Dinosaur, which cost $125m, lumbered into the fray a week before the Memorial Day holiday weekend and scored a record-breaking $38m in receipts, despite worries that its odd combination of mild violence and extreme sappiness might alienate or irritate parents.

The reason you know the summer season is here is because the top 12 movies scared up an astounding $100m between them. Gladiator held firm at number two, and U-571 and Frequency held on without losing too many viewers over last weekend. Woody Allen's new comedy Small Time Crooks - the first project under a new deal he has with DreamWorks - had a better opening than any movie he's released in the last 20 years, evidence of the potency of the SKG marketing dollar.

It arrives barely five months after the release of Allen's last movie, Sweet and Lowdown, and has been marketed as a family comedy, helped somewhat by the presence of Tracey Ullman as Allen's long-suffering wife and Michael Rappaport as a spectacularly dim criminal associate.

The only movie that did badly was the badly conceived, badly made, badly acted and sadly crappy Battlefield Earth, which functioned as a punchbag for me and every other movie writer last week. It averaged only $1,100 per screen in its second weekend.

I saw my favourite new movie of the week, Road Trip, in a jam-packed sneak-preview a couple of weeks ago. Boy, was that a happy audience. It's this year's first entry in the American Pie teen gross-out stakes, and is the feature debut of gonzo documentarian Todd Phillips. His last project was an HBO TV documentary about fraternity hazing rituals, and he and his crew were permitted to film these primitive rites only if they agreed to submit to the same humiliations themselves.

The resulting documentary is currently in litigation because, as I understand it, the parents of the most spectacularly bestial fratboy aren't anxious for his degenerate excesses to be broadcast on national TV.

Phillips started out at NYU with a documentary about self-proclaimed "scum rocker" GG Allin. I saw an Allin show in LA in 1993. He came, he shat on the stage, he smeared himself with it and then ran at us with fists flying. The last thing I saw before the cops and the Fire Marshal raided the show was Allin being beaten up with folding metal chairs as somebody emptied a fire extinguisher at him. He was dead two weeks later. Now that's entertainment.

Road Trip is just that, a cross-country comedy about a guy who accidentally mails his girlfriend a tape of himself having sex with another woman. He and three idiot pals have three days to cover 1,500 miles and overtake the US Postal Service. We are treated to the kind of shit-sex-drug-big-tit humour that is this genre's stock in trade.

There's the old man who keeps knocking stuff over with his hard-on, the visit to a sperm bank that culminates with a vigorous prostate massage (a cinematic first, I do declare), and a full complement of topless bimbos. The sniggering tackiness of the whole enterprise put my hair up in curlers for a week. Wonderful stuff.

Road Trip's biggest star is the gross-out comedian Tom Green, whose star is currently in the ascendant because of the success of his MTV show, in which he performs provocative acts of street theatre to see if anyone will beat him up.

Green started out on the Canadian Comedy Network a few years ago and made a name for himself with shows like his spoof cookery programme. For this he invited his lovely, naive old grandmother to come on and demonstrate her favourite recipes for the audience. He didn't tell her that all the stirring and mixing implements he'd stocked his studio kitchen with were vibrators and sex-aids.

The show culminated with Tom and Grandma licking opaque pancake batter off a gigantic pink dildo. After making Road Trip, Green was diagnosed with testicular cancer and after a few days of terror decided to make a special edition of his programme called The Cancer Show.

As he told Chris Heath in Rolling Stone, "It's like God said, 'Holy Shit, Tom, I'm going to give you a curable form of cancer on your genitals so you can have an unlimited licence to do all the potty humour you want and talk about your balls and your testicles on TV. And nobody's going to be able to say no because you've got cancer there, so it's serious, so go for it!' "

As he told Chris Heath in Rolling Stone, "It's like God said, 'Holy Shit, Tom, I'm going to give you a curable form of cancer on your genitals so you can have an unlimited licence to do all the potty humour you want and talk about your balls and your testicles on TV. And nobody's going to be able to say no because you've got cancer there, so it's serious, so go for it!' "

fields.headline: Blast from the past
fields.standfirst: Ground force, bog standards, more unwelcome smells and panic at the picnic
fields.trailText: Dramatic events in Grimsby, Lincolnshire, this week when explosives experts were called in to defuse a large bomb dating from the second world war.
fields.body:
Dig for victory


Dramatic events in Grimsby, Lincolnshire, this week when explosives experts were called in to defuse a large bomb dating from the second world war.

The bomb was buried in the garden of 78-year-old Margaret Clutterbuck, who had actually discovered the device 23 years ago when she bought her house. At the time she had merely covered it over with earth and forgotten about it.

Deciding it was time to give her garden a makeover, she remembered the bomb. Fearing it might not take kindly to having a water feature built on top of it, she contacted the police to see if they could come round and take it away.

Cue emergency. Army ordinance experts were flown in to examine the device, and a mass evacuation plan was set in motion to clear away all residents within a mile radius of the missile.

Thirteen hours of tense probing amongst Miss Clutterbuck's herbaceous borders with explosives detection equipment failed to reveal any sign of the bomb. It eventually emerged that the bomb was not a bomb at all, but an old air-raid shelter.

"We all make mistakes," said one expert. "A few years ago I spent 16 hours defusing a gift-wrapped pogo stick. It's always better to be safe than sorry."
Grimsby Evening Telegraph

Have I got loos for you


Life has taken a turn for the worse for the residents of a housing estate in Basildon, Essex.

The inhabitants of the Malyons council estate have had to put up with volcanoes of raw sewage erupting from their lavatories.

The trouble started a few weeks ago when several households reported that rather than removing waste from their bathroom, their toilets were bringing the stuff in, flooding the floors with a foul-smelling slick of noisome ordure.

"The toilet started making funny noises," said Leslie Joshua, 48. "And then suddenly it was full of disgusting sewage. I had to use a saucepan to bail it out to prevent the entire bathroom flooding."

Other residents reported similar problems, including one man who returned from his tai-kwando class to find a 3ft geyser of excrement spurting from his loo. "I'm a blue belt," he explained. "But there was nothing I could do to stop it."

Basildon council has begun an investigation, but those affected have threatened to withhold their council tax until their lavatories are returned to normal. "I've lived on this estate for 12 years," said one woman. "And frankly, I've had all the crap I can take."
This is Essex

Kicking up a stink


More unpleasant aromas in Sherborne, Dorset, where neighbours are up in arms about the smell coming from a local fibreglass factory.

Residents say the factory, owned by the German company CS Interglas, has always emitted an unpleasant odour. But over the last few months the stench has become unbearable.

"We're at the end of our tether," fumed George Kirkby. "We've been trying to sell our house, and the reason our buyers pulled out was the smell from the factory." "I'm sorry to be graphic," said another local man, "but it really is like living directly behind a giant who can't stop breaking wind. I've started wearing a cycle mask when I work in my garden."

CS Interglas insists that it is aware of the problem, and is taking action to deal with it, installing a £20,000 bio-mass filtration unit to dispel the vapours.

"I've no idea what a bio-mass filtration unit is," said one woman, "But if it gets rid of bad smells I might look at buying one to attach to my husband's armpits."
Western Gazette

Bee afraid - bee very afraid


It's not just Britain's youth who are accused of becoming increasingly delinquent. Our bees, too, it seems, no longer have any respect for law and order.

Such has certainly been the case at Iford Manor, Wiltshire, where a swarm of rebellious bees have been terrorising picnickers in a meadow beside the River Frome.

"We'd just opened the picnic basket," said one woman, "When this huge swarm of bees came at us out of the woods. We packed everything up and ran away, and the bees disappeared. When we tried to go back into the field, however, they came at us again. It's like they were deliberately trying to drive us away."

There have been similar reports of unprovoked apian aggression in the same meadow, and now Elizabeth Cartwright-Hignett, the owner of Iford Manor, has warned picnickers to avoid the place.

"There are a number of commercial hives on the hill above, and wild bees in the woods," she explained. "The combination of these and jam sandwiches is not a good one." She has advised picnickers to use other spots further along the river which, so far at least, seem to be free of bee activity.

"It's another example of how this country's going down the drain," said one man. "I fought in the war, and now I can't go for a walk without fear of being attacked. We should bring back National Service."
Bath Chronicle

Letter of the week


I read with disgust the comments of Robert Goodwill, my Tory MEP for Yorkshire and Humberside, about his ability to make a nice profit on travel expenses at my expense as a taxpayer.

He is reported to have said that when he flies from Leeds-Bradford Airport to Brussels he gets a set fee of £500 - and so he buys an economy class ticket for between £160 and £250 and pockets the difference.

He allegedly says that as a capitalist and a British Conservative he sees it as a challenge to make some profit because that is the system.

Well I'm glad you feel that way, Mr Goodwill. You have just ripped me off as a taxpayer. And as such you have lost my good will, and also my vote in the next European elections. I shall now vote for any party that wants to pull out of Europe because no matter which of the major parties one votes for, the gravy train still rolls along merrily and unabated."
Ian Cartwright, This is Grimsby

webTitle: May 26: In brief and casting news

fields.headline: May 26: In brief and casting news
fields.trailText: Tom Hanks bemoans his beard, Joe Pantoliano set for directing debut, Ben Stiller: male supermodel, Disney to remake The Brave One, and Renny Harlin and Jackie Chan project on the cards
fields.body:
 Legendary nice guy Tom Hanks has been having a grumble about the physical requirements of his role in Bob Zemeckis' Cast Away. Hanks starts off as a corpulent and over-indulgent city worker: "I got as big as a house, which was fun" said Hanks of this period. However, the character is then stranded on a desert island, and Hanks was required to undergo a drastic weight loss and hair growth programme. "Losing the weight was tough. I'm older now. The old metabolism isn't as good as when I lost all that weight [to play an AIDS patient] for Philadelphia," Hanks told online magazine Cinescape. And as for the beard, "everybody hates the beard - nobody as much as me. If someone needs me to play Fidel Castro or Ted Kaczynski, I'm available."

 Joe Pantoliano, best known for his role in The Matrix, will make his directorial debut with Just Like Mona, a $3m indie film. Set for an October shoot in New Jersey, Chazz Palminteri, and Andy Garcia are among the actors already committed to the project. Told in flashbacks to the 60s and 70s, the story centres on a teenage boy and his relationship with his foul-mouthed and criminal mother. Pantoliano co-wrote the script.

 Ben Stiller is negotiating to direct as well as star in Zoolander, a comedy based on a naive male supermodel character. Stiller created the character for the VH1 Fashion Awards three years ago, and it generated enough buzz to attract studio Fox - where Stiller had a producing deal - into building a film around an international fashion misadventure.

 Walt Disney is remaking the 1956 Academy Award-winning film The Brave One with director Jay Russell. The story follows a poor Mexican boy and his attachment to a bull who was born to die in the bull ring. "This is a classic story which I believe fits perfectly with Disney's live-action family films, and I hope it will be remembered and loved as much Old Yeller," said Russell.

 Renny Harlin (Deep Blue Sea) is in talks to direct Jackie Chan in a project called Nosebleed. The movie, which is likely to start shooting next year, will tell the story of a window washer at the World Trade Center who teams up with a bartender and a waitress to thwart terrorists intent on blowing up the twin buildings.

webTitle: Regional cricket is the way forward

fields.headline: Regional cricket is the way forward
fields.standfirst: Got something to say? Your rant could appear on wisden.com next weekend. Send your Punter's Point to beamer@guardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The debate over the structure of English cricket and the introduction of two divisions has highlighted the fact that any change must happen within the confines of the 18-county structure. Their existence is regarded as sacrosanct. For this reason, the idea of abolishing the counties and having a regional Championship comprising only the best players and thus raising the level of competition was always a non-starter. Yet regional cricket can, and indeed should, be part of our first-class programme.
fields.body:
The debate over the structure of English cricket and the introduction of two divisions has highlighted the fact that any change must happen within the confines of the 18-county structure. Their existence is regarded as sacrosanct. For this reason, the idea of abolishing the counties and having a regional Championship comprising only the best players and thus raising the level of competition was always a non-starter. Yet regional cricket can, and indeed should, be part of our first-class programme.

Accommodating it would be easy. When the exclusively four-day County Championship programme was introduced, each county played each other once. Now, following the split into two, they play the others in their division twice to make up the number of games. They should, however, play the other eight just once. This would create the necessary space on the fixture calendar for a triangular regional championship played on a round-robin, home-and-away basis, featuring the North, South, and Midlands/Wales.

Numerous benefits would arise from a regional Championship. Firstly, the higher level of competition would give a better guide as to which county players are good enough for international cricket, thus reducing the number of players with three Test caps or less who are tried but then fail and disappear, such as Aftab Habib, Ronnie Irani, Tim Munton, Martin McCague, and Mark Lathwell, to name a few. The presence of such players in the England team has meant inconsistency of selection and every Test team in the last 15 years carrying at least one or two passengers, an unaffordable luxury at the highest level.

Secondly, by incorporating quotas of Under-21s and non-internationals, youngsters and other possible Test candidates would be given the chance to impress.

Thirdly, the difficulty of assessing the merit of performances in the second division in comparison to the first can be resolved by having three or four second-division players in each team.

Finally, the games themselves should generate enough sponsorship, media and TV interest, and spectators to more than make up the financial shortfall of fewer county games.

County cricket, by supplying the players for regional teams, would still have an important role to play in the overall structure. Indeed, competition for regional places could enhance the county game, not least if financial rewards and incentives are provided for the counties who produce the most players for regional teams, and for the players themselves. It would encourage a move away from the culture of old lags hanging around for a benefit year. Sponsorship money for the regional championship could be used for this purpose.

Test trials were used in the past to determine selection. In view of the current standard of county cricket, inconsistency of selections, and the need to fast-track young talent, the regional Championship has to happen - and soon.

Charles Britten, 27, is a customer-service advisor at the Co-operative Bank, and comes from Marple, Cheshire. His great grandfather played for Northants.

webTitle: Seeking a breakthrough in the peace process

fields.headline: Seeking a breakthrough in the peace process
fields.standfirst: On Saturday, the Ulster Unionists meet to vote on a deal to return to government with Sinn Fein. Derek Brown, former Guardian correspondent in Belfast, examines the latest hopes of a breakthrough in the peace process
fields.trailText: On Saturday, the Ulster Unionists meet to vote on a deal to return to government with Sinn Fein. Derek Brown, former Guardian correspondent in Belfast, examines the latest hopes of a breakthrough in the peace process.
fields.body:
Why are the Ulster Unionists in the spotlight?
The Ulster Unionist party leader, David Trimble, is attempting to sell to his party members the latest formula for his party to rejoin Sinn Fein in the Northern Ireland assembly after the IRA's declaration that they will put their weapons beyond use. Today he meets party rival Jeffrey Donaldson, who stormed out of the Unionist negotiating team just before the Good Friday agreement was signed, in an attempt to persuade him to back the deal.

Will Trimble succeed?
He may not win round Mr Donaldson, but according to a poll in the Belfast Telegraph, 72% of Ulster Unionists want to return to the power-sharing executive now. Mr Trimble's more conservative deputy, John Taylor, hailed the deal as a "breakthrough" and also backs a return to the assembly. If this feeling at the top is reflected in tomorrow's crucial vote of the Unionists' 860-strong ruling council, the party will officially support the new deal and pave the way for a return to devolved government by June 5.

What is the IRA offering?
At the start of May, the IRA promised to put its arms beyond use, and agreed to open its secret arms dumps to inspections by two respected international observers, the former Finnish president Martti Ahtisaari and the former African National Congress secretary general Cyril Ramaphosa. They will return regularly to check that the caches are secure, and that the weapons in them have not been used.

When will IRA disarmament occur?
The old deadline for paramilitary disarmament was May 22. The new target date for all arms to be out of commission is June next year.

What is in it for the IRA and Sinn Fein?
They are demanding full implementation of all the political elements in the Good Friday peace accord, including the resumption of power-sharing, police reforms, and the establishment of cross-border bodies. They will also be looking for an early reduction in Britain's military presence in Northern Ireland. Some troops could be withdrawn within days.

And what is in it for the unionists?
The new formula falls short of demands for a full surrender of all paramilitary arms as a precondition of power-sharing. But it does go much further than any previous offer, and amounts to a declaration by the IRA that its 30-year war is over.

Who came up with the new formula?
The British and Irish governments, together with the pro-peace parties, have been locked in intensive discussions for several weeks, trying to avoid the glare of publicity and the mutual recrimination which has soured earlier negotiations. Much of the credit for the arms inspection idea is being given to the quietly effective Irish foreign minister, Brian Cowen.

fields.headline: Food on the net
fields.standfirst: www.barbecue.com
fields.trailText: It's the late May bank holiday, which means it's nearly summer, which means it's time to drag the barbecue out of the shed. Nobody takes the art of barbecuing more seriously than the Americans, and this site is an exhaustive guide to all things smoky.
fields.body:
It's the late May bank holiday, which means it's nearly summer, which means it's time to drag the barbecue out of the shed. Nobody takes the art of barbecuing more seriously than the Americans, and this site is an exhaustive guide to all things smoky.

Pros: Hints on choosing your grill, your spices, your seasonings (there's more to barbecuing than incinerating burgers), plus lots of authentic American recipes.

Cons: Tends towards the serious - but then, we don't have barbecuing championships to prepare for. It may surprise you to learn that UK versions don't really qualify as barbecuing, but there are recipes for "grilling" too.

Coming soon: The sun?

fields.headline: On the menu: brick
fields.trailText: What is it? Brick, or possibly brik, bric or briq.
fields.body:
What is it? Brick, or possibly brik, bric or briq.

But not brick as in dropping one? Assuredly not, although it might be said to be one of the building blocks of Moroccan and Tunisian cooking.

So far, so fashionable, but how so? They are part of the family of borek, bstilla, brouiat, sambusak, fila, spanakatopitta and lahma bi ajeen, which are all variations on the pastry filled with something ideal.

Oh, not wholly unlike our own Cornish pasty. Well, just about as unlike as you can get, these Middle Eastern versions being small, light and highly flavoured.

Filled with? Well, almost anything: eggs and chopped mushrooms or coriander; quail and almonds; or tuna, onions, cheese and eggs.

webTitle: Quick bites... where to eat out in under 15 minutes

fields.headline: Quick bites... where to eat out in under 15 minutes
fields.standfirst: Kambi's, 107 Western Road, Brighton. Tel: 01273 327934
fields.trailText: Kambi's, 107 Western Road, Brighton. Tel: 01273 327934
fields.body: It's hard to love Western Road but it does, however, boast Kambi's, a Lebanese BYO restaurant, with a takeaway counter to satisfy the quickest and pickiest of quick biters. Starters include arayess (minced lamb with parsley, grilled in Lebanese bread and marinated in olive oil) and sawdadajaj (fried chicken liver with lemon). Veggies should go straight for the specialist main courses for makdous bitinjan (baby aubergine stuffed with walnuts, spices, garlic and marinated in olive oil), tabouleh, hummus, kabis (Lebanese pickles) and warakinab (stuffed vine leaves). All at under £3 a shot. Chargrilling is a speciality, but only, natch, for meaties.

fields.headline: Braised or roasted, sir?
fields.standfirst: France is shocked by the news that a man has been caught eating his dogs. But why are we so horrified by the idea of cooking our pets?  Matthew Fort  investigates
fields.trailText: France is shocked by the news that a man has been caught eating his dogs. But why are we so horrified by the idea of cooking our pets? Matthew Fort investigates
fields.body:
Earlier this week Jean-Louis Lacoste was fined £300 in France for eating an unknown number of the dogs in his care. Sadly, the reports in the newspapers here told us nothing about how he cooked them. Did he, for example, braise them with soy sauce, sugar, fermented bean curd, dried bean curd, water and rice wine to make the classic Chinese dish of hon tsao go zo (red cooked dog)? Or did he favour the Hawaiian style of spatchcocking them and grilling them on the barbecue with sweet potatoes?

Of course, it could never happen here. In a country where a large number of people will take direct action on behalf of veal calves and mink (although not for the less appealing battery chickens or farmed salmon), Lacoste would probably have been lynched by a mob of Barbara Cartland lookalikes long before he got to court.

It's many years since dog and cat have been on the menu in the western world, with the exception of aberrations such as the Swiss gedörrtes hundefleisch (dried dog meat) and the Spanish recipe caldo de gato Extremadura (Estremaduran cat stew in which the feline is cooked in white wine with bay leaves and thyme and served with broad beans, carrots, turnips, potatoes and onions). But this wasn't always the case.

At the same time that the Greeks were debating the shape of political institutions and the transmigration of souls, they were also partial to a spot of dog. Indeed, Hippocrates recommended dog or puppy flesh as part of a health-giving diet. But subsequently their position as our most favoured domestic companions, frequently with human qualities ascribed to them, has created a taboo against eating them almost as powerful as that of cannibalism.

There has never been the same prohibition in other parts of the world against eating dog or cat. The Mexican hairless dog was a prime food source for the Aztecs. In his landmark work, Unmentionable Cuisine, Calvin W Schwabe lists 10 recipes for dog and four for cat, covering China, Ghana, Hawaii, Burma and the Philippines, as well as those from Switzerland and Spain already described. He fails to mention Korea, where there is a fine tradition for eating dog (indeed, there is said to be a Korean restaurant in New Malden where you may be served dog if you ask for it politely), and he only touches briefly on the Filipino passion for dog, which is so great that the government had to control the consumption after several people contracted rabies as a result of eating rabid animals.

Generally speaking, Europeans have only turned to eating dog flesh in extremis. During the siege of Paris in 1870, a contemporary calculated that Parisians ate 1,200 dogs, 5,000 cats and 65,000 horses before they turned to rats and the contents of the Paris zoo with the same enthusiasm and ingenuity that they reserve for more conventional foods.

No doubt in similar circumstances we British would eventually take to the same course of action, albeit with rather more soul-searching. "I had a slice of spaniel the other day," wrote the English journalist and member of parliament, Henry Labouchere, in a report from Paris during the siege, adding that "it made me feel like a cannibal". Sir Ernest Shackleton's expedition team to the Antarctic, trapped in the polar ice, also managed to stomach man's best friend rather than face starvation.

There has never been quite the same revulsion at the thought of eating horse meat as there has been for dog and cat. The demand may be declining now, but it is still vigorous in Belgium, Italy and France. The tradition goes back to the Romans, who would eat just about anything including door mice. Subsequently eating horse meat fell from grace because the Roman Catholic church frowned on it, associating it with pagan practices.

However, it is said that demand for this old favourite was rekindled after the Battle of Eylau when Baron Larrey, military surgeon to the First Empire, advised the exhausted French troops to eat the flesh of the dead horses, braised in the cavalry breast plates and seasoned with gunpowder, because it was a ready source of protein. La Grande Armée developed rather a taste for it, and French soldiers demanded horse meat whenever they returned home .

While we have looked to the French for so much of our culinary culture, it might be thought that we haven't shared this particular passion for equine gastronomy. However, we haven't always been quite so squeamish about eating horse meat.

The first serious attempt to get the British to eat chevaline occurred in 1867. Following the success of Banquet Hippographique in Paris in 1865, which included consommé de cheval, cheval bouilli aux choux, cheval à la mode and côte de cheval braise, a dinner was organised by the Society for the Propagation of Horse Flesh at the Langham Hotel, following a sharp rise in the price of beef as a result of an epidemic among cattle - a familiar enough tale.

At the time it was reported that several shops were doing a roaring trade in horse meat, no doubt helped by the fact that it was considerably cheaper than beef.

In spite of this early success horse did not become the meat of choice, but its consumption in parts of the country survived until relatively recently. In particular, Yorkshire used to be a hotbed of equine gourmets, the last butcher devoted to the preparation of horse meat closing in Bradford in 1938. And now there are persistent rumours about horse butchery making a surreptitious return to the meat counter. It is said that there's a butcher selling horse meat in Birmingham and of another in Brixton market.

At the beginning of the BSE disaster some authorities in this country saw horse meat as a ready substitute for beef, pointing out that it had the additional advantages of being extremely healthy. It is low in fat and free of any form of prophylactic antibiotics. There was even a proposal that the anthem of the television cowboy Roy Rogers to his horse Trigger could be adapted as an advertising jingle, along the lines of: "A four-legged friend, a four-legged friend, he'll never let you down. Tender and tasty right up to the end, that wonderful one, two, three, four-legged friend."

Not surprisingly this solution did not catch on, in part because the horses that once might have fulfilled the specifications are too much in demand for leisure. By the time they've seen out their days as mounts for Thelwell kids, their meat is fit only for dogs or cats, a neat irony.

In case you're wondering what you're missing by not tucking into dog, the food writer Paul Levy, who really is the man who has eaten everything, says that the braised dog that he was served in Hong Kong "was quite fatty and looked like pork" and "was chewy, and had a very strong, though not disagreeable, flavour, like mutton, venison or goat".

webTitle: Cheapskate... where to eat out for under £15

fields.headline: Cheapskate... where to eat out for under £15
fields.standfirst: Saucy, 8 Church Road, Hove. Tel: 01273 324080
fields.trailText: Saucy, 8 Church Road, Hove. Tel: 01273 324080
fields.body: Saucy is a quintessential Brighton restaurant with brilliant British food and an adequately designed interior. You could eat here with your posse but your granny would like it too. She would also appreciate the simple, well-balanced £12.50 lunch menu which is confident enough in the quality of staple dishes to offer them straight - bangers and mash are lovely, as is the lemon-fresh risotto with herb roast tomatoes and sugar snap peas. Puddings are reassuring: banana, toffee and pecan crumble is served with custard and the cappuccino crème brûlée is as fancy as it gets. A great cheap eat at any time, but perfect for a lazy midweek brunch.

webTitle: Russian cinema fears loss of prop

fields.headline: Russian cinema fears loss of prop
fields.standfirst: Russia: special report
fields.trailText: Russia's film-making community is in uproar over President Vladimir Putin's decision to abolish the film ministry - a move they claim will cripple the struggling industry.
fields.body:
Russia's film-making community is in uproar over President Vladimir Putin's decision to abolish the film ministry - a move they claim will cripple the struggling industry.

Leading film directors this week held an emergency meeting to protest that Russia's cinema tradition would not survive without the support of the powerful state committee for cinematography (Goskino) to lobby for it.

As part of a government streamlining drive ordered by Mr Putin this week, Goskino is to be swallowed up by the ministry of culture. "Everything will go to pieces, there will be a total collapse," Sergei Lazaruk, Goskino's deputy chairman, warned yesterday.

The head of Russia's independent film studio, Mosfilm, was also adamant that the decision would have dire consequences. "The abolition of this ministry just when Russia's film industry is beginning to come back to life can only be interpreted as a deliberate attempt to destroy the country's cinema," he said.

Russia's most famous and politically influential director, Nikita Mikhalkov - who made the Oscar-winning Burnt by the Sun - is to lead a group of prominent film industry figures to appeal to Mr Putin next week, in an attempt to get him to rethink.

Protesters are worried that without the expertise concentrated in the walls of Goskino, bureaucracy will intensify and the quality of Russia's films will drop. There is also concern that the modest profits the industry has recently begun to make will be siphoned off to subsidise other cultural projects.

"Five years ago when Russian film was destitute and half dead, no one paid any attention to Goskino," Mr Mikhalkov said. The government had noticed it only because "the industry has started to be profitable," he said.

No independent-minded film makers would have campaigned for the preservation of Goskino 20 years ago. The organisation has its roots in a 1919 decree by Lenin, ordering the film industry to be harnessed to the state's crusade for ideological enlightenment.

In the Soviet era, Goskino's remit was to "strengthen the role of cinema in the building of communism" and to "help in the active promotion of Marxist-Leninist views among the Soviet people". Censors in the script-reading room of Goskino's Moscow headquarters spent all day scanning new texts for ideological suitability.

The organisation was disbanded in 1991, but after several months of chaos film-makers decided they needed a central coordinating body and Goskino was resurrected to allocate government subsidies and to organise film distribution. It has worked since then in an administrative support capacity, championing the interests of film-makers.

After a barren stretch, the film industry is beginning to see a revival. Domestic enthusiasm for cinema is growing; in the mid-1990s, 97% of Russians did not visit the cinema even once a year. Last year, 35% ventured out to the cinema at least once.

In last year's budget, the government allocated £10.5m to the film business.

webTitle: Retired Healy still raking it in

fields.headline: Retired Healy still raking it in
fields.standfirst: wisden.com's Friday column reveals this week how Ian Healy is still raking in the money, explains why the Surrey team are abandoning their Vauxhall Vectras in Canterbury and reports on cricket's "Do of the Week" (a curry and beers affair in north London)
fields.trailText: Healy's consolation prize: about 60 grand
fields.body:
Healy's consolation prize: about 60 grand

Seven months after his retirement from the game, Ian Healy is still being paid a handsome retainer by the Australian Cricket Board. Only at the end of next month will the great wicketkeeper come to the end of his last 12-month contract. The ACB does not disclose figures for individuals, which are based on secret player rankings, but Healy's "base retainer" as a senior player not required for one-day duties is likely to have been around the £50,000 mark.

Yet Healy was picked for only the first four of Australia's 13 Tests in the 1999-2000 contract period, scoring 30 runs at an average of six, and taking six catches, in three Tests in Sri Lanka and the one-off in Zimbabwe. He arrived home last October to find himself forced into immediate retirement, having been denied his wish to bow out with a flourish in front of his home crowd in Brisbane in the first Test against Pakistan.

As well as the retainer, Healy should have earned an additional £15-20,000 or so in match fees, tour fees and his share of prize money.

The ACB says that it was "comfortable" about meeting contractual commitments to Healy for the year now coming to a close, and has no regrets about awarding him that deal. Yet the two principal criteria for selecting Healy - who had just had a miserable tour of the West Indies - and the other 24 players given 1999-2000 contracts were "the form of the players, and their likelihood of Australian selection over the next 12 months".

Surrey let the coach take the strain

This weekend's Benson & Hedges Cup semi-finals presented Surrey's all-star team with a nightmarish prospect: a Bank Holiday Friday-night drive from Canterbury to Cardiff, which could take four to six hours. In a fixture list that is jammed solid, the big game against Glamorgan at 10.45am tomorrow comes straight after the Championship match against Kent scheduled to finish at 6.30pm today.

The solution? The club has laid on a "top-of-the-range" coach to ferry the team in comfort all the way from Canterbury to Cardiff. The sponsored cars - in which the players invariably travel - will be abandoned at Canterbury. Surrey's spokesman, Toby Codrington, says: "At least the guys can kip on the way to and from Wales."

The players will be magically reunited with their vehicles when they emerge blinking at The Oval after the coach ride back from the semi-final - the team's Vauxhall Vectras and Omegas will be retrieved from Canterbury by club stewards, and driven back to London. Bank-holiday drivers on the M2 will have a surprise as they spot vehicles emblazoned with the Surrey crest and sponsors' logos and wonder why there aren't any recognisable faces behind the wheel.

England's other Lord's debutant

Chris Schofield wasn't the only England debutant at Lord's. After 25 years on the county circuit, Hampshire scorer Vic Isaacs was finally given a Test. It was almost worth the wait: he found himself recording England biggest's victory, statistically speaking, since 1974.

England's scorer for the match would normally have been MCC's David Kendix, but he stood down in a special gesture to mark Isaacs' silver anniversary. The ECB was also fulfilling a promise made several years ago to the Association of County Cricket Scorers that, in seasons featuring two Tests at Lord's, a county scorer would be called up for one of them.

This concession was intended to mollify the county men, who were furious that Malcolm Ashton - rather than one of their number - had been appointed England's official scorer on tour. Isaacs, who founded the association, had led the protests; a couple of his colleagues even talked of strike action.

This week Isaacs, 55, the longest-serving scorer on the circuit, was more relaxed: "I've always wanted, before I finally retire, to do at least one Test, preferably at Lord's," he said. "I wasn't a bit nervous, but there was a little bit of adrenaline flowing on the first day. The atmosphere was different, and I felt very important. And I have a 100 per cent England record!"

After the game he nipped round to the England dressing-room, "congratulated the boys" and joined in the victory celebrations. "The whole match was a super experience, " he concluded, "though it would have been nice to have some sort of medallion, certificate or something - all I have is a Cornhill tie. Scorers are given very scant recognition."

Thorpe finds some form

Graham Thorpe's omission from the England side for Lord's had one advantage: he was able to take part in a long-planned golf day organised by his benefit fund (inquiries: call 0207 267 4774). While England scythed through Zimbabwe on the first day of the Test, Thorpe was joined by other well-known sports figures at the Arden course in Warwickshire, scene of this year's English Open.

Among those teeing off were Ron Atkinson, football manager turned ITV pundit, and Eddie "The Eagle" Edwards. Victory went to a team led by Carl Llewellyn, the jockey who has won two Grand Nationals. But Thorpe, a handy golfer, landed the "nearest the pin" prize. The day must have taken his mind briefly off his poor start to the season. Like so many beneficiaries before him, Thorpe has found form deserting him at just the wrong moment.

Cricket Do of the Week (the first in an occasional series)

Occasion: the launch of Simon Hughes' Yakking Around the World (Simon & Schuster, £12.99, June 5), billed as a tale of "sun, seam and sex".
Format: unusual. "Curry and beers" at a Bangladeshi restaurant near Lord's, on the evening of the second day of the Test.
Attendance: 30, including Hughes' Channel 4 colleague Barry Richards, Angus Fraser, Derek Pringle and Vic Marks; Hughes proved a notably good host.
Conspicuously absent: Hughes' Daily Telegraph colleague Michael Henderson, who dismissed him as an "execrable writer" on radio in 1995. Hughes responded by letting down one of the tyres of Henderson's car.
Main revelation in book: Hughes' highly original type of cricket average. As he wanders across the globe, playing for 41 different teams in four continents, he gives each city a mark out of ten for its people, its beaches and the standard of its cricket. Add these three together, multiply by the number of (romantic) catches he made in each place, and you have its overall rating in his scheme of things. Sydney and Auckland tie in second place, with London top on 43 - but only after Hughes has cheated, substituting parks (8 out of ten) for beaches. As the author conceded at his dinner, his ratings system doesn't really work - except as a dig at those players whose books finish with page upon page of conventional statistics.

Charles de Lisle is the author, with Christopher Martin-Jenkins, of An Australian Summer: The Story of the 1998/9 Ashes Series (Faber). He is also a former deputy editor of The Daily Telegraph's Peterborough column. He can be contacted at cdelisle@compuserve.com

"I wasn't a bit nervous, but there was a little bit of adrenaline flowing on the first day. The atmosphere was different, and I felt very important. And I have a 100 per cent England record!" After the game he nipped round to the England dressing-room, "congratulated the boys" and joined in the victory celebrations. "The whole match was a super experience, " he concluded, "though it would have been nice to have some sort of medallion, certificate or something - all I have is a Cornhill tie. Scorers are given very scant recognition." Thorpe finds some form Graham Thorpe's omission from the England side for Lord's had one advantage: he was able to take part in a long-planned golf day organised by his benefit fund (inquiries: call 0207 267 4774). While England scythed through Zimbabwe on the first day of the Test, Thorpe was joined by other well-known sports figures at the Arden course in Warwickshire, scene of this year's English Open. Among those teeing off were Ron Atkinson, football manager turned ITV pundit, and Eddie "The Eagle" Edwards. Victory went to a team led by Carl Llewellyn, the jockey who has won two Grand Nationals. But Thorpe, a handy golfer, landed the "nearest the pin" prize. The day must have taken his mind briefly off his poor start to the season. Like so many beneficiaries before him, Thorpe has found form deserting him at just the wrong moment. Cricket Do of the Week (the first in an occasional series) Occasion: the launch of Simon Hughes' Yakking Around the World (Simon & Schuster, £12.99, June 5), billed as a tale of "sun, seam and sex". Format: unusual. "Curry and beers" at a Bangladeshi restaurant near Lord's, on the evening of the second day of the Test. Attendance: 30, including Hughes' Channel 4 colleague Barry Richards, Angus Fraser, Derek Pringle and Vic Marks; Hughes proved a notably good host. Conspicuously absent: Hughes' Daily Telegraph colleague Michael Henderson, who dismissed him as an "execrable writer" on radio in 1995. Hughes responded by letting down one of the tyres of Henderson's car. Main revelation in book: Hughes' highly original type of cricket average. As he wanders across the globe, playing for 41 different teams in four continents, he gives each city a mark out of ten for its people, its beaches and the standard of its cricket. Add these three together, multiply by the number of (romantic) catches he made in each place, and you have its overall rating in his scheme of things. Sydney and Auckland tie in second place, with London top on 43 - but only after Hughes has cheated, substituting parks (8 out of ten) for beaches. As the author conceded at his dinner, his ratings system doesn't really work - except as a dig at those players whose books finish with page upon page of conventional statistics. Charles de Lisle is the author, with Christopher Martin-Jenkins, of An Australian Summer: The Story of the 1998/9 Ashes Series (Faber). He is also a former deputy editor of The Daily Telegraph's Peterborough column. webTitle: Mission: Impossible 2 blasts into US box office

fields.headline: Mission: Impossible 2 blasts into US box office
fields.trailText: Tom Cruise's Mission: Impossible 2 defied lukewarm reviews and negative rumours about its script and took an impressive $12.5m on its opening day in the US
fields.body:
Tom Cruise's Mission: Impossible 2 defied lukewarm reviews and negative rumours about its script (see Thursday's in brief story), and took an impressive $12.5m on its opening day in the US.

"We're ecstatic," Paramount Pictures president of distribution Wayne Lewellen said. "Anytime you exceed the original film's opening day by 50%, it's great."

With such a strong start at the box office, the Tom Cruise vehicle is on its way to become one of the top five films to reach $100m in the fewest days.

 Mission: Impossible 2 opens in the UK on July 7

webTitle: Ashley Judd faces real-life legal jeopardy

fields.headline: Ashley Judd faces real-life legal jeopardy
fields.trailText: In a reversal of the usual pattern of celebrities suing journalists for slander, actress Ashley Judd is being sued by a Kentucky-based freelance journalist, Larry Birkhead
fields.body:
In a reversal of the usual pattern of celebrities suing journalists for slander, actress Ashley Judd is facing a lawsuit from a Kentucky-based freelance journalist, Larry Birkhead, who alleges that the 32-year-old actress 'dissed him' on the TV show Entertainment Tonight.

Last August, Birkhead interviewed Judd's mom, Naomi, about her stance on the proliferation of violence and sex in Hollywood. In an article that appeared in USA Today, Birkhead quoted Naomi as saying she didn't want Ashley to make the 1996 TV movie Norma Jean and Marilyn, about the life of Marilyn Monroe. "Pop and I wouldn't watch it," said the Judd matriarch.

Then Birkhead asked about Double Jeopardy, in which Judd plays a revenge-minded woman wrongly jailed for the murder of her husband, and, according to his article, Naomi refused to comment.

Judd subsequently appeared on Entertainment Tonight, where she said the article was a "complete fabrication and her mother gave her total enthusiastic response to the film."

Birkhead is seeking punitive and compensatory damages from Judd, along with Entertainment Tonight, as he has effectively been accused of lying.

A spokesman for Judd said: "We're very aware that there is a lawsuit, but we have no further information."

webTitle: Black barrister to fight Grant seat

fields.headline: Black barrister to fight Grant seat
fields.standfirst:
Quiz: could you be an MP?
Tottenham Labour party picks its candidate for MP
fields.trailText: A high-flying barrister favoured by Millbank was selected last night as the Labour candidate to fight next month's Tottenham by-election caused by the death of Bernie Grant.
fields.body:
A high-flying barrister favoured by Millbank was selected last night as the Labour candidate to fight next month's Tottenham by-election caused by the death of Bernie Grant.

David Lammy, 27, in 1996 the first black Briton to study at Harvard, won the nomination with 59.1% of the vote.

His victory ensures that Tottenham, a safe Labour seat which is one of the most multi-cultural constituencies in Britain, will continue to be represented by a black MP. Mr Grant, who died in March, held the seat for 13 years.

Mr Lammy said after his victory that he was "delighted and a bit overwhelmed". The barrister, who will have to give up his seat on the Greater London assembly if he wins the Tottenham byelection on June 22, added: "I feel privileged to have been chosen as Labour's candidate by the members of Tottenham Labour Party."

His success will delight Millbank, which had quietly endorsed Mr Lammy over his nearest rival, Sharon Grant, the widow of the late MP. Mrs Grant, 47, is a leftwinger who would not have shied away from confronting Millbank.

Mr Lammy's success was welcomed by some black activists, who felt that Tottenham should continue to be represented by a black MP. Nearly half of the constituency's population come from ethnic minority communities.

But Mr Lammy said last night the contest was not about race. He said: "It was not about black and white. It was about having an authentic representative for the people of Tottenham. I was born and raised here and that helped me to win support."

One black activist said that she was disappointed by Mr Lammy's victory because she felt that Mrs Grant, who is white, would have been better placed to continue her husband's work. Linda Bellos, the former leader of Lambeth council and a former vice-chair of Labour's black section, said: "The legacy of Bernie Grant is not going to be upheld. He represents a completely different type of politician."

However, Mrs Grant en dorsed Mr Lammy. She said: "I am disappointed. But the Labour Party is a democratic party. I congratulate David. I think he will carry on Bernie's legacy."

Mr Lammy's victory will provide encouragement to Millbank that a Blairite candidate should win so emphatically in a "heartland" area where many party activists are dismayed by the slow pace of reform.

If Mr Lammy wins the byelection his seat on the GLA will be taken by Jeanette Arnold, who is also black.

Mr Lammy's victory was welcomed by his supporters. Ray Ankrah, a local management accountant, said: "David represents the future. He will be the perfect role model for young black people in Tottenham."

Mr Lammy studied law at London University, qualifying as the youngest barrister in 1994. He then studied for a Masters at Harvard.
