webTitle: Victims of crime to get chance to declare suffering

fields.headline: Victims of crime to get chance to declare suffering
fields.standfirst:
Home Office
Victim Support
US study on victim impact statements
fields.trailText: Victims of crime will be able to make personal  statements about how they have suffered mentally and  physically under a Home Office scheme to be  launched today.
fields.body:
Victims of crime will be able to make personal statements about how they have suffered mentally and physically under a Home Office scheme to be launched today.

Relatives of people who have been murdered and the parents of child victims will have the opportunity to put on record the anguish they have felt under the victim personal statement scheme, which will be announced by the home secretary, Jack Straw.

The government hopes that the personal statements, which will be available to the courts, will give victims of crime a greater voice in the criminal justice system.

A spokeswoman for the Home Office said last night: "It will give the victims and their families a chance to say how the crime has affected them personally, whether it be physically, emotionally, psychologically or financially."

Under the scheme, which will be operating in England and Wales from early next year, police will ask victims whether they want to make a personal statement at the same time as they take witness statements.

If a victim declines the opportunity, he or she will be able to change their mind and make a statement at a later date.

Victims will also be able to amend the statement if they suffer long-term effects from the crime.

Although sentencing will be a matter for judges and magistrates, the statements will be available to defence and prosecution teams as well as other agencies involved in the case.

The Home Office said people who ran small businesses would also be able to make statements about how they had suffered financially.

Dame Helen Reeve, chief executive of Victim Support, welcomed the scheme. "For the first time victims will be able to communicate directly with all the people dealing with their case," she said.

"They will be able to have their own interests considered by asking for the compensation, support, or protection they need."

The scheme falls short of "impact statements" made by victims of crime in the United States, where they can request specific sentences. It follows various pilot studies and consultation with the court service, police, the Magistrates Association and the Lord Chancellor's Department.

webTitle: Dando murder suspect held after raid on flat close to TV presenter's home

fields.headline: Dando murder suspect held after raid on flat close to TV presenter's home
fields.standfirst: More about the Dando case
fields.trailText: Detectives investigating Jill Dando's murder were questioning a suspect last night following the arrest of a 36-year-old man at his south London home, less than half a mile from where the television presenter was shot dead.
fields.body:
Detectives investigating Jill Dando's murder were questioning a suspect last night following the arrest of a 36-year-old man at his south London home, less than half a mile from where the television presenter was shot dead.

Sources described the arrest as a "highly significant" development in an inquiry which began when Ms Dando was shot in the side of the head on the doorstep of her home in Gowan Avenue, Fulham, south-west London, 13 months ago.

Scotland Yard refused to elaborate on the identity of the man being held. But neighbours named him as Barry Bulsara.

Mr Bulsara lives alone in a raised ground-floor housing association flat in Crookham Road, Fulham, barely five minutes walk from Ms Dando's home.

Four officers went to his flat at 6.30am yesterday and arrested him without a struggle.

Sensitivity about the case is so acute that the police refused to elaborate on a bald statement issued 90 minutes after unarmed officers from the murder squad went to the flat and took him for questioning at Hammersmith police station.

It said: "Officers investigating the murder of Jill Dando have this morning arrested a man on suspicion of murder. He was arrested at about 6.30am and taken to a police station in London where he remains in custody."

Neighbours said Mr Bulsara lived alone, after the end of his marriage to a Japanese woman. He did not work due to ill health. He told neighbours that he had served in the Territorial Army.

He had also told friends that Freddie Mercury, the late singer with the group Queen, was his cousin.

Freddie Mercury's real surname was Bulsara.

One friend, Emiko Okoturo, 29, said Mr Bulsara had told him that he had information about Ms Dando's killer.

A month ago Mr Bulsara complained to Mr Okoturo that the police had raided his flat, and a flat owned by his mother in Acton, west London.

"He told me they had searched the premises and he was really upset about it," said Mr Okoturo, a student.

Last night, forensic experts were conducting a finger-tip search of Mr Bulsara's flat, packing dozens of crates to be taken away for examination.

Police sources stressed the suspect had not been arrested before.

However, Mr Bulsara's neighbours were adamant he had been seen by detectives about a month ago. Louise Cole, 24, a model who lives in a first-floor flat directly opposite Mr Bulsara, said several police officers were spotted outside his flat three weeks ago.

Police confirmed that the information which led to the arrest was given to the police several weeks ago - before the BBC television Crimewatch programme appeal to mark the first anniversary of her death on April 26 - but could not be acted on immediately.

"Information and evidence are very different things," said a source. "We couldn't take the call and run out to make an arrest.

"We've worked very hard. The arrest came after a long, considered process. The officers are extremely worried about saying anything that will prejudice the inquiry at this stage."

Under the police and criminal evidence act, any suspect can be held for an initial period of 24-hours. If Mr Campbell wants to continue questioning beyond that, he will need to ask from a 12-hour extension from a superintendent or a magistrate.

Further extensions can be granted up to a total of 96 hours.

News of the arrest was kept from Ms Dando's relatives and friends until after the man was in custody.

Before yesterday, police had arrested three people in connection with the murder. On previous occasions, sources stressed the arrests were not significant. This is the first time a man has been arrested and questioned on suspicion of murder.

4,000 letters, 10,000 calls, 13,000 emails - and now one Dando suspect

There have been a number of false dawns, numerous blind alleys and myriad theories. So why was yesterday morning's arrest being taken so seriously? There are few genuine clues.

One, perhaps, is more significant than the others.

Detective Chief Inspector Hamish Campbell, the man leading the Jill Dando murder hunt, is not an excitable sort of chap.

But, according to his colleagues, he was excited yesterday. Scotland Yard sources said he had reason to be. Translated into plain English, this is police-speak for: "Hamish might have got his man."

Few murder inquiries in recent memory have put as much pressure on a detective or his squad. Ch Insp Campbell is, however, a methodical and patient officer who has not allowed the strain to deflect him from a sincere belief that the murder on April 26 last year could be solved. The 13-month-old inquiry has had several phases, which have ultimately taken him full circle.

Initial theories were that Ms Dando, 37, was targeted by a stalker or obsessive. A man carrying a mobile phone was seen loitering in Gowan Avenue just before she died, and witnesses remembered seeing someone running away from the scene shortly after Ms Dando screamed. This prime suspect has never been identified and as days passed, the picture of what happened in the road that morning became increasingly blurred. A Range Rover car was spotted parked in Gowan Avenue, and a similar car was seen speeding from the area. Other witnesses spoke of a sweating man at a bus stop. Despite repeated appeals, some of the men and women who were in Gowan Avenue that morning - they couldn't all have been involved in the murder - did not come forward to be eliminated as suspects.

"There were 23 sightings, yet none of these men have come forward!" Ch Insp Campbell told the Guardian in exasperation. "Why not? As I sit here in the middle of this storm, I think that is pretty extraordinary."

Ms Dando's involvement in the Crimewatch programme could not be dismissed as a possible motive, though Ch Insp Campbell was never happy with that thesis. The war in Kosovo and the possibility that Ms Dando might have been killed in a revenge assassination for the Nato bombing of a Serbian television station, was also floated in the media. Faced with a mass of conflicting evidence, no eyewitnesses, no motive and no strong leads, Ch Insp Campbell had to, in effect, start the whole inquiry from scratch, ruling nothing in, ruling nothing out.

With new theories from unnamed and apparently ill-informed sources exploding around him all the time, he set his 45-strong murder squad on a huge "fishing expedition" for potential clues. During deadpan press conferences, he told the same story, apologising to reporters for not offering them anything more exciting or specific. He said his team was working on two theories: that Ms Dando was targeted by an obsessive or a contract killer, probably working with a small gang.

They drew up a list of 400 suspects, which included men with a history of violence and mental illness. Among them were 40 or 50 known obsessives. They took more than 1,000 statements and saw 3,000 people. Officers gutted Ms Dando's filofax, which had the names of 486 friends, and scoured through 4,000 letters and messages sent to the incident room. They also read the 13,700 emails sent to the BBC. They asked mobile phone companies to try to identify the 10,000 calls made in west London on the morning she died. Newspapers swelled the reward for information leading to an arrest to £250,000. Psychological profiles were commissioned, gun experts from the UK, America and Russia tried and failed to identify the curious indentations - possibly made by a drawing pin - on the cartridge shell found at the scene. It was fired, experts said, from a semi-automatic 9mm pistol, but they could not tell the manufacturer.

By process of careful elimination, Ch Insp Campbell decided earlier this year that the killer was most likely a loner, not a contract killer, and that the man's obsession may have been triggered to murderous intent by the publicity surrounding Ms Dando's engagement to Alan Farthing, a gynaecologist. His hunch was supported by evidence that Ms Dando was being stalked, albeit surreptitiously, in the months before she died.

A man calling himself James Dando and claiming to be the presenter's brother, rang the gas, electricity and water companies in February last year to try to have her bills transferred into his name. Another man, who was found and ruled out of the inquiry, used the internet service 192.com to pinpoint exactly where Ms Dando lived; another caller to British Telecom seemed to have her ex-directory telephone number.

Underworld

There were other pointers. Despite the huge reward, nobody came forward from the underworld claiming knowledge of the killer. Ch Insp Campbell told the Guardian his officers had been laughed at by villains they had interviewed about the murder. "The major criminals all say the same thing: 'Why would we want to do that? She was a newscaster who did holiday programmes. So why her?'"

Three men have been arrested in the course of the investigation, but they were released quickly and Scotland Yard sources quietly insisted that the developments were not significant. Ch Insp Campbell braced himself for scepticism, even derision, at the lack of progress on the anniversary of Ms Dando's death, but there was very little carping in the media. Ch Insp Campbell was certain that the killer would watch the Crimewatch appeal to mark the occasion, and might even give himself up. Failing that, he hoped that someone who knew the killer might come forward.

"Someone knows who he is," said a source. "They might not realise it, but they do. We need a bit of luck."

They got it. Several weeks ago a fresh piece of information about a man whom they had not interviewed before was given to the murder squad, which is based in Kensington.

A surveillance operation started which culminated at 6.30 yesterday morning, when officers raided the suspect's home and arrested him.

Ch Insp Campbell does not give his feelings away cheaply.

It remains to be seen if he really does have something to smile about.

High-flying detective with the worst job in British policing

The man in charge of one of the most high profile murder investigations ever faced by Scotland Yard, Detective Chief Inspector Hamish Campbell, has had everyone from the commissioner of the Metropolitan Police to the millions of Crimewatch viewers clamouring for a result.

Until yesterday colleagues of all ranks agreed he had the worst job in British policing. But Ch Insp Campbell knows all about pressure for success, and while others suggested that the chances of catching Jill Dando's killer were fading, he never allowed that thought to pervade his attitude or that of his 45-strong team of detectives.

An approachable man of Scottish descent and highly regarded by his senior officers, Ch Insp Campbell joined the police in 1974. A 21-year career in CID has included stints at the Yard's anti-terrorist branch and the ultra-secret criminal intelligence unit.

Before the Dando investigation he was in charge of two other particularly baffling cases on his west London patch: the disappearance of Argentinian Gracia Morton in Kensington in November 1997 and the murder of Macedonian schoolgirl Katrina Koneva in Hammersmith in May of the same year.

He was given the Dando case four months after being promoted to the Yard's elite group of special investigating officers, who receive special training to run and control major cases.

Credited by his colleagues as stubborn but with lots of stamina (he has cycled to Italy for charity), once a week he leaves his office in a building next to Kensington police station to work off his frustration on the judo mats.

Colleagues describe him as a family man, but he has had little time to spend at home in the past 13 months, during which he has put in 13-hour days in the hunt for the television presenter's killer.

Despite repeated appeals, some of the men and women who were in Gowan Avenue that morning - they couldn't all have been involved in the murder - did not come forward to be eliminated as suspects. "There were 23 sightings, yet none of these men have come forward!" Ch Insp Campbell told the Guardian in exasperation. "Why not? As I sit here in the middle of this storm, I think that is pretty extraordinary." Ms Dando's involvement in the Crimewatch programme could not be dismissed as a possible motive, though Ch Insp Campbell was never happy with that thesis. The war in Kosovo and the possibility that Ms Dando might have been killed in a revenge assassination for the Nato bombing of a Serbian television station, was also floated in the media. Faced with a mass of conflicting evidence, no eyewitnesses, no motive and no strong leads, Ch Insp Campbell had to, in effect, start the whole inquiry from scratch, ruling nothing in, ruling nothing out. With new theories from unnamed and apparently ill-informed sources exploding around him all the time, he set his 45-strong murder squad on a huge "fishing expedition" for potential clues. During deadpan press conferences, he told the same story, apologising to reporters for not offering them anything more exciting or specific. He said his team was working on two theories: that Ms Dando was targeted by an obsessive or a contract killer, probably working with a small gang. They drew up a list of 400 suspects, which included men with a history of violence and mental illness. Among them were 40 or 50 known obsessives. They took more than 1,000 statements and saw 3,000 people. Officers gutted Ms Dando's filofax, which had the names of 486 friends, and scoured through 4,000 letters and messages sent to the incident room. They also read the 13,700 emails sent to the BBC. They asked mobile phone companies to try to identify the 10,000 calls made in west London on the morning she died. Newspapers swelled the reward for information leading to an arrest to £250,000. Psychological profiles were commissioned, gun experts from the UK, America and Russia tried and failed to identify the curious indentations - possibly made by a drawing pin - on the cartridge shell found at the scene. It was fired, experts said, from a semi-automatic 9mm pistol, but they could not tell the manufacturer. By process of careful elimination, Ch Insp Campbell decided earlier this year that the killer was most likely a loner, not a contract killer, and that the man's obsession may have been triggered to murderous intent by the publicity surrounding Ms Dando's engagement to Alan Farthing, a gynaecologist. His hunch was supported by evidence that Ms Dando was being stalked, albeit surreptitiously, in the months before she died. A man calling himself James Dando and claiming to be the presenter's brother, rang the gas, electricity and water companies in February last year to try to have her bills transferred into his name. Another man, who was found and ruled out of the inquiry, used the internet service 192.com to pinpoint exactly where Ms Dando lived; another caller to British Telecom seemed to have her ex-directory telephone number. Underworld There were other pointers. Despite the huge reward, nobody came forward from the underworld claiming knowledge of the killer. Ch Insp Campbell told the Guardian his officers had been laughed at by villains they had interviewed about the murder. "The major criminals all say the same thing: 'Why would we want to do that? She was a newscaster who did holiday programmes. So why her?'" Three men have been arrested in the course of the investigation, but they were released quickly and Scotland Yard sources quietly insisted that the developments were not significant. Ch Insp Campbell braced himself for scepticism, even derision, at the lack of progress on the anniversary of Ms Dando's death, but there was very little carping in the media. Ch Insp Campbell was certain that the killer would watch the Crimewatch appeal to mark the occasion, and might even give himself up. Failing that, he hoped that someone who knew the killer might come forward. "Someone knows who he is," said a source. "They might not realise it, but they do. We need a bit of luck." They got it. Several weeks ago a fresh piece of information about a man whom they had not interviewed before was given to the murder squad, which is based in Kensington. A surveillance operation started which culminated at 6.30 yesterday morning, when officers raided the suspect's home and arrested him. Ch Insp Campbell does not give his feelings away cheaply. It remains to be seen if he really does have something to smile about. High-flying detective with the worst job in British policing The man in charge of one of the most high profile murder investigations ever faced by Scotland Yard, Detective Chief Inspector Hamish Campbell, has had everyone from the commissioner of the Metropolitan Police to the millions of Crimewatch viewers clamouring for a result. Until yesterday colleagues of all ranks agreed he had the worst job in British policing. But Ch Insp Campbell knows all about pressure for success, and while others suggested that the chances of catching Jill Dando's killer were fading, he never allowed that thought to pervade his attitude or that of his 45-strong team of detectives. An approachable man of Scottish descent and highly regarded by his senior officers, Ch Insp Campbell joined the police in 1974. A 21-year career in CID has included stints at the Yard's anti-terrorist branch and the ultra-secret criminal intelligence unit. Before the Dando investigation he was in charge of two other particularly baffling cases on his west London patch: the disappearance of Argentinian Gracia Morton in Kensington in November 1997 and the murder of Macedonian schoolgirl Katrina Koneva in Hammersmith in May of the same year. He was given the Dando case four months after being promoted to the Yard's elite group of special investigating officers, who receive special training to run and control major cases. Credited by his colleagues as stubborn but with lots of stamina (he has cycled to Italy for charity), once a week he leaves his office in a building next to Kensington police station to work off his frustration on the judo mats. Colleagues describe him as a family man, but he has had little time to spend at home in the past 13 months, during which he has put in 13-hour days in the hunt for the television presenter's killer.

fields.headline: Unfazed ICL still to split
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: ICL, the Fujitsu-owned computer services company, plans to press ahead with two spin-offs and a stock market flotation of its own later in the year despite continuing volatility among hi-tech stocks
fields.body:
ICL, the Fujitsu-owned computer services company, plans to press ahead with two spin-offs and a stock market flotation of its own later in the year despite continuing volatility among hi-tech stocks.

Chief executive Keith Todd said yesterday that he was confident that interest among institutional investors would remain strong. "There's inevitably going to be some bad weather around but I don't think it will knock us off course," he said.

"I'm glad this correction has happened now and I think we should not be surprised that there is this amount of turbulence in a period of such dramatic change. I do not think substantive businesses will be materially affected by it."

ICL has consistently said it plans to relist by the end of 2000 and is working closely with UBS Warburg to reposition itself as an e-business services company. Analysts believe it could command a valuation of around £5bn at flotation.

Mr Todd said plans to list ICL's e-learning division Knowledge Pool in London and its Nordic group, ICL Invia, in Helsinki over the summer remain unchanged.

In the year to March 31 it recorded an operating loss of £67.9m compared to an operating profit of £36m the previous year. Turnover remained relatively flat, climbing £39m to £2.77bn although e-business revenues doubled to £179m. The disposal of ICL's Finnish operation for £141m allowed the group to report a pre-tax profit of £96.1m.

webTitle: Two cry off, but Filmgroup aims to float on regardless

fields.headline: Two cry off, but Filmgroup aims to float on regardless
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Volatile market conditions put paid to the flotation ambitions of two more hi-tech companies yesterday when LetsBuyIt.com and Vodafone Airtouch's Australasian unit each postponed plans for stock market listings.
fields.body:
Volatile market conditions put paid to the flotation ambitions of two more hi-tech companies yesterday when LetsBuyIt.com and Vodafone Airtouch's Australasian unit each postponed plans for stock market listings.

However, video-on-demand business Filmgroup was one company which said it was determined to press ahead with its £177m flotation despite last week's decision by its rival, Yes Television, to abandon its plans.

Several other fledgling firms are understood to be reassessing flotation plans after heavy selling of hi-tech shares on the Nasdaq and London markets at the start of the week.

London-based LetsBuyIt said yesterday that it was postponing its float on the Neuer Markt because it felt it would not have obtained a correct evaluation due to market conditions. Executives at the company have spent the last few days insisting that volatility would not upset its plans and that its shares would start trading on June 7.

LetsBuyIt.com's chief executive, Martin Coles, said the company had decided to postpone its float indefinitely after consulting bankers, Robertson Stephens International. "We have been watching the market carefully and have taken a pragmatic decision," he said.

Mr Coles said LetsBuyIt had a strong cash position with around €30m (£18m) in the bank and had the continued support of its shareholders. It would scale back television advertising and seek further funds through a private placement towards the end of the summer.

Vodafone Pacific cited the same reason when announcing that its plans to raise A$2bn to A$3bn (£777m-£1.5bn) through a listing on the Australia stock exchange had been shelved.

Vodafone said it "remains committed to pursuing an initial public offering, and will continue to monitor market conditions in order to assess the optimal timing for the transaction".

Shares in Vodafone still managed to rise 9% to 287p on continued speculation that France Telecom would shortly launch a bid of around £30m for Orange, the mobile operator Vodafone is planning to offload.

Filmgroup's chief executive, Simon Franks, said the business had been well received in roadshows to potential investors.

"People are seeing us," he said. "Investors are still looking for good companies". He said there was no chance of lowering the offer price which has already seen the company's value reduced from up to £300m.

fields.headline: Ministers rebel over English assemblies
fields.standfirst: Devolution in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is facing a ministerial revolt in Labour's heartlands over Downing Street's continued resistance to a network of English regional assemblies to match devolution in Scotland, Wales and London.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is facing a ministerial revolt in Labour's heartlands over Downing Street's continued resistance to a network of English regional assemblies to match devolution in Scotland, Wales and London.

With members of the party's national policy forum pressing for some commitment from the party in the next election manifesto, ministers are openly questioning No 10's insistence that there is little demand for regional government.

In the prime minister's absence at question time this week, his deputy, John Prescott, again made plain his backing for regional government, albeit in coded form.

The latest to signal support for a campaign centred in Mr Blair's own base in the north east, is Hilary Armstrong, the local government minister and Blair constituency neighbour in Co Durham.

As the region closest to Scotland the north east has long been keenest to match its regional perks.

"What we will have to do is bring forward enabling legislation to enable referendumns to take place. We are doing that at the moment. We will have a referendum," Ms Armstrong said this week.

But Mr Blair is feeling bruised over his experience so far with devolution. "The feeling in No 10 is that we need this like a hole in the head," said one official. Party HQ in Millbank shares the view that Brirtain is now suffering voting fatigue where electors are reluctant to turn out for existing forms of local government.

But the junior environment minister, and MP for Sunderland South, Chris Mullin - who recently broke ranks by calling for a boycott of Barclays Bank in protest at rural branch closures - even called this week for the devolution referendum in the north east to coincide with the next general election to boost voter turn-out.

Joyce Quin, junior agriculture minister and a neighbouring Tyneside MP, has said she would be very disappointed if the government stalled on English devolution after transferring powers to Edinburgh and Cardiff.

Pressed by the Newcastle Central MP, Jim Cousins, in the Commons, Mr Prescott said: "We will be looking at what we put in the manifesto and I will be arguing for re gional government." Pressure on Downing Street intensified yesterday when campaigners for an assembly in the north east released the findings of a survey showing that 19 MPs in the region, including a government whip, two ministers and two former ministers, backed regional government.

Ten north east MPs did not reply to the survey - including Tony Blair, Hilary Armstrong, the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers and the agriculture minister, Nick Brown. Alan Milburn, the health secretary, said he was "preparing a response".

Ms Armstrong told regional government campaigners at a London meeting that the government could introduce legislation to test support in a series of referendums. Millbank calls that "an aspiration, rather than a pledge".

Labour's national policy forum - charged with drawing up the election manifesto - has urged the government to set out the options for regional government in a green paper.

webTitle: The new economy is about to click for Britain

fields.headline: The new economy is about to click for Britain
fields.standfirst:
The hi-tech sector should not be dismissed because of a few conspicuous failures

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: First Boo.com. Then Net Imperative. Who next? With investors losing faith in the hi-tech sector it will not be long before others join the list of dot.com casualties in Britain. For sceptics unable to hide their glee, such moments reinforce their prejudices about the hype surrounding the so-called new economy.
fields.body:
First Boo.com. Then Net Imperative. Who next? With investors losing faith in the hi-tech sector it will not be long before others join the list of dot.com casualties in Britain. For sceptics unable to hide their glee, such moments reinforce their prejudices about the hype surrounding the so-called new economy.

But a few high profile collapses that are probably due to flawed business plans and poor management rather than a systemic crisis should not hide the very real potential benefits of the internet.

In a paper published this week Ben Broadbent and David Walton of Goldman Sachs argue that Britain is already two-thirds of the way towards rebuilding itself as a new economy, boasting greater stability and lower unemployment.

It is still missing the final building block - faster productivity growth - but Broadbent and Walton argue there is plenty of scope for investment in computers to pick up, and that this will facilitate the spread of e-commerce, particularly in business to business, where the real action is taking place.

They think business to business could boost growth and productivity by 0.5% points annually over the next decade, creating a cumulative increase in output of £45bn. Their predictions seem more than just pie in the sky: anecodotal evidence suggests many big established businesses are embracing e-commerce enthusiastically, not always knowing where it will lead.

At a conference on the digital economy this week organised by the Royal Institute of International Affairs, Mark Hunter, chief executive officer of Axon consultancy, said he was working with many FTSE 100 companies to help them adapt their business models to the net, breaking down corporate barriers and redesigning supply chains.

While mocking predictions of sales people becoming irrelevant and large profitable companies being vanquished by unprofitable start-ups, he argued that the net was bringing customers and suppliers closer together - often for mutual benefit. He cited the example of WH Smith - which, instead of a linear supply chain with publishers at one end and newsagents at the other, now had a much more integrated approach.

Other big companies reinventing themselves as clicks and mortar operations included Wal-Mart, which had set up a dot.com competitor for itself, and Unilever, which was becoming a house cleaning company, he said.

Research published today by consul tancy London Economics suggests the same benefits of greater internet use are waiting to be grasped by small and medium sized business, which account for nearly half of Britain's turnover and the working population.

Commissioned by GroupTrade, a new firm planning to use the net to buy goods and services on a pooled basis for smaller businesses, the report estimates the savings from business to business e-commerce could eventually reach as much as £24bn a year, which is equivalent to 3% of national output - although it stresses progress will be gradual.

Of the estimated savings around 30% are accounted for by discounts negotiated by bulk-buying intermediaries, such as GroupTrade, chaired by Adair Turner, the former director general of the CBI.

The remaining 70% come from reducing the time and expense of searching, or dering and accounting for purchases. "These reductions are comprised of savings in search costs, time saved in procurement, reduced errors in ordering and invoicing, intelligent stock management, lower ordering and billing costs and reduced inventory costs," says the report.

Cost savings for firms with between five and 250 employees average £37,000 a year and businesses employing more than 200 could benefit by £600,000 a year.

"These are substantial sums with immediate benefits for a company's bottom line," said Mr Turner.

In competitive markets Turner says he would expect the benefits ultimately to accrue to consumers in the form of lower prices. But the potential rewards in the short term of being a first mover should not be underestimated.

Investors spotted that potential some time ago, pouring millions into speculative hi-tech ventures. Many made costly mistakes, taking a punt on almost anything with a dot.com in its name instead of making sure the company had a sensible business plan first.

Boo.com is a case in point. While its founders had plenty of glamour, they appear to have lacked basic business skills and were trying to sell a product - fashion wear - that has proved difficult to shift on the net. In that case investors' greed got the better of fear. Now, with hi-tech share prices collapsing around the globe, it is the other way around.

Fear is in the driving seat and speculative funding is drying up. But it does not mean there was no substance to the internet goldrush in the first place.

As Sushil Wadhwani of the Bank of England's monetary policy committee told MPs on Tuesday: "Valuations in some sectors have looked a bit racy and you are seeing an inevitable correction, but behind the hype there is a real transformation occurring and we need to focus on that."

webTitle: Short ministry praised for Kosovo aid effort

fields.headline: Short ministry praised for Kosovo aid effort
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Clare Short's international development department played an important role easing the humanitarian crisis in Kosovo but needs to be better prepared in the event of future emergencies, parliament's financial watchdog is expected to report today.
fields.body:
Clare Short's international development department played an important role easing the humanitarian crisis in Kosovo but needs to be better prepared in the event of future emergencies, parliament's financial watchdog is expected to report today.

The national audit office praised the agency for its £110m cash help in tackling the largest and most sudden population movement in Europe since the second world war. "The department has made a major contribution to easing the humanitarian crisis arising from the problems in Kosovo.

"It has worked quickly with a wide range of other organisations to deliver aid on the ground in difficult and dangerous conditions," the audit office says. It says that the department helped to restore power and water supplies and played a leading role in mine survey and clearance - "a crucial task, with the number of casualties from mines and unexploded munitions in Kosovo running at five a day at one point".

However, it points out that it deposited too much cash with the crown agents, a private company which runs the government's emergency logistics management team. The funds exceeded the sums that were needed and balances never fell below £2.7m, money which could have been left in interest-bearing accounts.

The audit office also says that between April and July last year the department used 54 air charters, costing £2.3m, but could not demonstrate whether it was getting the best deal and paying the correct fee.

David Davis, chairman of the Commons public accounts committee, said: "The department's arrangements with contractors left something to be desired. They spent over £2m on air charters but did not do enough to satisfy themselves that they got a good deal."

webTitle: Lib-Lab tribalism 'may cut tactical election voting'

fields.headline: Lib-Lab tribalism 'may cut tactical election voting'
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is today warned that his dream of a new politics centring on Labour-Lib Dem co-operation is in danger of being "squandered" thanks to tribalism and short-term thinking in his party.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is today warned that his dream of a new politics centring on Labour-Lib Dem co-operation is in danger of being "squandered" thanks to tribalism and short-term thinking in his party.

A forceful denunciation of the state of relations between the Liberal Democrats and Labour, written by former advisers closely linked to the leadership of both parties, argues that voters are ahead of politicians in wanting to see a "more adult relationship" between political parties.

Opponents of co-operation are warned that tactical voting delivered both parties significant numbers of seats in the 1997 general election, and that - if the tactical vote does not materialise next time - the Labour majority would plummet to less than 60 even if the Conservatives fail to win a single extra vote.

webTitle: Fall in number of asylum seekers

fields.headline: Fall in number of asylum seekers
fields.standfirst: Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Asylum applications to Britain fell below 6,000 last month for the first time since May 1999 and removed some of the political heat facing the home secretary, Jack Straw, on the issue.
fields.body:
Asylum applications to Britain fell below 6,000 last month for the first time since May 1999 and removed some of the political heat facing the home secretary, Jack Straw, on the issue.

The Home Office figures for April reveal there were 5,890 new asylum applications compared with 6,680 in March and showed that the new fines on lorry drivers, and the non-cash voucher and dispersal system introduced last month are beginning to bite.

The 9,650 decisions made in April - the second highest on record and far outstripping the number of applications - also show that Britain's asylum system is continuing its slow recovery. By the end of the month the backlog of cases had been cut by nearly 4,000 although it still stood at 94,540.

The official rate at which asylum seekers were either recognised as full refugees or given exceptional leave to remain in Britain reached nearly 50% of the decisions made last month and so undermined the claims that nearly all asylum seekers are abusive or fraudulent.

Of the 9,650 decisions some 26% were granted asylum and a further 23% were granted exceptional leave to remain. A further unknown proportion of those whose cases were heard on appeal were also allowed to stay. Many of those given refugee status came from Somalia where a civil war has been raging for several years, Iraq and Sierra Leone.

The largest number of new applications came from asy lum seekers fleeing Sri Lanka, China and Afghanistan. The number of applications from the former Yugoslavia has fallen sharply in recent months and ministers are now encouraging Kosovans who came to Britain last year under the UN emergency programme to return home.

Ministers yesterday also pointed to a fall in applications from the Czech Republic, Romania and other parts of eastern Europe where Britain's new tighter asylum laws had been getting extensive coverage in newspapers and television.

The largest fall in applications - down 25% - came among those who applied at the port or airport on the day they arrived in Britain - which suggests the fines on lorry drivers are effective.

Nick Hardwick, the chief executive of the Refugee Council, said the figures showed that half of all asylum decisions in April resulted in Britain giving protection to people fleeing human rights abuses.

"These figures prove that a much higher proportion of asylum seekers are given protection than is generally acknowledged - even by the Home Office where the decisions are made," he said.

"What is also clear is that that the harsh decision to force asylum seekers to live on vouchers instead of benefits does not seem to have had an impact on the number of people arriving here.

"But do we want the impact of other recent changes in legislation, such as fines on lorries, to prevent those desperately in need of sanctuary from actually reaching our shores?"

fields.headline: Sony's dream weaver
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Another May, another corporate reorganisation at Sony, the Japanese electronics and media company jockeying to position itself at the hub of the networked society of the future. Following a reshuffle of operations last year, the ever-watchful president, Nobuyuki Idei, is again shaking up the board and shifting the focus of corporate strategy.
fields.body:
Another May, another corporate reorganisation at Sony, the Japanese electronics and media company jockeying to position itself at the hub of the networked society of the future. Following a reshuffle of operations last year, the ever-watchful president, Nobuyuki Idei, is again shaking up the board and shifting the focus of corporate strategy.

In a streamlining of the executive that will take effect next month, down or out will go powerful members of the old guard, such as former chief executive Norio Ogha, who powered Sony to success with hardware marvels like the Walkman. In will come executives who share Idei's vision of a business that not only manufactures hardware, but uses it to connect everyone to everything.

Idei will remain in charge, although his title will shift to chairman, giving him less responsibility for running day-to-day affairs and more time to concentrate on the internet plans.

His place as president will be taken by Kunitake Ando, a gizmo lover who declared on taking his post that his primary aim will be to add palmtop internet terminals to Sony's core line-up, along with the PlayStation2 game console, digital televisions and the Vaio computer range. "I can imagine a time soon when you download music into your cellphone and listen to it when you aren't talking," said Ando, extolling the virtues of the mobile internet - a fast-growing area where Sony has been slow to gain a foothold. "Or we could put a wireless transmitter in your camcorder so you can send video clips as soon as you take them, kind of like email."

The company structure is also being revamped. Its film and music businesses - which will provide the content for the network - are being put under one umbrella. Head office in Tokyo has been renamed "eHQ" to emphasise the priority that Sony places on its internet sales business: So-net.

So-net, jointly operated by Sony Communication Network and Play-Station.com, has caused a stir in Japan since its launch earlier this year. Bypassing traditional distribution outlets, it offers a wide range of Sony products on the net. When the PlayStation 2 console was launched in March, almost half the initial sales were made online.

The scale of Sony's internet ambitions were underlined in March when it revealed plans to establish an online bank in an alliance with Sakura Bank and JP Morgan. Sony also recently announced plans to link up with the H.I.S. travel agency to sell air tickets and tour packages through So-net. For Idei, such changes are vital to survive the impact of the internet, which he compares to the meteorite that wiped out the dinosaurs. With the advent of broadband connections to the web over the next few years, he is betting that old-fashioned firms will become extinct, while forward-thinking firms, such as Sony, prosper.

"Sony can be the leader in the broadband networked society. That will be a bigger role than this company has ever had," he said recently. "Sony has both the contents and the hardware. The plan is to use both to produce new businesses, in addition to strengthening what we already have."

Jam tomorrow

In Idei's vision of the future, Sony films and Sony music will be distributed through Sony networks, downloaded by Sony PlayStation terminals, edited on Sony computers and screened on Sony televisions. Not everyone is so enthusiastic. For Sony's engineers and salarymen, the changes are a big readjustment that they have to take on trust.

Investors have grown increasingly impatient with promises of jam tomorrow from Idei's grand networking strategy. Sony's recent performance has been patchy. The company posted a 32% decline in profits last year and since April, its share price has fallen by a third. Reflecting the global reality check on the internet boom, many of the analysts who were extolling the virtues of Sony's strategy last year are now playing up the potential pitfalls.

Why, they ask, should consumers use PlayStation 2 to download films and other content when sophisticated set-top boxes can do the same thing? Isn't it risky, others say, for Sony to enter the mobile internet business - where the company has never been particularly competitive? Many point out that some of Sony's leading products will soon face strong competition, while the concept of a wired world is being superseded by one in which mobile phones and palm top devices overtake personal computers as the preferred route to access the internet.

"In the mid-term is hard to see where profit growth will come from for Sony," noted a recent report by the Daiwa Research Institute, which downgraded its rating of the company's shares.

Despite such doubts, Sony remains an extremely healthy company. Its ability to produce stylish hardware will be underlined this autumn, with the launch of Sony's first palmtop internet terminals and the start of European and US sales of PlayStation 2. Whether consumers use those devices to connect to a wider world is another question.

webTitle: Israel is not a victim of others but rather of its own illusions

fields.headline: Israel is not a victim of others but rather of its own illusions
fields.standfirst:
The retreat from southern Lebanon exposes a fateful weakness

Hizbollah
Israel ministry of foreign affairs
Lebanese government
fields.trailText: The wheat was just turning to gold in the stone-walled fields of southern Lebanon as the Israelis, who had invaded the region in retaliation for a PLO commando raid near Tel Aviv, began to withdraw their forces in April 1978. A Ghanaian general, Emmanuel Erskine, sat on his shooting stick, high above the Litani river, waiting for the signal for his UN forces to occupy the vacated Israeli positions.
fields.body:
The wheat was just turning to gold in the stone-walled fields of southern Lebanon as the Israelis, who had invaded the region in retaliation for a PLO commando raid near Tel Aviv, began to withdraw their forces in April 1978. A Ghanaian general, Emmanuel Erskine, sat on his shooting stick, high above the Litani river, waiting for the signal for his UN forces to occupy the vacated Israeli positions. He waited in vain, until an Israeli officer approached to tell him that most of the positions had instead been handed over to Lebanese Christian militiamen allied to Israel. Erskine, a formidable combination of British military style and African male presence, looked the Israeli up and down and pronounced: "Major, you are a fuck-up."

It is a phrase that could be applied to almost everything Israel has attempted in Lebanon since, including this week's final retreat. Operation Litani, the name the Israelis gave their 1978 incursion, was to be followed in June 1982 by a full-scale invasion that took their troops to Beirut and led to the Sabra and Shatilla massacres, and the expulsion of the PLO from Lebanon. After that came countless other ground actions, bombings, and shellings as spring followed spring in southern Lebanon. Somehow, in spite of it all, the wheat continued to be sown and harvested, an example of human obduracy from which the Israelis should have learned a lesson. The Israeli record in Lebanon illustrated again and again that military power is often an illusory currency which a state can spend and spend without permanent gain or result.

Israel in its early years was a country bent only on survival. The fortunes of war then brought it control over the West Bank, Gaza, and the Sinai, and from this position of widened power, Israel launched an ambitious attempt to remake the Middle East in a way more suited to her interests. The Lebanese entrapment, as Israelis came to see it, was just one aspect of a broader imprisonment as Israel, aware that these larger designs were foundering, nevertheless continued to find it hugely difficult to abandon the positions which it had occupied in pursuit of them.

Twenty years ago Menachem Begin, the Likud prime minister, had taken up Anwar Sadat's offer of peace, but not, it swiftly turned out, as a stepping stone to agreements with Israel's other enemies. Instead he moved to confront them, first diluting his commitment to Palestinian autonomy, on which Sadat had set such store, then annexing the Golan Heights, and then allowing his defence minister, Ariel Sharon, to invade Lebanon with the object of destroying the PLO. The grand plan, at least for Sharon, did not end there. Sharon's hope was to change Lebanon into a Maronite-run satellite and then, by shifting Palestinians into Jordan, to bring about the fall of that kingdom and its replacement by a Palestinian state, into which much of the West Bank and Gaza population could be decanted. This mad scheme was soon in ruins, but in a way the retreat from it ended only yesterday, when the last Israeli soldiers pulled out.

Even before these developments, Sadat, in one of his meetings in Cairo with the Israeli ambassador, had been so angered by Begin's growing betrayal of their compact that he kept repeating: "May God forgive you, O Menachem!" Avi Shlaim, the Israeli historian who records this incident in his compelling survey of Israel's relationship with the Arabs over the last half-century, shows how Begin took a course in 1981 and 1982 whose disastrous consequences are still apparent today.

It is also to be recorded that many Israeli politicians, officials and soldiers were doubtful or opposed, but, as so often in that nation's history, did not prevail. Even Begin was misled by the wilful Sharon and came to regret the Lebanon war deeply.

Yet what was done was done. The decision, in spite of his promises to Sadat, to refuse any meaningful autonomy or self-government to the Palestinians has shaped Likud policy, and influenced that of the Labour party, up to Netanyahu and beyond. The decision to annex the Golan set the hostile relationship with Syria in concrete and helped create a proxy theatre of war in southern Lebanon. The invasion of Lebanon brought into being a political and military force, Hizbullah, that over the years became a much more effective foe than the PLO had been on that front. Hizbullah turned out to be so tough, in fact, that Israel's surrogate, the Christian militia it supported, could not manage on its own. More and more the Israelis had to steel themselves to the steady loss of their own young men.

The story of Israel and the Middle East in the past two decades has been of halting and painful attempts to reverse the Israeli decisions of the early 80s. They were, in Yehoshafat Harkabi's phrase, "fateful" decisions, and showed, as that astute former head of Israeli military intelligence remarked, that Israel was not so much a victim of others as it was of its own illusions. Through all this time Israelis have shown a growing awareness that their policies are in the long term untenable, infuriatingly combined with a refusal to pay the necessary price for peace. Oslo allowed progress toward agreement with the Palestinians to begin. That progress, however, was undermined by Binyamin Netanyahu, perhaps the supreme example of the Israeli tendency to believe that peace can be secured without concessions. But then came Ehud Barak, and many, in Israel and abroad, thought he carried with him the key to final settlements with the Palestinians, the Syrians and the Lebanese. It seemed that at last the mischief of 1981 and 1982 would be undone.

But Barak has proved to be a conjuror who, as the Israeli columnist Nahum Barnea has written, constantly suggested he could do the trick, but never actually did it. Trying to balance an undisciplined coalition, he could not offer Syria the complete restitution of territory in the Golan that President Assad, for his own compelling political reasons, naturally demanded. Resolving nevertheless to go ahead with his promise to get the boys out of Lebanon, but now without agreement with the Syrians or the Lebanese, he saw the withdrawal degenerate into a run for the border. Israel's Christian allies, about to be abandoned without even a half-baked deal on their future, not unexpectedly started to fold and, with no buffer left, the Israelis had to get out fast.

The scuttle in prospect had already pumped up Palestinian street protest, at a high level anyway because Barak had left certain key concessions too late. The Golan, the Lebanon, and the Palestinian lands are as interconnected today as they were in 1981. Lining them up again in a manageable sequence, a sequence in which agreement follows agreement until a general peace is attained, is not impossible, but it is not going to be easy.

webTitle: Chips away Intel spends $2bn on semiconductor capacity

fields.headline: Chips away Intel spends $2bn on semiconductor capacity
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Computer chip maker Intel expects a tight supply position in the industry for another 12 months as components run short, president and chief executive Craig Barrett said yesterday.
fields.body:
Computer chip maker Intel expects a tight supply position in the industry for another 12 months as components run short, president and chief executive Craig Barrett said yesterday.

"There is nil balance between supply and demand," he said in response to a question on the state of the semiconductor industry. He added that investments made to address the shortage will take time to result in increased capacity.

"I think the semiconductor industry underinvested in 1998 and 1999," he said. "I'd expect some shortage of components for the next 12 months or so."

Intel's stock surged $7 to close at $117 on Wednesday after it said it would spend $2bn over three years to boost the number of chips it can make at its New Mexico plant. The announcement reversed a fall on the Nasdaq, which gained 3.35%, but Mr Barrett shrugged off any link between the market and the announcement.

"I haven't the faintest idea on what sends the Nasdaq up or down on a daily basis," he said. "I am quite sure the announcement on New Mexico did not send the Nasdaq up or down."

But the Intel announcement and the Nasdaq rebound echoed yesterday in Europe, where stocks of chip makers surged.

fields.headline: Prescott's peak
fields.standfirst:
His rail summit missed the point
Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: What makes the unsatisfactory performance of the railway worse is the absence of a coherent and convincing plan for improvement. Yesterday's rail summit did little more than remind us of where the deficiencies lie.
fields.body:
What makes the unsatisfactory performance of the railway worse is the absence of a coherent and convincing plan for improvement. Yesterday's rail summit did little more than remind us of where the deficiencies lie.

For all his well-meaning bluster, John Prescott is out of his depth. For electoral reasons he needs rail users quickly to feel better. But the expansion of capacity that would make their carriages less crowded, bring fares down and get the trains running faster can only take place over time. Labour inherited a business model from the Tories in which private companies, obliged to seek maximum returns for their shareholders, were entrusted not just with safety but with dynamic expansion involving huge, long-term capital investment. "Partnership" - Mr Prescott's mantra - just has not convinced. Why should public money be pumped into companies geared to profit? A Railtrack executive yesterday acknowledged he had an identity problem. We stayed on the shareholder agenda too long, he said, but "are now firmly on the public service agenda". Before the Treasury gives Mr Prescott the meagre dole he seems to have been promised in the summer spending round much thought needs to be given to the nature of these rail-service companies. Why not an equity stake for the state, perhaps, in both Railtrack and infrastructure improvement by the rail operating companies? If part-renationalisation is what it takes to run a safe, clean, quick railway, so be it.

The summit said travellers let down by train operators should get better compensation. But cash back or vouchers if you are delayed miss the point. Passengers would accept overcrowding and delays if they were understood to be temporary - the result of past under-investment and the soft-touch regulation engendered by the Tories (woe betide attempts by them to make capital out of railway failings). Of course the rail regulator should penalise companies that do not run advertised services. But it is what happens next that really matters. Where is the grand plan for the west coast line; where are the blueprints for expanding capacity in the conurbations, especially London? Those fall within the province of the Strategic Rail Authority, a curiously half-time body presiding over a curious and unstable division of interest between Railtrack and train operating companies and John Prescott.

fields.headline: MPs urge BNFL rethink
fields.standfirst: Britain's nuclear industry: special report
fields.trailText: The end of reprocessing nuclear waste at British Nuclear Fuels moved a significant step forward yesterday when a Commons committee urged ministers to re-examine the commercial case for reprocessing at BNFL's Sellafield site.
fields.body:
The end of reprocessing nuclear waste at British Nuclear Fuels moved a significant step forward yesterday when a Commons committee urged ministers to re-examine the commercial case for reprocessing at BNFL's Sellafield site.

The trade and industry select committee endorsed the government's March decision to postpone a partial privatisation of BNFL until late 2002 at the earliest but bluntly told ministers to get a grip on a state-owned company given a free rein for far too long - effectively 30 years.

Martin O'Neill, the committee chairman, said last night: "I think that reprocessing is very much in the balance at the moment, and I get the impression that there is not the same total commitment to it on the part of the new management at BNFL that there was before."

BNFL, under its new chief executive, Norman Askew, is under mounting pressure, not least from neighbouring states, including Ireland, Iceland and Norway, to abandon reprocessing in favour of waste management and clean-up.

On Tuesday the company announced plans to close six of its eight ageing Magnox nuclear power plants by 2010, with the remaining two given a potentially longer life, and to shut down the plant for reprocessing Magnox waste.

Mr O'Neill said Mr Askew was "not prepared to go to the wall" over reprocessing. He suggested the new management could eventually build new gas-fired power stations on the sites of the closed Magnox stations to give the com pany a new lease of life and export electricity.

The MPs' hard-hitting report, condemning successive ministers for failure to control public money "sloshing around" BNFL, said the government should re-examine "from a fresh and commercially orientated" perspective the case for the Thorp reprocessing plant at Sellafield.

It also urged ministers to decide one way or the other on commissioning the £300m MOX (mixed oxide) plant at the Cumbrian site. The government, the committee said, should use the delay in the planned 49% float of BNFL, but it said partial privatisation was the best means available for introducing commercial disciplines into BNFL - a policy first formulated by Tony Benn as industry secretary 30 years ago.

fields.headline: No deal on 'free' music
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Music sales over the internet in Europe hung in the balance last night after EU trade ministers, including Britain's Helen Liddell, failed to decide whether the record industry could use software to stop people downloading free copies of their favourite songs.
fields.body:
Music sales over the internet in Europe hung in the balance last night after EU trade ministers, including Britain's Helen Liddell, failed to decide whether the record industry could use software to stop people downloading free copies of their favourite songs.

Yesterday's meeting in Brussels had been expected to yield an agreement for Europe-wide copyright legislation for the net to be put in place by the end of the year.

The music industry is demanding the right to use sophisticated encryption techniques to stop consumers obtaining music free. It says billions of pounds in revenue are at stake. "All our business and investment depends on a high level of protection. This legislation is going to determine the future of the industry and how we put music online," one executive said.

Manufacturers of hardware that allows people to make private copies disagree. "This is about the consumer and about five companies in Hollywood wanting them to pay for things which they have been doing for free for the last 20 years," Townsend Feehan of lobby group EACEM said.

Britain, which unlike other European countries does not impose a levy on the sale of blank CDs and tapes, believes consumers should be allowed to make private copies under certain conditions.

EU officials said France, anxious to secure maximum protection for online recordings, blocked agreement. A ministerial meeting may be held next month to break the deadlock.

webTitle: Confronting the issue of the week

fields.headline: Confronting the issue of the week
fields.standfirst:
Don't think it's easy to grapple with Cherie's problem child

Blairs' baby: special report
fields.trailText: Don't think it's easy to grapple with Cherie's problem child
fields.body:
Another week another problem. Last week, I was up all hours writing pieces and being cross-questioned on the media about the revealing dress that TV presenter Carol Vorderman wore to the Bafta awards. Was it a major step forward for the socio-sexual self-confidence of the middle-aged woman? Or did it represent a woman being forced to conform to the male notion of youthful sexuality?

Seven days later, already the whole issue of Ms Vorderman and her dress seems very passé, very mid-May 2000. Who was Carol Vorderman, and why were we worried sick about that dress of hers? No one can remember. We as a society have moved on since those tortured days of last week and the problems we wish to grapple with are very, very different. So I turn to the file labelled "Blair Baby - Issues, Problems and Solutions", knowing that once again the media will be beating a path to my door for my thoughts-in-progress.

Will Cherie breastfeed baby Leo? And, if she does, will she be running the risk of reducing him to a lifetime of subconscious mother-dependency, perhaps resulting in psychological turmoil, leading to a complete nervous breakdown, in his mid-to-late twenties? On the other hand, she might opt to bottle-feed him, in which case she should be made aware that breast-denial can prove to be a major - and in some cases terminal - source of trauma among middle-income males in their early thirties. But please, Cherie, on no account mix the bottle and the breast - many of those whose mothers attempted this method in the early 60s are now irreparably damaged as fully functional members of society.

Leo's toys might also prove a major problem. Many commentators and experts, including myself, will be scouring the first photographs of young Leo Blair for any sign that he is already being encouraged to play with handguns, real or simulated. Certainly, I will be the first to criticise Tony and Cherie if I catch the tell-tale glint of a Magnum 45 in their baby's hands. At less than a week old, he will be frankly far too young to be entrusted with a loaded handgun of any type, and anyone (even the prime minister) who places a pump-action pistol in infant hands must expect to be roundly condemned as thoroughly irresponsible.

Having a baby is, of course, the In Thing. It now seems likely that Cherie got the idea from reading about Liam Gallagher and Patsy Kensit and their baby son Lennon in the newspapers. But should a top legal brain be so influenced by the vagaries of fashion? Is it not wholly irresponsible of the wife of a serving prime minister to have a baby just because a pop star has had one? It is now widely accepted in political circles that Cherie named the baby after top 70s singer Leo Sayer, whose hits include Home Again, Naturally, and who is a frequent visitor to Number 10. Throughout this week, Cherie will have been on the telephone not only to Sayer but also to Patsy Kensit asking for tips, not only on the breastfeeding question but on a wide range of issues from selecting the most environmentally friendly nappies to whether to vaccinate immediately for whooping cough and diphtheria.

But some decisions should be taken by both parents: GM foods, for instance. Should young Leo Blair be subjected from an early age foods with GM additives - or should his parents wait until tests have proved, one way or the other, whether they are safe? And though girls are more prone to anorexia than boys, every action should be taken by his parents to prevent young Leo from becoming a severe anorexic at any time after the age of seven or eight. Already it may be too late - if, by sticking over-rigidly to feeding times, Cherie has inculcated the notion of food as an emotional-psychological necessity in her infant, he may well bear the scars in 10 years' time.

On an intensely personal note, I should confess that I myself have undergone the traumas suffered by infants at the hands of their parents. My mother now admits that she used to feed me milk chocolate regularly "as a treat" when I was just five years of age. Result? Aged 12, I was caught shoplifting. Aged 15, I was experiencing learning difficulties. Aged 16, I was bulimic. Aged 17, I was failing my maths O level for the 12th time. By 18, I was pregnant. And by the age of 35, my second marriage had broken up, leaving my children seriously dysfunctional. Thanks, mum: thanks a bloody lot.

So let's hope Cherie hasn't already condemned Leo to a life of intractable personal guilt - including his own contribution to the worldwide population explosion. For further help, I would recommend my two baby manuals, You and Your New Problem, and Your Baby and You: Conflict Management.

Next week: Mourning Dead Flowers: Coming to Terms with Garden Bereavement.

webTitle: Laser weapon offers hope for Israelis

fields.headline: Laser weapon offers hope for Israelis
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: The US and Israel are on the verge of completing the latest tests of a laser weapon which, within months, they claim, could profoundly alter the military balance on the Lebanon-Israel border in the wake of this week's Israeli withdrawal from southern Lebanon.
fields.body:
The US and Israel are on the verge of completing the latest tests of a laser weapon which, within months, they claim, could profoundly alter the military balance on the Lebanon-Israel border in the wake of this week's Israeli withdrawal from southern Lebanon.

The tactical high energy laser system has been specifically designed to shoot down katyusha and other short-range missiles of the sort which the Hizbullah movement has repeatedly used in the past to attack Israel's northern towns and villages.

The latest tests of the limited range combat laser - the world's first - began this week at the White Sands missile range in New Mexico, but were interrupted by a faulty mirror on the laser. The crucial mid-air shoot-down phase, which will include the destruction of a single katyusha and will be followed by tests involving the destruction of multiple missiles, has now been postponed until June.

"The single rocket shoot-down is the most critical, because it will once and for all show that we've been able to design and develop a bona fide high-powered laser system," the US army programme manager, Gerald Wilson, said.

The system concentrates a high intensity beam on the incoming rocket, subjecting it to temperatures many times higher than the surface of the sun. "Not too many substances known by mankind can withstand that," Mr Wilson said.

If the tests are satisfactory, the system will be available for deployment by Israel before the end of September, a spokesman for the US army space and missile defence command said yesterday. "Our tests have been extremely successful. We are on course for delivery," said the spokesman, William Congo.

Deployment of the laser weapons to defend frequently attacked northern Israeli communities such as Kiryat Shmona is seen as a decisive new military advantage in Israel's favour, as the struggle on the Lebanon border shifts from troops to technology.

The Israeli defence ministry said earlier this month that it would deploy the system along the northern border.

"It is a system that is designed specifically to deal with katyusha rocket attacks from across the border," a Pentagon spokesman, Kenneth Bacon, said this week.

The weapon has the capacity to deliver up to 60 laser beam shots without reloading. The beams can be moved around at will to defend against multiple targets, the designers say.

The combat laser represents the first potentially successful development from research begun in President Ronald Reagan's "Star Wars" Strategic Defence Initiative of the 1980s.

webTitle: Barak tries to woo frontline settlers

fields.headline: Barak tries to woo frontline settlers
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, yesterday went to the border town hit by 4,000 katyusha rockets to wipe out any resistance to the notion that his unilateral withdrawal from Lebanon was a brilliant success.
fields.body:
Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, yesterday went to the border town hit by 4,000 katyusha rockets to wipe out any resistance to the notion that his unilateral withdrawal from Lebanon was a brilliant success.

With his soldiers out of south Lebanon after 22 years, Mr Barak immediately opened two new fronts: to consolidate public opinion which has begun to swing behind the pullout, and to persuade the United Nations that Israel has met all its conditions for a withdrawal.

The former general faces the toughest battle of his campaign at Kiryat Shmona, where Palestinian, and later Hizbullah guerrillas, have rained down rockets since the early 1970s.

But even here, where jeering protesters milled outside the town hall hosting the first session of the knesset, or parliament, to be held outside Jerusalem yesterday, he was making some headway.

"Mother I came out of Lebanon," read the banner held aloft by Hadas Goldstein from the Kfar Blum kibbutz, where three people were injured in a Hizbullah rocket attack last year. "Ehud, you came out great."

An opinion poll published in the Yedioth Ahronot newspaper found that 72% of respondents backed the withdrawal. But 58% of those polled said their opinion of Mr Barak remained unchanged.

These are early days - as the Ma'ariv newspaper pointed out on its front pages yesterday morning. "Less than 48 hours have passed since the Israeli defence forces left Lebanon, and Israel's soul is still vacillating between outrage and exultation," the paper said. "There has not been enough time to absorb exactly what happened over there, before our astonished eyes. Who was saved and who won, who was defeated and who became stuck."

Most Israelis were horrified by the first images of the withdrawal - a precipitate exodus that left their ally in the occupation zone, the South Lebanon Army, in the lurch, and sent 6,500 SLA troops rushing to Israel's borders.

By yesterday morning, however, Israel was heaving a collective sigh of relief that an unpopular war was over, and the last troops had been extricated without a scratch. "Strong, swift and elegant", a Ma'ariv headline proclaimed. A day earlier, the rival Yediot Ahronot was mourning "a national humiliation".

Mr Barak may find it harder to sell the victory to Kiryat Shmona and people living in the kibbutzes. They are now only yards away from the Hizbullah guerrillas who completely control the strip of land evacuated by Israel.

Because Israel was forced to retreat six weeks early, none of the defences Mr Barak promised are ready. All along the border yesterday, earth movers were at work, fortifying Israel's defences.

The frenzied pace underlined the enormous gamble undertaken by Mr Barak, who is staking Israel's security on his claim that he has removed all pretext for attack. Following the unilateral withdrawal, he told reporters on Wednesday night, that Lebanese guerrillas would have "no legitimisation, no justification, not even an excuse" to target Israeli soldiers or civilians.

Most Israeli newspapers yesterday were too caught up in the tumult of events to weigh the odds. "It is too early to conjecture whether the unilateral withdrawal will prove to be the right thing to have done with respect to quiet on the northern border," said a leader comment in Ha'aretz.

But at the Misgav Am kibbutz, doubts crept in with the armoured bulldozers ploughing a strip of earth where the new border fence will go. With the end of the occupation, Lebanon now begins about 10 yards away from its electric yellow gates.

On Wednesday, army bulldozers flattened the Olish post on the nearest hill to Misgav Am, as Israel pulled out of the last patches of occupied land. The destruction of the post, and the government's promise yesterday to pull out of another piece of land near the disputed Shebaa farms, is essential for the UN to ratify that Israel has indeed withdrawn to a border line sketched out in 1923 by British and French civil servants.

But until the costly security systems are in place, Misgav Am's defences consist of a single rusty sentry box and a few Israeli troops.

"I remember receiving perfumed rice and candy when we first went into Lebanon. I remember the grenades they turned into when the Hizbullah began," said Mike Ginsberg, the security officer of the Misgav Am kibbutz. "It looks like we are entering a new stage, and the fear is not of what we know, but of what we don't know."

That incomprehension is shared by Israelis and Lebanese alike. During astonishing scenes on the Lebanese side of the Good Fence border yesterday, hundreds of people arrived for a look at the red roofs of the town of Metullah, stretching their hands through the loops of barbed wire.

It was still the land of the enemy. "Only three or four days ago, they killed us without blinking an eye," said Abdul Latif Abdallah, an English teacher, who spent five years in London.

Others screamed insults at the soldiers sitting impassively in their watch towers. "Don't go to sleep." Aside from a few hurled watermelons and rolls of toilet paper, the lightly armed Hizbullah guards kept order on the frontier.

With his soldiers out of south Lebanon after 22 years, Mr Barak immediately opened two new fronts: to consolidate public opinion which has begun to swing behind the pullout, and to persuade the United Nations that Israel has met all its conditions for a withdrawal. The former general faces the toughest battle of his campaign at Kiryat Shmona, where Palestinian, and later Hizbullah guerrillas, have rained down rockets since the early 1970s. "Less than 48 hours have passed since the Israeli defence forces left Lebanon, and Israel's soul is still vacillating between outrage and exultation," the paper said. "There has not been enough time to absorb exactly what happened over there, before our astonished eyes. Who was saved and who won, who was defeated and who became stuck."
