fields.headline: Night shift
fields.standfirst:
Lib Dem backs women MPs' protest

Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Amid growing protests by women MPs over hours and conditions in the House of Commons, the men are fighting back. But male voices are not - publicly - defending the current system: Liberal Democrat MP Mark Oaten stressed yesterday that men are just as fed up as women with lengthy Commons hours and "the public schoolboy games" played by some politicians.
fields.body:
Amid growing protests by women MPs over hours and conditions in the House of Commons, the men are fighting back. But male voices are not - publicly - defending the current system: Liberal Democrat MP Mark Oaten stressed yesterday that men are just as fed up as women with lengthy Commons hours and "the public schoolboy games" played by some politicians.

The Winchester MP, who is chief parliamentary aide to Lib Dem leader Charles Kennedy, said he and many male colleagues from across all parties were also exasperated by unnecessary parliamentary traditions. He cited the "bobbing up and down" MPs had to resort to in order to catch the Speaker's eye to raise a question in the Commons. He did not see why members could not clap if someone made a good point instead of being forced to say "Hear, Hear" - a sound reminiscent of "farmyard animals". He also claimed electronic voting could replace the late night "pushing and shoving" in the lobbies.

Mr Oaten, who made his points as MPs prepared to depart for the Whitsun recess, made clear his remarks were directly linked to the decision by Labour's Tess Kingham to stand down as MP for Gloucester at the next general election. Ms Kingham had twins in January, but has made clear that her decision to go was down not to family pressures but to frustration at the long hours and "schoolboy politics" of the Commons.

Mr Oaten, a keen parliamentary reformer, said: "I think it's important that male MPs do stand up and argue these things as well, otherwise it will be seen, frankly in tabloid terms, as the Blair Babes who are revolting on this issue."

He loved his job and enjoyed being member for Winchester but felt "deeply dissatisfied with the process by which we actually have to act as members of Parliament. "Those who are arguing for a change in the working hours do not want to do this because we want to have longer lie-ins in bed in the morning, because we can't stand the pace of working at 2am, or that we want to have longer holidays throughout the year, " he told MPs.

He was not happy that a "couple" of MPs wished to throw the business of the House into chaos. "If you actually examine some of the speeches made those MPs at 1am, 2am or 3am - there are no points of substance which are being put forward," he said.

fields.headline: Zen Research
fields.trailText: Not everyone is being put off by the recent slump in technology stocks. Zen Research said yesterday that it still intends to push ahead with its proposed flotation.
fields.body:
Not everyone is being put off by the recent slump in technology stocks. Zen Research said yesterday that it still intends to push ahead with its proposed flotation.

Of course, despite the Hitchhikers' Guide to the Galaxy nomenclature, Zen has a much more solid foundation for its faith in the future than the more recent arrivals of the web.

Zen has developed a new "beam technology" for use with DVDs and CDs. While it is yet to be decisively proven that money can be made on the net, most of the civilised world has been obsessed by TV and music since it was mass marketed. The development of new technologies for reproduction and distribution of sound and vision has usually proved to be a moneyspinner.

Zen expects to be valued at around £270m when it lists in London. The company provides DVD technology to companies such as Infineon, Sanyo Electric and LG Electronics. So far it has raised around £27m from strategic partners and its sponsor UBS Warburg.

The hi-tech firm, which has labs in Israel and marketing offices in silicon valley, expects to list in the early summer and to raise £70m from the move.

Finance director David Aber said yesterday: "We are not deterred by market conditions. We rely on the advice of Warburg and we share very high confidence. The market wants our technology now."

Good to hear such faith at a time when those who were not so quiet in their confidence have delayed or cut their floats.

The listing will be through Zen's holding company via a global offer of new and existing shares to institutional investors. Chief executive Emil Jachmann said: "We have made great strides in licensing our technology and intellectual property to international partners for the design, manufacture and marketing of solutions powered by Zen. The listing, with our strong, experienced management and patented technologies, provides the opportunity to build new strategic relationships around the world."

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: It was an good day for Vodafone Airtouch, so the London stock market went up as well.
fields.body:
It was an good day for Vodafone Airtouch, so the London stock market went up as well.

A storming rally in Vodafone , Britain's biggest company, sent the shares up from 264p to 287p - worth a short 70 points on the FTSE 100 index, which in turn gained 112.5 points to 6,231.1.

The interest in Vodafone was triggered by the belated realisation there there will be a real auction for control of Orange, the rival mobile phone group which Vodafone acquired as part of the Mannesmann deal, but which regulators say it has to sell. The management at Orange would like to be refloated.

But then all the big tele coms firms were in demand yesterday, with Colt Telecom flying up 291p to £20.79, Telewest Communications rising 24.5p to 257p and Cable & Wireless ending the day 92p higher at £10.02.

Other new economy stocks to benefit on the day included software group Logica , up from £15.62 to £16.58, and rival Guardian IT , which ended the session 112.5p higher at £11.75.

The move higher in London came in spite of a bout of selling in New York. The Dow was trading down during dealing time in London, although the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index managed a 2% bounce after recent heavy selling.

Prudential was rewarded with a 32.5p rise in its shares to £10.05 for its determination to press ahead with the flotation of Egg.

In the brewing sector, confirmation of the Whitbread move to sell its brewing business to Belgium's Interbrew helped its stock price rise from 567p to 579p, although Bass (which is in the process of selling its own beer business) shed 1.5p to 768.5p.

Among the medium-sized tech stocks, there was some excitement in the market for one-time fringe stockbroker Durlacher , which jumped from 56.5p to 74.5p. Some big holders of the stock have been selling over recent days, after a slump in the market price from mid-February's high of 451p. Ahead of yester day's rally, the shares were trading at a level not seen since last October.

Wireless Group , the radio company, joined the market and had a reasonable first day. Against a 190p sale price, the shares dipped to 182p and then recovered to a 205p close. Aero Investory , a firm specialising in investory management for the aerospace industry, held at its 123p float price, but the day's other new issue, media group E-comsport , sank to 66p from a 75p float price on AIM.

Money Channel , the financial TV firm, confirmed news of its carriage contract with Telewest and saw its shares rise 8p to 92p.

webTitle: Mothercare free to deliver true potential

fields.headline: Mothercare free to deliver true potential
fields.trailText: With the disposal of Bhs to a certain Philip Green - who had originally, remember, set his cap at Marks & Spencer - the Storehouse group shrank to encompassing just Mothercare. Now that move is to be codified: the company yesterday announced that the group's name will change to Mothercare plc following the disposal of Bhs for £224m.
fields.body:
With the disposal of Bhs to a certain Philip Green - who had originally, remember, set his cap at Marks & Spencer - the Storehouse group shrank to encompassing just Mothercare. Now that move is to be codified: the company yesterday announced that the group's name will change to Mothercare plc following the disposal of Bhs for £224m.

The cash will be handy. Yesterday the retail group revealed an operating profit before exceptionals of £13.5m in the year to April 1, compared to £104.3m the year before. Group sales were £1.26bn, compared to £1.32bn a year ago.

Ongoing Mothercare business generated a profit before exceptionals of just £400,000, compared to £17.9m, although this was with a return to profit in the second half of £3.7m after a first-half loss.

The company said it had taken an exceptional charge of £396.4m relating to the loss on the disposal of Bhs, the restructuring of Mothercare and the break-up of the Storehouse head office.

But retail sales in the first seven weeks in the ongoing business rose on a like-for-like basis by 3.4% and margins were up year on year.

Storehouse chairman Alan Smith said: "With the completion of the sale of Bhs we can now focus on delivering Mothercare's full potential."

It is self-evident that it should be a simpler job rebuilding the Mothercare brand without having to worry about Bhs. Shareholders had been disappointed that a buyer could not be found for the group, but as Storehouse's market value has plunged they will now see Mothercare restore some of its true value.

Despite the lack of buyers for Mothercare, it is still one of those instantly recognis able brands. Its out-of-town stores have potential for real growth. Yesterday the company was highlighting Mothercare.com, its e-business, due to be launched next month that will allow consumers access to products and information.

The ongoing business, however, will have to improve its clothing range and operating standards, chief executive Chris Martin admitted yesterday. He added that the home, travel and toys businesses had continued to grow, but that the clothing range was being refocused on the pre-school range.

Mr Smith pointed to the recovery of the share price from under 30p earlier this year. The shares closed up 4p at 44.25p.

Maybe Monaco-based Mr Green was right when he said he would have been prepared to bid for the whole group if the Storehouse board had turned down his offer for Bhs - but then admitted that the management was "down the road to sorting out Mothercare, and I'd rather focus on sorting out Bhs".

fields.headline: United plans power by proxy
fields.standfirst: Multi-utility seeks contracts to run other firms' operations
fields.trailText: United Utilities, the north-west multi-utility, yesterday revealed plans to run more of the country's gas and electricity operation under contract.
fields.body:
United Utilities, the north-west multi-utility, yesterday revealed plans to run more of the country's gas and electricity operation under contract.

The company has set up a contract asset management business as part of a general restructuring of its operations. United directors believe that the way utilities are run is going to change dramatically in the coming years as a result of competition and restructuring.

John Roberts, United's chief executive, said that licence holders and new entrants in the utilities sector would increasingly want to contract out parts of their business.

Western Power Distribution, the US group contemplating a bid for Hyder, the Welsh multi-utility company, has already indicated that it would employ United to manage and maintain Welsh Water's assets.

Mr Roberts said the management of United would be restructured to form five separate businesses - licensed asset management, contract asset management, customer sales, Vertex and Norweb Telecom.

The plan to sell its Norweb Energi electricity and gas supply business, announced in December, was on track for completion sometime in the summer. Talks were taking place with about a dozen interested parties.

Mr Roberts said the group was still hoping to float about 25% of its fast-expanding Norweb Telecom business in December or early next year.

United has invested about £125m in the telecom business and expects to invest millions more to boost growth, either organically or by acquisition.

Mr Roberts said Norweb Telecom would maintain last year's 60% growth during the current year. However it is still losing money and is not expected to start moving towards profit until the end of next year.

United's pre-tax profits for the year to March 31 rose just under 1% to £459.4m. The total dividend for the year will be 2% higher at 45.2p a share.

The group is planning to slash £400m from the costs of its water and electricity operations over the next five years to meet efficiency targets set by the regulators.

Pennon, owner of South West Water, yesterday reported annual pre-tax profits of £121.6m, down from £126.6m the previous year. A final dividend of 32.4p a share will lift the total for the year by 4.8% to 47.8p a share.

The company said cost cuts and efficiency schemes implemented this year were unlikely to offset the £35m lost as a result of price cuts imposed by the regulators.

Finance director Ken Hill said Pennon was looking at strategic options.

"We would rule nothing out and nothing in at this stage," he said.

webTitle: Real ale drinkers will thirst for choice

fields.headline: Real ale drinkers will thirst for choice
fields.standfirst: Global brands land bitter blow | Odd game |   Some hope
fields.trailText: Global brands land bitter blow | Odd game | Some hope
fields.body:
Global brands land bitter blow

The days of spinsters cycling to the pub through the morning mist for a pint of warm cloudy ale could be numbered. A hefty slice of Britain's brewing industry is on the way to mainland Europe - Whitbread yesterday sold its manufacturing operations to Belgian multinational Interbrew and Bass is likely to announce a similar exit within weeks.

The implications for the traditional pint are not good.

All the companies concerned ruminated at length on the importance of global brands. Stella Artois and Carling are definitely in, Old Speckled Chicken's Finger is out.

Sales of real ale have been declining for years, faced with an onslaught of trendy commercials promoting premium lager brands. Local beers are rarely on offer in the city centre bars which are luring drinkers away from neighbourhood boozers.

For Interbrew, Carlsberg-Tetley and even Scottish & Newcastle - which is buying Kronenbourg's manufacturer Groupe Danone - the only way forward is to develop global products with equal appeal in Birmingham and Beijing. Sheer size is critical to fund massive advertising blitzes - even a sizeable national player cannot compete with the promotional budgets behind Heineken and Carlsberg.

Prices have also come under pressure - despite Whitbread's claim that Stella is "reassuringly expensive", the market leaders are pitching their offerings increasingly competitively - which is good news for lager fans but means a squeeze for smaller producers.

There was a cry of pain yesterday from the Independent Family Brewers of Britain - tellingly, the organisation only has 34 remaining members. It forecast more brewery closures - and there have been many already in the last year, most notably the Vaux brewery in Sunderland and Morland's Old Speckled Hen site in Abingdon.

Interbrew's chief executive Hugo Powell insisted that he would continue producing Whitbread's local ales yesterday, but it is hard to see the Belgian group maintaining a long-term commitment to the likes of Fuggles Imperial, Welsh Smooth and Castle Eden Ale.

Whitbread's three main sites should be safe as they can continue to pump out volume lager, but fans of Fuggles should consider stocking up.

Odd game

Strange tactics yesterday from Focus Do It All as it pursues its £327m bid for rival DIY chain Wickes, with the predator indicating it would not sell the 29.9% stake it has bought in Wickes if its bid fails.

The move will keep alive hopes of a bid at a later date as well as removing the prospect of a large chunk of Wickes' shares suddenly being unloaded onto the market.

As a result Wickes shareholders would seem to have little to lose if they stay with their present management team and its recovery plans.

Shareholders will benefit if the Wickes management delivers the goods, and will probably be bailed out by Focus if it does not.

The offer closes on June 2, but while both sides claim to speak for 30% of the shares, the bidder is already talking like a frustrated loser - which is why shares in Wickes are now sitting at a 7% discount to the cash on the table.

Some hope

"The matter is submitted. Thank you, counsel." With this, Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson left what he evidently hoped was his last day in court, presiding over the landmark legal battle between the American government and Microsoft. Expecting at least a few more sessions in court, government lawyers were left scrambling to decipher what the judge wanted them to do, while Microsoft's lawyers declared they would not just appeal the actual judgment but also now dispute the amount of time allotted to discuss a break-up.

Yet in many ways, Microsoft has the most to gain from the judge's decision this week. Long before his ruling that it had abused its monopoly, Microsoft was threatening to go to a higher court. If Microsoft feels that it will "prevail" in the appeals court, as its lawyers kept saying in Washington this week, why should it want further delays?

The assumption is that Microsoft expects a softer political climate in the US by the autumn election, while just months in the computing industry can move the competitive and legal goal-posts. But its position also reflects a corporate culture that is as much on trial. Microsoft has consistently denied that it has done anything wrong and appears to have rejected any suggestion of a break-up. Such steadfastness - arrogance even - means the firm will do anything to head off a negative ruling.

It also means that this case has some time left to run - in spite of Judge Jackson making it clear that whatever else is in Microsoft's power, he is not.

webTitle: Seminal firm aims to cash in on bull market

fields.headline: Seminal firm aims to cash in on bull market
fields.trailText: A Cheshire cattle breeding company is hoping to raise £3m in a flotation on the alternative investment market, to fund technology which can separate bulls' semen into its male and female constituents.
fields.body:
A Cheshire cattle breeding company is hoping to raise £3m in a flotation on the alternative investment market, to fund technology which can separate bulls' semen into its male and female constituents.

Genus, which is currently on the lightly regulated exchange Ofex, is likely to be valued at about £65m.

It believes the technology could prevent the slaughter at birth of hundreds of thousands of male calves each year.

Chief executive Richard Wood said: "If you're a dairy farmer, you only want to breed female calves - so you can milk them. At the moment, most dairy Fresians which turn out to be male are simply shot at birth."

Under the new process, licensed by Genus from a Canadian biotechnology firm, Gensel, scientists can take a beaker of bull semen and add antibodies which attach themselves to male sperm. These sperm then grow in size, and can be filtered out.

Mr Wood said: "This is an entirely natural process - it doesn't involve any genetic modification."

If successful, farmers will be able to buy purely female semen to impregnate their herds. The market price for a dose of bull semen is £10 to £30 a dose, but Mr Wood said that gender-specific semen could command double this price.

Genus has secured the international marketing rights to the technology from Gensel and a commercial launch is likely within two years.

Mr Wood said Genus had been pondering a listing on the main market but decided to go for Aim due to the recent volatility in share prices.

He said a move up to the main market remained a long-term goal, where a listing on the hi-tech exchange, Techmark could be a possibility.

"Techmark is certainly something we will be discussing with the exchange," said Mr Wood. "But the problem we have for the moment is just getting ourselves known. There aren't really any comparable companies on the stockmarket."

The group employs just over 1,500 people and has 300 cows.

Its underlying operating profits doubled to £7.3m last year, with strong revenue from semen sales and consulting on cattle breeding.

However, pre-tax profits slipped 2% to £5.11m due to fewer property sales and higher acquisition costs.

fields.headline: Lyons' roar
fields.trailText: As a rank-and-file MSF member, I didn't see the article on Roger Lyons' "expenses" as a "nasty, anti-union dig at our general secretary and our campaigning union" as our president, Brenda Warrington, claims (Letters, May 25) but as a legitimate story about someone who seems to be making a nice living representing workers who don't make such a nice living.
fields.body:
As a rank-and-file MSF member, I didn't see the article on Roger Lyons' "expenses" as a "nasty, anti-union dig at our general secretary and our campaigning union" as our president, Brenda Warrington, claims (Letters, May 25) but as a legitimate story about someone who seems to be making a nice living representing workers who don't make such a nice living.

How does he find the time to earn the £15,000 on the competition commission which he can add to his £68,000 salary? Many MSF workers don't even earn £15,000 - so, no competition there. It's noticeable that she did not comment on the union's approval of putting the takeaways, drinks from off-licences, the video, the radio, the briefcase on to expenses.
Harry Harmer
London

fields.headline: Discord in musical chairs
fields.trailText: So musical chairs "teaches aggression" (Wam! Bam! May 24). In my nursery we have played it and musical statues for many years. As with most activities in life, there is an element of competition.
fields.body:
So musical chairs "teaches aggression" (Wam! Bam! May 24). In my nursery we have played it and musical statues for many years. As with most activities in life, there is an element of competition. Whether this is channelled productively or destructively depends on how the teacher applies the rules of the game. We do not applaud "the strongest, fastest one", but everyone who takes part. The children who don't want to play become the audience. When we pretend to be lions in musical statues the children know the parameters of the game and nobody is mauled out of existence.
Felitsa Matziorini-Birnberg
London

 Games such as musical chairs serve to teach that order, community and gain through achievement are integral values in our society, achieved by care, compro mise and cooperation - far from the insidious systemised intimidation that pervades when children, left to their own devices, create a directly consumerist hierarchy structured with playing cards depicting sworn enemies and assailants vested with spurious powers, locked in an endless game that can never be won.
Julian Firth
London

 This mildly boisterous pastime has gone underground. Small groups of chairs are beginning to appear in public spaces. Short bursts of music can be heard and groups of individuals, pretending to be otherwise occupied, can be seen jostling for seats. Police are aware of this new development but say they are sitting on it.
Linda Swann
London

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In a report from Valencia, page 6, yesterday, we said that last year Spain had the fastest economic growth in the EU. In fact it was the second fastest, with Ireland first.
fields.body:
In a report from Valencia, page 6, yesterday, we said that last year Spain had the fastest economic growth in the EU. In fact it was the second fastest, with Ireland first.

In a report headed Microsoft break-up nears, page 27 (Finance) yesterday, we referred to Microsoft's rivals including "some micro systems, and Novel". That should have been Sun Microsystems and Novell.

The figures in a panel on page 3 yesterday purporting to show the result of the 1997 parliamentary election in Tottenham actually showed the outcome of the election in 1992. The figures for 1997 were as follows: Labour 26,121; Conservative 5,921; Lib Dem 4,064; Green 1,059; Other 539. Labour majority 20,200.

Contrary to the suggestion in an article headed Wham! Bam!, page 4, G2, May 24, the employment minister Margaret Hodge does not endorse the views which some reports attributed to the author of the pamphlet Towards a Non-Violent Society on the supposedly aggressive nature of musical chairs. We joined some other papers in jumping to the wrong conclusion.

In our report headed SAS baked cake after IRA death, page 4, May 24, we gave the impression that Martin Hurson died in 1984. He died in 1981, along with other IRA hunger strikers.

webTitle: Where nationalists and the government take issue on the future of Ulster policing

fields.headline: Where nationalists and the government take issue on the future of Ulster policing
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The government has announced a series of changes to Chris Patten's proposals on the future of policing in Northern Ireland in an attempt to appease unionists.
fields.body:
The government has announced a series of changes to Chris Patten's proposals on the future of policing in Northern Ireland in an attempt to appease unionists.

Nationalists have reacted angrily, saying that the changes fall outside the Good Friday agreement which set up the Patten report.

Seamus Mallon, deputy leader of the SDLP, has claimed there are 44 differences between the government's policing legislation and Patten's report.

The main differences are:

Force's name
The government is watering down Patten's proposal to abolish the name of the RUC.

Patten said the Royal Ulster Constabulary should be named the Northern Ireland Police Service. But the government is proposing to keep the RUC's name alive in by saying that the new force incorporates the RUC.

It is leaving the final decision on the name to the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson.

Mr Mandelson said: "I believe that the sensible way forward is to provide a legal description in the bill which incorporates the Royal Ulster Constabulary, in effect the title deeds of the new service, while introducing a new name that will be used for all working and operational purposes. The Police Service of Northern Ireland is the best suggestion so far."

Badge
Mr Mandelson will amend Patten's proposal for a neutral badge. Patten said: "The Northern Ireland Police Service should adopt a new badge and symbols which are entirely free from any association with either the British or Irish states."

Mr Mandelson said: "I am not convinced that [the badge] needs to be entirely free of association with either tradition, as recommended." He has suggested the new badge could incorporate the George Cross, recently awarded to the RUC.

Flag
The government will rule on whether the union flag should fly over police buildings. This contradicts the Patten report which said: "The union flag should no longer be flown from police buildings."

The police bill says the secretary of state "may make regulations regulating the flying or carrying of [a flag for the police force] or any other flag".

Oath
Nationalists are concerned that the police oath, which makes no mention of the crown, will only be sworn by new recruits to the new police service. Patten said: "There should be a new oath, taken individually by all new and existing police officers, expressing an explicit commitment to upholding human rights." He said it should include a commitment to respect all "traditions and beliefs".

The bill merely says members of the force will swear the oath "on appointment". There is no mention of respecting traditions and beliefs.

Police board
Patten: "The policing board should have the power to follow up any report from the chief constable by initiating an inquiry into any aspect of the police service or police conduct."

The only limitations would be "national security, sensitive personnel matters and cases before the courts."

The bill will limit the board's powers in two ways. Firstly, the chief constable will be able to appeal to the secretary of state to block an inquiry if it could "prejudice the prevention or detection of crime, the apprehension or prosecution of offenders or the administration of justice". Secondly, if the board insists on holding an inquiry, against the wishes of the chief constable, the secretary of state will be able to block it if he thinks it "would not be in the interests of the efficiency or effectiveness of the police force".

Oversight commissioner
The commissioner, who will monitor whether the police reforms are being implemented, will not be set up on a statutory basis. There is also unease among nationalists that ministers have approached Thomas Constantine, the former head of the US drug enforcement administration, without consulting them.

Patten said the commissioner "would provide more than a stocktaking function". There is no mention of the commissioner in the bill.

District policing partnerships
Patten said district councils should be able to contribute a up to 3p in the pound towards local policing costs. This is not mentioned in the bill, which says that the role of the partnerships is "primarily consultative".

Ombudsman
Patten: "The police ombudsman should exercise the power to initiate inquiries or investigations."

Nationalists complain the government has no plans to amend legislation preventing the ombudsman from investigating complaints about the direction and control of the force.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: • Is there anything nicer than watching an old friend prosper? Actually, yes (watching a colleague fail, for one thing), but it's still a joy to see boulevardier Andrew Neil showing such a typically deft touch in staff management as publisher of the Barclay brothers' Scotsman.
fields.body:
 Is there anything nicer than watching an old friend prosper? Actually, yes (watching a colleague fail, for one thing), but it's still a joy to see boulevardier Andrew Neil showing such a typically deft touch in staff management as publisher of the Barclay brothers' Scotsman.

All those rumours about pretty boy and his adorably good natured editor Rebecca Hardy destroying everything good about the paper in a chaotic flurry of wildly incompetent butchery has clearly been invented. After all, standards can hardly be plummeting as claimed when on Wednesday Ian Bell - seen by staff as a symbol of the paper's integrity and a role model for younger journalists - won columnist of the year at the Bank of Scotland press awards. And if it's true that on Tuesday Mr Bell resigned in disgust at all the recent sackings, so what? Mr Bell is to join a new business paper run by Scotsmen-in-exile, recently dismissed in our media section by Andrew, mannerly to the last, as "dead wood" and "cart horses" - and it was to these two groups that Mr Bell dedicated his award. All this and poor circulation... carry on, Andrew, you're doing splendid work.

 Moving to another titan of newspapers, there is news of Janet Street-Porter. Janet, whose editorship of the Independent on Sunday is seen as restoring the tradition begun by Stephen Glover, delivered a lecture to the cadets at Sandhurst College on Tuesday. The subject, Kelvin MacKenzie will be interested to learn, was "leadership".

Clearly the officer who arranges speakers read Chris Horrie and Adam Nathan's fine book about L!ve TV with care. Next week's Sandhurst speaker, on the subject "securing one's position", is Robert Ayling.

 A fax arrives from Labour MP David Winnick, who recently asked Mr Tony about the arrest of the rebel leader in Sri Lanka (a masterstroke sadly corrected by Hansard to Sierra Leone). David disputes our claim about Harold Wilson's epithet for him. "Up to now the Tories have alleged that Wilson said I was the silliest man. Now it has been escalated to the stupidest. I am now waiting to be told that he called me the most evil man ever to enter the House."

Now that's just daft, David... and on the basis that one must discount anything the Tories allege, I think it safer to stick with "stupidest". Readers are reminded of our Stupidest MP 2000 contest to discover if he retains the title. Nominations are welcome, with champagne to the best.

 Speaking of champagne, invitations to the Spectator's forthcoming party shock recipients to the point of ague. "6.30 pm: Krug champagne", it reads. Good God, the neo-Archerian vulgarity of it. "They might as well say '6.30 pm: very expensive champagne'," says one invitee. "If the party has been sponsored by Krug why don't they say so? The way they have done it is so... low."

We ring the mag's editor, but a man sounding curiously like the late Arthur Mullard answers. "Yus my dear?" he says. Is Boris the Jackal Johnson there? "The guv'nor ain't 'ere. 'E's gawn dahn the caff for some Muvver's Pride toast and a pot of Tetley's tea." Your guv'nor seems obsessed with branding. "Yus. Now sod orf and stop pullin' my bell end, son, or I'll do some brandin' of me own. Wiv the iron."

 Polygraph to the Treasury, polygraph to the Treasury... Gordon Brown's office has rubbished our report that the weirdo chancellor has split up, very gently, with Sarah Macaulay. With New Labour, as you know, the only reliable confirmation of anything is the blanket denial. Of course, as you also know, this column has been wrong, often spectacularly, about almost everything for five years. And yet, as not only Gordon's intimates but close friends of Sarah are in no doubt that they are the Liz and Hugh of British politics, not this time (we think).

Mr Bell is to join a new business paper run by Scotsmen-in-exile, recently dismissed in our media section by Andrew, mannerly to the last, as "dead wood" and "cart horses" - and it was to these two groups that Mr Bell dedicated his award. All this and poor circulation... carry on, Andrew, you're doing splendid work.  Moving to another titan of newspapers, there is news of Janet Street-Porter. Janet, whose editorship of the Independent on Sunday is seen as restoring the tradition begun by Stephen Glover, delivered a lecture to the cadets at Sandhurst College on Tuesday. The subject, Kelvin MacKenzie will be interested to learn, was "leadership". Clearly the officer who arranges speakers read Chris Horrie and Adam Nathan's fine book about L!ve TV with care. Next week's Sandhurst speaker, on the subject "securing one's position", is Robert Ayling.  A fax arrives from Labour MP David Winnick, who recently asked Mr Tony about the arrest of the rebel leader in Sri Lanka (a masterstroke sadly corrected by Hansard to Sierra Leone). David disputes our claim about Harold Wilson's epithet for him. "Up to now the Tories have alleged that Wilson said I was the silliest man. Now it has been escalated to the stupidest. I am now waiting to be told that he called me the most evil man ever to enter the House." Now that's just daft, David... and on the basis that one must discount anything the Tories allege, I think it safer to stick with "stupidest". Readers are reminded of our Stupidest MP 2000 contest to discover if he retains the title. Nominations are welcome, with champagne to the best.  Speaking of champagne, invitations to the Spectator's forthcoming party shock recipients to the point of ague. "6.30 pm: Krug champagne", it reads. Good God, the neo-Archerian vulgarity of it. "They might as well say '6.30 pm: very expensive champagne'," says one invitee. "If the party has been sponsored by Krug why don't they say so? The way they have done it is so... low." We ring the mag's editor, but a man sounding curiously like the late Arthur Mullard answers. "Yus my dear?" he says. Is Boris the Jackal Johnson there? "The guv'nor ain't 'ere. 'E's gawn dahn the caff for some Muvver's Pride toast and a pot of Tetley's tea." Your guv'nor seems obsessed with branding. "Yus. Now sod orf and stop pullin' my bell end, son, or I'll do some brandin' of me own. Wiv the iron."  Polygraph to the Treasury, polygraph to the Treasury... Gordon Brown's office has rubbished our report that the weirdo chancellor has split up, very gently, with Sarah Macaulay. With New Labour, as you know, the only reliable confirmation of anything is the blanket denial. Of course, as you also know, this column has been wrong, often spectacularly, about almost everything for five years. And yet, as not only Gordon's intimates but close friends of Sarah are in no doubt that they are the Liz and Hugh of British politics, not this time (we think).

fields.headline: A study of Oxbridge bias
fields.trailText: Alan and Lesley Fowler (Letters, May 25) ask why so few candidates from northern comprehensives achieve Oxbridge places. So far, the debate suggests that admissions tutors are middle-class types who "smugly recruit in their own image".
fields.body:
Alan and Lesley Fowler (Letters, May 25) ask why so few candidates from northern comprehensives achieve Oxbridge places. So far, the debate suggests that admissions tutors are middle-class types who "smugly recruit in their own image".

Though this kind of bias undoubtedly exists, the primary factor is that privately funded and state-funded education deliver different kinds of 18 year olds. The state system - a mass-delivery machine, constrained by resources - focuses on getting as many children as possible to pass exams. Private education has the time and resources to deliver the skill of thinking, the art of moving beyond the requirements of the particular paper you are sitting and to create entirely new links.

In an Oxbridge interview, the knowledge that you have acquired is quite secondary to the thinking skills you demonstrate. I vividly remember my inquisitor asking a rapid sequence of questions until he found an area about which I knew nothing. It was this area - macro-economics in the Middle East, as it happens - that we inhabited for the remainder of the interview. His purpose was to test my thinking skills, to see how I would cope with entirely new information. Having had the good fortune to go to a state-funded grammar, with a good track record of Oxbridge entry, I had - quite unconsciously - accumulated a range of skills that put me in good stead. I was offered, and accepted, a place.

Other things being equal, a privately educated student will have encountered along the path of her education more of the questions, elliptical inquiries and lateral links that Oxbridge is looking for. She is more likely to get in than her state-educated counterpart.

What to do? Privately funded educational institutions should receive state subsidies only if they make their resources and skills available to the state sector - in the form of teacher placements, access to modern information and communications technology equipment, loans of their tennis coach. Over time, I would expect fewer parents to want a private education, since the state sector would be providing a competitive alternative.

Even better, children from northern comprehensives would be better armed to tackle the narrow-minded, pampered-since-prep-school elite, could tell them where to shove their tutorials, and could build alternatives rather better suited to the 21st century.
David Fell
London
david.fell@virgin.net

 The point about the rejection of Laura Spence by Oxford (Oxford Blues, G2, May 24) is not the unfairness encountered in Oxbridge entrance, but the extraordinary attitude of her headteacher that failure to get into Oxford automatically means leaving the country and going to Harvard. Not only does this vaunt Oxford as a medical school perhaps rather higher than it deserves, but it effectively writes off every other university in the country. In his rather backhanded way, Laura's headteacher is contributing to the persistent Oxbridge-is-best myth.
Sean Lang
Cambridge
slang@hrsfc.ac.uk

 Liz Fuller (Letters, May 25) writes of the brave and imaginative decision of Oxford university to discriminate in favour of state-school applicants like her 25 years ago. I too was at Oxford then, and vividly remember Liz as a plucky proletarian outsider who had overcome educational and social disadvantage to seize her entitlement. But there weren't a lot of others like that.
Tony Hufton
Norwich
hufton@compuserve.com

webTitle: We (and our wives) tried to bring order to the house

fields.headline: We (and our wives) tried to bring order to the house
fields.trailText: Oona King (Male members, May 19) says that MPs routinely discuss legislation affecting millions in the middle of the night. No they don't: most simply wait to troop through the lobbies to vote.
fields.body:
Oona King (Male members, May 19) says that MPs routinely discuss legislation affecting millions in the middle of the night. No they don't: most simply wait to troop through the lobbies to vote.

A number of Labour MPs, and our wives, tried to change the hours of the Commons to 9am to 7pm in the 1970s. We failed: first because Labour MPs who represented constituencies outside London (most of them) were nervous about being at a loose end in London at night and worried that their families and constituents would think they were exposed to temptation. Secondly, because a large number of MPs (mostly Conservative) wanted to earn money in the courts and the City in the mornings.
John Garrett
Norwich

 As the first British Asian woman MEP, I have a good deal of sympathy for Trevor Phillips' comments on ethnic minority MP targets (Activists demand better race balance in Commons, May 25) for there is a need for greater representation within our party. Nonetheless, it is a sad reflection on British politics that the Labour party is the only one to have a black member on the Greater London Assembly.

Despite the 101 women MPs, despite the increasing numbers of black politicians working hard for the people of Britain - we cannot afford to be complacent. Forward thinking policy is reflected in the emerging numbers of black people we see in Westminster today and nearly 1,000 local black councillors across the UK. Nevertheless, there is still all to play for, we can take nothing for granted.

It is our duty, as members of a party devoted to equal opportunities, to work together for positive action. Positive action - based on merit - has worked before and it can work again, not only for women and black people, but for other groups we have not yet targeted.

But positive action does not begin and end at the door of central policy. At present there are a number of black candidates on the approved parliamentary list. Here is a real opportunity for the wider membership, through party constituencies, to take responsibility on the ground, choose more black candidates and effect real change.
Neena Gill MEP

 Surely the selection procedure in Tottenham has yet again thrown up a classic example of Millbank imposing a member of the fragrant barristocracy that controls New Labour upon one of England's most deprived constituencies (Bernie Grant's legacy: Politics, race and the fight to inherit, May 25).
James Randolph
London
james_randolph@hotmail.com

 The real issues for voters should be the dire performance of Haringey council, which Grant lead for two years before entering the Commons in 1987. Policies from that period have created some of the worst poverty and crime in Britain.
Neville Collins
Tottenham, London
NevilleJulian@aol.com

fields.headline: They would, wouldn't they?
fields.standfirst: Denials are often economical with the truth
fields.trailText: Which is the least credible: a claim which is balls, another which is crap or a third which is mere garbage? Is "pure fiction" more untrue than "complete and utter rubbish"? Where exactly does "fabrication" rank?
fields.body:
Which is the least credible: a claim which is balls, another which is crap or a third which is mere garbage? Is "pure fiction" more untrue than "complete and utter rubbish"? Where exactly does "fabrication" rank?

These are the questions the spin doctor has to weigh as he thumbs through his phrasebook of denial. Yesterday we were treated to a full-scale deployment of the vocabulary of dismissal, occasioned by our report of a telephone call between Tony Blair and Bill Clinton (further details of which we provide today). The terminology favoured by this administration tends to be robustly Anglo-Saxon: "bollocks" is a favourite. Margaret Thatcher's mouthpiece, Bernard Ingham, preferred quainter, Beano-style lingo: "bunkum and balderdash" was a regular knock-down. US press secretaries have tended to favour more technical formulations: a claim is not so much untrue as "inoperative".

The trouble is, denial has become a tricky act to pull off for the governing class: their denials have too often been found to be economical with the truth themselves. Ever since John Profumo told the House of Commons, "There was no impropriety whatsoever in my acquaintanceship with Miss Keeler," we have become slightly sceptical of denials from those at the top. Let us recall Richard Nixon insisting that "I am not a crook," or Mr Clinton himself telling a watching world and wagging his finger to declare: "I did not have sexual relations with that woman, Monica Lewinsky."

Or we can look closer to home. In 1998 the prime minister's official spokesman, Alistair Campbell, landed in hot water when he dismissed as "crap" and a "complete joke" reports that Mr Blair had had a phone conversation with the then Italian prime minister, Romano Prodi, touching on Rupert Murdoch's commercial plans in Italy. The reports were denied and denied and denied. Until, that is, Mr Campbell had to admit they were true after all.

fields.headline: Clinton and the RUC
fields.trailText: Jonathan Freedland (Comment, May 25) juxtaposes President Clinton's opposition to the new Northern Ireland policing bill's divergence from the Patten report with the president's comparison of an overwhelmingly Protestant RUC to an all-white Alabama or Georgia police force. Since Mr Freedland offers no description of the policing bill's content, he tendentiously implies that the bill purports to leave the RUC nearly 90% Protestant.
fields.body:
Jonathan Freedland (Comment, May 25) juxtaposes President Clinton's opposition to the new Northern Ireland policing bill's divergence from the Patten report with the president's comparison of an overwhelmingly Protestant RUC to an all-white Alabama or Georgia police force. Since Mr Freedland offers no description of the policing bill's content, he tendentiously implies that the bill purports to leave the RUC nearly 90% Protestant. In fact, it does nothing of the kind. The bill retains the Patten report's aim of recruiting equal numbers of Catholics and Protestants, and indeed incorporates a substantial majority of the report's operational recommendations.
Jonathan Stevenson
International Institute for Strategic Studies
 Bill Clinton understands the political difficulties of implementing the Good Friday agreement better than Tony Blair or Bertie Ahern.

Both Clinton and Chris Patten recognise that an unreformed RUC (including the name change) will have no chance of recruiting officers from nationalist communities. Clinton's analogy of the unacceptability of an all-white police force in places like Alabama demonstrates that, like Patten, he is aware that a respected cross-community police service is essential to establishing a genuine and permanent peace as opposed to the current precarious situation of a "cessation of hostilities".

The dogged determination of the UUP to hold on to the RUC, "warts and all", vindicates the long-held beliefs of nationalists that the RUC has never been anything less than an armed loyalist militia.
Ignatius Vroop
London
ignatiusvroop@hotmail.com

webTitle: Queen Mother opens public space she inspired

fields.headline: Queen Mother opens public space she inspired
fields.standfirst: The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: Civil servants who occupied Somerset House for centuries could not have known it, but their fate was sealed 10 years ago when the Queen Mother glanced out of a window into the courtyard.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
Civil servants who occupied Somerset House for centuries could not have known it, but their fate was sealed 10 years ago when the Queen Mother glanced out of a window into the courtyard.

In 1990 she was there to open the Courtauld Institute Galleries, the first arts invader to start nudging out the civil servants.

Eric Fernie, director of the Courtauld, revealed yesterday that the Queen Mother had looked out of the window and remarked: "What a beautiful courtyard - it is a pity about the motor cars."

The fate of the 144 civil servants who enjoyed the most elegant parking spaces in Britain was sealed.

The rest was history, and over £40m in grants from government, lottery money and private donations. Yesterday the Queen Mother returned to declare the palatial riverside building in London a public open space - giving her daughter, who opened the Dulwich Picture Gallery, south London, yesterday morning, a rare afternoon off in the stream of recent openings of giant lottery-funded arts projects.

The courtyard, the river terrace - blocked off since the 19th century - and a new pedestrian bridge linking the building to Waterloo Bridge, open today, along with the priceless Gilbert Collection of gold and silver. The first outdoor concert will be held in the courtyard on bank holiday Monday, and cafes and restaurants open next month.

By autumn the most elaborate fountains in London will be switched on in the courtyard, and a rotating collection of treasures on loan from the Hermitage in St Petersburg, one of the world's most famous museums, will also open.

Somerset House was built during the later years of the 18th century, on the site of a 16th century royal palace famous for its beau tiful riverside gardens. It is regarded as the architectural masterpiece of Sir William Chambers.

It was the first purpose-built civil service complex, with almost 1,000 rooms originally housing the Navy Office and other government offices.

fields.headline: Rising in the east
fields.standfirst: The new Chinese century starts here
fields.trailText: The vote in the US Congress to normalise trade relations with China is a watershed event whose huge significance stretches far beyond the confines of Capitol Hill. It is also an enormous, two-way gamble.
fields.body:
The vote in the US Congress to normalise trade relations with China is a watershed event whose huge significance stretches far beyond the confines of Capitol Hill. It is also an enormous, two-way gamble. The decision has its roots, in an historical sense, in the crude efforts of 19th-century European powers to expand and control the China trade by gunboat diplomacy and unequal treaties. It is the lineal descendant of Deng Xiaoping's cautious opening to the west a generation ago. Right now, it can be seen as a signal victory for Presidents Bill Clinton and Jiang Zemin who, for different reasons, had much riding on this vote. In the immediate future, and following a similar agreement with the European Union last week, it paves the way for China's accession to the World Trade Organisation (WTO), dramatic tariff reductions (especially in hi-tech products), a surge in foreign investment, and unprecedented access to China's 1.3bn consumers. But in the longer term, the decision is likely to have fundamental consequences for China's political organisation, society and culture, and for US strategic, economic and military global dominance. It potentially makes of China the superpower which it believes itself to be by right and destiny, with all the good and bad that may entail. It is a decision which will eventually touch all our lives.

China's leaders prefer to view WTO membership, first and last, as a wholly economic breakthrough. In the limited sense that increased trade can bring increased prosperity, they are right. Internally, the decision is also a triumph for reformers over communist hardliners and ideologues. But the impact on China's already ailing state monopolies, its heavy industry, its peasant agriculture, and on the urban and rural workforce, is likely to be highly dislocating - and very risky. Rising consumer expectations, greater affluence, freer conventional and electronic information flows, increased labour mobility, and deeper exposure to western culture will have an incalculable, unavoidable effect on political discourse. China yesterday angrily rejected renewed US attempts to link freer trade to human rights monitoring. But the present-day activities of dissidents may soon seem like very small beer for rulers faced by an entire population rapidly awakening to the possibilities of individual as well as collective advancement, demanding the right to speak out as well as to buy and sell, and wanting to choose what they do, where they go, and who leads them. Encapsulated in this week's decision may lie the seeds of final oblivion for China's 50-year-old communist era.

For America and the west, the Chinese market, despite many disappointments, remains a sort of business Shangri-la. The idea of selling cars to all those cyclists (whatever the consequences for global warming) leaves hard-faced Detroit motormen slavering with anticipation. There is altruism, too. Many sincerely believe with Mike Moore, the WTO chief, that a rule-based trading system is the key to global felicity. Why should the Chinese people be excluded? But for all its confidence in the self-fortifying power of unfettered capitalism, the US is also plunging deep into the unknown. It is also an enormous, two-way gamble. The decision has its roots, in an historical sense, in the crude efforts of 19th-century European powers to expand and control the China trade by gunboat diplomacy and unequal treaties. It is the lineal descendant of Deng Xiaoping's cautious opening to the west a generation ago. Right now, it can be seen as a signal victory for Presidents Bill Clinton and Jiang Zemin who, for different reasons, had much riding on this vote. In the immediate future, and following a similar agreement with the European Union last week, it paves the way for China's accession to the World Trade Organisation (WTO), dramatic tariff reductions (especially in hi-tech products), a surge in foreign investment, and unprecedented access to China's 1.3bn consumers. But in the longer term, the decision is likely to have fundamental consequences for China's political organisation, society and culture, and for US strategic, economic and military global dominance. It potentially makes of China the superpower which it believes itself to be by right and destiny, with all the good and bad that may entail. It is a decision which will eventually touch all our lives. China's leaders prefer to view WTO membership, first and last, as a wholly economic breakthrough. In the limited sense that increased trade can bring increased prosperity, they are right. Internally, the decision is also a triumph for reformers over communist hardliners and ideologues. fields.headline: Meacher praises organic farming
fields.standfirst: Countryside in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: The government is considering another substantial increase in money for organic farming after being presented with "comprehensive" evidence that it supports far more wildlife than conventional farming.
fields.body:
The government is considering another substantial increase in money for organic farming after being presented with "comprehensive" evidence that it supports far more wildlife than conventional farming.

Michael Meacher, environment minister, yesterday said there was a question over funding - even though state aid in England is to double from £11.5m a year to £23m by 2004 - and hinted that further sums would be announced in the summer.

He commended evidence from research over the past 13 years, compiled by organic flag-bearers, the Soil Association, which concluded that farms using their methods grew five times more wild plants and 57 extra species than other farms; had up to 44% more birds, including twice as many breeding skylarks; and 1.6 times more insects and invertebrates, which provide food for birds.

The material was drawn from 23 research projects, mainly in southern lowlands, funded from sources including the government. Campaigners for organic farming presented the material after Elliot Morley, minister for the countryside, urged them to provide concrete, rather than anecdotal, evidence of benefits.

The results, and ministers' reactions, were a boost for campaigners after rows between scientists over whether organic food is safer or better for people than conventionally grown crops and livestock.

Mr Meacher said the association's report set out evidence "comprehensively, forcibly and effectively", and he gave strong hints of extra funds.

Tony Blair has set a target of 9% of farmland to be using organic methods by 2006, three times present levels, but many MPs do not think this is enough.

Mr Meacher was careful not to criticise Mr Blair but said: "This is an acutely important issue the government must continue to review, and will. There is no question that organic farming is good for biodiversity, good for the natural countryside, good for the whole web of life."

He delighted the organic lobby further by noting: "There is no denying there are some aspects of intensive agriculture which have had a devastating impact in and around our fields."

The government was still considering measures to limit the use of pesticides, despite its shelving of plans for a pesticides tax due to the parlous state of agriculture generally.

He recognised organic aid funds had temporarily run out because there was so many applications for conversion but said ministers had been taking account of the demand. It would be July before it was known whether the Treasury would agree to more money.

Lady Young, chairman of English Nature, the government's adviser on biodiversity, said most organic food was imported, which "does not help either British wildlife or British farmers."

fields.headline: Hard times and harder words
fields.standfirst:
In the overwhelmingly Protestant community of Portavogie, the only decommissioning the locals acknowledge is of their trawlers

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: They breed them hard in Portavogie. Robert Anderson, master mariner, had considered balaclavas and baseball bats to sort out a longstanding work dispute. You have to deal dirt with dirt, he spat, admitting he was persuaded to adopt less fearsome tactics.
fields.body:
They breed them hard in Portavogie. Robert Anderson, master mariner, had considered balaclavas and baseball bats to sort out a longstanding work dispute. You have to deal dirt with dirt, he spat, admitting he was persuaded to adopt less fearsome tactics.

It was perhaps to be expected that fishermen in this overwhelmingly Protestant community would pelt with eggs the then agriculture minister Brid Rodgers, of the nationalist SDLP, when she arrived on a fact-finding mission last December. But so uncompromising are the fishermen that even Ian Paisley, unsurpassed scourge of the sellout, received similar treatment. Traitor, they taunted.

His sin? To bring along his agriculture committee three months ago. It included two Sinn Fein members, and angry scenes ensued.

The towns of Portadown, Larne and Antrim are more familiar names as bastions of Orangeism. There, conflict between the Protestant majority and Catholic minority is endemic, and often violent.

Portavogie is different, for, as recently as five years ago, it is believed there was not a single Catholic among the 1,700 population. None who would admit it anyway. Efforts to track down the handful who have moved in as the village expands were fruitless yesterday.

Even the road passing the harbour is daubed with loyalist graffiti, complex designs painstakingly etched on to Tarmac, and the kerbstones are daubed red, white and blue like nowhere else in Northern Ireland. So too is the village monument, an anchor.

The colour scheme extends to many of the 70 trawlers. There are 300 fishermen here, and times are hard. They call this Hungry May, with the tides working against decent prawn catches.

All this is a jolt as the casual driver, enjoying stunning views of the Ards peninsula , winds his way into Portavogie. The town is, though, strangely welcoming of strangers, a place where humour is black and talk straightforward.

Mark Paden, 26, who has a 22-month-old baby, is painting Jubilee Star, launched in 1977, and so named to mark the Queen's 25th year on the throne. It is on the slipway next to Princess Anne Way; the Princess Royal opened the harbour offices 15 years ago.

He says: "I voted No to the Good Friday agreement. It was a scam all along. Those who couldn't see it were blind. Not only was there never going to be any decommissioning, but it was as obvious as the nose on your face Sinn Fein were going to start misbehaving as soon as they got into government. All that stuff about the flags? How could anyone be surprised at that?"

He is referring to Bairbre de Brun and Martin McGuinness, Sinn Fein's ministers in the short-lived power-sharing executive, who decreed that no union flag should fly from their departmental headquarters, health and education respectively. It is this week one of the most striking themes of unionist anger.

The only decommissioning Paden can see is the old trawlers bought by the government to cut the fleet. They are cut up and towed to nearby Green island, where, Viking-like, they are set on fire.

Chance His colleague, Richard O'Sullivan, 39, a father of four who has just given up running a chip shop to become a fisherman, says: "I voted No, but funnily enough, once it was up and running, I wanted to see it given a chance. It needed at least a year."

Portavogie is in Strangford, the constituency of John Taylor, deputy leader of the Ulster Unionists, and the party's weathervane-in-chief. He returns from east Asia today, when he will be wooed further by Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, to rally behind the Hillsborough proposals leading to restored devolution.

Paul Carson, 27, a former fisherman at Portavogie, is the local Ulster Unionist councillor. He thinks Taylor will have handed the once-safe Westminster seat to Iris Robinson, of the Democratic Unionist party, if he backs the party leader, David Trimble, in his drive to restore the power-sharing executive.

Carson says: "I supported the agreement, believing it was a good deal, as long as the promises in it were kept. They have been thrown back in our faces, and Tony Blair's pledges ahead of the referendum campaign have proved to be worthless."

He laughs as he recalls: "I joined the party when David Trimble won as leader five years ago. I thought it would be a new beginning, and young people would be encouraged. How wrong can you be?"

Strangford, although insulated from the worst of the Troubles, is precisely where the anti-agreement camp believes it is making huge inroads. It calculates it needs to persuade four delegates to switch sides in each of the 18 constituencies to win tomorrow, and believes it is far in excess of that in Taylor's constituency.

Philip Weir, chairman of the Young Unionists, says: "One of the strangest features coming out of our canvassing is that the areas where we are making most gains are where there has been limited conflict. The border areas seem pretty much delineated."

Anti-agreement The anti-agreement camp believes Strangford went 80:20 in favour of the agreement. It now thinks it is running at no more than 60:40.

But councillor Ronald Ferguson, 47, another delegate at the Waterfront Hall in Belfast tomorrow, says: "We have no alternative, and people are realising that. I would prefer all the world was a unionist, but we have to operate in the real world. I respect Sinn Fein's mandate, and I hope they respect me too."

Leading Orangemen David McNarry, also a councillor and delegate, is a key Trimble ally, and his intervention on Good Friday two years ago was critical to the deal being sealed. He is sitting on the fence, at least in public, but he says he is an avid devolutionist.

Whisper it. But so too, is Captain Anderson, 56, who, on the advice of his friend Tommy Drysdale, 56, is fighting for his former job as harbourmaster through the ombudsman and local ministers. He is pinning his faith on the SDLP and DUP.

A strange notion, perhaps, in hardline Portavogie. But as Captain Anderson says simply: "Needs must."

fields.headline: Tripp charges dropped
fields.trailText: Another chapter in the Clinton impeachment saga closed yesterday when prosecutors in Maryland dropped their illegal wire-tapping case against the Pentagon aide Linda Tripp after a judge ruled that evidence given by Monica Lewinsky against her was legally "tainted".
fields.body:
Another chapter in the Clinton impeachment saga closed yesterday when prosecutors in Maryland dropped their illegal wire-tapping case against the Pentagon aide Linda Tripp after a judge ruled that evidence given by Monica Lewinsky against her was legally "tainted".

The White House intern's treacherous former confidante had been on course to be the only person in the Clinton-Lewinsky imbroglio to face criminal charges after prosecutors indicted her last July for disclosing the contents of a phone conversation with Ms Lewinsky which she had taped at her Maryland home. Taping of telephone conversations without mutual consent is illegal in Maryland.

Last week, however, a state judge said that almost all of Ms Lewinsky's pre-trial testimony - central to the task of authenticating the taped calls - must be ruled out. Judge Diane Leasure ruled that much of Ms Lewinsky's evidence was tainted because it relied on information given to the independent counsel Kenneth Starr under a grant of immunity.

As a result, Maryland prosecutor Stephen Montanarelli has announced that he is dropping all charges against Ms Tripp, who could have faced 10 years in prison and a $20,000 (£13,000) fine if she had been convicted.

fields.headline: Railways to get £1.6bn boost
fields.standfirst: Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: More than £1.6bn is to be clawed back by the government and ploughed into Britain's cash starved railway system, it emerged last night.
fields.body:
More than £1.6bn is to be clawed back by the government and ploughed into Britain's cash starved railway system, it emerged last night.

The money will be diverted from payments which the train operating companies are committed to making to the Treasury over the next 10 years.

Officials at the shadow strategic rail authority (SSRA) confirmed yesterday that the government had given "a nod and a wink" to the plan, which is expected to be announced during the summer.

The arrangement affects Virgin Trains, which is committed to paying back £1bn to the Treasury between 2003 and 2011. This is because it operates what is thought to be the most lucrative franchise in Britain, the west coast line route between London, Birmingham, Manchester and Glasgow.

But the Virgin service is not expected to become profitable until after 2002, by which time its tilting trains should be operating on the Manchester to London route with a journey time of less than two hours.

The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, is hoping to squeeze extra funds out of the chancellor, Gordon Brown, in the public spending round. Mr Prescott wants to announce details in July, but he is still in negotiations with the chancellor.

Mr Prescott was unable to reveal anything to the industry at a national rail summit, attended by Railtrack, the train companies and the unions.

His message to passengers was that he was on their side, and would always put safety above punctuality.

The rail regulator, Tom Winsor, told the summit that he was acting to prevent Railtrack selling railway land for commercial purposes if he thought that it was required for rail purposes.

He has written to 70 planning authorities throughout Britain asking if they have received applications from Railtrack seeking permission to develop land for commercial purposes. He said that he had been forced to send the letters because Railtrack had refused to give him the information.

Mr Winsor is investigating the exploitation of railway land by the company after intervening in a case at his own station, Staplehurst, Kent.

Railtrack wanted to sell land by the station for a supermarket, but the local train operating company, Connex, is planning to build a car park.

Mr Winsor intervened because he can use his powers to keep the land for rail use. He said: "Rail land must be protected against exploitation. I am taking this matter very seriously."

Mike Grant, chief executive of the SSRA, said that it was proposing to compensate commuters with instant cash refunds if trains ran more than 30 minutes late.

Monthly and yearly ticket season holders are refunded for poor performance when a yearly average of punctuality is taken into account. Every year 75,000 trains run at least 30 minutes late.

The Rail Passengers' Council issues a report today showing that passengers using "turn up and go" fares are paying much more than travellers on protected fares.

Its chairman, Stewart Francis, said rail fare increases were above inflation. "Rail companies often raise unregulated fares by far more than the rate of inflation to compensate for lower regulated fares."

webTitle: Carnage in New York burger bar recalls more violent era

fields.headline: Carnage in New York burger bar recalls more violent era
fields.trailText: Echoes of the lawlessness that once made America's biggest city a byword for violence sounded yesterday with the murders of five workers found shot, bound and gagged in the refrigerator unit of a fast-food restaurant.
fields.body:
Echoes of the lawlessness that once made America's biggest city a byword for violence sounded yesterday with the murders of five workers found shot, bound and gagged in the refrigerator unit of a fast-food restaurant.

All five, and two more who survived, were shot in the head during an apparent robbery at a Wendy's in Queens, New York City.

Police, who said they were looking for two young black men, were searching sewers and rubbish bins for clues and handing out Wanted leaflets.

"It probably was the worst crime scene that I've seen in the nine years I've been district attorney of Queens," said Richard Brown.

Lolita Rouquin, who works at the burger restaurant, said: "I'm really shocked. I cried because I can't believe it."

Another Wendy's employee, Olga Purdie, who went home two hours before the attack, said: "When I heard the news at first I thought 'Thank God I wasn't there'. Then I felt so sorry. It's my co-workers and I just left them last night not expecting something like this to happen. I was shook up. I just started crying."

The New York Police Department chief of detectives, William Allee said: "We believe the motive was robbery." He added: "The responding officers looked through the glass and saw two people in the restaurant area that were apparently wounded. The door was locked. They broke the glass and went in.

"They were then directed to the basement, where they saw five more victims in the refrigerator unit."

The two killers struck as the restaurant was being closed for the night, herding the seven staff - aged between 18 and 44 - downstairs to where the safe was kept.

The victims were tied up, tape stuck on their mouths and then each was shot in the head. One of the two survivors managed to untie himself and raise the alarm two hours later. The other was critically ill. Four men and one woman died.

The manager of a McDonald's a few doors away, who did not want to be named, said: "I'm frightened to come to work and my employees are scared. It's the first time it's ever happened. I don't know what to do."

Queens is the most ethnically diverse of Manhattan's five boroughs and the Flushing area, where the shootings happened, is home to Shea stadium, where the New York Mets baseball team plays, and to the National Tennis Centre, where the United States Open is held.

Mass murders are rare in the city, despite the hangover of its reputation as an ungovernable metropolis. Eight people, including the gunman, were killed in a fire after a shooting in a store in Harlem five years ago and two weeks later five people were murdered in a shoe shop in the Bronx.

Rudolph Giuliani, the mayor, ritually describes New York as "America's safest large city" and considers success in the war on crime as the finest achievement of his seven-year administration.

There were 667 murders in the city last year, a level not seen for nearly 40 years and a huge fall from the record of 2,290 set in 1990. But the rate has risen by 12.4% in the first three months of this year.

This is ascribed to a range of factors, including police wariness to act after becoming embroiled in controversy over high-profile shootings of unarmed black men and the fact that criminals jailed a decade ago are starting to be released.

Wendy's is the third-largest fast-food chain, coming after McDonald's and Burger King. The operation is based in Dublin, Ohio and has about 5,500 stores worldwide, 4,600 of them in the US.

Lolita Rouquin, who works at the burger restaurant, said: "I'm really shocked. I cried because I can't believe it." Another Wendy's employee, Olga Purdie, who went home two hours before the attack, said: "When I heard the news at first I thought 'Thank God I wasn't there'. Then I felt so sorry. It's my co-workers and I just left them last night not expecting something like this to happen. I was shook up. I just started crying." The New York Police Department chief of detectives, William Allee said: "We believe the motive was robbery." He added: "The responding officers looked through the glass and saw two people in the restaurant area that were apparently wounded. The door was locked. They broke the glass and went in. "They were then directed to the basement, where they saw five more victims in the refrigerator unit." The two killers struck as the restaurant was being closed for the night, herding the seven staff - aged between 18 and 44 - downstairs to where the safe was kept. The victims were tied up, tape stuck on their mouths and then each was shot in the head. One of the two survivors managed to untie himself and raise the alarm two hours later. The other was critically ill. Four men and one woman died. The manager of a McDonald's a few doors away, who did not want to be named, said: "I'm frightened to come to work and my employees are scared. It's the first time it's ever happened. I don't know what to do." Queens is the most ethnically diverse of Manhattan's five boroughs and the Flushing area, where the shootings happened, is home to Shea stadium, where the New York Mets baseball team plays, and to the National Tennis Centre, where the United States Open is held. Mass murders are rare in the city, despite the hangover of its reputation as an ungovernable metropolis. Eight people, including the gunman, were killed in a fire after a shooting in a store in Harlem five years ago and two weeks later five people were murdered in a shoe shop in the Bronx. Rudolph Giuliani, the mayor, ritually describes New York as "America's safest large city" and considers success in the war on crime as the finest achievement of his seven-year administration. There were 667 murders in the city last year, a level not seen for nearly 40 years and a huge fall from the record of 2,290 set in 1990. But the rate has risen by 12.4% in the first three months of this year. This is ascribed to a range of factors, including police wariness to act after becoming embroiled in controversy over high-profile shootings of unarmed black men and the fact that criminals jailed a decade ago are starting to be released. Wendy's is the third-largest fast-food chain, coming after McDonald's and Burger King. The operation is based in Dublin, Ohio and has about 5,500 stores worldwide, 4,600 of them in the US.
