fields.headline: Mexican villagers fear army attack
fields.standfirst: The anti-drugs war is being used as a cover for raids on communities suspected of aiding rebels
fields.trailText: An intricate tale of Mexican counter-insurgency strategy cloaked in the justification of the fight against drugs is being played out on the tiny stage of the indigenous community of Barranca de Guadalupe. The Indian villagers insist that they know nothing about either narcotics or guerrillas, but they shudder at what the next act might bring.
fields.byline: Jo Tuckman  in Barranca de Guadalupe
fields.body:
An intricate tale of Mexican counter-insurgency strategy cloaked in the justification of the fight against drugs is being played out on the tiny stage of the indigenous community of Barranca de Guadalupe. The Indian villagers insist that they know nothing about either narcotics or guerrillas, but they shudder at what the next act might bring.

Mexican troops have saturated the area in the name of combating opium and marijuana production, a war that under US pressure and guidance has become increasingly dependent on the military.

"Before, the soldiers came just occasionally, but now they pass through all the time. There are rumours that they are going to come for us during the night, and we don't know what to do," Portonato Flores said during a village gathering to discuss the army pressure that has prompted many residents to avoid sleeping in their houses.

Barranca de Guadalupe nestles on the steep slopes of the southern Sierra Madre, in the poverty-stricken state of Guerrero that is Mexico's prime producer of opium paste and home to two militarily weak but symbolically mighty armed insurgent groups.

"Obviously there is cultivation, but in many areas the number of soldiers deployed is disproportionate," said Abel Barrera, head of the Guerrero branch of a human rights organisation named after a Jesuit priest, Augustin Pro. "The military is involved in a surgical operation to leave the fish [the rebels] without water [potential popular support]."

Barranca de Guadalupe looks like a textbook case, the kind possibly described in the scribbled copy of the "Manual of Irregular Warfare" that Captain Porfirio Hernandez was studying in the nearby Buena Vista military camp the day he insisted he was a mere cook, and that there was nobody available to answer questions on operations in the area.

When soldiers in February destroyed what they claimed was a clandestine opium poppy field that the villagers insisted contained only aloe plants, the villagers filed a complaint against the army with the help of a local human rights group. That was followed by a series of arbitrary detentions, interrogations under torture and a mysterious murder of an alleged military informer, which was blamed on the community leader's son.

But what has really frightened the villagers is the news that the security forces are circulating a list of 23 alleged members of the Popular Revolutionary Army (EPR), including 18 people from Barranca.

"I am on the list, but if I were an armed guerrilla why would I be afraid to sleep in my house," said Rodrigo Flores, adding that he also felt scared to go to the local town, a five-hour fast walk down mountain paths or a two-hour bumpy drive along a dirt track.

The underlying counter- insurgency focus of much military activity in Guerrero could explain why the specially-trained units with all their mobility and intelligence skills have had only lacklustre success in destroying poppy fields.

The US anti-drug tsar, Barry McCaffrey, recently lauded the estimated cut in Mexican opium gum production from six tonnes in 1998 to four tonnes in 1999. But the eradication of poppy fields fell by only 8%, compared with more than 30% between 1997 and 1998.

A Mexican military analyst, Jorge Luis Sierra, said: "The military very rarely admits to carrying out counter-insurgency activities. They don't want to give that kind of recognition to the armed groups."

Compared with the Zapatistas of Chiapas, with their charismatic leader, Subcomandante Marcos, and their clearly identifiable areas of support among the indigenous population, the guerrillas in Guerrero are far more clandestine, but are trying to build bridges with communities in a state that is historically perhaps the most socially fragile and politically explosive.

"The only effective strategy of contention is to destroy the groups completely. Not only their military capacity but their logistical infrastructure and any support they might have," Mr Sierra said.

Members of a local pressure group, the Coordinator of Peasant and Social Groups, say that Barranca de Guadalupe has attracted military attention because its efforts to set up community projects to improve basic living conditions were viewed as too radical.

"Perhaps they [the military] think that at any moment it could all explode, that these people who have so little to lose might take the decision [to link up with the rebels]," said Onesimo Gil, whose name is on the list of alleged rebels.

Mr Gil, a committed believer in "organisation" as the motor of change, condemned the "simplistic logic that assumes that if you are critical of the system you are a guerrilla".

Looking out over a spectacular mountain ravine that pans out below Barranca de Guadalupe, a grinning Andrea Eugenio, 19, mused on her vision of "organising to make things better, to be free".

But a few hours before she had been far from smiling when the pick-up truck she was travelling in to the village was stopped by a military patrol. "We are applying the federal law against arms and the permanent struggle against drug trafficking," said Captain Miguel Aredondo.

But a less tight-lipped soldier admitted the tangential nature of the search. "We don't really think they have anything; they are just poor peasants," said Enrique Cardenas. That, it appears, is precisely the problem.

fields.headline: Rift over lesbian rabbi
fields.standfirst: Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Members of a Jewish reform synagogue in north London have split over a decision to reject the appointment of a lesbian rabbi.
fields.body:
Members of a Jewish reform synagogue in north London have split over a decision to reject the appointment of a lesbian rabbi.

Accusations of bigotry and prejudice have followed the decision in the Finchley reform synagogue, the fifth largest reform synagogue in the country and one of the Jewish community's progressive powerbases.

Moves to appoint Melinda Carr were narrowly defeated following a heated meeting of the 800 strong community. Although Ms Carr, who has made no secret of her sexuality and is a rabbi at the smaller Ealing and East Anglia liberal synagogues, was unanimously recommended by the Finchley reform council, at the meeting she fell seven votes short of the two-thirds majority required.

In a letter to today's Jewish Chronicle a former member of the synagogue, Danny Burkeman, said: "Finchley reform has chosen to ignore the main principles of reform Judaism in favour of supporting bigoted and prejudiced views."

Mandy King, chairwoman of the synagogue, told the Guardian yesterday: "Some [were] concerned that [Ms Carr] was South African and as we already had an American rabbi that meant there would not be a British presence. But it would be naive and stupid to say that her sexuality did not play a part."

The community already has a lesbian rabbi, Sheila Shulman, assistant minister in charge of the synagogue's youth training organisation.

fields.headline: Maths error 'undermines Lockerbie case'
fields.standfirst: Libya and the Lockerbie trial: special report
fields.trailText: A British air accident investigator has told the Lockerbie trial there was a significant mathematical error in the official report on the disaster which could seriously undermine the crown's case that a bomb actually exploded inside a luggage container in the plane's cargo bay.
fields.body:
A British air accident investigator has told the Lockerbie trial there was a significant mathematical error in the official report on the disaster which could seriously undermine the crown's case that a bomb actually exploded inside a luggage container in the plane's cargo bay.

Christopher Protheroe, a senior inspector with the air accident investigation branch, said he informed prosecution lawyers in a meeting on Monday that a formula used to calculate blast wave effects after an initial explosion had been incorrectly applied in the 1990 AAIB report.

Mr Protheroe admitted under cross examination from defence lawyer. Richard Keen that correct calculation of the so-called "mach stem" phenomenon would indicate that the bomb which destroyed Pan Am Flight 103 over Scotland went off closer to its fuselage skin than originally thought.

The prosecution alleges that Abdel Basset al-Megrahi and Al-Amin Khalifa Fahima, working as Libyan intelligence agents, planted a bomb in an unaccompanied suitcase in Malta which was eventually loaded onto the doomed aircraft in London.

If the defence is able to create doubt that the bomb actually exploded inside a luggage container in the plane's cargo bay, it would be a serious blow to the crown's case.

The AAIB report indicated that damage discernible in debris from the forward cargo hold of the plane showed that the distance would have been about 25 inches (63 cm). Mr Protheroe said in his testimony on Thursday that the distance, if calculated correctly, would be around 12 inches (30 cm).

The crash killed all 259 people aboard and 11 people on the ground when flaming wreckage rained down on Lockerbie, Scotland, on the night of December 21, 1988.

Mr Protheroe told the the specially built Scottish court in the Netherlands that he was not able to remember whether the crucial calculation in the final AAIB report had been carried out by his team or by outside experts in explosive effects commissioned by the board in the course of its investigation.

"At this point I'm not certain what is the reason for that error," Mr Protheroe said.

Earlier, Mr Protheroe held up a model of the jumbo jet, with red, green and yellow patches showing how the plane had disintegrated in mid-air. Family members of the victims and of the Libyan defendants watched as he used the model and diagrams to illustrate the effects of the explosion.

Outside the court, Jack Flynn, of New Jersey, who lost a 21-year-old son in the disaster, said that he had found that part of the testimony difficult to watch. "What I was thinking about, when I saw those pictures of the wreckage reassembled on a hangar floor, was where my son had been sitting when that plane broke up," a tearful Mr Flynn said.

As another AAIB investiga tor had done in his testimony on Wednesday, Mr Protheroe described how the blast initially blew a 20 by 20 inch (50 cm) hole in the fuselage and created further "starburst fractures" and "petalling" of the plane's metal skin from the subsequent explosion of hot gases.

AAIB photographs produced in court of a partial three-dimensional reconstruction of the smashed plane showed clear evidence, Mr Protheroe said, of a "shatter zone" in the left front cargo bay almost di rectly under the second "A" in the Pan Am logo on the side of the jet's giant forward cabin.

As the morning session ended, judges were considering a defence request that a full size reconstruction of a damaged cargo container be allowed into courtroom.

Presiding judge Lord Sutherland asked that during the lunch break lawyers decide how that could be achieved and whether proceedings should be adjourned to allow the necessary work to be done.

The hearing continues.

fields.headline: 79% vote for junior doctor deal
fields.trailText: Junior doctors yesterday voted by 79% to accept a deal to improve pay and conditions.
fields.body:
Junior doctors yesterday voted by 79% to accept a deal to improve pay and conditions.

The deal was thrashed out by Department of Health negotiators and the BMA's junior doctors committee after juniors threatened to strike last September over a pay system which saw some of them earning only £4 an hour for night and weekend shifts.

From December, they will get a basic salary and supplements depending on the intensity of their job and hours worked.

The committee chairman, Andrew Hobart, said: "The new system provides the opportunity to start bringing down the hours worked by junior doctors." Hospital trusts that expoited them would "pay the price".

At present any time over 40 hours a week is overtime, paid at half juniors' hourly salaried rate - which they say means that the more they work the cheaper they are to employ. Under the new system, when they are no longer paid by the hour, trusts will have to pay more if they employ them on long, intense, anti-social shifts.

The average junior doctor now earning £24,164 will receive £25,890, rising to £31,068 in 2002.

The BMA chairman, Ian Bogle, called the contract "one of the best deals made in the last 30 years at the BMA."

Of 30,000 junior doctor members of the BMA, 14,000 voted on the new pay deal. Press Association

webTitle: Labour considers internet votes to boost turnout

fields.headline: Labour considers internet votes to boost turnout
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Ministers are considering introducing voting on the internet in line with practice in the US.
fields.body:
Ministers are considering introducing voting on the internet in line with practice in the US.

The move is being considered by ministers as part of a fresh attempt to find some way to increase the declining turn-out in local elections.

They also intend to introduce postal balloting in all local elections, before making it available in general elections. Experiments in the local elections earlier this month showed postal balloting was the only new voting method that had a positive impact on turn-out.

Voting on Sundays or at supermarkets failed to improve voting figures.

The reform would not be introduced in time for the next general election since it might require primary legislation.

British based advisers to Al Gore, the Democrats' presi dential nominee, have already seen internet voting used in some of the state Democrat primaries and believe it will be popular with younger generations of voters.

The technology is said to be relatively easy, so long as voters are given secure passwords, something the government intends to do as part of its drive to provide more government services online .

"We have got to do something radical to get voters out," one minister said. "We are looking more and more at electronic democracy."

Ministers have been advised that on current trends turn-out will fall below 70%at the next general election, reflecting a growing disillusionment with politics.

A group of MPs, led by Peter Hain, the Foreign Office minister, have been pressing the government to consider compulsory voting, a requirement in Australia. Mr Hain submit ted a detailed paper on the issue to the home secretary, Jack Straw.

He regards voting as a civic duty comparable to paying taxes.

Mo Mowlam, the Cabinet Office minister, is already funding an inquiry into declining public participation in politics. She has said she is opposed to compulsory voting, but expressed the view that she may yet find herself in a minority amongst Labour MPs.

fields.headline: Shoplifter picks up £333 bill
fields.trailText: A successful civil case to make a shoplifter pay costs may point the way for the retail industry to an additional deterrent to theft.
fields.body:
A successful civil case to make a shoplifter pay costs may point the way for the retail industry to an additional deterrent to theft.

Last November Trago Mills, which runs three large stores in Devon and Cornwall, began a policy of billing shoplifters for £80 to cover the time of security staff who apprehended them. Of 100 cases, most have paid up despite their having received merely a caution from police rather than being prosecuted.

Andrew Payne, 30, was caught at one shop near Liskeard days after the policy began. Though convicted of theft by Bodmin magistrates, he contested the £80 in Bodmin small claims court.

Solicitors for the shop argued that, as well as the criminal offence of theft, he had committed the civil tort of conversion, and sued him under the 1977 Interference with Goods Act.

District judge Lee Thomas ordered Payne to pay the £80, plus £3.52 interest and £250 claimant and court costs, a total of £333.52. Four packs of rewriteable CDs were recovered at the time, so the store did not claim their cost of £47.96.

A spokesman for the British Retail Consortium, which represents 90% of shops, said: "This is an avenue many other retailers are keen to explore. There is no one magic bullet to the problem of shoplifting but our members feel civil recovery could be very effective."

webTitle: MEPs force pace on smoking warnings

fields.headline: MEPs force pace on smoking warnings
fields.standfirst: The European Parliament: special report Smoking: special report
fields.trailText: MEPs have voted for almost half of every cigarette packet made or sold in Europe to be covered with health warnings and possibly pictures of cancerous lungs.
fields.body:
MEPs have voted for almost half of every cigarette packet made or sold in Europe to be covered with health warnings and possibly pictures of cancerous lungs.

If the proposal is agreed by health ministers of the member states of the European Union, 40% of the front of packets will be given over to warnings as well as half the space on the back.

This would represent a massive defeat for the industry; it is currently obliged to cover 4% of the area of packets with warnings in Europe, and 6% in the UK.

Nicotine and tar levels would have to be reduced, the MEPs propose, and manufacturers would be banned from describing their products as "low tar" or "light" or "mild".

Minimising the impact of health warnings by placing them in a web of complicated and colourful graphics would not be allowed; warnings would have to be printed on a black and white background.

Individual EU countries might be allowed to make manufacturers reproduce on their packets graphic pictures of smoking-related illnesses, as part of the proposal adopted by the European parliament's environment committee.

Chris Davies, Liberal Democrat MEP for the north-west of England, proposed this amendment, and he said he believed yesterday's vote was of crucial importance. "If people want to smoke, that's their right. But let's not for a second allow cigarettes to be regarded as any normal product. "

Mr Davies said he expected the full assembly next month to ratify the committee's decision: "This is a good marker for what the full parliament will do in three weeks time."

EU health ministers will also have to vote to accept the rules before they acquire any force, but MEPs believe many are in favour of a harsher regime.

The idea for using pictures came from Canada, said Mr Davies. Images comparing healthy and cancer-choked lungs, and a drooping cigarette representing a smoking-induced lower male sexual drive, were two of a range of possibilities, he said.

The proposed rules would apply to cigarettes sold within the 15-nation EU and also cover exports of cigarettes produced here.

A proposal from the European commission to require cigarette manufacturers to cover 25% of each packet with health warnings has been described by the industry as "excessive"; it wants instead a 10% ceiling to allow manufacturers to include promotional material and other information about their product. It has threatened to move manufacturing outside Europe if the commission goes ahead.

A spokesman for Forest, the group which campaigns for smokers, was dismissive of yesterday's vote: "This is totally pointless. It's a waste of taxpayers' money paying for MEPs to sit around debating this. I don't think there's any point having a warning any more."

fields.headline: Motorist fined after M25 deaths
fields.trailText: A motorist walked free from court yesterday over an accident in which two people died when he reversed on the M25 without lights on New Year's Eve.
fields.body:
A motorist walked free from court yesterday over an accident in which two people died when he reversed on the M25 without lights on New Year's Eve.

May Ling McDougall, a City high flyer, and Frank Jones, driver of the taxi she was in, died in a pile-up a few minutes after Waqas Ahmed reversed on the hard shoulder on to the northbound carriageway near junction 17 at Maple Cross, Herts, in 1998.

At Reading crown court, which had heard there were no bulbs in the car's rear lights and no hazard lights on, Ahmed, 24, a computer engineer now of Dundee, was cleared of causing death by dangerous driving and dangerous driving, but convicted of careless driving. He was fined £400.

Ahmed had collided with a car driven by Clare Eyles, a purser for Virgin Atlantic Airways. As traffic stacked up, the taxi driven by Mr Jones, 53, of Amersham, Buckinghamshire, was crushed between two lorries in another accident. He and Ms McDougall, 34, of Chorleywood, Hertfordshire, who was head of risk management at the Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi in London, were killed instantly.

Miss Eyles, 31, who has not worked since because of a back injury, said: "I didn't really care about him going to prison; I just wanted to make sure he never drives again."

Ahmed told the court he stopped on the hard shoulder when his rev counter played up but could not explain why his car veered across the carriageway. Judge Bruce McIntyre said the careless driving of lorry driver Matthias Harkness, fined at a separate hearing, was the more immediate cause of the deaths. Press Association

webTitle: Woman with cyst paid for 'baby' error

fields.headline: Woman with cyst paid for 'baby' error
fields.trailText: A woman who was told by her doctor she was nearly seven months pregnant when in fact she had an ovarian cyst has received compensation from her health authority.
fields.body:
A woman who was told by her doctor she was nearly seven months pregnant when in fact she had an ovarian cyst has received compensation from her health authority.

Karen Jones, of Cannock, Staffordshire, visited her GP, Pinakin Thaker, after feeling pain in her back and stomach. After further visits, in October 1997 he told her that he could hear a heartbeat and that she was 24 weeks pregnant.

Miss Jones and her partner began making preparations for the birth. But when she visited Cannock Chase hospital for a scan she was told that she actually had a large ovarian cyst.

She underwent emergency surgery to remove the tube and ovary.

Miss Jones settled out of court. Her solicitor, Helen Bradin, said she was unable to reveal the damages awarded by Staffordshire health authority, but it was less than £5,000.

She said: "Karen was awarded damages for the pain and psychological effect that this had upon her life due to the fact that she and her partner thought that they were going to start a family they had wanted for so long.

"Her GP advised her, without proper foundation, that she was pregnant. Karen and her partner were devastated when they found that they were not going to start a family."

fields.headline: Detention law 'an abuse of rights'
fields.trailText: Ministers have admitted that their plan to detain psychopaths deemed to be dangerous could mean unconvicted people being locked up until they die.
fields.body:
Ministers have admitted that their plan to detain psychopaths deemed to be dangerous could mean unconvicted people being locked up until they die.

Paul Boateng, home office minister, told MPs that the overriding interest of public protection meant some people should be held until a time, "if ever", that the risk they posed was minimised.

His remarks will fuel opposition to the plan for preventative detention of up to 2,500 people, almost all men, considered to have a severe psychopathic or personality disorder. Up to 600 of them are living in the community.

However, Mr Boateng sought to calm civil liberty fears by saying it was "almost inconceivable" that people with unblemished criminal records would be forcibly detained.

The government is expected before the next general election to move forward on its plan, drawn up after the conviction of Michael Stone for the murder in Kent of Lin Russell and her daughter, Megan, and the attempted murder of Megan's sister, Josie.

Stone, who had several previous convictions, has a personality disorder considered untreatable by some psychiatrists. It has been claimed that he sought, and was refused, treatment before the killings.

In a consultation paper last summer, ministers proposed either detaining "dangerous" people in hospitals and prisons or setting up a separate service for them, as in the Netherlands.

The home affairs select committee has backed the latter option, but warned it would prove "exceptionally difficult" to justify detention of somebody who has never been convicted of a serious offence. It said no other country interned non-offenders in such a way.

Mr Boateng, addressing the Commons health committee, said the authorities were powerless to apprehend people they knew would offend but were not considered to have a treatable mental illness.

Ministers were confident that European human rights provisions would not be breached, Mr Boateng said. "It is almost inconceivable that this would apply to somebody who had never had any previous contact with the criminal justice system".

Such assurances are unlikely to appease critics of the plan. Peter Brand, Liberal Democrat MP for the Isle of Wight, told the minister that "this is how Russia functioned with their mental hospitals".

The Royal College of Psychiatrists has said it is "very concerned that psychiatrists should be involved in extending the sentence of those who have committed a crime or in imposing one on those who have not".

fields.headline: Pilot dies in runway collision
fields.trailText: Experts from the air accident investigation board were yesterday helping French authorities after a British co-pilot died in a runway collision at Charles de Gaulle airport outside Paris.
fields.body:
Experts from the air accident investigation board were yesterday helping French authorities after a British co-pilot died in a runway collision at Charles de Gaulle airport outside Paris.

The dead man was named as John Andrews, 44, a father of four from Little Billing, Northamptonshire. The pilot, who was last night in hospital with injuries described as not life-threatening, was named as Gary Grant, 42, from the Midlands.

The two men were preparing to take off on a mail flight for Britain when the accident occurred, at about 3am on the airport's northern runway. Their Shorts-330 twin-engined aircraft, operated by the Luton-based company Streamline Aviation, collided with a French Air Liberté passenger jet carrying 150 Spanish football fans home.

The president of the airport authority Aeroports de Paris, Yves Cousquer, said that as the Air Liberté plane was taking off, its wing struck the cockpit of the cargo plane. No one on the passenger jet, a MacDonnell-Douglas MD80, was injured.

"This is a run that we do five nights a week," a Streamline spokeswoman said. "The plane was carrying about three tonnes of mail. It's too early yet to say what happened but we have sent investigators to Paris to help out in whatever way they can."

Aeroports de Paris said a full French accident investigation team was at the scene. A judicial inquiry would be opened by the French public prosecutor's office and the transport ministry would also investigate.

fields.headline: McCartney's genius honoured
fields.standfirst: Veteran songwriter and his musical heirs feted at annual Ivor Novello awards
fields.trailText: Sir Paul McCartney was honoured as one of the greatest composers of all time yesterday after being given a fellowship by the British Academy of Composers and Songwriters at its annual Ivor Novello Awards in London.
fields.body:
Sir Paul McCartney was honoured as one of the greatest composers of all time yesterday after being given a fellowship by the British Academy of Composers and Songwriters at its annual Ivor Novello Awards in London.

Sir Paul, 57, who in 1965 penned Yesterday, the world's most recorded track, was given a minute long standing ovation at the Grosvenor House Hotel as he received the accolade and said it was a great honour.

BACS chairman, Guy Fletcher, said that Sir Paul had a "major role in changing the course of British popular music" and was "an exemplary role model for young people the world over".

The musician said that he had been watching the movie Amadeus and the scenes of Mozart composing had brought home his own role in creating music.

"I remember welling up and thinking: 'I'm one of them, I'm in that tradition,' maybe not like Mozart but I'm in that tradition. Everyone who's ever had a hit is so proud to be part of it. I'm pleased to be honoured with Lieber and Stoller, Elton, Travis and the Pet Shop Boys."

He added: "I remember coming here the very first time with my mates John, George and Ringo and sitting back there, just little kids we were, younger than my kids are now.

"It was just fantastic to be part of this whole songwriting thing. It was always just the greatest award, the greatest thing to get for songwriters and it still is many years later."

Wearing a black smock coat with a large jewel tie pin, Sir Elton John presented an award to the Pet Shop Boys and said he was glad to see a gay band win musical recognition. "I always seem to work with straight lyricists," he said, before making a crude reference to his own song Can You Feel My Love Tonight?

Sir Elton who was rewarded for his contribution to the Lion King stage show, which took an award for international achievement in musical theatre, also launched a mock attack on Canadians for knocking Candle in the Wind from their top 10 chart.

He said: "I was feeling fucking depressed because my record had gone out of the top 10 for the first time in two and a half years in Canada. What a bunch of wankers those Canadians are. I thought I am never going to write another song."

The Travis star, Fran Healy, was also celebrating after taking two titles. Travis's single Why Does it Always Rain on Me? won best contemporary song, while its author, Healy, was named songwriter of the year.

Composers who won the accolades

Best song musically and lyrically Strong, Robbie Williams

Best contemporary song Why Does it Always Rain on Me?, Travis

Best original music for TV or radio broadcast Trial by Fire, Richard Mitchell

Best original film score The World is Not Enough, David Arnold

The Ivors dance award Re-Rewind, Artful Dodger

Performing Rights Society most performed workB eautiful Stranger, Madonna

International hit of the year Genie in a Bottle, Christina Aguilera

International achievement in musical theatre Composers of the Lion King including Sir Tim Rice and Sir Elton John

PRS outstanding contribution to British music Neil Tennant and Chris Lowe (Pet Shop Boys)

Jimmy Kennedy award Geoff Stephens

Outstanding song collection Madness

Songwriter of the year Fran Healy (Travis)

Special international award Jerry Leiber and Mike Stoller

Academy fellowship Sir Paul McCartney

webTitle: Sierra Leone refugees say rebels enslave children to dig for gems

fields.headline: Sierra Leone refugees say rebels enslave children to dig for gems
fields.standfirst: Sierra Leone: special report
fields.trailText: Camp Splendid's residents long ago judged Sierra Leone's reality much better than the politicians. When peace was proclaimed last July, the 8,000 refugees did not celebrate. When the UN said the war was over, none made the long trek back home. And when the rebels went back to war this month, no one was surprised.
fields.body:
Camp Splendid's residents long ago judged Sierra Leone's reality much better than the politicians. When peace was proclaimed last July, the 8,000 refugees did not celebrate. When the UN said the war was over, none made the long trek back home. And when the rebels went back to war this month, no one was surprised.

They had seen the Revolutinary United Front in action and had learned in the worst possible way what its war was really about.

The refugees arrived in Camp Splendid, in the southern city of Bo, more than a year ago after the rebels descended on the diamond-rich Kono district. The RUF ordered entire villages emptied, and villagers were murdered at random to speed up the exodus. But the rebels were keen to hang on to the children, as tens of thousands of people fled in all directions.

Mary Kamara lost both her children in the flight from Kono. She was separated from her 10-year-old daughter on the 100 mile or more march through the bush to Bo. Her 15-year-old son was snatched by the rebels.

"The rebel who took him told me that that if I ask him to let the boy go he would kill me. I wanted to speak but he pointed the gun, and I gave him cooking oil and he didn't kill me," she said. Her son, she said, "used to brush for me and collect the wood. Right now I have no one to brush. I don't know what has happened to him."

In the chaos of flight, the refugees could do little more than try and keep their families together and stay alive. There was no time to think about why the rebels were so keen to grab the young men, yet drive everyone else away.

But after the harrowing walk to the relative safety of Camp Splendid, Ms Kamara and the other refugees began to swap stories. They concluded that the RUF had taken the youths and able bodied men to work as forced labourers on the diamond mines that fund the rebels' war against the people of Sierra Leone.

"They were trying to get us out from the district and to capture forced labour to dig for diamonds," said Joseph Sahl Bendu. "They were looking for men from 12 years. As soon as I heard I fled, but they captured my nephew. I spent two months in the bush. The rebels killed so many people. They torture you to show where you have put your belongings. They look for diamonds and food."

Some of the refugees have ventured back to Kono, but quickly returned to Camp Splendid. They report the wholesale destruction of homes to clear the ground for diamond mining, and an army of labourers digging in the myriad of open cast mines.

"Some of my family went to check there in Kono," said Ms Kamara. "They said the rebels burned houses so they could look for diamonds. Conditions are not good. There is a food problem and no medical facilities, and the rebels are in charge."

When peace was proclaimed in July there were not many in Camp Splendid who believed the war was over. Ms Kamara's elderly mother also survived the flight from Kono. Kumba Abu Kamara once worked as a nanny for the Englishmen who ran Kono's mines in colonial days. She said she had seen too much to believe that Foday Sankoh, the rebel leader, and his men were ever interested in sharing power.

"That terrible Sankoh was not agreeing to peace at all. He went on killing people in the bush and he went on taking the diamonds. We wanted to go home, but we all knew it was not safe," she said.

So the refugees stayed put, even though life is not easy in the camp. The women rely on the World Food Programme to feed their families. Ironically, some of the young men are doing just the work they fled Kono to avoid - digging for diamonds.

Half an hour's drive south from Bo, a myriad of diggings appears on either side of the road. Thousands of youths work in teams of four - one to shovel the earth into a large rudimentary sieve, another to pour in buckets of water and the other pair to work the mud with their spades in the hope that a tiny diamond will emerge at the end.

But there is a crucial difference. If the frantic diggers get lucky they will be rich by the standards of Camp Splendid, not funding a war that its victims fear will never end.

Sierra Leone's president, Ahmed Tejan Kabbah, yesterday yesterday assured Britain that thousands of guns being supplied to the government will not fall into the hands of child soldiers.

In talks with the British high commissioner, Alan Jones, Mr Kabbah said all soldiers under 18 would be demobilised from pro-government forces and sent home. Mr Jones also won assurances that a 14-year-old child soldier pictured carrying what appeared to be a British rifle had been disarmed.

In talks with the British high commissioner, Alan Jones, Mr Kabbah said all soldiers under 18 would be demobilised from pro-government forces and sent home. Mr Jones also won assurances that a 14-year-old child soldier pictured carrying what appeared to be a British rifle had been disarmed.

webTitle: Ministers pressed to destroy GM crops

fields.headline: Ministers pressed to destroy GM crops
fields.standfirst:
GM debate: special report
Greenpeace
fields.trailText: Greenpeace is threatening to take the government to court to make it order the destruction of crops accidentally contaminated by genetically modified material.
fields.body:
Greenpeace is threatening to take the government to court to make it order the destruction of crops accidentally contaminated by genetically modified material.

The environmental group also gave ministers seven days to warn farmers they could face criminal prosecution if they sold produce grown from contaminated seed. Greenpeace would start high court proceedings in a week's time if ministers did not comply, it told them in a letter.

The warning came as France followed Sweden in ordering the destruction of similarly affected crops. In the UK, ministers yesterday showed little sign of changing their view that there was no bar to farmers selling on their unwittingly tainted crop - even though some supermarkets are reluctant to use the material.

The government is also refusing to authorise compensation to farmers who are beginning to destroy their crops of oil seed rape. Advanta, the seed company involved in the mistake, said that it had not considered compensation since it was "awaiting some advice from government on what course of action to take".

The company also said that it had had little contact with government officials, beyond answering questions, since April 17 when it had informed them that thousands of acres of crops in Britain and Europe had been sown over the last two springs with seed accidentally contaminated with GM material. Some of last year's harvest will have entered human or animal food.

The government has spent weeks taking legal and scientific advice, but one insider suggested a potentially disastrous stand-off was developing because all parties were entering new legal territory. "We all find ourselves on an ice floe, we can hear it cracking and no one wants to be the first to go through."

It emerged yesterday that prominent farmers like the Marquess of Lansdowne and the RSPB had decided to destroy such crops. The peer, in a letter to the Times, stated that the government had known a fortnight before he had sown 540 acres of his cereal land in Perthshire, Scotland. He had only been informed by seed merchants last Friday.

Ministers admit there is an urgent need to set international standards for purity of seeds. But they argue that there would be grounds for destroying contaminated crops only if they were a danger to human health or the environment, and scientific advisers suggest this is not the case.

Greenpeace, which is also threatening action against German authorities, said any marketing of the "polluted' rape seed would constitute an illegal act because the European Union had not given the necessary consent for the GM material involved. The Ministry of Agriculture said it would be studying the Greenpeace letter and would respond "in due course".

Meanwhile, ministers were keen not to seem to be bounced into agreeing to seed companies' demands that Europe accepts contamination levels of up to 1% in conventional seed, because of problems of keeping seeds pure. Michael Meacher, the environment minister, said: "We shall have to take a very careful hard look at that, before we can agree ... we need more evidence of public opinion."

In Scotland , there were calls for the resignation of the agriculture minister, Nick Brown, after it emerged that officials in Whitehall had not informed counterparts in Scotland or Wales until May 15, a month after they knew. Ross Finnie, the Scottish rural affairs minister, spoke of his "deep anger and annoyance".

fields.headline: 'Missing cash' shock for lottery winners
fields.trailText: Millions of national lottery players may have been deprived of some of their winnings due to a computer fault that generated a flood of phantom tickets.
fields.body:
Millions of national lottery players may have been deprived of some of their winnings due to a computer fault that generated a flood of phantom tickets.

Camelot is investigating more than 14bn tickets sales, but a computer expert contests its claim that only a fraction of winners was affected and that no phantom ticket had won a jackpot or any prize of £50,000 and above.

On tonight's BBC1's Weekend Watchdog programme, David Armitage, who was an engineer for Camelot's software supplier, GTech, claims the scale is far worse.

The error registered some tickets twice at terminals for the game's first 3 years, although this became public only last week. From early inquiries, Camelot claimed 0.0007% of transactions were involved, around 98,000. Mr Armitage told the programme "hundreds of thousands" of tickets had been involved. "No one knows how much money has been affected," he said. "All I can say is that, on every day I looked at, there were hundreds of phantom tickets recorded on the central computer - and the phantom tickets had definitely won prizes."

In 1998 he traced the problem to the 27,000 lottery terminals in shops around the country, he said. If a terminal lid was lifted while a transaction was taking place - for example, when the printer jammed - the terminal would print the ticket as normal when the lid was closed, but would also send the same message again - creating a second, identical line of numbers on the central computer.

If the numbers turned out a winner, the parallel phantom ticket would affect every prize greater than the £10 fixed win, because all prize money is from a central pot. Mr Armitage told the programme: "It was hard to believe something so serious had gone wrong."

Camelot said it discovered only last week that a fault had been found two years ago in software supplied by GTech, a US-owned firm based in Watford, Hertfordshire. Camelot has run the lottery since its launch in November 1994 and is bidding to run it for the next seven years.

Mr Armitage claimed that in 1998 managers at GTech looked at tracing winners who had lost out. "We knew it would be complicated, and the meeting broke up without any decision. A week later I was told we wouldn't be doing anything. I was stunned."

GTech declined to respond to this allegation, but confirmed the fault was identified in 1998. A spokesman said it was cooperating with the inquiry being conducted by Camelot and supervised by the lottery commission, and would not comment further until that was complete.

webTitle: Maths team keeps buses on time

fields.headline: Maths team keeps buses on time
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Cracking the riddle of why buses turn up in threes has helped to earn more than £1m for mathematicians at Leeds University.
fields.body:
Cracking the riddle of why buses turn up in threes has helped to earn more than £1m for mathematicians at Leeds University.

Equations they devised have been bought by the biggest operator to tackle the mysteries of bunching, dawdling and other oddities in its fleet of 10,000 buses.

The contract with FirstGroup will see software programmed to account for minute details, like a few extra minutes on crews' lunchbreaks, combined with driver rosters worked out by experiments on the road in Leeds and Oldham.

Two computer-operated scheduling systems will interact with a reporting package which keeps an eye on how closely the theory of perfect bus movements works out in practice.

The sale is the biggest to date for the Leeds team, whose leader, Tony Wren, pioneered the world's first computerised train schedule 40 years ago. Regularly updated versions, usually tailored to particular conditions faced by operators, have been bought by more than 40 bus and rail companies, with increasing savings in time and money.

"We don't offer instant, computerised reaction on the day," said Professor Wren, "but the system has a range of alternative scheduling options based on different experiences of traffic." A company facing snarl-ups can switch to another scheduling arrangement, as well as using phone or radio contact to adjust buses' speed or timing.

Prof Wren, whose ground-breaking rail timetable was devised with a computer the size of a room but less powerful than a cheap modern laptop, said: "Even in cases where computerised systems were already in existence, our package consistently produces greater savings.

"We work with each operator to ensure that our systems are adapted to meet all their needs."

The six-strong team in Leeds school of computer studies is particularly strong on devising algorithms, or computer scenarios, to cope with the variables of traffic and timetabling.

FirstGroup's bus manager, Simon Hall, said the package, whose reporting component has been developed with the computer systems company Omnibus, was specific to the daily rounds of the group's 26 operating divisions. "They were willing to work with us to tailor and enhance things to meet our needs."

The "smart bus" system cannot guarantee to eliminate the three-bus cluster, however. "If the first bus is delayed by traffic fluctuations then there are more passengers waiting for it," said Prof Wren. "They take longer to board the bus than expected, and it leaves fewer people waiting for the second bus, and even fewer for the third, so the buses catch up with each other.

"However sophisticated we are in our scheduling, we can't yet eliminate that."

fields.headline: Yesterday
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Good day
fields.body:
Good day

Agriculture minister Joyce Quin announced in the Commons that Cyprus is to be included in the passports for pets scheme, enabling servicemen and women to transport their beloved dogs and cats. The pilot scheme allows pets that have been microchipped, given a rabies vaccine, and had a subsequent blood test one month later to enter Britain without having to spend six months in quarantine.

Bad day

MORI. Sir Richard Wilson, cabinet secretary, has banned ministers from taking part in the opinion poll firm's twice-yearly survey of MPs, which and asks probing questions about favourite newspapers and TV programmes. MORI chairman, Bob Worcester, above, said: "We can interview in the Kremlin and the White House, but we can't interview in Whitehall."

Today

Whitsun recess. Parliament returns on June 5.

fields.headline: Meacher wins 25% target for recycling
fields.standfirst: Minister toughens up white paper and gives conditional promise of no new incinerators as contamination fears confirmed
fields.trailText: The government yesterday set legally binding guidelines to make local councils recycle at least a quarter of all household waste by 2005. Michael Meacher, the environment minister, attacked as "pathetic" Britain's present average of 8% of rubbish recycled.
fields.body:
The government yesterday set legally binding guidelines to make local councils recycle at least a quarter of all household waste by 2005. Michael Meacher, the environment minister, attacked as "pathetic" Britain's present average of 8% of rubbish recycled.

The announcement is a victory for the minister, who has won over more sceptical colleagues to rewrite the white paper on waste. He has still to win a battle with the Treasury to get it to approve the funding to enable councils to implement the plan.

Mr Meacher also promised to limit the number of incinerators to be built in Britain. He even pledged to try not to build any at all if Britain could do without them and still meet tough European Union targets to cut the use of landfill dumps for rubbish disposal from 85% to 35% by 2016 or 2020.

He described, no doubt play fully, as "unmitigated rubbish" suggestions that the government would allow 165 incinerators to be built across the country.

Mr Meacher's protestations were at odds with the white paper itself. It says: "If we are to achieve a sustainable waste management system, then incinerators with energy recovery will need to play a full and integrated part in local and regional solutions developed over the next few years ... Waste incineration is one of the most technically highly developed waste management options at this time. The environmental performance of waste incinerators has improved immensely since the early 1990s."

He also promised to redirect the landfill tax credits scheme, which provides £100m a year for environmental projects from donations by waste companies, toward recycling schemes run by non-profit making bodies rather than private companies or councils.

Mr Meacher came under attack from the Conservatives and the Liberal Democrats, but his proposals to force through recycling received warm support from local government and some waste companies. He got a mixed response from environmentalists like Friends of the Earth; it welcomed the recycling targets but attacked ministers for supporting incinerator programmes.

Sir Jeremy Beecham, chairman of the Local Government Association, said: "We welcome the strategy, which is forward looking, imaginative and realistic. Local authorities can now make plans to meet the challenges of reducing the amount of household waste produced and of disposing of it in a more environmentally friendly way."

Sir John Harman, chairman of the environment agency, said: "The strategy is an excellent foundation for the future, but the real work and hard decisions are only just about to start. If, as a nation, we don't change our attitudes to waste, the municipal waste quantities could double in 20 years."

Peter Jones, director of Biffa waste services, warned ministers that by committing themselves to some large incinerators they were leaving the way open "for environmental and financial white elephants".

Facing facts on rubbish

 Britain's greenest council, the Isle of Wight, recycles 41.4% of household rubbish.

 Britain's worst council, Wansbeck in Northumberland, recycles 0.9%.

 Scotland, at 5.7%, has the worst recycling record in Europe; the best in Europe is Switzerland, 52%.

 Switzerland is also top in Europe for recycling glass, re-using 91% of all bottles; Britain is the worst in Europe with 24%.

 Within Britain, the worst industries for generating waste are chemical, rubber and mineral products, responsible for 9m tonnes a year.

 Use of wheelie bins by councils increased from 38% of households in 1995 to 42% in 1997.

 More rubbish is generated every year:25.9m tonnes in 1995, 27.9m tonnes in 1998.

 There are 12 large industrial incinerators in Britain and four large "energy from waste" burners in England.

 In 1998 three further large incinerators were approved and another two reached the planning stage.

webTitle: Ethiopia elated at victory in border war with Eritrea

fields.headline: Ethiopia elated at victory in border war with Eritrea
fields.standfirst:
Ethiopia: special report
Eritrea online
fields.trailText: Ethiopia claimed victory in its two-year war with Eritrea yesterday following its capture of Zalambessa, denying Eritrean claims that it voluntarily withdrew from the key border town.
fields.body:
Ethiopia claimed victory in its two-year war with Eritrea yesterday following its capture of Zalambessa, denying Eritrean claims that it voluntarily withdrew from the key border town.

"They were thrashed, they were kicked out, they were destroyed," an Ethiopian government spokesperson, Selome Tadesse, said.

An Eritrean government spokesman admitted that the Ethiopian flag now flew over Zalambessa, but denied that the Eritrean army had been forced from the town. He maintained instead that the Eritrean withdrawal was in response to a plea from the Organisation of African Unity (OAU) to withdraw. "We are going the extra mile to try and find peace," he said.

The chairman of the OAU, the Algerian president, Abdelaziz Bouteflika, has spent the last two days shuttling between both capitals to try and find a diplomatic solution to the war.

The UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, welcomed the Eritrean "withdrawal" and called on Ethiopia to respond positively. But independent military sources in Addis Ababa, the Ethiopian capital, said that after its battlefield success, Ethiopia was in no mood to accommodate the Eritrean calls for peace; they scoffed at the idea that the withdrawal had been ordered in the name of peace.

"Eritrea has withdrawn because they have suffered a humiliating defeat in the fighting of the past two weeks," said one source.

When Eritrean forces were driven out of the town of Badme in March last year, the Eritrean government also said that it was prepared to accept an OAU peace proposal, which it had previously rejected.

Observers were stunned at the speed of the latest Ethiopian victory, which they hope will bring an end to a war that began in May 1998 when Eritrea invaded northern Ethiopia. Two years of trench warfare followed, with Ethiopia finding it difficult to dislodge the Eritreans from their well dug-in positions. But this time the Ethiopian army, operating to a well-planned campaign, broke through the trench lines and swept up through western Eritrea to encircle Zalambessa.

According to one western diplomat in Addis Ababa, the Ethiopian army has evolved into "one of the most stable and important organisations on the African continent".

At least 50,000 people are believed to have died before this latest offensive began.

Eritrea only came into being as an independent country in 1993, when it won independence from Ethiopia after a 30-year battle against emperor Haile Selassie and later the Soviet-backed government of Mengistu Haile Mariam.

It remains to be seen what effect the loss of this war will have on the government of the country's founder, President Isaias Afwerki.

A western diplomat in Addis Ababa said yesterday that it was too early to say definitively what the chances were of Mr Afwerki staying in power, but speculated that at present "they don't look much better than 50:50".

"At the moment, we're looking through a cracked crystal ball, but once the dust settles on this, both [Afwerki] and his administration will have a lot of questions [from the Eritrean people] to answer."

While the political fallout from Ethiopia's victory remains difficult to predict, the obvious humanitarian consequences, already severe, look set to worsen.

Even before this latest stage of the conflict erupted two weeks ago, some 300,000 Eritreans were in need of emergency food relief, and the latest Ethiopian offensive - which has reached deep into Eritrea - has displaced hundreds of thousands more.

A spokesperson for the UN World Food Programme said that the organisation estimated that of the 500,000 Eritreans displaced by the war, two-thirds were in need of emergency aid.

As many as 100,000 Eritreans have already fled across the border into neighbouring Sudan, and it is feared that the number will rise. Sudan is itself embroiled in a civil war and it is in no position to assist the recent influx of people from Eritrea.

The Sudanese state of Kassala said recently that it had exhausted its stocks of food and medicine, and had launched an emergency appeal for international assistance.

The Sudanese state of Kassala said recently that it had exhausted its stocks of food and medicine, and had launched an emergency appeal for international assistance.

webTitle: Boy, 9, stows away on flight to the sun

fields.headline: Boy, 9, stows away on flight to the sun
fields.trailText: Airport and airline chiefs were last night investigating how a boy of nine sneaked aboard a jet without a ticket or passport.
fields.body:
Airport and airline chiefs were last night investigating how a boy of nine sneaked aboard a jet without a ticket or passport.

The boy, who is not being named, was only discovered halfway through the Airtours flight to Tenerife.

He joined 196 passengers on the journey after slipping through security checks.

Cabin staff became suspicious during the flight and discovered the lapse when they asked him for a ticket. They kept him on the plane until it reached the Canary Isles.

The boy, who was flown back to Britain on the next available flight, returned to Gatwick yesterday.

Airline chiefs were yesterday carrying out an investigation after the boy was returned to his foster parents.

The youngster boarded the 7pm flight on Tuesday. Officials believe he hid among passengers to slip through passport control. Then he mingled with the passengers and sat in one of the 37 spare seats.

The boy, who is known to airport staff, has tried to board aircraft in the past.

A Gatwick airport spokesman said: "The boy passed through a full security screening process. There was no threat to passengers, staff or the aircraft at any time."

A police spokesman at Gatwick said: "The matter is being fully investigated but we are not in any position to comment at this time without knowing all the issues surrounding this breach of security.

"The boy is below the age of criminal responsibility and so cannot be held accountable for his actions."

An Airtours spokeswoman said: "In view of this unusual occurrence we have immediately asked the airport and our handling agent to review their procedures."

Simon Evans, of the air transport users council, said the incident raised issues about security and the competence of staff checking boarding passes.

webTitle: Dioxins found in allotments near incinerator

fields.headline: Dioxins found in allotments near incinerator
fields.trailText: High levels of poisoned ash and the first suspected evidence of cancer-causing dioxin emissions were discovered yesterday in allotments surrounding a waste incinerator plant championed by the government.
fields.body:
High levels of poisoned ash and the first suspected evidence of cancer-causing dioxin emissions were discovered yesterday in allotments surrounding a waste incinerator plant championed by the government.

Residents in Byker, Newcastle upon Tyne's poorest area, have been warned not to eat any vegetables grown on their allotments for the next year. The warning follows scientific findings that some 2,000 tonnes of incinerator ash deposited there by the local authority to make pathways had contaminated content, including lead, zinc and cadmium, up to 800 times recommended safety levels.

Allotments next to the plant, where no ash had been used, recorded dioxins - the most dangerous man-made substance - at eight times recommended safety levels. This finding yesterday led Nick Brown, the agriculture minister and constituency MP, to demand urgent action. "This anomalous finding must be investigated as a matter of urgency," he said. He has already written to the health authority, council and the environment agency.

The Lancet meanwhile reported that scientists have found that the industrial explosion at Seveso, northern Italy, in 1974 which spewed out an estimated 30kg of dioxins has led to a dearth of boy babies in the area.

The Italian population study found that fathers who were less than 19 when they were exposed to the fallout were more likely than older men to have girl children. The scientists suggest that the effect of the dioxin was most marked on boys undergoing the hormonal changes of puberty - and that it was permanent.

Michael Meacher, the environment minister, launched his new waste strategy yesterday and tried to calm fears that the country will be covered with incinerators, which are known to emit dioxins.

The Newcastle findings have brought calls for a public inquiry from campaigners opposed to plans to increase the burning of waste at the Byker incinerator. Campaign spokeswoman Val Barton said: "Our food is not safe and unknown amounts of dioxins have been raining down on the people of Byker and Walker for the past 20 years. We demand a full public inquiry into this whole fiasco and expect the environment agency to commence criminal proceedings against the operators of the plant and the city council."

Researchers at Newcastle University examined 16 allotment sites where the ash was used; 13 were found to have "very heavily elevated levels of copper, lead and zinc".

The city's public works director, Barry Rowland, said yesterday: "I realise that people are concerned about the levels of contamination and felt that it was important that this information should be in the public domain.

"With the benefit of hindsight we would not have used the ash on footpaths at allotments. The environment agency has launched an investigation into the use of the ash."

Public health officials said the advice not to eat vegetables was precautionary and there was no evidence of a threat to public health. But they have barred children from playing in the ash. More tests are to be carried out.

Newcastle and North Tyneside health authority's director of public health, Tricia Cresswell, said: "The only evidence we had was of a hazard in the environment and that has now been removed. We now need the results of further testing on eggs, soil and vegetables to assess possible exposure before we can give detailed advice on any potential risk."

The Italian findings show that in Seveso, between 1977 and 1996, 346 girls and 328 boys were born to potentially exposed parents, inverting the normal gender ratio. The more dioxins in the father's blood at the time of the disaster, the more likely the couple were to have a girl. Exposure of the mother did not seem to be a factor.

Boys who were going through puberty at the time of the disaster are more likely than not to have had girl children since, even though the concentration of dioxin in their blood has since dropped to a relatively low level. The proportion of male children born to these fathers was 38.2% - well below average.

fields.headline: Solicitor defrauded legal aid of £170,000
fields.trailText: A solicitor defrauded the legal aid board of £170,000 to fund a lifestyle of mistresses, houses and fast cars, Newcastle crown court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A solicitor defrauded the legal aid board of £170,000 to fund a lifestyle of mistresses, houses and fast cars, Newcastle crown court heard yesterday.

Bernard Ridsdale-Tombling, 45, faked thousands of legal aid applications from his practice in Middlesbrough over three years. By the time of his arrest he had assets estimated at £2.5m, including several properties, two of which he had bought for mistresses.

He had cars including two Mercedes, a Jeep Cherokee, and a Mitsubishi Shogun.

Paul Worsley QC, prosecuting, told the court: "It was a case not of need but greed. For this man abused his position as a solicitor to finance his extravagant lifestyle."

Ridsdale-Tombling avoided raising suspicions by putting in claims for amounts of no more than £50. He was caught after a former employee, a retired police sergeant, tipped off detectives about the fraud.

Mr Worsley told the court: "He would get clients, many of whom were vulnerable, to sign legal aid green forms and then would fill in the blanks and claim the money.

"A lot of the time he would claim for 30 minutes work when he had only ever carried out five or 10, or claim for work he never carried out."

When fraud squad officers arrested the solicitor they unearthed a double life.

He and his second wife, Amanda, and his two young children lived in a luxury £500,000 home on Middlesbrough's exclusive Normanby Hall Park estate.

He provided his mistress of seven years, who had changed her surname to his by deed poll, with a £250,000 house in Teesside and a Mitsubishi Shogun car.

Another mistress owned a luxury home and car, while the lawyer and his wife each drove £80,000 Mercedes sports cars.

He invested thousands of pounds in accounts he had opened falsely using the names of other members of his family.

Ridsdale-Tombling was known as a charmer but to staff at his practice, which he had run for 19 years, he was a tyrant and a bully, the court heard.

He told police he had carried out the fraud to "get back" at the board for withholding previous payments.

He had been convicted at Sheffield crown court in October 1998 of indecently assaulting a woman client. He was struck off the solicitors' roll in July 1999 after losing an appeal against his 15-month sentence.

He admitted obtaining money by deception at Newcastle crown court in April this year, along with matters relating to false bank accounts.

The prosecution is expected to make an application to confiscate the assets he gained through fraud. He was remanded in custody and is expected to be sentenced today.

webTitle: Dancer died in fall from ballet stage

fields.headline: Dancer died in fall from ballet stage
fields.trailText: An inquest heard yesterday how a ballet dancer died in a stage accident while trying to help the director of his new production.
fields.body:
An inquest heard yesterday how a ballet dancer died in a stage accident while trying to help the director of his new production.

Alexander Money-Kyrle, 35, a former pupil of the Royal Ballet School, fell 10ft into an orchestra pit while rehearsing Romeo and Juliet with the Dutch National Ballet in Amsterdam in 1998. He had rushed forward to try to rescue the artistic director, Wayne Eagleing, who had fallen into the pit after mistaking dark safety netting for part of the stage.

The inquest at Chippenham, in Wiltshire, heard that Mr Money-Kyrle, whose family live near Calne, in Wiltshire, died two days later in hospital from head injuries.

In a report read out to the inquest, the Netherlands equivalent of the health and safety executive suggested there was insufficient lighting of the stage at the Met Musik Theatre. Inspectors concluded: "Several witnesses concluded the black netting wasn't easy to see, and that they thought it formed part of the stage." The inquest also heard that during rehearsals the pit was usually raised to stage level but that day had been lowered to allow electricians access. A verdict of accidental death was recorded.

Mr Money-Kyrle's brother, Julian, attended the inquest, and said afterward that he would take legal advice as to whether there was a case against the theatre for negligence. Press Association

webTitle: Son of Evening Standard editor dies in China

fields.headline: Son of Evening Standard editor dies in China
fields.trailText: The son of Max Hastings, editor of London's Evening Standard, has died in China, it was announced yesterday.
fields.body:
The son of Max Hastings, editor of London's Evening Standard, has died in China, it was announced yesterday.

Charles Hastings, 27, died in Shanghai on Wednesday, a statement by Daily Mail and General Holdings Ltd said. He was believed to have been working as an English teacher after travelling in the country.

Max Hastings was contacted by the Foreign Office on Wednesday night and flew out to Shanghai yesterday to get first hand details of his son's death.

The Foreign Office said there were no suspicious circumstances, but the incidence of violence against foreigners is rising. Earlier this month, Shirine Harburn, a London backpacker, died after being stabbed 12 times on Paomao mountain in Sichuan, and a German executive and his family were murdered in their compound in Nanjing on April 2.

fields.headline: Ploughing through agriculture questions
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Summer in the Commons, and agriculture questions provide a riot of colour. Sitting on benches as green as rolling hills, Shona McIsaac and Joan Ruddock are both wearing yellow jackets, the colour of genetically modified oilseed rape. Joyce Quin, a junior minister, is in dark green, like a field of early barley, and Ruth Kelly sports   a suit the colour of bluebells in a sunlit copse.
fields.body:
Summer in the Commons, and agriculture questions provide a riot of colour. Sitting on benches as green as rolling hills, Shona McIsaac and Joan Ruddock are both wearing yellow jackets, the colour of genetically modified oilseed rape. Joyce Quin, a junior minister, is in dark green, like a field of early barley, and Ruth Kelly sports a suit the colour of bluebells in a sunlit copse.

Only Anne McIntosh, Tory MP for the Vale of York, trim and elegant in her brown jacket, reminds us of the sombre hues of winter. But Ms McIntosh has no need for artificial cheer. She leads a life crammed with exciting incident, all of which she faxes to our Guardian office here at Westminster.

"MP queries council bid for new tennis centre," we learn. "MP says, let's talk more pork!" and "Just the ticket! MP debates bus services in Vale of York."

One recent arrival records: "MP puts Vale of York on the map", which is kind of her, though not strictly necessary. It's a vale, near York.

Other Tories attacked the agriculture minister, Nick Brown, who they detest because he seems so nerdy. On pigmeat prices, Edward Leigh said that the French would never put up with the situation. "We want a minister who is less nice, and acts more like a Frenchman!"

(He didn't say which Frenchman, but Marcel Marceau would be my choice. His speeches were so short.)

"Bonjour, Madam Speaker," said Mr Brown, to howls of laughter. This is an example of parliamentary humour, being completely unamusing out of context, but at the time, frightfully dreary.

Mr Brown had a reply, one of those superb pieces of jargon which modern farming tends to throw up. "Supply exceeds demand," he said, then added: "the classic pig cycle has plummeted." It sounded like the storyboard from a Warner Bros cartoon.

On we ploughed. Mr Doug Naysmith wanted to know when the full passports for pets scheme would be "rolled out". You'll know when you start to see people holding up their dobermans in the photo booths, trying to get their eyes level with the flash.

John Bercow, the doberman of the Tory benches, essayed a sneer at Peter Mandelson, not something I would ever do. Will any ministers be taking advantage of the scheme, he asked. "Will the Northern Ireland secretary's dog Bobby be an early beneficiary?"

There were many implications in this question, including the suggestion that the law might have been changed for one minister, and the faintly camp whiff which clings to single men who love their little dogs. But Mr Bercow was shot down, port engine ablaze, by Ms Quin. "You seem to have forgotten that Northern Ireland is part of the United Kingdom."

It would be an exaggeration to say that Mr Bercow looked embarrassed. He wouldn't look embarrassed if he arrived in the chamber with his hair replaced by oilseed rape. But he did look rather silly.

The jargon continued. Mr James Paice, a Tory spokesman, demanded the government "amalgamate set-aside in terms of headlands, so farmers can be persuaded to convert headlands to go to conservation set-aside," a remark which appeared to make perfect sense to everyone except me.

Only Derek Wyatt could grow lyrical about this subject. "Lapwings, skylarks, bunting and curlew numbers are growing. How can we cope if nature prefers set-aside?"

My eyes strayed to Ms Judy Mallaber, MP for Amber Valley. Her hair, a mass of red curls, made her look like a majestic copper beech. We should have set-aside in the Commons, so that birds can make their homes in those glorious tresses.

fields.headline: Points taken by French teachers
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: A groundbreaking French law meant to give unmarried couples the same rights as husbands and wives is being used by reluctant conscripts to evade military service and unhappy teachers to obtain transfers to sunnier climes.
fields.body:
A groundbreaking French law meant to give unmarried couples the same rights as husbands and wives is being used by reluctant conscripts to evade military service and unhappy teachers to obtain transfers to sunnier climes.

The pacte civile de solidarité, known by its acronym, Pacs, which after years of campaigning by gay rights groups finally became law last year, offers legal recognition for all cohabiting couples, including homosexuals.

Hailed by supporters as France's first truly modern piece of legislation for decades and denounced by opponents as effectively legalising gay marriages, it is now being seized on as a painless way to fool the authorities.

To move to a new job in a different region, French teachers must accumulate points, with the most popular jobs in the warm and stress-free south demanding the biggest total. Marrying someone from the Midi gets you lots of points - and so, now, does signing a Pacs.

"I found a guy in Avignon who's willing to Pacs with me for £300," said Marie-Ange, 32, a biology teacher in the troubled Paris suburb of Seine-Saint-Denis. "That gives me 90 extra points. With another year's service plus my bonus for working in a tough school, I should have enough to head south in 2002."

Another secondary school teacher, who asked not to be named, said he knew of four male colleagues who had signed cohabitation contracts with other men to be able to move to an area where they wanted to work.

"You have to be a little bit careful because it can backfire on you," he said. "Some people find their fake Pacs partners on the internet, but I would only do it with someone I knew. You need to be sure you can de-Pacs when you want to."

Pacs contracts - which have so far been signed by some 18,000 people including a statistically surprising 2,000 teachers - were designed to help not only young couples but also retirees or relatives who live together.

Under the law, they can file joint tax returns, share property rights and enjoy the same social welfare and inheritance advantages as families. Until now, unmarried couples in France have faced major problems with legal recognition for pensions, wills and life insurance when they separate or one of the partners falls ill or dies.

In theory, those wanting to benefit from the new rules are supposed to have lived together for at least two years. In practice little proof is needed. "I signed with my girlfiend and I've only known her for a year," said Benoit, 26.

An engineer from Normandy who has successfully put off his military service for five years to finish his studies, he has received his call-up papers for France's last full intake of conscripts, due to begin service in October.

"Conscripts who are married or have signed a Pacs can be excused service if their partners are economically dependent on them," Benoit said. "My girlfriend's a student. Fingers crossed, but I should be fine."

A Socialist party spokeswoman said the government was aware of "teething troubles" with the law and that amendments would inevitably be introduced. "So far, though, the bill has done far more good than harm," she said.

Pacs contracts - which have so far been signed by some 18,000 people including a statistically surprising 2,000 teachers - were designed to help not only young couples but also retirees or relatives who live together. Under the law, they can file joint tax returns, share property rights and enjoy the same social welfare and inheritance advantages as families. Until now, unmarried couples in France have faced major problems with legal recognition for pensions, wills and life insurance when they separate or one of the partners falls ill or dies. In theory, those wanting to benefit from the new rules are supposed to have lived together for at least two years. In practice little proof is needed. "I signed with my girlfiend and I've only known her for a year," said Benoit, 26. An engineer from Normandy who has successfully put off his military service for five years to finish his studies, he has received his call-up papers for France's last full intake of conscripts, due to begin service in October. "Conscripts who are married or have signed a Pacs can be excused service if their partners are economically dependent on them," Benoit said. "My girlfriend's a student. Fingers crossed, but I should be fine." A Socialist party spokeswoman said the government was aware of "teething troubles" with the law and that amendments would inevitably be introduced. "So far, though, the bill has done far more good than harm," she said.

webTitle: Indonesian masseur turns knead to greed

fields.headline: Indonesian masseur turns knead to greed
fields.trailText: The official masseur of the Indonesian president, Abdurrahman Wahid, has used his position to manipulate an ambitious bureaucrat and make off with £2.8m in civil servants' charity donations, it was confirmed yesterday.
fields.body:
The official masseur of the Indonesian president, Abdurrahman Wahid, has used his position to manipulate an ambitious bureaucrat and make off with £2.8m in civil servants' charity donations, it was confirmed yesterday.

Last January the masseur, Anpeng Sui, conned Sapuan, the deputy chief of the national logistics agency, into believing that he would persuade Mr Wahid, while caressing away the presidential aches and stresses, to promote the venal official to head the government's food distribution body.

The food distribution agency is considered one of the most corrupt government bodies in Indonesia; an audit last year by the western consultants Arthur Anderson found that officials had stolen £600m during the past five years.

The price tag asked by the masseur for influencing the president was a cool 35bn ru piahs (£2.8m), or 1.4m times the average charge for an hour-long rub in Jakarta.

Mr Sapuan claimed to his then boss, Jusuf Kalla, that Mr Wahid had authorised the money to be spent on "activities" in the restive province of Aceh. He never specified what the activities were.

Mr Kalla refused to authorise the transaction after failing to receive confirmation from Mr Wahid. So Mr Sapuan, it is thought with the help of other agency employees, took the money from the employees' charity foundation account, according to Rizal Ramli, the head of the agency.

Mr Sapuan was formally dismissed yesterday and then went to the Jakarta police headquarters for questioning.

Mr Sui, meanwhile, has fled abroad. Police believe he is hiding either in Thailand or Laos, but efforts to reclaim the money may prove difficult: no one appears to know what Mr Sui looks like, and the authorities have no picture of him.
