fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Condiments: Mustard | Classic FM In Concert
fields.body:
Cookery writer Sophie Grigson considers one of those vital but rarely mentioned culinary extras which enliven so many meals. The Romans, stunned by the dank chill of the British climate, imported sinapis alba in an effort to bring a little warmth into their lives. Condiments: Mustard (3.45pm, Radio 4) traces the plant back 5,000 years, when it jollied up the Sumerian diet. Hippocrates also used it liberally to dose his patients, offering an alternative explanation for the famous oath.

For nearly 40 years the school founded by Yehudi Menuhin has helped young musicians develop their special talents as part of a broad general education. Among its graduates have been Nigel Kennedy, Tasmin Little, Kathryn Stott, Melvyn Tan and cellist Paul Watkins. Now Classic FM In Concert (9.0pm, Classic FM) offers listeners the chance to spot potential new stars when it showcases the school's string quartet. They play Dvorak's American Quartet and Janacek's Kreutzer.

fields.headline: Knowledge is power
fields.trailText: John Hannah. Now there's a man not to play at Trivial Pursuit. Not only must he know all about ancient Egypt, Ruben Carter's boxing career, police procedures in Scotland and WH Auden, he's also got an encyclopedic knowledge of natural history. Barely a week goes by without him explaining how starlings flock together or describing the movement of lava flows and glaciers on some nature programme or another. If you watched The Discovery Channel for long enough, you could probably pretend you were going out with him. But caught between Hannah and Bill Paterson, you'd end up hobbling round that Trivial Pursuit board with only a humiliated grimace and no pieces of pie.
fields.body:
John Hannah. Now there's a man not to play at Trivial Pursuit. Not only must he know all about ancient Egypt, Ruben Carter's boxing career, police procedures in Scotland and WH Auden, he's also got an encyclopedic knowledge of natural history. Barely a week goes by without him explaining how starlings flock together or describing the movement of lava flows and glaciers on some nature programme or another. If you watched The Discovery Channel for long enough, you could probably pretend you were going out with him. But caught between Hannah and Bill Paterson, you'd end up hobbling round that Trivial Pursuit board with only a humiliated grimace and no pieces of pie.

In Predators (BBC1), Hannah lent his dulcet tones to the tale of animals eating each other. Hardly a new subject, but by saying obvious - nay, meaningless - things with typical Hannah gravitas, it felt all exciting. What with Hannah, fancy camerawork and the Leftfield-esque music, it was like we'd never seen a zebra tackled down by a lioness before.

Poor zebras - surely they must know TV people aren't interested in them for their own sake. A whinny (or neigh?) must go up round the herd whenever a camera crew turn up to "hang around" with the stripy ones. "Death waits in the long grass!" they must neigh (or whinny). But with the resignation of those designated "prey" in the great scheme of things, they graze and await their fate, only occasionally fighting back. Perhaps just for the cameras.

For an actor, pretending to be Elizabeth I or William Cecil in a history programme must be one step up from appearing in a Crimewatch reconstruction. A few more opportunities for donning breeches and the odd goatee beard, and they could at least pretend they're in a costume drama.

Of course, Elizabeth (C4) was a costume drama of sorts, and the historical reconstructions - during which the players didn't say much and stared off into the middle-distance to appear enigmatic/scheming/ deep in thought - solved at least part of the problem of what to show when your presenter is conveying the driest of historical information. Better than close-ups on paintings and panning across maps, the Elizabethan docusoap bits broke up the mesmerising appearances from the man who was playing David Starkey. As he scurried across courtyards, it was all too easy to forget what he was saying and imagine him as a tiny chinchilla, getting chased by whatever chases chinchillas (Hannah has yet to reveal that nugget of information).

Reaching its conclusion with "Gloriana", Starkey's exploration of Elizabeth's reign maintained its pace and raised questions about power, the mob and royalty which still need answers today. Like the best of history documentaries, it had contemporary resonance. And it made great use of hundreds of candles - employed, one presumes, as a recurring motif to signify monarchy, but there was a touch of Habitat merchandiser throwing caution to the wind after reading Kevin McCloud's book on lighting. With Liz dead and James VI and I just another bloke with a funny beard, another series seems unlikely. All those actors will have to pack away the goatees and breeches and start impersonating car thieves.

While the gentle, academic musings of Starkey were positively soothing (even when talking about the burning of Cadiz and executing nobles), Missileers (BBC2) was the kind of scary telly that would have had the soberest of viewers building a bunker under the stairs, stockpiling enough puzzle books to last a nuclear winter.

Rene wanted to be a missileer - one of the 200 people who sit with their fingers poised above big red buttons at the FE Warren Airforce Base in Wyoming, an elite with the fate of America's 550 nuclear warheads in their hands. Literally. While the mere thought of accidentally unleashing Armageddon with a spill of your coffee would have the fainthearted running for the hills, Rene was determined. A single mistake, he explained, could destroy a missileer's career and bring shame to the entire squadron. As a man with a wife and children to support, this concerned him (much more than a mistake razing a city to dust and initiating the end of the world). But, hey, the man has bills to pay. Not a pleasant thought, though. What Missileers really needed was a "Don't have nightmares" proviso from Nick Ross. Or John Hannah.

webTitle: Tears in court as couple lose final spin of the wheel

fields.headline: Tears in court as couple lose final spin of the wheel
fields.trailText: It was the gambling world's "trial of the century" and it ended in tears this week in Las Vegas. The former girlfriend of the casino millionaire Ted Binion and her lover were jailed for life with a recommendation that they serve at least 20 years for a plot straight out of the pages of pulp novelist James M Cain.
fields.body:
It was the gambling world's "trial of the century" and it ended in tears this week in Las Vegas. The former girlfriend of the casino millionaire Ted Binion and her lover were jailed for life with a recommendation that they serve at least 20 years for a plot straight out of the pages of pulp novelist James M Cain.

Sandy Murphy, 28, who modelled costumes for topless dancers, wept as she made a personal plea for mercy following her conviction for the murder of Lonnie "Ted" Binion, 55. "I am sad for all the hopes and dreams, the wedding that will never be and the children that will never come," she told the jury who made their sentence recommendation yesterday.

Her co-defendant, Rick Tabish, 35, a small-time crook and partner of the dead man, also wept as he begged the jury: "Please let me get out while my parents are still alive." Members of the dead man's family had also wept as they urged the jury to press for a life sentence without parole.

Mr Binion was the son of the founder of Las Vegas's famous Horseshoe Club which had a reputation for never turning down a bet. The family business helped him amass a £38m fortune. But he also acquired heroin and alcohol habits which led to his disbarment from the casino and his eventual meeting with Murphy in 1995 at Cheetah's nightclub in gambling's capital. "He was drunk and I was drunk," said Murphy later.

Sandy Murphy had just ended a relationship and Mr Binion was on the point of splitting up with Doris, his wife of 15 years. She was also hard up, having just blown £9,000 on the tables at Caesar's Palace. The couple were together for nearly three years, to the disapproval of other members of the Binion clan, and Murphy seemed prepared to tolerate Mr Binion's violence towards her when he was drunk or drugged up.

Then on September 17 1998, Murphy dialled 911 to tell the emergency services that she had found Mr Binion dead at his home. There was some heroin paraphernalia beside the body and an empty bottle of the prescription drug Xanax. It had all the appearance of an overdose. The local police spokesman described it at the time as "an ingestion error in regards to medication". It turned out that Mr Binion had bought 12 balloons of heroin from a dealer the previous day.

But the night after the death police found Rick Tabish at one of Mr Binion's properties in the remote Nevada town of Pahrump on the road to Death Valley. Tabish, who had been hired by Mr Binion to build a secret storage for £9.5m in silver coins which Mr Binion had accumulated, was using an excavator to try to remove the silver from the vault.

Asked by the police how he came to be trying to remove a vast cache of silver coins at 3am, Tabish assured them that he was just following Mr Binion's instructions to remove the silver in the event of his death and pass it on to his daughter before anyone else got their hands on it.

Initially, the police seemed to believe that Mr Binion had died from an intentional or unintentional overdose but the Binion family, always suspicious of Murphy who stood to inherit around £1m and a mansion, hired a private detective to investigate.

Eventually, the district attorney's office decided that Murphy and Tabish had conspired to kill Mr Binion and get their hands on his money, money that Tabish knew was now hidden away in Pahrump. The plot had echoes of James M Cain's Double Indemnity and had an equally unhappy ending for the perpetrators. The pair were arrested and accused of having forced Mr Binion to swallow the heroin and Xanax before suffocating him.

"Take Sandy out of the will if she doesn't kill me tonight," Mr Binion was said to have told his lawyer the day before he died. "If I'm dead in the morning, you'll know what happened."

webTitle: Unionist rivals to meet before crucial vote on return to power sharing

fields.headline: Unionist rivals to meet before crucial vote on return to power sharing
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: David Trimble, the leader of the Ulster Unionists, and rival Jeffrey Donaldson, the anti-Good Friday agreement MP, will meet today in a last-ditch attempt to resolve their differences before a critical vote tomorrow of their party's ruling council.
fields.body:
David Trimble, the leader of the Ulster Unionists, and rival Jeffrey Donaldson, the anti-Good Friday agreement MP, will meet today in a last-ditch attempt to resolve their differences before a critical vote tomorrow of their party's ruling council.

Mr Donaldson has yet to produce his alternative plan to a quick return to government with Sinn Fein following the British and Irish government's Hillsborough proposals and the IRA's unprecedented offer to put arms beyond use. He asked for today's meeting.

But Mr Trimble indicated yesterday that he was against making any conditions on restoring devolution. In November he gave his 860-strong ruling council assurances that he would quit in February if there had been no IRA decommissioning by then.

It emerged last night that there would be no rush to restore devolution if tomorrow's meeting of the 860-strong ruling council supports Mr Trimble. The date pencilled in is June 5.

Mr Trimble's camp was cheered by an opinion poll in the Belfast Telegraph showing that 72% of Ulster Unionists wanted to return to the power-sharing executive now.

Ulster Unionist Michael McGimpsey, who was minister for culture, arts and sport in the executive, suspended three months ago, said: "This is a ringing endorsement for David Trimble and his tireless efforts to get the best possible deal for Unionists."

Meanwhile, it also emerged that President Bill Clinton resisted pressure from within his own administration when he rebuffed British pleas to lean on Dublin and Sinn Fein, as revealed in the Guardian yesterday.

Despite public denials in both London and Washington yesterday, US officials spoke privately of how Mr Clinton had refused to pressurise the Irish government and republicans into accepting a compromise on the proposed name change of the Royal Ulster Constabulary.

Some White House officials had urged the president to help out Tony Blair - who had explained that Unionists could refuse to enter devolved government alongside Sinn Fein if the name change went ahead. But in two phone calls with Mr Blair Mr Clinton did not budge.

As Downing Street robustly dismissed the Guardian's revelation of the Clinton-Blair exchanges yesterday as "complete and total fiction", a range of US and diplomatic sources confirmed that the president had indeed rejected moves to water down the proposals on police reform.

Coinciding with the Guardian's report yesterday were similar accounts of events - with almost all of the key details in common - in leading Irish-American newspapers the Irish Voice and Irish Echo. Both accounts were sourced to high-placed US officials close to the peace talks.

fields.headline: She's all that
fields.standfirst: When she blasted onto our screens as Anna in This Life, Scottish actress Daniela Nardini became an icon for a generation of women. But fame was never on her agenda, as she explains to  Maxton Walker
fields.trailText: When she blasted onto our screens as Anna in This Life, Scottish actress Daniela Nardini became an icon for a generation of women. But fame was never on her agenda, as she explains to Maxton Walker
fields.body:
Daniela Nardini is cripplingly shy. Famous for it. Which is no doubt why I'm standing here listening to her telling a bawdy story about an acquaintance who found some naughty pictures of her on the internet. This may sound like the perfect fantasy for some men. But I'm too shocked to listen properly to the tale, which involves her friend refusing to stump up the cash required to get the "full monty".

Actually, this is very unfair. She is, for the most part of our meeting in the plush drawing room of a west London hotel near her home, the epitome of an immaculate hostess. She jumps up to shut the door when the wind blows it open, pours the tea, and even laughs politely at an unfunny anecdote about Tom Cruise. The shyness thing (totally untrue, you'll have gathered) arose from the first interviews she did to promote This Life. "I did used to get panicky talking to journalists," she admits in a very soft version of that instantly recognisable voice. "They got confused because I wasn't at all like Anna. So they said, 'she's shy'. And I think it's also part of the Scottish thing. I don't have that English public school confidence."

It doesn't show. The only real trait that escapes from behind the effortlessly charming exterior - the sort you get from a good, austere Scottish upbringing - is the merest hint of world-weariness. Although this may only be that she's tiring of a steady stream of journalists asking the same banal questions ("It seems to be Daniela Nardini week in Scotland. Every time my dad picks up a paper, I'm in it").

She is obviously more used to the attention she receives these days, although she still remembers clearly the almost physical shock of instant fame that came with This Life. "I was pestered a lot in bars. It was ridiculous. Like being in Take That."

This was around the time, you may remember, when there were editorials in newspapers calling for senior BBC executives to be lynched after it transpired that the second series of This Life would be the last. The corporation was accused of dragging its heels until the actors moved on to other projects. But Nardini doesn't remember it that way: "We'd done 22 episodes in five months," she says. "We were like vegetables. And towards the end we all felt, well it's been great fun, these characters have been fantastic, but we have to move on."

Since then, she's made shrewd use of the springboard that This Life gave her. Instead of going on to lend spurious credibility to the rash of clones which followed, like some of her ex-co-stars - she's chosen her projects more carefully. Most memorably, we've seen her as a 60s feminist in Fay Weldon's Big Women and a plainclothes policewoman with marriage problems in Undercover Heart. She is aware, though, that nothing has quite managed to dislodge Anna from producers' minds. "I do seem to get offered the parts of professional women juggling career and emotions. Women are a strange combination of things, especially these days when there is so much pressure to be good at your work. And then when you hit your 30s, you have to think about things like: when will I have a family?"

It's odd, though, that she doesn't betray any obvious symptoms of the driven actor: no furious chain-smoking or fingernail-chewing. Nor are there any hints that she might be a pathological attention-seeker. Isn't she a bit too well balanced to be an actor? "I don't think," she admits, "that I ever wanted to be famous. The fact is, the more famous you are, the more interesting jobs you get offered." And there are days, she says, when it seems like hard work. "Sometimes I get quite tired of acting. I think how nice it must be to have a proper career and to know what's going to happen next."

What's happening now is Rough Treatment, a two-part ITV drama, starting this weekend. In her first fully fledged starring role, she plays a career-minded army officer battling sexism in the forces. When she is raped by two fellow officers she sets out for revenge. It's an odd drama in many ways - grim viewing at times, and something of an old-fashioned morality tale. Her character, Eve, is not entirely sympathetic, even unhinged at some points. But what it proves is that Nardini has the screen presence to carry a drama. And she clearly hopes it might give her the chance to try something different. No easy task, it seems. "The more you work, the more defined you come, so the stuff you really want to do actually gets less. You have to become more discerning, otherwise it's all about money. And it gets harder for women."

And for the future? She's "resting" at the moment, although she admits she'd love to do something different - a horror film, perhaps. Does Hollywood appeal? "Not really. I'm getting old and tired now [she's 33]. I don't think it's my kind of existence and I think you really have to want it. I've been up for castings with American directors but they don't know me from sliced bread and at this stage in my life, I have to ask, do I really want to humiliate myself? I'm not 25 and it just doesn't beckon very loudly. Perhaps if the right British film came along..."

It's only when I'm packing up to leave and Jo, her publicity agent, turns up that she launches into her X-rated internet story. Their dirty laughter fills the room as I walk out.

Shy girls, it seems, have all the fun.

Which is no doubt why I'm standing here listening to her telling a bawdy story about an acquaintance who found some naughty pictures of her on the internet. This may sound like the perfect fantasy for some men. But I'm too shocked to listen properly to the tale, which involves her friend refusing to stump up the cash required to get the "full monty". Actually, this is very unfair. She is, for the most part of our meeting in the plush drawing room of a west London hotel near her home, the epitome of an immaculate hostess. She jumps up to shut the door when the wind blows it open, pours the tea, and even laughs politely at an unfunny anecdote about Tom Cruise. The shyness thing (totally untrue, you'll have gathered) arose from the first interviews she did to promote This Life. webTitle: Watch this: satellite, cable and digital

fields.headline: Watch this: satellite, cable and digital
fields.trailText: Strictly Ballroom | Hannah And Her Sisters | LA Confidential | Savior
fields.body:
Strictly Ballroom (Baz Luhrmann, 1992)

8pm, FilmFour

Luhrmann starts out in near-documentary style then sweeps you off your feet with dazzling comic swirls. Paul Mercurio is quickstepping Scott, who aims to be beau of the ballroom with some daring improvisations. Wallflower novice Fran (Tara Morice) agrees to tango (well, flamenco) in this bright and knowing Aussie comedy.

Hannah And Her Sisters (Woody Allen, 1985)

10pm, Paramount

Back in Manhattan and funny with it, this is Woody Allen near his best, telling a Chekhovian tale of three sisters (Mia Farrow, Dianne Wiest, Barbara Hershey). Good to see Michael Caine extending himself as Farrow's foolish husband, chasing Hershey all over town; and Allen pondering life and death, testing Islam and Catholicism before plumping for the Marx brothers.

LA Confidential (Curtis Hanson, 1997)

12midnight, Sky Premier

Superb, dense and dark thriller with Russell "Gladiator" Crowe as a hardnut cop who teams up with colleagues Guy Pearce and Kevin Spacey to root out crime and corruption. Hanson and Brian Helgeland richly deserved their Oscars for adapting Ellroy's long, intricate novel, and the murky underworld of 50s LA is brilliantly realised, from shining chrome car bumpers to dead bodies in a diner. Kim Basinger is impressive as a nearly fatal femme, but the biggest surprise, after his kindly farmer in Babe, is James Cromwell's calculating police captain.

Savior (Peter Antonijevic, 1998)
12.20am, Sky Premier

This Oliver Stone production, set in the hell that was Bosnia in 1993, is as anti-war as movies get. A mercenary (Dennis Quaid) arbitrarily decides to escort a young mother (Nastassja Kinski) and her baby to safety. But this is no Hollywood hero: Quaid is dead-eyed and almost beyond caring, a million miles from his usual twinkling charmers. And as a picture of war, this is raw and compelling.

webTitle: Labour plan to kill anti-hunt clause

fields.headline: Labour plan to kill anti-hunt clause
fields.standfirst: The hunting debate: special report
fields.trailText: Michael Meacher, the environment minister, has authorised a deal with the Conservatives to kill a Labour MP's latest move to abolish fox hunting.
fields.body:
Michael Meacher, the environment minister, has authorised a deal with the Conservatives to kill a Labour MP's latest move to abolish fox hunting.

The action follows a decision by Gordon Prentice, MP for Pendle, to table an amendment to the government's countryside bill, abolishing fox hunting, when it comes back for debate in the Commons next month.

Mr Meacher has asked for Tory support because he does not want to lose his countryside bill - which introduces the right to roam and gives fresh protection for endangered species - in the Lords.

His action suggests that the government is taking very seriously filibustering in the Lords which has been organised by Lord Kimball, the deputy chairman of the Countryside Alliance and a pro-hunting Tory peer.

Details of the deal have emerged in a letter from the Countryside Alliance to the Master of Foxhounds Association seen by the Guardian. It reveals that Labour whip Kevin Hughes told his Tory counterpart Geoffrey Clifton-Brown that Mr Meacher was prepared to order Labour backbenchers to vote against the amendment - to prevent his bill being wrecked.

Such a move is against a Labour manifesto commitment for a free vote on hunting - and could leave the party facing a new rebellion.

The letter also reveals that, as part of the deal, the Countryside Alliance is planning to take a low profile in its opposition to the anti-hunting amendment. This is aimed to prevent Labour MPs becoming further inflamed and deciding to back Mr Prentice.

Last night Mr Prentice confirmed that Mr Meacher and Chris Mullin, the junior environment minister, had urged him not to go ahead because he they thought it would damage the chances of the countryside bill becoming law.

Mr Prentice, however, tabled the amendment and expects to get the support of 75 MPs.

fields.headline: Behind the screen
fields.standfirst: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip
fields.trailText: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip
fields.body:
Ant & Dec have come on in youthful leaps and bounds since they first graced our screens in Byker Grove. But will they ever make a living as stand-up comedians? An unlikely thought, but one worth pondering given there's a tug-of-war going on over who manages the winsome pair. Avalon, the stable of talented stars like Frank Skinner and Harry Hill, is attempting to woo The Foreheads over to its agency, suggesting they're not getting all that they might do out of their existing management deal.

But hang on. They have broken into the holy grail of BBC TV - early evening primetime on Saturdays with Friends Like These. Why do they need a late-night Channel 4 or Sky slot in which to use four-letter words (if they know any) before slumming it at the Edinburgh Festival for three weeks? Then again, perhaps that's exactly what Ant & Dec do need to shake off that Biddy Baxter-esque quality of "butter wouldn't melt" harmless TV toys. A few televised late gigs, with a few cans of something intoxicating tucked under the sofa, might be just the job for the duo in order to broaden their appeal beyond the pre-teens.

One person who already has a more worldly appeal, George Best, is to grace our TVs again this bank holiday weekend in an unashamedly populist drive to get people tuning into the BBC's most technically complex live broadcast for years. No, not the Queen Mum's parade - you must know what's happened to that by now. It's BBC Music Live, of course, a 24-hour music marathon which will include Georgio's top tunes. And he'll be doing more than just talking about his favourite records, we're told. No doubt we'll be treated to a re-run of some of his top footie moments as well. Don't say that's just about all the football the Beeb has as the moment. That would be cruel.

 Lucy Rouse is editor of Broadcast magazine

webTitle: Blair urged to take on eurosceptics

fields.headline: Blair urged to take on eurosceptics
fields.trailText: Romano Prodi, the president of the European Commission, yesterday stepped into the cabinet row over the European single currency when he chided Tony Blair for failing to take a lead on the euro.
fields.body:
Romano Prodi, the president of the European Commission, yesterday stepped into the cabinet row over the European single currency when he chided Tony Blair for failing to take a lead on the euro.

In a rare rebuke to a European leader, Mr Prodi accused the prime minister of setting himself a "mission impossible" by failing to confront British eurosceptics opposed to the currency.

His intervention is likely to be welcomed in private by pro-European cabinet ministers, such as the foreign secretary Robin Cook, who are urging the prime minister to speak out about the potential benefits if Britain joined the euro.

Mr Prodi tried yesterday to reach out to opponents of the euro by saying that Britain could abandon the single currency after joining.

In an interview with the eurosceptic Spectator, Mr Prodi said that it would be possible for Britain to leave the euro and retain its membership of the European Union in "exceptional circumstances provided it was not done in a way which was hostile to the EU".

The commission president added: "In an extreme case, one could always foresee, for example, that Texas might leave the dollar. But this is not strictly in the US constitution."

Mr Prodi's most provocative remarks came when he voiced fears that Mr Blair was taking a low profile on the euro. Asked whether he was surprised that Mr Blair was not doing more to move Britain towards membership of the euro, Mr Prodi said: "No I'm not surprised. The public is too biased now. A politician must be aware of public opinion. Of course a leader cannot only follow, but this does not mean that he must make a mission impossible."

His remarks echo the private thoughts of cabinet ministers such as Mr Cook who believes that Downing Street is in danger of throwing away Britain's chances of joining the euro after the next election. The prime minister says he is in favour in principle of joining a successful euro, but he will only call a referendum if Britain meets a series of economic tests.

The foreign secretary, who is supported in cabinet by the pro-Europeans Peter Mandelson and Stephen Byers, agrees with the prime minister's position. But Mr Cook believes that Downing Street should do more to spell out the potential benefits of joining the euro.

The prime minister will take some comfort from Mr Prodi's interview because he admits that it is not all down to the British government to spell out the case for the euro. "You will be convinced only by the good behaviour of the euro," Mr Prodi said. "And of course, by the good behaviour of the Europeans."

Mr Prodi voiced the hope that Britain would quickly change its mind over the euro, in the way that voters decided to endorse British membership of the EEC in 1975 after opinion polls had shown overwhelming opposition.

"It will be like the common market" he said. "You were against it for a long time. Then, in one weekend, you decided: 'These terrible continentals are boring, but they buy and sell a lot'."

Opponents of the euro seized on Mr Prodi's interview as a sign of the crisis over the currency. Andrew Halbendy, from the Business for Sterling campaign, said: "The political leaders of the euro-zone have no idea how to build confidence in the single currency and Prodi's comments today are extremely unhelpful."

fields.headline: Challenge to speeding buffer zone
fields.standfirst: Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Police forces are to be challenged in the high court over how they enforce speed limits on the roads.
fields.body:
Police forces are to be challenged in the high court over how they enforce speed limits on the roads.

The legal challenge follows the disclosure earlier this year of internal police guidelines covering England, Wales and Northern Ireland which recommend that drivers who broke the 30mph limit should not be prosecuted unless they were doing more than 35mph.

Transport 2000, a pressure group, has been given leave by the high court to challenge this 5mph "buffer zone".

The campaigners argue that the policy is illegal and want to see the 30mph limit strictly enforced. "This would send a signal to drivers that speeding kills and is a crime," said Transport 2000's director, Stephen Joseph.

An average of 10 people a day are killed on British roads and a further 100 injured. Government research shows that someone hit by a car at 35mph is more than twice as likely to be killed as someone hit at 30mph.

"We believe this edging up of the speed limit set by parliament will mean more people killed and seriously hurt on the roads," said Lynn Sloman, of Transport 2000.

"We are particularly concerned about child safety - nearly 100 children are killed or badly injured every week."

The speed enforcement policy was introduced by the Association of Chief Police Officers in February. It was designed to bring some consistency into the way speeding motorists are treated across England, Wales and Northern Ireland.

Ken Williams, chief constable for Norfolk and chairman of the association's traffic committee, said that the police were committed to catching speeding drivers, but would defend the guidelines in court.

"My association is committed to a strategy of contributing to the reduction of deaths and injury on the road through partnership with all those who share a common goal," said Mr Williams.

He added that he hoped to be talking to the Transport 2000 campaigners about their concerns. Transport 2000 is also arguing for tougher penalties for speeding in 30mph areas. At present guilty drivers face a fixed £60 fine and three penalty points on their licence. The group wants all drivers caught speeding to face court; police practice is to prosecute when in excess of 50mph.

 Transport 2000
 Royal Society for the Prevention of Accidents

fields.headline: Hijacker's getaway at 6,000ft
fields.trailText: A jilted husband carrying a grenade, a home-made parachute and the valuables of 278 passengers made his escape yesterday from the rear door of a Philippine Airlines Airbus - at 6,000 feet (1,800 metres).
fields.body:
A jilted husband carrying a grenade, a home-made parachute and the valuables of 278 passengers made his escape yesterday from the rear door of a Philippine Airlines Airbus - at 6,000 feet (1,800 metres).

At such a height and after an ominous thump on the rear tail section, few on the flight deck thought the hijacker could have survived.

The hooded man from economy class departed the plane almost as quickly as he had emerged in the final minutes of a domestic flight from Davao to Manila.

Wearing a mask and swimming goggles, the man pulled a gun on a flight attendant, dragged her into the cockpit and threatened to blow up the plane.

The hijacker fired a shot into the aircraft bulkhead to force Captain Butch Generoso to let him into the cockpit, and then waved his gun and a grenade.

"He was very angry, very temperamental. The man said, 'If you do not do what I say, we will die together'," said Capt Generoso.

Dr Daniel Dial, from San Diego, California, said the pilot announced over the intercom that there was a "problem" in the cockpit.

"We got a little bit disturbed when we heard yelling in the background followed by a gunshot," he said.

Another passenger added: "All of a sudden he removed the mask and he was demanding money - and we gave money, all of us shelled out to appease him."

"Everybody wanted to survive so we all co-operated," said Dr Dial.

"My family is gone. I will get revenge," the hijacker shouted.

Captain Butch Generoso said the man had often appeared close to tears. "He said his family had left him and that his wife had an affair with a policeman."

After the collection, the pilot brought the plane down to 6,000 feet so the rear door could be opened to allow the hijacker, complete with parachute made from tent fabric, to escape.

A steward later said he pushed the man to help him out of the plane, but did not elaborate.

An airport official said the army later captured the hijacker, but there was no official confirmation.

The Philippine Airlines Airbus A330 landed safely in Manila with the rear door still open and badly damaged.

"I thought I only see that scene in the movies," said a passenger.

Indeed he had. Dan Cooper, a hijacker who parachuted from the back of a NorthWest Airlines plane over the north-west US in 1971 with $200,000 in ransom money on his back has spawned books, a film, a play and even annual festivals

The rumour lives on that Cooper, who jumped into conditions of -50C wearing only a business suit and soft shoes, survived the 10,000 feet plunge.

An FBI manhunt found no trace of Cooper although $6,000 in notes was found along a river in the area years later.

Hundreds of people attend festivals in Ariel, Washington state, thinking Cooper is alive and well.

The hijacker fired a shot into the aircraft bulkhead to force Captain Butch Generoso to let him into the cockpit, and then waved his gun and a grenade. "He was very angry, very temperamental. The man said, 'If you do not do what I say, we will die together'," said Capt Generoso. Dr Daniel Dial, from San Diego, California, said the pilot announced over the intercom that there was a "problem" in the cockpit. "We got a little bit disturbed when we heard yelling in the background followed by a gunshot," he said. Another passenger added: "All of a sudden he removed the mask and he was demanding money - and we gave money, all of us shelled out to appease him." "Everybody wanted to survive so we all co-operated," said Dr Dial. "My family is gone. I will get revenge," the hijacker shouted. Captain Butch Generoso said the man had often appeared close to tears. "He said his family had left him and that his wife had an affair with a policeman." After the collection, the pilot brought the plane down to 6,000 feet so the rear door could be opened to allow the hijacker, complete with parachute made from tent fabric, to escape. A steward later said he pushed the man to help him out of the plane, but did not elaborate. An airport official said the army later captured the hijacker, but there was no official confirmation. The Philippine Airlines Airbus A330 landed safely in Manila with the rear door still open and badly damaged. "I thought I only see that scene in the movies," said a passenger. Indeed he had. Dan Cooper, a hijacker who parachuted from the back of a NorthWest Airlines plane over the north-west US in 1971 with $200,000 in ransom money on his back has spawned books, a film, a play and even annual festivals The rumour lives on that Cooper, who jumped into conditions of -50C wearing only a business suit and soft shoes, survived the 10,000 feet plunge. An FBI manhunt found no trace of Cooper although $6,000 in notes was found along a river in the area years later. Hundreds of people attend festivals in Ariel, Washington state, thinking Cooper is alive and well.

fields.headline: Black's £16.4m move
fields.standfirst: Who's Who publisher sells
fields.trailText: Bloomsbury, publisher of the best selling Harry Potter children's books, has moved to bolster its reference division by agreeing to buy the long-established publisher of the Who's Who directory and Blue Guide travel books for £16.4m.
fields.body:
Bloomsbury, publisher of the best selling Harry Potter children's books, has moved to bolster its reference division by agreeing to buy the long-established publisher of the Who's Who directory and Blue Guide travel books for £16.4m.

A&C Black has recommended Bloomsbury's offer of 1.47 shares for each of its own, which values its shares at 1,025p each. There is a cash alternative of 985p for each Black share.

One of the main beneficiaries of the deal will be BBC chairman Sir Christopher Bland, whose 9% stake in Black is valued at £1.5m.

Black's book list includes the Writers' and Artists' Yearbook, Black's Medical Dictionary and a number of children's titles. Chairman Charles Black said he had asked Bloomsbury to buy the 113-year-old business because of its marketing and electronic publishing expertise.

Bloomsbury's chief executive, Nigel Newton, expects the deal to lead to production cost savings, while greater cash flow from the combined group would al low increased investment in acquiring rights, identifying and nurturing new authors.

He will need to invest in digitising Black's content, and Bloomsbury said it planned to raise £2.75m through a placing of new shares at 670p each.

Shares in Black have underperformed its sector over the past year and many analysts have viewed it as a sleepy operation in need of a shake-up. Black's shares shot up 118% or 515p to 950p on the announcement of the offer.

Kit van Tulleken, of pub lishing mergers and acquisitions specialist the van Tulleken company, said: "A&C Black is a very elegant publishing house with an excellent staff and imprints but it has remained a hidden gem and never really pushed itself. I'm sure it will benefit from Bloomsbury's marketing expertise."

Bloomsbury shares, which have quadrupled in value over the past 12 months largely due to strong sales of the Harry Potter series, written by JK Rowling (pictured), closed off 2.5p at 695p.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText:
Royal cashes in NatWest stake
Royal Bank of Scotland, the new owner of NatWest, received a £670m windfall yesterday when it sold its holding in NatWest's former venture capital business to Coller Capital. NatWest Equity Partners was taken private through a management buy-out during NatWest's battle for independence, and is now known as Bridgepoint Capital.
fields.body:
Royal cashes in NatWest stake
Royal Bank of Scotland, the new owner of NatWest, received a £670m windfall yesterday when it sold its holding in NatWest's former venture capital business to Coller Capital. NatWest Equity Partners was taken private through a management buy-out during NatWest's battle for independence, and is now known as Bridgepoint Capital.


Liquidators thrown a bone
The Sharjah emirate in the United Arab Emirates has agreed to pay $76m (£52m) to liquidators of the failed Bank of Credit and Commerce International (BCCI) against a claim of $465.9m, newspapers reported yesterday.


XTL shelves London float

XTL, the Israeli-based biotech firm, has shelved its £125m London float because of volatility in hi-tech stocks. The company specialises in irradiating mice to destroy their immune systems then implanting them with human tissue for drug tests. A spokesman said the company had got "80% of the way" to raising the £25m of new money it wanted, and that it would try again in the autumn if the market had calmed.


Wickes wins more backing
British home improvement retailer Wickes said yesterday that it now had the backing of shareholders owning a 31.6% stake in the company against a hostile bid from rival firm Focus Do It All. FDIA is offering 430p in cash per share, valuing Wickes at £327m. FDIA will not sell its 29.9% stake if its bid fails, it said.


UBS Warburg profits soar
The London-based investment banking arm of Swiss bank UBS achieved record results in the first quarter of this year, up 86% on the same period last year. UBS Warburg made a pretax profit of SFr1.3bn (£515m) although personnel costs rose 49% to SFr2.7bn as a result of bonus payments.

The asset management business reported a 18% fall in pre-tax profits in the last quarter of the previous year. Overall, UBS reported record net profit after tax of SFr2.2bn.

Airtours sails past Thomson

Airtours has flown past Thomson to become the UK's leading tour operator, it emerged yesterday. Airtours expects to take 6m holidaymakers out of Britain this year, compared with a projected 5.4m for Thomson.

webTitle: Strong pound forces firms to cut prices

fields.headline: Strong pound forces firms to cut prices
fields.trailText: Nine out of 10 manufacturing firms in Britain are being forced to peg or cut prices to cope with ferocious competitive pressures and the impact of the strong pound, the Confederation of British Industry reported yesterday.
fields.body:
Nine out of 10 manufacturing firms in Britain are being forced to peg or cut prices to cope with ferocious competitive pressures and the impact of the strong pound, the Confederation of British Industry reported yesterday.

The CBI's latest monthly snapshot of UK industry showed factories poised on the brink of a fresh period of retrenchment, with production expected to decline and prices set to drop sharply.

Only 8% of the 1,061 manufacturers responding to the survey said that they would be able to raise prices over the next four months, against 60% who said they would remain the same and 29% who were planning to announce reductions. The gap of 21% between firms expecting falls and those anticipating rises compared to 13% in April and just 4% at the start of the year. Prices in the consumer sector, where the market is being flooded with imports made cheaper by the pound's rise, are falling fastest, the CBI said.

It added that while the strength of the domestic economy was helping to bolster overall order books, the high level of sterling on the foreign exchanges over the past month had left export order books well below normal.

Although the recent government figures have hinted that industrial output may be picking up following destocking in the wake of the millennium, the CBI said that more firms (28%) planned to cut production over the next four months than expected to raise it (22%). This was the first negative reading in 10 months.

Sudhir Junankar, the CBI's associate director of economic analysis, said: "The deterioration in export orders and the dip in output expected by manufacturers is a sign that sterling continues to bite. Price competition is also intensifying, forcing companies to hold prices or reduce them to boost orders in the home market."

The employers' organisation warned that one direct result of the squeeze on prices and corporate profitability would be deep cuts in manufacturing investment. Following a 13.6% cutback in capital spending last year, the CBI is pencilling in a further fall of 8.8% this year and 1.8% in 2001. Corporate profits will be squeezed in 2000 for the third successive year, and post only a modest 1.5% increase next year, the CBI said.

In its overall forecasts for the economy over the next 18 months, the CBI said Britain would remain a two-speed nation, with growth of 3% this year and 2.6% in 2001 driven by the strength of consumer spending and kept in check by the weakness of exports.

Kate Barker, the CBI's chief economist said that weak investment could constrain growth over the long term. Urging the Bank of England to leave interest rates on hold in response to muted inflationary pressure, she said that the mood in manufacturing had "deteriorated since the turn of the year".

fields.headline: Booker links up with Iceland
fields.trailText: Booker, the troubled wholesale grocer, yesterday announced a marriage of convenience with retailer Iceland. The deal gives Iceland 61.1% of the merged group and ends Booker's history as an independent company.
fields.body:
Booker, the troubled wholesale grocer, yesterday announced a marriage of convenience with retailer Iceland. The deal gives Iceland 61.1% of the merged group and ends Booker's history as an independent company.

This merger puts together a business founded the same year as the battle of Waterloo with one founded in 1970, and the dominant status of the latter is an indication of the depth of Booker's problems.

Worth nearly £1bn, the combined company - which may take a new name - aims to get the best out of Booker's extensive warehousing facilities in partnership with Iceland's 700-plus store chain and home-delivery business. Together, the two groups hope to move swiftly to exploit the potential for internet shopping.

Although billed as a merger, the agreement effectively makes Booker shareholders into members of Iceland, giving them 0.53 Iceland shares for every Booker share. Investors treated the deal as a takeover, bumping Booker's shares 14p to 141p and marking Iceland down 13p to 271p.

The pooled assets of the group combine Iceland's 760 shops and 1,000 vans with Booker's 300 vans and 182 depots. Booker/Iceland believes its vertical integration will make it a strong and trusted player in e-commerce.

Booker/Iceland will have combined sales of £5bn, split roughly 33% to retail customers, 19% to caterers and 48% to independent grocers and other outlets. Iceland has traditionally been involved in chilled and frozen foods, while Booker has strength in produce that can be stored at room temperature.

Booker, founded in 1815, has its roots in the colonial sugar and rum industries of Guyana. Most famously, it had interests in the copyrights of Ian Fleming and Agatha Christie, and started the eponymous literary price.

Booker yesterday also reported a rise in pre-tax profit to £35.4 million in the year to March 25, compared to £3.6m the year before.

fields.headline: William Jennings
fields.trailText: Co-founder of the Mattachine Society, the first major gay rights organisation in the United States
fields.body:
In 1950, William Jennings, who has died of respiratory failure aged 82, was one of the co-founders of the Mattachine Society, the first major gay rights organisation in the United States. The society was based on the notion that its members should fight for their civil rights on the grounds that they were an oppressed cultural minority.

Jennings also had the distinction, half a century ago, of writing for the first major gay publication, One, and of being the first gay man in California to be acquitted of indecent behaviour charges in a police entrapment case.

Jennings moved from his home town of Denver, Colorado, to Los Angeles in the late 1930s, just as the city was becoming the birthplace of the American gay and lesbian rights movement, before it spread in the 1960s to San Francisco and New York. The Mattachine Society emerged at the time of his arrest in 1950 in Griffith Park, parts of which were - and still are - known as gay cruising areas.

Jennings opted for trial by jury. He told the court that he was gay, and that he had been in the park - but that there was nothing indecent about his behaviour. His stance was remarkable at a time when those arrested usually sought to have their cases dealt with quietly, as it could mean professional ruin. In an unprecedented event, the jury acquitted him, although it appears to have had little effect on the continuing police practice of using plain-clothes officers to arrest gay men in public places.

This was a historic period for gay rights in America: around the same time, a lesbian group, the Sisters of Bilitis, was formed in Los Angeles, and One magazine was launched.

The magazine was confiscated by the postmaster in Los Angeles in 1954 on the grounds that it was obscene - an action that led to a landmark decision in 1958, when the US supreme court ruled that a publication concerned with homosexual equality was not obscene.

During the second world war, Jennings served with the armed forces in the south Pacific and was honourably discharged in 1946. He went to the University of Southern California theatre school, but later established himself as a writer, mainly in magazines. He also wrote three books, The Ronin, (based on a Zen myth), The Sinking Of The Sarah Diamond and The Cowboys, which was made into a 1972 film, starring John Wayne, and later became a shortlived television series.

Writing in reflective vein in the Los Angeles Times almost a decade ago, Jennings said: "We worked for no special privileges but for understanding and co-operation. Our basic argument was that changes in sex laws would not benefit us alone but everyone." He felt that the Mattachine Society, which no longer exists, had played a significant role: "Homosexuals simply want privacy and the freedom from prying into their personal lives, which are no one's personal business but their own."

 William Dale Jennings, writer and campaigner, born 1918; died May 11, 2000

fields.headline: John Sloane
fields.standfirst: Eminent pathologist who pioneered breast cancer treatment
fields.trailText: Eminent pathologist who pioneered breast cancer treatment
fields.body:
Professor John Sloane of Liverpool University, who has died of a myocardial infarction aged 54, was an internationally recognised surgical pathologist, and an expert in the diagnosis of early breast cancer. He was outstanding in the field of histopathology - the study of the microscopic structure of diseased tissues - brilliantly combining observation, appraisal and exposition.

Active in the early development of tissue markers, particularly for tumours, and more recently in the diagnostic applications of molecular techniques, John made major contributions in analysing tissue changes in leukaemic patients after bone marrow transplantation; and, above all, in the field of breast cancer. Chairing a group of pathologists, he formulated guidelines for the standard reporting of breast tissue biopsies and establishing a national external quality assessment scheme for all histopathologists participating in the National Health Service's breast screening programme.

The consequences, in terms of improved diagnostic accuracy and consistency, are already apparent. John subsequently chaired a group of European pathologists, which has led to many of the British approaches being adopted globally and laid the histopathological basis for the potential development of breast cancer. Recently, he embarked on a successful study of endocrine-related factors in the progression of breast cancer throughout its early phases.

Born in Chesterfield, Derbyshire, John was educated at Chesterfield school, where he excelled at rugby and athletics, and Charing Cross medical school, London. He qualified in 1969, captained the rugby team and played for United Hospitals. After house jobs at the Charing Cross and Wembley hospitals, he began his career in laboratory medicine with successive appointments in haematology, microbiology and chemical pathology.

While experience of histopathology at Charing Cross had kindled John's interest in the subject, the course of his life was determined by an appointment as registrar in histopathology at Hammersmith hospital's postgraduate medical school. He thrived under the supervision of Professor John Azzopardi, developing his rigorous approach to diagnostic work, particularly with respect to human breast cancer. His understanding of the importance of recognising fine and unique details provided the basis for his identification of new entities with predictable behavioural properties within early breast cancer.

From 1974 until 1995, he was based at the Royal Marsden hospital site in Sutton, Surrey, where he was, successively, research fellow at the Ludwig Institute for Cancer Research, Vandervell research fellow and, aged 29, consultant pathologist. Shortly afterwards, he became senior lecturer.

In 1995, John moved to a personal chair at Liverpool University. Within its department of pathology, he found the environment where his ideas and visions could flourish. He had great ideas - which he was starting to implement - for developing regional cancer services. He chaired the North-West Cancer Research Fund Research Committee, where he reorganised the distribution of funds and developed substantial initiatives for Merseyside.

His leadership and administrative skills were increasingly drawn on by the Department of Health and the Royal College of Pathologists. This added to his large workload of diagnostic sessions, research and teaching.

Success did not change John. Enthusiastic and energetic, he was loved and respected by all who knew him, with a direct, easy manner and a distinctive sense of humour. His leisure time during the past four years was spent with his wife, Pat, who shared his love of cycling. His favourite interest was classical music; he played the clarinet and viola, and enjoyed concerts at Liverpool's Philharmonic Hall.

He is survived by Pat, their sons Peter and Richard, and his parents and sister.

fields.headline: Pat Sandys
fields.standfirst: Television producer behind the honest drama of The Bill
fields.trailText: Television producer behind the honest drama of The Bill
fields.body:
Throughout the vintage years of ITV's police saga The Bill, my wife and I would watch each episode and try to guess the name of the producer before the end credits rolled. Whenever the story seemed particularly truthful - probably not very strong on action, but somehow treating the human predicaments with instinctive fidelity - we would cry "Pat Sandys". And most times we would be right. Though Sandys, who has died aged 73, never rose to be the overall producer of the show, she gave it its heart and conscience.

The daughter of Sandy Trotter, a celebrated editor of the Scottish Daily Express, Pat grew up in Glasgow. By the age of 13, she was already stage-struck, and in summer holidays would haunt the Alhambra theatre, where the Wilson Barrett repertory company played regular seasons. "A small, and in spite of everything her parents could do, exceedingly dirty schoolgirl" was how Wilson Barrett, a queenly actor-manager of the old school, described her in his memoirs. He gave her odd jobs, and one or two small parts to play.

At 16, Pat informed her parents that she was going to join the company permanently. For a stage name she reversed "Sandy's Pat" to yield Pat Sandys. Not rating her prospects highly as an actress, he groomed her as the company's stage director, a particularly important job in a troupe with no permanent home but playing the Scottish cities in turn, with occasional forays south of the border. In 1944, however, Pat was given her first leading role, and, in 1947, Barrett judged her to be a "most moving" Ophelia to his own, somewhat elderly Hamlet.

The following year, to Barrett's indignation, she left suddenly to take a part at the Shakespeare Memorial theatre at Stratford-upon-Avon. A period of freelance theatre work followed, though it was not conspicuously noteworthy except, perhaps, for her being the first actress in Britain to play Abigail, in Arthur Miller's Crucible, at the Bristol Old Vic in 1954 (Pat later named her first daughter Abigail).

Meanwhile, the refreshingly varied opportunities offered by television were attracting her. She even played straight-person to Tommy Cooper in a TV series. But after her marriage to the actor Philip Bond in 1959, and the arrival of a boy as well as two girls, she drifted into the literary or interpretative side of drama.

At home, after her children were in bed, Pat read scripts for the London ITV company, Associated-Rediffusion, supplying an outline and brief verdict on each. From her father, it may be, she had inherited a nose for a good story, and several of her finds became successful series. As her children started school, she turned to script-editing, and in 1968 - when Rediffusion was submerged into Thames Television - she followed her old boss, Peter Willes, to Yorkshire Television as head of scripts.

From script-editing to producing was a logical step at the time, and Sandys duly took it in the early 1980s, with a Hedda Gabler adapted by John Osborne and starring Diana Rigg. She went on to make a speciality of adaptations from Agatha Christie.

Her first stint with The Bill was from 1988 to 1990, after which she was lured by the BBC to EastEnders. But, within a year, she found she did not really like drama on tap, and, at the invitation of the executive producer, Michael Chapman, went happily back to the mostly rounded-off chapters of The Bill, which has now run for nearly 16 years.

She shunned personal publicity and never gave interviews. Her marriage had ended, but she took great satisfaction in the achievements of her three children. Abigail and Samantha both became actresses, Matthew a distinguished journalist.

 Pat Sandys (Patricia Mary Trotter), actress and producer, born July 26 1926; died May 19 2000

fields.headline: Denis Gifford
fields.standfirst: Engaging historian of comic nostalgia who shared his fascination with millions
fields.trailText: Engaging historian of comic nostalgia who shared his fascination with millions
fields.body:
Denis Gifford, who has died aged 72, turned Big-Hearted Arthur and Stinker Murdoch's "Ah, happy days" sigh into a way of life. Whether known as "Britain's most eminent comic historian" or the more cheery "Mr Nostalgia", Gifford had an infectious enthusiasm for days gone by, which he spread to a wide audience through books, radio and television.

The creator of Sounds Familiar in 1966, and its television counterpart Looks Familiar (hosted by Denis Norden) in 1972, Gifford served up a feast of clips and anecdotes that were far more interesting than the quiz element of the shows.

The author of more than 50 books, his writing was often light-hearted, as in Test Your NQ - it stood for nostalgia quotient - (1972) or Run Adolf Run: The World War Two Fun Book (1975). But to achieve that easygoing, yet remarkably informed, style required an immense amount of research; his skill was an ability to communicate to readers his passion for the things he devoted himself to - films, radio, music, comics.

In each area, he studied thoroughly and catalogued meticulously, though often the best resource was his own vast collection, built up over 60 years. His books included biographies, such as [Boris] Karloff: The Man, The Monster, The Movies (1973) and The Movie Makers: Chaplin (1974), histories of horror and science-fiction movies, animation and cartoons, the extensive directory of Entertainers In British Films: A Century Of Showbiz In The Cinema (1998) and the definitive British Film Catalogue, first published in 1973.

Gifford was born in Forest Hill, south London, and attended Dulwich College, where he developed an early interest in drawing and sketching. As his enthusiasm grew, he began producing a magazine for sale around the school, using heated gelatine and hectograph ink - since the process was only good for about 12 copies, The Junior, priced 1d, earned him a shilling an issue.

During summer holidays, Gifford sent some drawings to the Dandy comic, which were accepted with a request for more, earning the 14-year-old half-a-crown each for various headings. In 1944, he became an office junior at Reynolds News before joining the RAF. While serving around the country, Gifford freelanced, producing the complete contents of many thin comicbooks that flourished while the paper shortage rationed the appearance of many favourite titles. His distinctive drawing style later found a home in the London Evening News, where he drew the Telestrip cartoon (later revived in Rex magazine), and on bubblegum and cigarette sweet packets.

Gifford's talent for comic writing and knockabout took him to radio - writing scripts for The Light Optimists and People Are Funny - and television. In 1954, he teamed up with Tony Hawes to try and rescue the critically drubbed BBC comedy Running Wild, which marked the live television debut of Morecambe and Wise; Gifford would later pen The Alberts' Channel Too with Tom Parkinson, which was intended to launch BBC2 in April 1964, only to have the whole evening lost to a power blackout.

After three years of rejections, Gifford launched the radio show Sounds Familiar, and later created its television parallel and Quick On The Draw for Thames, as well as writing scripts for Witch's Brew, Junior Showtime and The Laughing Policeman for Yorkshire Television. A less successful writing venture was an unproduced script for a Carry On movie.

In 1971, he wrote Discovering Comics, the first of his many books about comic strips and comic characters; later titles included Victorian Comics (1974), Happy Days: A Century Of Comics (1975), The International Book Of Comics (1984), The Complete Catalogue Of British Comics (1985), Encyclopedia Of Comic Characters (1987) and American Comic Book Catalogue (1990).

In person, Gifford was as full of anecdotes as his books, and bookfairs or comic marts would often end with a trip to the nearest tea-house for rambling conversations with his fellow enthusiasts. He recognised his own foibles and had a self-deprecating wit. If he had a fault, it was a tactlessness with other writers: his occasional blunt claim that he could do a job better made him appear possessive of his crown as first among nostalgists.

Even after a hernia operation in his last few weeks, Gifford maintained a steady output as an obituarist for the Guardian and the Independent. His last commission was phoned in from his home in Sydenham, south London, to his editor on Thursday, May 18; it is thought he died the same day.

Gifford's marriage to Angela Kalagias, whom he met while working for Pathe Films, was later dissolved; the couple had one daughter, Pandora Jane.

 Denis Gifford, comic strip artist, historian and journalist, born December 26 1927; died May 18 2000

webTitle: Fiji rebels demand more after capitulation by chiefs

fields.headline: Fiji rebels demand more after capitulation by chiefs
fields.trailText: Fiji's traditional chiefs yesterday bowed to the racially-motivated coup attempt that has brought the country to a standstill, by deciding to agree to the demands of the armed group that has been holding the prime minister and more than 30 members of his government hostage in the parliamentary complex.
fields.body:
Fiji's traditional chiefs yesterday bowed to the racially-motivated coup attempt that has brought the country to a standstill, by deciding to agree to the demands of the armed group that has been holding the prime minister and more than 30 members of his government hostage in the parliamentary complex.

They urged the president, Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara, to replace the ethnic Indian prime minister, Mahendra Chaudhry, with an indigenous Fijian, and called for the constitution to be changed to enshrine again the dominance of indigenous Fijians in senior government posts and, in effect, the wider society.

The president should appoint a caretaker government in the meantime, the chiefs said. The plan also called for the rebel leader, George Speight, and his men to be prosecuted but then pardoned after releasing the hostages and laying down their arms.

But the rebels rejected the proposals as insufficient. Simione Taikani, "information minister" in Mr Speight's self-styled government, said the rebels' three key demands - the resignation of President Mara, the complete annulment of the constitution, and immunity from prosecution, not just a pardon - had not been met.

"They [the chiefs] have just escalated the crisis by coming with all these proposals that are totally beyond our imagining," Mr Taikani said. He said the rebels would meet representatives of the chiefs again today to try to reach a solution. A spokesman for the Great Council of Chiefs, Epoli Kanaimaii, told reporters that "the door is still open for dialogue".

Earlier, the chairman of the chiefs' council, Sitiveni Rabuka, admitted at a news conference that the chiefs' proposals for a solution to the crisis would probably be unacceptable to the rest of the world, and that sanctions on Fiji should be expected. But the proposed outcome was the least damaging of all the "bad solutions", he told journalists.

Democracy was a concept introduced by colonialists and traditional hierarchical systems should be included in the administration of Pacific countries, Mr Rabuka, the leader of a coup in 1987, said. "It [the chief's plan] is a very bad indication of democracy in the region," he said. "But then, democracy is a foreign flower, and something we should be able to adapt

Mr Rabuka said the chiefs' plan was aimed at guaranteeing the safety of the hostages and ensuring that the rioting and looting that followed Mr Speight's seizure of the parliament last Friday was not repeated.

New Zealand's foreign minister, Phil Goff, condemned the chiefs' move, warning that the world would not tolerate "people who can only be described as terrorists" overthrowing elected governments.

He warned that the move could lead to Fiji's removal from the Commonwealth. A new government favouring indigenous Fijians would run counter to the Common wealth's 1991 Harare declaration that commits member countries to ensuring equal rights for all their citizens regardless of gender, race, creed or political belief.

Fiji was only recently readmitted to the Commonwealth after its expulsion following the 1987 coup.

The US, Australia and New Zealand have all warned of tough diplomatic and economic sanctions if the government is removed.

webTitle: Protest over rape and killing of student

fields.headline: Protest over rape and killing of student
fields.trailText: Thousands of Chinese students yesterday mourned the death of a fellow student after two days of protest which have alarmed government officials in Beijing.
fields.body:
Thousands of Chinese students yesterday mourned the death of a fellow student after two days of protest which have alarmed government officials in Beijing.

The students at Beijing University complained about lax policing and demanded the resignation of senior staff after 19-year-old Qiu Qingfeng was raped and murdered near a university annexe.

Ms Qiu's body was discovered on Saturday in an orchard where she had been waylaid after missing her bus. After taking another bus part of the way, she faced a 40- minute walk through unlit countryside to her dormitory.

Beijing officials are acutely sensitive to unrest at the university which is a traditional centre of student protest since the early years of Chinese nationalism. The 11th anniversary of the June 3 1989 Beijing massacre is only a few days away.

Officials have promised to meet student leaders to respond to demands for better safety and improvements in university administration.

Earlier this week Communist party officials were said to have ordered a news blackout on the tragedy but this was ignored by contributors to internet bulletin boards.

The university vice-president, Lin Junjing was shouted down by students at a meeting on Wednesday after cries of: "Do you have any conscience?"

Mourning messages hung on noticeboards around the campus, and a makeshift shrine to Ms Qiu was set up. An online site in Ms Qiu's memory registered more than 12,700 hits expressing sorrow and anger.

Students said yesterday that internet bulletin boards had been closed down at Beijing University and at neighbouring Qinghua University.

Most Chinese students today say they have no desire to confront the authorities over political questions in the way that ended so disastrously in June 1989. But the government knows that student protests on non-political issues have in the past escalated into more serious challenges to its authority.

fields.headline: Ivy Supersonic
fields.trailText: Who she? "If you're wondering who is Ivy Supersonic, you're probably not alone," says her website, "because Ivy Supersonic is an enigma..."
fields.body:
Who she? "If you're wondering who is Ivy Supersonic, you're probably not alone," says her website, "because Ivy Supersonic is an enigma..."

But you've solved the enigma, haven't you? I have.

Well? The erstwhile Ivy Silberstein, leader of the "Groovy Gals", is a designer of exotic hats to New York's glitterati. Celebrated blondies Pamela Anderson, Debbie Harry and, er, Hillary Clinton have all been seen with her creations balanced on their barnets.

That doesn't sound very enigmatic... You don't know the half of it. Let me tell you about the Naked Feathered Hat Shows.

Oh, go on then. Ivy's models don't wear clothes. Instead they're body-painted. Or dressed in broccoli. Or cauliflower.

Bit of a self-promoter, this Supersonic character? She describes herself as "a marketing machine with a mission: to unite the wild and the free". Which hardly explains the Sqrat.

The what? Part-rat, part-squirrel. It's terrorising Manhattan's parks, says Supersonic, in her latest scheme to colonise the Big Apple's front pages. "It is conceivable that the two species have mated. I'm not a scientist, but I thought it would be a great mascot for New York City."

A woman with a liking for hairy and verminous pests? This can only be... A Liam Gallagher story, of course! The Oasis crooner stands accused of adultery with the media-harassing milliner.

I'm feeling Supersonic, give me gin and tonic... Well, precisely. The loutish popster is said to have shared a New York hotel suite with Ivy for six long hours.

What's Ivy say? She was measuring him for a hat.

Crikey! I knew he had a big head, but... Wronged wife Patsy Kensit has fled to a private hospital, it says here, suffering from "exhaustion and severe depression".

Well, she has spent five years with him. Don't be cruel.

Most likely to say: Her slogan: "Get ready - Get naked - and Get involved".

Not to be confused with: The Bionic Man, The Ivy, Ivan the Terrible.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Youth 'set on fire' charged
fields.body:
Youth 'set on fire' charged

A black 17-year-old who claimed he was doused in petrol and set alight by white youths will appear before Didcot youth court, Oxfordshire, on June 2 charged with wasting police time.

He told officers that four youths surrounded him in Berinsfield, near Abingdon, made racist insults and set his jumper alight.

Union official jailed for theft

A TGWU branch secretary who stole £22,000 from branch coffers was jailed for 18 months at Southwark crown court yesterday.

David Guyett, 50, of Hillingdon, west London, used colleagues' cash to pay household bills.

New NoW editor picks deputy

The new editor of the News of the World, Rebekah Wade, yesterday appointed Andy Coulson as her deputy. Mr Coulson, 32, a former associate editor of the Sun, replaces Bob Bird, who moves to another senior position within News International.

Bail for athlete's ex-boyfriend

Chris Cotter, ex-boyfriend of black Olympic triple jumper Ashia Hansen, was granted bail with co-defendants Craig Wynn and Surjit Singh Klair yesterday at Birmingham crown court.

The three are to appear before magistrates next Wednesday on charges of racially aggravated threatening behaviour relating to a letter sent to Miss Hansen.

Charity loses arms firm cash

NCH Action for Children, whose workers objected to its taking donations of up to £600,000 from the arms manufacturer BAe Systems, has been passed over for the sponsorship, which will go to another charity.

McEnroe and Borg play again

John McEnroe and Bjorn Borg are to relive their classic Wimbledon finals at a charity tennis afternoon hosted by the Duke of York on the Buckingham Palace tennis court in aid of the NSPCC Full Stop campaign.

Hillsborough messages lost

Messages of condolence written after the 1989 Hillsborough football ground disaster have disappeared.

Liverpool council said it thought they had been sent to Liverpool FC or the Anglican cathedral, but both say they never received them.

McEnroe and Borg play again John McEnroe and Bjorn Borg are to relive their classic Wimbledon finals at a charity tennis afternoon hosted by the Duke of York on the Buckingham Palace tennis court in aid of the NSPCC Full Stop campaign. Hillsborough messages lost Messages of condolence written after the 1989 Hillsborough football ground disaster have disappeared. Liverpool council said it thought they had been sent to Liverpool FC or the Anglican cathedral, but both say they never received them.

fields.headline: Private lives
fields.trailText: Is there a polite way of finding out who invited me to their wedding?
fields.body:
Is there a polite way of finding out who invited me to their wedding?

I have just received a wedding invitation in the post. I was delighted when I realised what it was, but then dismayed that the names of the bride, the groom, the bride's mother and the bride's father all fail to ring any bells whatsoever with me.

I must know them, or at least one of them, unless it's some bizarre practical joke. I have checked with my mother and she also claims never to have heard of any of them. Emails to friends have failed to provide clues. I could simply refuse the invite, but I'm now extremely curious about the happy couple.

How can I find out who they really are without completely putting my foot in it and offending them?

Check with the church
If the wedding is being held in a church, call there and explain your problem to the person officiating the marriage. They can provide you with more information about the couple.

If these details fail to ring a bell, you probably have the same name as a person on their guest list whose address they do not have. When they searched for the address of this person, your information turned up and you got the invitation.
Siobhan Kelley
Dublin

Is it for someone else?
Perhaps the bride or groom has forgotten the address of a friend, looked in the telephone directory, and chosen yours by mistake. My husband's details are in a directory connected with his profession and we often received letters, Christmas cards and even condolences on his wife's death, meant for a colleague whose name differed by one initial but lived in the same area.

Ignoring the invitation or a polite refusal could mean the intended recipient missing out. Even worse, it could be regarded as indifference or a snub. Why not write a friendly note to wish them well and suggest that it was meant for someone else?
Jean Jones
Wirral

Think like a detective
This sounds like the opening gambit of an Agatha Christie novel. Think like a detective. Cull Miss Manners and other modern wedding etiquette books for a list of appropriate questions anyone might need to ask: What shops have your gift list? Is she (or he) still vegetarian? Can I just let you know I'm allergic to nuts? Is it okay to bring my partner?

The address on the RSVP is probably (if it's a traditional wedding) that of the bride's parents. Ring them. Ask one of the questions on your list and casually add that you seem to have lost their daughter's phone number, can they let you have it? Ring her.

Ask another of the questions on your list and casually drop into the conversation "Can you remember how long it's been since we last met? Where was that, do you remember?"

Ask to speak to the groom and try again with him. See if you can get hold of the groom's parent's number and ring them. Think like Miss Marple: ask all the questions and give nothing away.

With any luck, one of these conversations will spark some clue and you will find yourself exclaiming: "Of course! You're the strange woman I met at a demo at Greenham Common and you were calling yourself North Moon!"; or "I remember now - we used to get drunk together at the student union, and I thought Dave Bleurgh was your real name!"

If none of these conversations ends in a clear resolution, however, you could just turn up at the wedding reception and enjoy the party. Maybe you'll recognise someone.
Jane Carnall
Reading

Just get on the phone
How silly can you be? Just pick up the phone and find out exactly who has invited you to the wedding. Unless you are suffering from a memory disorder to which you have not referred, then those who have apparently invited you are unlikely to be people who are significant in your life and a polite enquiry is not going to offend anyone. If you have time to worry about such things, I suggest you get out more.
Stan
Sheffield

Ask for the guest list
You could write to the couple explaining that you are unsure whether you will be able to attend due to difficulties with transport and asking whether you could have a copy of the guest list to see if there is anyone you can approach to share a lift. This may yield sufficient clues to satisfy your curiosity.
Karen Bradbury
No address given

Next week
I am a 37-year-old single man with a well paid job and excellent prospects. My problem is that I have been betrayed by two women and I can't understand why.

Until seven months ago I was involved for five years with a girl much younger than me. During this time I paid her rent, paid off her debts, bought her expensive jewellery and got her a good job only to find that she was sleeping with her ex-boyfriend. I was devastated but feel that she should pay me back. She has refused.

I met the second woman at a conference and she is 31 and was engaged to another man. I thought I had found someone special, but although she said she liked me she wanted to stay with her fiancé. She told me that if she split up with him she would go out with me, but they did split up last month and she now says that she is not interested in me.

I have a lot of money and everything to offer but have been let down twice and it's tearing me apart. What should I do?

 Private Lives appears every Friday. Each week we publish a letter to which readers are invited to respond. Replies, giving an account of your personal experience, should reach us by Thursday. Readers are also welcome to propose other problems, of around 300 words.
