fields.headline: Video releases
fields.standfirst: Election | The World is not Enough | EDtv
fields.trailText: Election | The World is not Enough | EDtv
fields.body:
Election
Rental
Paramount Cert 15
****

A nicely acerbic high-school comedy in which an election for school president parallels its real-life national political equivalent, sex scandal and all. Matthew Broderick has won teacher of the year three times, but when he decides to block the unopposed bid for school president of star pupil Reese Witherspoon, things begin to unravel for all concerned.

Director/co-writer Alexander Payne's teachers are far from ideal: Carver High might be twinned with Rushmore. Broderick watches porn while fellow teacher Mark Harelik not only seduces the scheming Witherspoon but more shockingly uses a Lionel Ritchie record to do it. Behind a respectable middle-American facade, all sorts are going on - Election is like a companion piece to American Beauty and Broderick is set for humiliations no less painful than Kevin Spacey's.

But the star role is Witherspoon's - she's terrific as an impossibly prissy, superior and condescending schoolgirl, middle-aged before her years, single-mindedly power-grabbing and, in her own words, "truly destined to be special." This, you feel, is what it would have been like to share a Grantham classroom with Margaret Roberts, around 1941. Even the hairstyle is early Thatcher. Payne gives us multiple points of view as Broderick, Witherspoon and her two election opponents, ingenuous jock Chris Klein and his anarchic sister, Jessica Campbell, take turns as narrator. Election is a good game of consequences too: look out for Broderick's unwitting insult to the janitor early on and its deep ramifications.

The World is not Enough
Rental and DVD (£19.99)
Fox Pathe Cert 12
***

A smoothly efficient number 19 in the series. It confirms Pierce Brosnan's comfortable playing of the Bond role after Timothy Dalton's uneasy "new man" Bond and Roger Moore's frankly "old man" version. Brosnan is much nearer Ian Fleming's description: "a quiet, hard, ruthless, sardonic fatalist".

Sadly, this will be the last appearance as Q of the late Desmond Llewelyn, whose touch of JR Hartley amid the Martini commercial Bond world will be much missed. Presciently, John Cleese is wheeled in here as his replacement, R.

Stunts include speedboats on the Thames. (The Dome is a near fatality, which could have provided taxpayers with a windfall the size of a Bond budget.) Robbie Coltrane makes a second appearance, while his old Cracker adversary, Robert Carlyle, is the world's most dangerous terrorist since, oh, the last Bond movie. Goldie, described as "a gold-encrusted fool", wins the Best Teeth Since Richard Kiel award and tradition also provides a Shirley on theme song (Manson not Bassey these days). The DVD has a full 90 minutes of extras - interviews, stunt lowdown, Garbage's video and a tribute to Llewelyn. Dr No is also out on DVD. The rest follow.

EDtv
Rental and DVD (£19.99)
Paramount/ Columbia Tristar Cert 12
***

EDtv crept into UK cinemas belatedly, the time lapse making it seem in the distant slipstream of the similarly-themed Truman Show. It's not a patch on that, but it is quite enjoyable. Matthew McConaughey is the everyday guy selected for a new show by a San Francisco cable show, which follows him around for a 24-hours a day programme.

As with Truman, EDtv has fun watching the show's audience: "The old guy in the wheelchair. They're gonna have him die." That's Ed's dad, played by Martin Landau, who gets most of the best lines. The intense scrutiny unearths plenty of embarrassment. "How many skeletons can one family have?" asks delighted, devious TV boss Rob Reiner. As the show picks up ratings, Ed becomes a celeb and meets a publicity-mad Liz Hurley, who introduces herself with: "I'm a model and sort of an actress" (stop that sniggering at the back) and attempts a live TV seduction. As Ed wearies of his new role, the show becomes more determined to keep him. Can Ed turn the tables? It reaches a satisfying conclusion.

fields.headline: James Belushi
fields.trailText: James Belushi
fields.body:
What was your first film?

X-15, about the first aircraft that broke the sound barrier.

Your favourite film?

Being There. It accomplished all the right things: social satire, a very physical cast, great story and one of the best performances by Peter Sellers.

Your most erotic film?

Two Moon Junction, every scene. I'm getting hot just thinking about it so I can't say any more.

What is the most annoying habit in the cinema?

Too many ads.

When was the last time you snogged in the cinema?

It was more than a kiss with my present wife during Friday the 13th. She looked great that night.

Your most erotic moment in the cinema?

Return to Me. The chemistry between David Duchovny and Minnie Driver is so strong. They both give an honest, poignant performance. I laughed at my scenes.

What's your favourite line of dialogue?

It's from the Blues Brothers. Elwood Blues: "We've got a full tank of gas, half a packet of cigarettes, it's dark and we're wearing sunglasses." Jake Blues: "Hit it!" Also, from About Last Night... between me and Rob Lowe. I'm describing a girl: "The tits, the legs, the ass," and Rob Lowe says, "Young ass?"

Who would you say is your favourite actor?

Me. I've got a great life, I wouldn't trade it with anybody.

Who's your favourite actress?

Gena Rowlands, she's everything. I love her in everything she's done.

And your top film character?

Chance the Gardener in Being There (Peter Sellers). He led a very simple and uncomplicated life.

How did your brother, John, influence you in your personal life?

I was dating a girl in college for nine months and we hadn't slept together. I asked John for advice, and he said, "If you really want to sleep with a girl, you will." Two weeks later it happened.

What was it like working with David Duchovny?

He's so charming. I hadn't seen a single episode of The X Files before I met him. I'm now hooked.

 James Belushi stars in Return to Me, which is released on June 9.

fields.headline: Curse of Jackson County
fields.standfirst: Jonathan Romney on an extraordinary documentary about life, death and insanity in turn-of-the-century Wisconsin
fields.trailText: Jonathan Romney on an extraordinary documentary about life, death and insanity in turn-of-the-century Wisconsin
fields.body:
In 1900, one out of every 472 inhabitants of Jackson County, Wisconsin was certified insane. In the last decade of the 19th century, everyday life in and around Black River Falls, a small Jackson County town, was a litany of madness, suicide, murder, disease and child mortality. And yet a local newspaperman was able to comment, "Nowhere in this great continent of ours can be found a more desirable residence than Black River Falls."

In 1973, American historian Michael Lesy published his book Wisconsin Death Trip - part photo album, part scrapbook, part impressionistic speculation on the late 19th-century American rural psyche. The book comprised a selection of photographs taken between 1890 and 1910 by a Black River Falls photographer, Charles Van Schaick, together with extracts from the local newspaper, the Badger State Banner, and from the records of the Mendota state asylum, a thriving institution at the time.

The photographs - from a collection of 30,000 glass plate negatives - tell one set of stories, preserving for posterity local worthies, bucolic rituals and floral tributes to the dead of all ages. The writing, largely by the Banner's English-born editor Frank Cooper and his son George, tells a different story, one that sometimes defies belief. Itinerants slash three cows' throats in a revenge killing. A widow is convinced that witches are persecuting her. A boy is unable to speak above a whisper for 16 months, following a visit to a hypnotist. An alleged wife-murderer devours the springs of his prison bed. Countless children die. Countless men and women go mad, kill themselves, kill each other.

Many of these anecdotes, and others equally uncanny, feature in a new film inspired by Lesy's book, also called Wisconsin Death Trip. While the book offers various social, historical and ideological readings of the time and place, the film's director, James Marsh, is less concerned to pursue Lesy's analysis than to bring to life the world of 1890s Black River Falls. His film is neither fiction, nor recognisable docu-drama, nor reconstructed history. It is more a dreamlike succession of vignettes, evoked as if in a seance or lantern show. "I tried to make the dramatic scenes like animated photographs," Marsh says.

Shot by Eigil Bryld in stark, crisp black and white to emulate the original photographs, Wisconsin Death Trip echoes the rural visions of American film-makers from John Ford to Terrence Malick, as well as the literary gothic of Poe, Faulkner and Cormac McCarthy. But this chilly exhibit of antique Americana comes from an unlikely source - British director Marsh made it for the BBC's Arena strand.

Marsh discovered Lesy's book in a New York bookshop nine years ago, and was struck by the faces in Van Schaick's photos: "Those long exposures create a rather haunted look in people's eyes." He originally planned to make a more conventional documentary, then opted to create a "self-contained world" - "It seemed right to do something much purer, without giving too much information, or trying to give reasons why these stories happened. You can allow an incremental sense of life at that time to unfold, by choosing these extreme examples of people's lives going wrong."

Hence these accumulated anecdotes, roughly arranged into four seasons and overall forming a quasi-musical pattern of parallels and repetitions. Charismatic figures emerge to grab their own headline space: Mary Sweeney, the Wisconsin Window Smasher, and opera singer Pauline L'Allemand, once the lead in Delibes' opera Lakmé, now reduced to eating cattlefeed.

Wisconsin Death Trip is always lyrical, sometimes blackly farcical, and sometimes terrifying, as it reveals the romanticised American frontier's true desperation. "The more stories you have of lovelorn suicides or madness," says Marsh, "the more you see what that time was really scared of. Today we don't report suicides or outbreaks of madness in the way they did - these are really the primal anxieties of that community and that time. They are parading what they are most scared of."

Both the book and the film convey a sense of how madness was understood in America at the time. Lesy refers to contemporary theories of "degeneracy" and "American nervousness", while his bibliography includes Foucault and Laing; he's interested in madness as social product and social discourse. He concludes that in 1890s rural America, there was little choice but to be either obsessive-compulsive or paranoid: in other words, an upstanding thrifty citizen or a barking backwoods crazy. But Lesy also outlines the concrete reasons why Wisconsin's supposedly Edenic terrain became hell for so many: disease, brutal winters and the overall economic depression of America in the 1890s.

Another aspect of the community's history features in the film, if only fleetingly. Early on, we see contemporary photos of Winnebago Indians: we hear how they obligingly allowed themselves to be displaced from their lands. There's only this brief mention, but the Winnebagos' absence represents an unspoken Repressed: the film is haunted by a key myth of American horror cinema (most spectacularly represented in Poltergeist and The Shining), namely the idea that Wasp prosperity was built on Native American burial grounds.

"The Winnebagos," Marsh explains, "were shipped out wholesale to Nebraska and kept walking back, to occupy marginal land outside communities like Black River Falls. In the film, that's nailed in three photos - you can draw your own conclusions." A punchline, however, comes in the film's closing sequence, with its present-day shots of a Native American-owned casino. "That suggests they've never been away, and that they've got our number. In the last 10 years, a lot of tribes have got very rich on servicing the gambling and greedy needs of the white population."

The film is a love letter to photographic history. Both Van Schaick's originals and Marsh's reconstructions closely parallel the likes of August Sander and Diane Arbus, although Marsh's unlikely cinematic model was Chris Marker's 1962 short, La Jetée, an object lesson in telling a story through stills. Many of Van Schaick's pictures were specially staged photo-cenotaphs: looking at his dead babies and (just about living) desiccated greybeards and matrons, it's hard not to think of his work as a kind of mummification.

"Memorial photography was the biggest genre of photography in the 1890s," Marsh says. "There's a certain act of magic that takes place for the subjects, and that's a conceptual notion that we tried to build into the film. We might find those images hard to look at, but they have a very honest and tender motivation - to remember a lost life by."

The film's oddly haunted feel - as though the actors are possessed by the ancestors they play - derives from the fact that its entire cast is from Wisconsin. Marsh arranged open casting calls in Madison and Milwaukee, specifically for people of Scandinavian or German origins. Two-thirds of them had never acted before, and in fact the film calls for them simply to be there, part of the tableaux. "Most of these people were like open canvases - I wanted them not to act but to be very blank and let the viewer bring the emotions to those faces."

A further ring of authenticity comes from the locations, all historical sites in Wisconsin. The film was made during four separate trips, over 16 months, but Marsh spent a year overall in Wisconsin, including time for research, returning to Lesy's original sources.

Ostensibly a television film, Wisconsin Death Trip really comes into its own on the big screen; it has already done the rounds of American and European festivals, where it has been widely acclaimed as one of the outstanding recent British films. Shot on a standard documentary budget, with input from American company Cinemax, it is one of several films made for Arena that have had a cinema life - others are Stonewall, Paris is Burning and I Shot Andy Warhol.

Marsh himself has made other contributions to Arena's distinctive line in genre-bending documentaries: among them, The Burger and the King (on Elvis Presley's regal diet), Trouble Man (on the death of Marvin Gaye) and assorted "biographies" of pop songs. But only a couple of years after embarking on Wisconsin Death Trip, he is doubtful whether such a film could still be made in Britain. "Arena is one of the last bastions of British TV where you can take an idea that seems so formless and experimental and hybrid and get a hearing. But it's increasingly hard to make those one-off maverick ideas." Now based in New York, Marsh is about to embark on his first fiction feature: murder figures prominently, and no doubt the tormented souls of Black River Falls will smile on his efforts.

 Wisconsin Death Trip screens at London's National Film Theatre from next Friday, and is shown on BBC2 on July 2. Michael Lesy's book, Wisconsin Death Trip, is published by University of New Mexico Press.

The book comprised a selection of photographs taken between 1890 and 1910 by a Black River Falls photographer, Charles Van Schaick, together with extracts from the local newspaper, the Badger State Banner, and from the records of the Mendota state asylum, a thriving institution at the time. The photographs - from a collection of 30,000 glass plate negatives - tell one set of stories, preserving for posterity local worthies, bucolic rituals and floral tributes to the dead of all ages. The writing, largely by the Banner's English-born editor Frank Cooper and his son George, tells a different story, one that sometimes defies belief. Itinerants slash three cows' throats in a revenge killing. A widow is convinced that witches are persecuting her. A boy is unable to speak above a whisper for 16 months, following a visit to a hypnotist. An alleged wife-murderer devours the springs of his prison bed. Countless children die. Countless men and women go mad, kill themselves, kill each other. Many of these anecdotes, and others equally uncanny, feature in a new film inspired by Lesy's book, also called Wisconsin Death Trip. While the book offers various social, historical and ideological readings of the time and place, the film's director, James Marsh, is less concerned to pursue Lesy's analysis than to bring to life the world of 1890s Black River Falls. His film is neither fiction, nor recognisable docu-drama, nor reconstructed history. It is more a dreamlike succession of vignettes, evoked as if in a seance or lantern show. "I tried to make the dramatic scenes like animated photographs," Marsh says. Shot by Eigil Bryld in stark, crisp black and white to emulate the original photographs, Wisconsin Death Trip echoes the rural visions of American film-makers from John Ford to Terrence Malick, as well as the literary gothic of Poe, Faulkner and Cormac McCarthy. But this chilly exhibit of antique Americana comes from an unlikely source - British director Marsh made it for the BBC's Arena strand. Marsh discovered Lesy's book in a New York bookshop nine years ago, and was struck by the faces in Van Schaick's photos: "Those long exposures create a rather haunted look in people's eyes." He originally planned to make a more conventional documentary, then opted to create a "self-contained world" - "It seemed right to do something much purer, without giving too much information, or trying to give reasons why these stories happened. You can allow an incremental sense of life at that time to unfold, by choosing these extreme examples of people's lives going wrong." Hence these accumulated anecdotes, roughly arranged into four seasons and overall forming a quasi-musical pattern of parallels and repetitions. Charismatic figures emerge to grab their own headline space: Mary Sweeney, the Wisconsin Window Smasher, and opera singer Pauline L'Allemand, once the lead in Delibes' opera Lakmé, now reduced to eating cattlefeed. Wisconsin Death Trip is always lyrical, sometimes blackly farcical, and sometimes terrifying, as it reveals the romanticised American frontier's true desperation. "The more stories you have of lovelorn suicides or madness," says Marsh, "the more you see what that time was really scared of. Today we don't report suicides or outbreaks of madness in the way they did - these are really the primal anxieties of that community and that time. They are parading what they are most scared of." Both the book and the film convey a sense of how madness was understood in America at the time. Lesy refers to contemporary theories of "degeneracy" and "American nervousness", while his bibliography includes Foucault and Laing; he's interested in madness as social product and social discourse. He concludes that in 1890s rural America, there was little choice but to be either obsessive-compulsive or paranoid: in other words, an upstanding thrifty citizen or a barking backwoods crazy. But Lesy also outlines the concrete reasons why Wisconsin's supposedly Edenic terrain became hell for so many: disease, brutal winters and the overall economic depression of America in the 1890s. Another aspect of the community's history features in the film, if only fleetingly. Early on, we see contemporary photos of Winnebago Indians: we hear how they obligingly allowed themselves to be displaced from their lands. There's only this brief mention, but the Winnebagos' absence represents an unspoken Repressed: the film is haunted by a key myth of American horror cinema (most spectacularly represented in Poltergeist and The Shining), namely the idea that Wasp prosperity was built on Native American burial grounds. "The Winnebagos," Marsh explains, "were shipped out wholesale to Nebraska and kept walking back, to occupy marginal land outside communities like Black River Falls. In the film, that's nailed in three photos - you can draw your own conclusions." A punchline, however, comes in the film's closing sequence, with its present-day shots of a Native American-owned casino. "That suggests they've never been away, and that they've got our number. In the last 10 years, a lot of tribes have got very rich on servicing the gambling and greedy needs of the white population." The film is a love letter to photographic history. Both Van Schaick's originals and Marsh's reconstructions closely parallel the likes of August Sander and Diane Arbus, although Marsh's unlikely cinematic model was Chris Marker's 1962 short, La Jetée, an object lesson in telling a story through stills. Many of Van Schaick's pictures were specially staged photo-cenotaphs: looking at his dead babies and (just about living) desiccated greybeards and matrons, it's hard not to think of his work as a kind of mummification. "Memorial photography was the biggest genre of photography in the 1890s," Marsh says. "There's a certain act of magic that takes place for the subjects, and that's a conceptual notion that we tried to build into the film. We might find those images hard to look at, but they have a very honest and tender motivation - to remember a lost life by." The film's oddly haunted feel - as though the actors are possessed by the ancestors they play - derives from the fact that its entire cast is from Wisconsin. Marsh arranged open casting calls in Madison and Milwaukee, specifically for people of Scandinavian or German origins. Two-thirds of them had never acted before, and in fact the film calls for them simply to be there, part of the tableaux. "Most of these people were like open canvases - I wanted them not to act but to be very blank and let the viewer bring the emotions to those faces." A further ring of authenticity comes from the locations, all historical sites in Wisconsin. The film was made during four separate trips, over 16 months, but Marsh spent a year overall in Wisconsin, including time for research, returning to Lesy's original sources. Ostensibly a television film, Wisconsin Death Trip really comes into its own on the big screen; it has already done the rounds of American and European festivals, where it has been widely acclaimed as one of the outstanding recent British films. Shot on a standard documentary budget, with input from American company Cinemax, it is one of several films made for Arena that have had a cinema life - others are Stonewall, Paris is Burning and I Shot Andy Warhol. Marsh himself has made other contributions to Arena's distinctive line in genre-bending documentaries: among them, The Burger and the King (on Elvis Presley's regal diet), Trouble Man (on the death of Marvin Gaye) and assorted "biographies" of pop songs. But only a couple of years after embarking on Wisconsin Death Trip, he is doubtful whether such a film could still be made in Britain. "Arena is one of the last bastions of British TV where you can take an idea that seems so formless and experimental and hybrid and get a hearing. But it's increasingly hard to make those one-off maverick ideas." Now based in New York, Marsh is about to embark on his first fiction feature: murder figures prominently, and no doubt the tormented souls of Black River Falls will smile on his efforts.  Wisconsin Death Trip screens at London's National Film Theatre from next Friday, and is shown on BBC2 on July 2. Michael Lesy's book, Wisconsin Death Trip, is published by University of New Mexico Press.

fields.headline: A guide to film Noiret
fields.standfirst: After 134 films, Philippe Noiret deserves his own genre. Peter Lennon meets France's most enduring star
fields.trailText: After 134 films, Philippe Noiret deserves his own genre. Peter Lennon meets France's most enduring star
fields.body:
In his latest film, The King of Paris, by first-time director Dominique Maillet, Philippe Noiret plays an egotistical stage celebrity of the 30s whose befriending of a calculating waif (Veronika Varga) with theatrical ambitions leads to family tragedy. It is a role his theatrical hero, Jules Berry would have relished: solid fare in the style of 40s Hollywood given resonance, as has so often been the case, by Noiret's performance.

"He had that dimension of folly," Noiret says, "which - alas! - no longer exists in our profession." Reclining at elegant ease in the French ambassador's residence in London, cravat impeccable, trousers pressed to a scimitar's sharpness, shoecaps reflecting the Bourbon trinkets on the marble mantlepiece, Noiret, now 69, gave a profound sigh for times past, the rich baritone-to-bass voice as polished an appendage as anything he wore.

Berry was, in real life and often in his roles, a glorious rogue. He played the fake curé of Renoir's Le Crime de Monsieur Lange and the saturnine seducer of Carné's Le Jour se Lève. "He was a vagabond," Noiret says with approval. "He was a terrible gambler and the bailiffs seized his furniture so often, he had to live permanently in a hotel. He stayed at the Lutetia at Sèvres Babylone. I went to school at the Institut Catholique round the corner and would often see him standing outside the hotel while the porter hailed a taxi for him to go to Longchamps."

Although he made his debut in Agnès Varda's fledgling 1955 work, La Pointe Courte, it was not until 1960 that Noiret, then a renowned stage actor, made his mark on French cinema. In Louis Malle's 1960 classic Zazie dans le Métro, he was the exasperated uncle put in charge of a foul-mouthed 11-year-old, who goes romping through Paris during a Métro strike.

Raymond Queneau's surrealist story gave Noiret the opportunity to put on display a number of his trademark characteristics: the world-weary insouciance (although he was only 30), the air of dreamy disconnection, the bloodhound lugubriousness and the sudden eruptions of robust anger. Above all, it introduced filmgoers to one of the great voices of French cinema, a deep cello sound which somehow escapes fruitiness or affectation.

For the moment he was more concerned with defending comedy, a genre which he believes does not get its due from French critics. He is soon to make a film with Philippe de Broca and applauds de Broca's recent remark: "I demand the right to frivolity."

"We are at an epoch," Noiret says, "when right-thinking people do not approve of making comedy films. It is true that we get less attention from the media when we do a comedy than when we do something serious. We live in a time when the intellectual power of the press has a tendency to be too serious. Above all in France - perhaps in England it is too much on the other side. The equilibrium is difficult to find between a dictatorship of the intellectuals or a dictatorship of entertainment pure and simple."

But Noiret is that kind of well-rounded personality who is as convincing in his defence of high seriousness as he is of its opposite. His international reputation is too often linked to sentimental works such as Il Postino, for which he won a Bafta, and Cinema Paradiso (the film made in 1988 and voted the Guardian readers' favourite film of the last 20 years a few years ago, in which that great voice was lost in the Italian dubbing) but he was also the leader of a bunch of suicidal gluttons in the truly bilious comedy, La Grande Bouffe. What was not evident when he made Zazie was a capacity for sustaining great dramatic roles as a trawl of his 134 films will confirm. It was Bertrand Tavernier who first effectively brought out that capacity in The Watchmaker of St Paul in 1974.

He has often collaborated with Tavernier since and in this professional relationship which has spanned more than 20 years there is a link to an earlier figure crucial to Noiret's development - Jean Vilar, director of the hugely successful Thétre National Populaire. Noiret began his career aged 23 with Vilar's theatre and stayed there for seven years. "I did a bit of everything in the repertoire," he says. "Molière, Mother Courage, Richard III, Murder in the Cathedral - I was one of the knights and also one of the assassins."

Was there a connection in his mind between these two personalities? "It is not by chance I have done so many films with Tavernier," he says. "I re-found Vilar's preoccupations in Tavernier. Tavernier makes films which are popular cinema in the best sense of the word, cinema which is accessible to everyone. But at the same time, they are carriers of certain values, certain commentary on our world. They both have a great sense of justice. They are people who have the courage to effectively participate in the social and political life of an epoch, people who reject this detachment of the artist who lives in his own world protected by his aesthetic preoccupations."

"But they are very different personalities," Noiret says. "One [Vilar] was after all a Protestant, even though he was a Protestant of the Midi, a person very severe of aspect but very kind. While Bertrand is a tempest, a gourmand, an ogre for life and information who does not limit himself in his appetites for culture of all kinds, cinema, Chinese, poetry, astronomy, everything. He wrote a book on Michael Powell - two volumes, not just the usual anecdotal stuff. They are two real books," he says with wonder.

"Tavernier is perhaps the most cultivated man I know. A spirit fabricated from material different from others. At least from mine." He assumes an air of lugubrious modesty.

But he cheers up quickly. We now get on to another monster of the cinema: Hitchcock. In 1969 Hitchcock, needing French actors for Topaz, asked a contact in Paris to put together a reel illustrating the talent and personality of various French actors. Noiret was among those chosen for this particularly sluggish CIA thriller.

"Because it was French critics who elevated Hitchcock to the top rank when his work was regarded as nothing more than good entertainment by the American press," Noiret says, "Hitchcock had a certain tenderness for France.

"We had a very friendly and agreeable relationship. We dined at his hotel, the Plaza Athénée. He liked it very much. He said I know the chef, the cuisine is good, so why go out when I have everything I want here? He did not want to go and have adventures with other restaurants."

Hitchcock was notorious for having worked out every shot and camera angle before shooting a foot of film, leaving little leeway in movement or interpretation for the actor. So how did Noiret feel about submitting to chalk marks? He laughs. "There were no chalk marks. He gave no directions at all," Noiret says. "He gave no hint as to interpretation. The positioning was so precise we did not have any need of guidance as to interpretation. One had a sensation of being, how will I put it..."

Cornered?

"Yes, cornered, but in the best sense. It is true that every movement had its proper space in the frame. One felt that each movement asked for had its raison d'être and this helped indicate your character."

And, after all that, it wasn't his best film?

Noiret laughs. "Far from it."

And what was it like doing Zazie? No chalk marks there?

Noiret reveals a secret of Zazie's curious narrative pace, eccentric even by nouvelle vague standards. This was not achieved by simple mechanical means such as slow and quick motion. "There were certain sequences," Noiret says, "where we were filmed speeded up. But in others Malle said: 'Slow down your movements and I will shoot at normal speed. But since you couldn't move with a truly accurate rhythm it will give something strange to your movements.' "

What became of the little girl, Catherine Demongeot? "She abandoned the cinema. She became a professor of French. She was very charming and had a talent for irony which is rare in a child. But she never made another film."

After moving to the commercial theatre, where he played in the first production of Françoise Sagan's Un Château en Suède, Noiret abandoned the theatre in favour of cinema. "I did both at the same time and found it was very disagreeable trying to fit it in," he says. "I lost the pleasure of working in the theatre and since the cinema was something new, I developed a taste for it. They also offered interesting roles.

"I remained 30 years without doing theatre and I regret it," he says. "But two years ago, I returned to the theatre just by chance. The film director, Bertrand Blier, wrote his first play for two actors, one part was written for Gérard Depardieu, who said yes and then no. We have the same agent and he suggested me and I did it."

In his next stage performance, he will take the Gambon part in The Unexpected Man, Yasmina Reza's double interior monologue of a novelist and a woman in a train compartment.

Noiret is married to the actress Monique Chaumette. They have a daughter. "We have been married 40 years," Noiret says. "I think they may be erecting a statue to us representing conjugal love."

 The King of Paris opens next Friday.

fields.headline: Mission: musical
fields.standfirst: Soundtracks are an integral part of movies and their promotion. Scott Hughes traces their track record and reviews the top 10
fields.trailText: Soundtracks are an integral part of movies and their promotion. Scott Hughes traces their track record and reviews the top 10
fields.body:
They'd never done it before. But, with a screening of some rough footage, and, no doubt, a big white grin, Tom Cruise managed to persuade US rock giants Metallica - for the first time in their two-decade career - to lend new material to a film. Their song I Disappear is the lead-off cut from the soundtrack to the Cruise-starring Mission: Impossible 2, which two weeks ago entered the US album chart at No 2, though the film has yet to appear. "If you are going to associate yourself with a movie, this is the perfect one," enthused the band's Lars Ulrich. "Everything about it is big. We love it."

Well, everybody else is doing it - why shouldn't they? This year alone, U2 have knocked out new tunes for Wim Wenders' The Million Dollar Hotel, while Madonna has warmed over Don McLean's American Pie for her latest vehicle, The Next Best Thing. And, as yet more pop stars attempt to launch movie careers, we find three-quarters of All Saints warbling Motown classics on the soundtrack to Honest (their debut acting gig), and the unstoppable Geri Halliwell announcing she will both star in and provide much of the music for a new British film, Therapy.

It's little wonder artists are so keen to get themselves on to these discs: a hit movie theme can be just what a big act needs to keep things ticking over between tours and studio albums. What's more, soundtracks have been the sleeper album chart success story of the last decade. In 1996 an America industry survey found that US music buyers were snapping up four times as many soundtrack albums as they had been 10 years before.

Over there, 15 soundtracks (unlike in the UK, they are included in the main album chart) accounted for 73 weeks at No 1 between the start of 1990 and the close of 1999, 20 of those weeks being registered by the album for The Bodyguard - the catalyst perhaps for the massive interest being witnessed now. Over here, two film themes - Bryan Adams's Everything I Do (I Do It for You) from Robin Hood: Prince of Thieves, and Wet Wet Wet's Love Is All Around (Four Weddings and a Funeral) - became the longest-running singles chart number ones ever.

Evidently, movie music in recent times has moved a lot of people, if only in the direction of the nearest HMV. Big theme songs, invariably belted out by big names, have increasingly been issued to radio before anybody has even seen the films from which they are taken - purpose-built to dominate the airwaves in the weeks before to the film's release and play their part in creating a "buzz". Put simply, soundtracks have shifted from being a mere film tie-in to a powerful, up-front marketing tool.

When distributor Miramax decided in 1994 to spend £1m giving a hip soundtrack to Kevin Smith's debut Clerks - a film which cost $27,000 to make - it seemed to be trying to launch a film off the back of a record than vice versa. Put big stars in your movie, put big stars on your soundtrack, the credo now seems to be, and sit back as hopefully one helps sell the other.

It goes without saying that Hollywood and the music business have always been good pals: Bond movies, for instance, have long relied on a brassy theme song by a top-drawer artist, and producer Robert Stigwood commissioned songs for Saturday Night Fever before the script and director were in place. But in recent years this friendship has become even closer - a development easily explained by the fact that Hollywood and the music business are now pretty much one and the same entity. Warners, DreamWorks and Sony/Columbia all produce records with one arm and films with another; in fact, of the major studios, only Fox and Paramount do not have an affiliated record label.

So when, say, a film is deemed to need a pop-oriented rather than score soundtrack (some have both), one of three things tends to happen. If the studio's associated record label is prepared to shell out serious cash, it gets its top artists to record new songs, producing a compilation which puts forward its biggest and best. Last summer's Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me, as a New Line Cinema release (a Warner subsidiary), got a soundtrack featuring Warner big guns such as Madonna, Lenny Kravitz, Green Day and REM.

Madonna's specially written track Beautiful Stranger was chosen to launch the album (released on Maverick, Madonna's own label and a Warner imprint), and its heavy airplay no doubt played a key part in creating advance awareness of the film. But the really clever move on the part of the record company was that, while Beautiful Stranger reached No 2 in the UK chart, it was not issued as a single in America - increasingly common practice in an effort to shift more albums (which make big profits) rather than singles (which don't). This meant that anyone wanting to own the track would have to buy the entire album, and 1.3m did.

Alternatively, a record company can take a song from a recent or upcoming release, perhaps by a nascent or struggling act who would benefit from the exposure afforded by a film. When a Columbia rep caught the live act of Nashville quintet Sixpence None The Richer, he hawked their ballad Kiss Me around various film producers until meeting with interest from the makers of 1999 teen sleeper She's All That.

An official soundtrack was never released, but ads for the movie used the cut, and the video featured leads Freddie Prinze Jr and Rachael Leigh Cooke, consolidating the film-music crossover. The result? Eight years after their formation, the band's 1997 album vaulted up the US chart. Naturally, though, the most cost-effective soundtrack albums are for those movies which don't require new recordings. Nostalgia-fests such as New Line's 1985-set The Wedding Singer gave Warner the opportunity to repackage various New Romantic hits from its archive and sell them again to a generation who'd never heard of Dead or Alive or Culture Club. Also riding the retro wave, the recent rash of 70s-set films (Boogie Nights, 54, Summer Of Sam) has caused the market to be flooded with uninspired disco compilations.

But at least the songs featured on such soundtracks might be said to have successfully evoked an era. Albums such as those for Mission: Impossible 2 and last year's The Matrix have predictably traded on the films' young male appeal to showcase hard rock or rap acts (Marilyn Manson, Limp Bizkit, Rage Against The Machine) but have only the most tenuous of links to the plot. Some records are even billed as "songs inspired by the motion picture", which generally seems to herald a collection of tunes whose inclusion is not only hard to justify artistically, but of which many are not even heard in the film.

Soundtrack albums are now less about complementing a director's vision than about overall brand strengthening, and, ultimately, seeking to be hit records in their own right. The very shape of a film is increasingly being dictated by the records a film producer or music supervisor has at his disposal. When they secured use of Britney Spears' hit (You Drive Me) Crazy, the makers of Close To You (a forthcoming Fox teen flick starring Melissa Joan Hart of Sabrina The Teenage Witch fame) promptly changed the movie's title to Drive Me Crazy.

It's enough to make one wonder just who is getting to choose what we hear in films. It's certainly not very often the director. Tom Cruise's involvement in the Mission: Impossible 2 soundtrack would just seem to signal yet another aspect of film production falling under the control of an A-list star. John Cusack had a hand in compiling the soundtrack to his new film, High Fidelity. For more dance-oriented soundtracks, the latest trend seems to be to have a top DJ put a set together: Pete Tong (working with director Danny Boyle) was music supervisor for The Beach, while Judge Jules worked on the album for Ibiza romp Kevin and Perry Go Large.

Some auteurs, though, are resisting the drive to choose movie music that will easily translate into hit records. Curtis Hanson, director of LA Confidential, insisted on control of the music for that film, assembling songs during writing and shooting, and has chosen four tracks by Bob Dylan (including one new recording) for his new offering, Wonder Boys. Martin Scorsese famously edits scenes to the music he has picked to help tell his story; it's then the label's job to hunt down and acquire the rights from various music publishers to what he has chosen.

And, encouragingly, some musicians are taking a more active role in the creation of movie music, by actually writing scores rather than just supplying one or two radio-friendly hits. Damon Albarn provided songs and score material for this year's Brit thriller Ordinary Decent Criminal, REM did the same for Andy Kaufman biopic Man On the Moon, and Air lent their dreamy electronica to The Virgin Suicides, while Magnolia was "inspired by Aimee Mann's songs".

Record companies would argue that soundtrack albums, however distant from the films they supposedly support, still represent good value for money for the record buyer. And maybe they have a point. The listener may be getting 10 to 15 tracks from a variety of artists for £13 - a cheaper option than searching out the albums they were taken from, or buying the singles.

But, as record companies, like film studios, wheel out ever bigger stars, the cost of producing these albums is spiralling, making assembling these records as much of a high-stakes business as film production itself. Bodyguards and Saturday Night Fevers are very few and far between: a great many of these albums will end up not in the record books, but the bargain bin.

Gross and grosser

America's biggest selling soundtracks of all time:

1. The Bodyguard (1992, 16 million) Spawned the monster/monstrous I Will Always Love You plus four other hits, now all back with a vengeance on Whitney Houston's current No 1 Greatest Hits set. The US's ninth biggest-selling album of all time.

2. Saturday Night Fever (1977, 15 million) Virtually every track has been covered or reworked (by the likes of er, N-Trance, 911, Kim Wilde). Never mind the Bee Gees' meaningless songs in high voices, this is the album that brought you disco interpretations of Mussorgsky's Night On Bare Mountain and Beethoven's Fifth. Honestly.

3. Purple Rain (1984, 13 million) Some memorable songs (Purple Rain, When Doves Cry, Let's Go Crazy); one eminently forgettable movie.

4. Dirty Dancing (1987, 11 million) Is anybody owning up to buying this? Pray Ricky Martin and Natalie Portman turn down rumoured offers to star in a sequel.

5. Titanic (1998, 11 million) The biggest-selling score soundtrack of all time, no doubt helped by the inclusion of Celine Dion's dirge-like My Heart Will Go On.

6. The Lion King (1994, 10 million) Disney movie in Best Original Song Oscar win shocker (for Can You Feel The Love Tonight). Ten weeks atop the US charts for Elton John-Tim Rice kiddie sing-a-long.

7. Grease (1978, 8 million) The only soundtrack to an actual musical left in the top 10. Spun off a succession of transatlantic smash hits (Summer Nights, You're The One That I Want).

8. Footloose (1984, 8 million) American youth defies small-town puritanism by getting on down to... Kenny Loggins. Oh, and Bonnie Tyler.

9. Top Gun (1986, 7 million) Gave us Berlin's end-of-the-evening power ballad Take My Breath Away, Kenny Loggins' Danger Zone and The Righteous Brothers' You've Lost That Lovin' Feeling - all on one handy album. Were we meant to be grateful?

10. Waiting To Exhale (1995, 7 million) Chick movie, chick soundtrack. Whitney again, though this time not hogging most of the album - appearances also by Toni Braxton, Mary J Blige and TLC.

But, with a screening of some rough footage, and, no doubt, a big white grin, Tom Cruise managed to persuade US rock giants Metallica - for the first time in their two-decade career - to lend new material to a film. Their song I Disappear is the lead-off cut from the soundtrack to the Cruise-starring Mission: Impossible 2, which two weeks ago entered the US album chart at No 2, though the film has yet to appear. "If you are going to associate yourself with a movie, this is the perfect one," enthused the band's Lars Ulrich. "Everything about it is big. We love it." Well, everybody else is doing it - why shouldn't they? This year alone, U2 have knocked out new tunes for Wim Wenders' The Million Dollar Hotel, while Madonna has warmed over Don McLean's American Pie for her latest vehicle, The Next Best Thing. And, as yet more pop stars attempt to launch movie careers, we find three-quarters of All Saints warbling Motown classics on the soundtrack to Honest (their debut acting gig), and the unstoppable Geri Halliwell announcing she will both star in and provide much of the music for a new British film, Therapy. It's little wonder artists are so keen to get themselves on to these discs: a hit movie theme can be just what a big act needs to keep things ticking over between tours and studio albums. What's more, soundtracks have been the sleeper album chart success story of the last decade. In 1996 an America industry survey found that US music buyers were snapping up four times as many soundtrack albums as they had been 10 years before. Over there, 15 soundtracks (unlike in the UK, they are included in the main album chart) accounted for 73 weeks at No 1 between the start of 1990 and the close of 1999, 20 of those weeks being registered by the album for The Bodyguard - the catalyst perhaps for the massive interest being witnessed now. Over here, two film themes - Bryan Adams's Everything I Do (I Do It for You) from Robin Hood: Prince of Thieves, and Wet Wet Wet's Love Is All Around (Four Weddings and a Funeral) - became the longest-running singles chart number ones ever. Evidently, movie music in recent times has moved a lot of people, if only in the direction of the nearest HMV. Big theme songs, invariably belted out by big names, have increasingly been issued to radio before anybody has even seen the films from which they are taken - purpose-built to dominate the airwaves in the weeks before to the film's release and play their part in creating a "buzz". Put simply, soundtracks have shifted from being a mere film tie-in to a powerful, up-front marketing tool. When distributor Miramax decided in 1994 to spend £1m giving a hip soundtrack to Kevin Smith's debut Clerks - a film which cost $27,000 to make - it seemed to be trying to launch a film off the back of a record than vice versa. Put big stars in your movie, put big stars on your soundtrack, the credo now seems to be, and sit back as hopefully one helps sell the other. It goes without saying that Hollywood and the music business have always been good pals: Bond movies, for instance, have long relied on a brassy theme song by a top-drawer artist, and producer Robert Stigwood commissioned songs for Saturday Night Fever before the script and director were in place. But in recent years this friendship has become even closer - a development easily explained by the fact that Hollywood and the music business are now pretty much one and the same entity. Warners, DreamWorks and Sony/Columbia all produce records with one arm and films with another; in fact, of the major studios, only Fox and Paramount do not have an affiliated record label. So when, say, a film is deemed to need a pop-oriented rather than score soundtrack (some have both), one of three things tends to happen. If the studio's associated record label is prepared to shell out serious cash, it gets its top artists to record new songs, producing a compilation which puts forward its biggest and best. Last summer's Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me, as a New Line Cinema release (a Warner subsidiary), got a soundtrack featuring Warner big guns such as Madonna, Lenny Kravitz, Green Day and REM. Madonna's specially written track Beautiful Stranger was chosen to launch the album (released on Maverick, Madonna's own label and a Warner imprint), and its heavy airplay no doubt played a key part in creating advance awareness of the film. fields.headline: Matt effect
fields.standfirst: Four years ago, Matthew McConaughey was all set to conquer Hollywood. Now, with U-571, it looks like he's finally achieved it. Libby Brooks caught up with him
fields.trailText: Four years ago, Matthew McConaughey was all set to conquer Hollywood. Now, with U-571, it looks like he's finally achieved it. Libby Brooks caught up with him
fields.body:
Stillness is not his style. Crammed into an armchair in an austere London hotel room, Matthew McConaughey's lengthy legs are experiencing a parallel jive-related existence underneath the coffee table. "Anywhere, anytime is a good time to dance," he opines. "It's the second form, after making love, of exercise. It's the original form of celebration. And everyone can do their own dance. You can tap yourself on the head for five straight minutes and that's your dance if that's what you hear." It's a rare moment of enthusiasm from the 30-year-old Texan, who appears to be saving his sunny-side-up for a rainier day than this one.

The McConaughey effect has been slow burning as a mosquito coil. It is four years since his performance as a campaigning lawyer in Joel Schumacher's A Time to Kill propelled him onto the cover of four magazines, including Vanity Fair, within a single month in 1996. But subsequent ill-aligned castings in Amistad and Contact did not serve to secure his footing as young pretender, while his homely hedonism signalled neither edge nor ease cleanly enough. The twinkly precision he displayed in Ron Howard's EDtv, as an every-bloke who stars in the access-all-hours show of his life, was unluckily adrift in the aftermath of The Truman Show.

The "new Newman" sobriquet may be ragged at the toes, but there remains a suspicion that McConaughey's vivid and instinctual star quality could yet ignite Hollywood's fickle tinder. Meanwhile, the man whose "innate integrity and elegance" so impressed Schumacher, remains keenly philosophical on the dynamic nexus between chance and self-determination.

"I think if you rely on Fate, it bites you in the butt. If you blow in the wind, you're going to get dropped in the gutter. But responsibility is when you create your own weather. Whether it's the people you hang out with, the places you choose to go, the things you choose to do, you have to be responsible to it, and the more responsible you are, the more Lady Luck, she shines on you. It's circular. It keeps coming back and regurgitates."

McConaughey's latest screen offering is the hot oil and deep water U-571. Heavy on incidental orchestrals and light on historical exactitude, it tells the ripping yarn of a daring US navy mission during the second world war to capture a secret Nazi coding device from a German U-boat. McConaughey plays an ambitious but compassionate officer who, following the demise of his captain, discovers that commanding his depleted crew demands tough decisions and tougher to deliver dialogue. And it reminds the viewer why there are so few great submarine movies.

He is certainly at one with the masculine imperative of the role. "I liked being the guy who took action; I was happy to see the dexterity of Andrew Tyler, to give an order here, receive information here, while doing this job there. I liked the dance." His character was the kind of leader he would like to be. "I've been asked a lot whether I would want to serve my country. For the right reason, the right cause, it would be an honour. And, yes, I would like to be the one in command.

"I think that I'm equipped as well as anyone. I trust myself to make the right decision at a time like that, objectively. I'm not a tyrant, I'm not follyful, I think I'm very fair-minded, and I'm not the guy who will lock up under pressure," he expounds, with the amiable certainty of a 16-year-old on a Sega. He is blurry on the question of historical accuracy. U-571 would appear to be based upon the first capture of an Enigma machine at sea by the British Navy, six months before America entered the war, and the film includes a mollifying dedication to "all the Allied sailors who captured Enigma machines".

But there is only a responsibility to historical truths if a film presents itself as a biography or documentary, he argues. "A lot of people go to films for the legitimate reason of escaping somewhere. We're storytellers, they're yarns."

McConaughey is, for all intents and purposes, a babe; though it is hard to fathom in his present begrudging slump. His perfectly pumped muscle groups seem to be in the right order, as a forlorn flower wilts atop his jacket pocket like a forgotten friend. The blond curls are slicked into submission, and his eyes wash over one with all the engagement and urgency of day-old bath water getting past a drain blockage. His soft, low drawl, at least, is charming.

He admits to being "pretty ambitious". Whether U-571 will augment his possibilities remains moot, but it has taken more in its first week in the US than EDtv made throughout its release. One cultivates an indifference for the box office, he says. "I learnt that lesson with EDtv - that movie was backed, marketed, had all kinds of money on it, and it just bombed. I thought we had a home run. On the opening weekend of U-571, I'd done everything I could, I was happy that people agreed, but it didn't improve the quality of my day."

He is equivocal about the notion of passion for acting. "Would I survive without it? Sure. Is it my end all? No. But it is my vocation, my occupation, it's what I grow through, and where I experiment. To what extent I'm giving back to the world through it I don't know, but it's my avenue of communication." His favourite art, he adds, is the art of living.

He's currently working on several projects of his own, including a biopic of his childhood hero, Evel Knievel. But rather poignantly, his first movie - the 70s-set high school stoner romp Dazed and Confused, which he made in 1993 - remains his favourite. "There's nothing like the first time," he says wistfully, "and I learned it the right way. I worked with great people, learnt to improvise. It was so pure, and really innocent. It worked."

Meanwhile, one might hazard that he'll keep on moving any which way he can, though probably with curtains shut. McConaughey was arrested last year while playing the bongos naked in his living room, and spent the night in police custody, although all charges, including that of possession of marijuana, were subsequently dropped.

He continues to play the bongos, both clothed and unclothed, and enjoys any music with bass and percussion. "I play my stomach and chest a lot. Depending on how much air I leave in my stomach and how high I go on my chest it makes four different drums." (No, he won't do it to order, although he does offer a weedy whistle instead.) He is ambivalent about cannabis legalisation. "It's been proven to be harmless if used responsibly. But I've seen people smoke themselves into such complacency. You've got to do something with your day."

As he talks, he is fiddling with what at first glance looks like an unravelled tampon. But as he is about to insist that his strength as an actor lies in "the ability to be the man's man" one must charitably assume it's something for cleaning guns. He is from the south after all.

The youngest of three brothers, McConaughey was raised on Methodism and manners in Uvalde, Texas. He originally went to the state university in Austin to study law, before switching to film studies after a year. He continues to reside there and, though mildly wary of the good ole boy persona, his truths are so homespun one can still see the thumbprints.

"I get asked, so are you a cowboy? Well, yeah, I'm a cowboy. I don't wear boots or a cowboy hat, but I hop in my car and go on cross-country road trips with myself all the time."

Spontaneity remains paramount. "I'm the guy who may give you a better present on Tuesday than on your birthday. I don't like being programmed. If I see something that reminds me of you, I'm gonna get it and give it to you tomorrow. It reminds me of that Willie Nelson lyric, 'I'd rather give you a puppy than diamonds and gold'." A good reason to leave town on a Monday night, then.

 U-571 opens next Friday.

fields.headline: Shame of a nation
fields.standfirst: Huge sums of money have been spent on British films in the past five years - and still most of them are awful. Jacques Peretti thinks he knows why
fields.trailText: Huge sums of money have been spent on British films in the past five years - and still most of them are awful. Jacques Peretti thinks he knows why
fields.body:
If the British film industry were a football team, they'd have spent three times what Manchester United spend in one season on players... with the success of Watford. If you think I'm exaggerating, the London Evening Standard has a running total on how much lottery money has been spent on British films. At present, the figure is £100m.

Why are British films so terrible? So stunningly, excruciatingly, exquisitely bad? Alan Parker, the new film tsar, blames the scripts. The "high concept", Cecil B DeMille once said, can be scribbled on the back of a cigarette packet. But most Brit-flicks have the entire script actually scribbled on the back of a cigarette packet, written in the time it took for someone to buy a drink at Soho House.

Next week sees the release of a film that could change the British film industry's fortunes. (How many times have you heard that before?) On paper, Maybe Baby has plenty going for it: a script by Ben Elton (disliked by the critics, but still a crowd-puller). Hugh Laurie and Joely Richardson playing a childless couple who embark on infertility treatment - with hilarious consequences!

Maybe Baby is the Platonic ideal of a Brit-flick. It is Peter's Friends, 10 years on: the generation ensemble movie with everyone present and politically correct: Dawn; Rowan; Jo-Jo Lummers; darling Joely and the Hugh that isn't Grant.

But since Peter's Friends, Ben's gang has been replaced by a new generation of lottery-flush actors and writers. The king and queen of the scene are Jude Law and Sadie Frost, who met on the set of that ram-raiding disaster, Shopping. It was during Shopping that Law perfected his latter-day Sid James persona: a little bit wooh/a little bit wey, the same in every single film.

Law and Frost have a coterie of collaborators, the Primrose Hill mob, who appear in just about any film going, no matter how dreadful. It includes Sean Pertwee (Jon's son), who spent the whole of Shopping saying "'Allo, Billy" with the worst mockney accent since Dick Van Dyke in Mary Poppins. Pertwee also starred in that Brit-surfing classic, Blue Juice, set in the crazy teashop scene round St Ives and starring that inflatable actress, Catherine Zeta-Jones. It's good to have a small group of people you can blame for this incessant stream of terrible films, because one of the first questions you ask yourself when you see something like Blue Juice is: Why? And then, more to the point: Who? Who is to blame for this crime?

Frost cannot go from one day to the next without appearing in a dog of a film. Because she has problems remembering which one she's in, Sadie makes life easier by having all her characters called Sadie. There was Sadie in Final Cut, and Sadie in Love, Honour & Obey. Did I say Jude was in that too? Well, he was. Playing Jude, the Vogue readers' Jamie Theakston.

Final Cut is physically unwatchable. In that sense, it's in a league of its own. Many bad films can be endured with a small amount of alcohol, but Final Cut is beyond drink. It's aversion therapy. Final Cut belongs to a clear sub-genre of Brit-flicks: the wobbly-super8-let's-just-get-all-our-showbiz-mates-together-and-arse-about movie (heavy on narration because action sequences require some cursory knowledge of film-making). It thinks it's Truffaut, but comes across as Grange Hill.

Other sub-genres include:

The Hardship Movie. Grubbing about in poverty with some of the biggest names in the business, such as Gary Oldman (Nil by Mouth) and Tim Roth (The War Zone) who, keen to outdo one another in the who-had-the-most-deprived-childhood, plunge to new depths of on-screen squalor.

These sorts of films are the arty cinematic equivalent of Oprah and Roseanne claiming they were abused as children. It doesn't cut the Colman's. Shane Meadows (TwentyFourSeven) is a seasoned newcomer to this genre, but needs a big hit in Hollywood before he can make it truly down'n'dirty. He's also slightly too good with a camera, which he'll need to rectify if he's to make an authentic Brit-flick.

Then there's The Clubbing Film: Human Traffic stands alone here, a towering giant amongst pigmies. Human Traffic was widely hyped as having the most authentic off-your-head scenes yet filmed (as if this was a recommendation). It's the kind of boast that puts club movies on the same footing as 3-D monster movies from the 1950s ("most realistic 3-D beast with or without the glasses!"). The film was as brainless as clubbing, and in that respect, was highly authentic.

Clogging the system like hair in a drain, the most crowded Brit-flick category of all (bar Cockney Gangster): The Brit-Rom-Com (British Romantic Comedy) or Notting Hill movie. Such an illustrious lineage: This Year's Love, with Kathy Burke - as entertaining as rickets; Fanny & Elvis, starring Kerry Fox (Shallow Grave) and Ray Winstone (hired by the Primrose Hill mob whenever they want a real actor to play a diamond geezer). Kerry drives a VW, looking like a mid-80s Nescafé ad, and Ray is a Jag man. Guess what? Opposites attract! Leading by a mile, however, is Martha Meet Frank, Daniel & Laurence. With a plot shorter than the title, this film assembled the most obnoxious cast since The Railway Children. It was compelling like a road crash.

This genre is also known as the Colin Firth movie. Interestingly, after Firth starred in Fever Pitch, the big Hollywood adaptation of High Fidelity, starring John Cusack and completely junking any Hornby element, demonstrates at a stroke why the US is the most successful movie-making nation on earth... and we are not.

In Britain, the film would have been faithful to the book, but at some late-point in production, swerved uncontrollably towards schmaltz. The resulting compromise, so typical of Brit-flicks, is the cinematic equivalent of welding two cars together. Its one of the reasons Brit-flicks look so weird.

The Americans, by contrast, have a fantastically fascistic rigour when it comes to the requirements of a formula movie. British directors, ably assisted by a huge slush fund of lottery cash, feel free to splash indulgently about in any subject matter they choose, unburdened by constraints like story or box-office success.

This leads to a surreal breadth of subject matter. Brit-flicks are nothing if not wide-ranging. Out now! There's Simon Magus, an off-kilter comedy about living in mud (a gap-toothed take on Harrison Ford's Witness). Guru in Seven, a black commitment-comedy. Honest: All Saints packing shooters in a Ladybird book rendering of the late 60s. The Clandestine Marriage: costume romp starring ex-EastEnder Paul Nicholls (more wooden than the set). And The Last Yellow: Meantime updated and given the obligatory Professionals/kipper-tie references. Brothers is still an unknown quantity, but the portents aren't good.

It's possible to see any combo of subjects in a Brit-flick, just so long as they're mad! And kooky! Seal-killing satire with a side-line in espionage and fish-keeping? Coming up (it won't be any good, or have made any money, but there'll be 12 copies at Blockbuster - all starring Samantha Janus).

The unintentional template for all Brit flicks is Absolute Beginners, Julien Temple's cavernous musical adaptation of Colin MacInnes's beat novel. The film was a badly-lit mistake starring Patsy Kensit, but with its strange mix of over-choreographed action, low-rent acting and soaring ambition, it has provided Brit-flicks with their holy trinity.

A therapist would say that film-makers unconsciously replicate the errors of their forebears, and so it has been with the descendants of Absolute Beginners. The current Brit-flick catastrophe, Circus, starring Eddie Izzard as kooky(!), mad(!) gangster (the funniest thing he's done for years) is pure Absolute Beginners. It's also, consciously, an attempt to gain some reflected ambience from A Clockwork Orange. The rape-operatics of Kubrick's classic have been mistakenly replicated in a thousand shit Brit-flicks. As a film that comments on the logical conclusion of banality as entertainment, however, A Clockwork Orange now looks less frightening than the kind of no-brain movie Kubrick was satirising.

In order to see if any film, no matter how tasteless, rubbish and moronic could be made, I asked a film producer friend of mine (let's call him Crispin) to look at some treatments I'd knocked up. Crispin, you must remember, has just been given money to make a third lottery flop. Modern film producers have come to resemble bands cashing-in on the tail end of punk. Films like Circus are the Sham 69 of Brit-flicks: ludicrous tribute acts with the even more ludicrous good fortune to get made.

Even Crispin knows his third film (a club movie - with "a surreal edge") will bomb without trace, but does he care? No.

We meet in Soho House (of course) and I lay my ideas on the table.

Film Proposal One: The Score

Me: "It's about a Glaswegian teenage drug-addict who gets signed to Manchester United's youth team (under the wing of a fatherly talent scout). I know the title's crap, but that's deliberate."

Crispin: "Not interested."

Me: "Why not? It's got two key Brit-flick ingredients: drugs and football."

Crispin: "Football is so 90s. Besides, you'd never get the access. United have their own TV franchise."

Me: "We could try a smaller club. Maybe Port Vale or Tranmere Rovers?"

Crispin draws my attention to three football turkeys: When Saturday Comes with Sean Bean; The Match with Max Beesley, who used to be an acid jazz drummer; and Fever Pitch with Colin Firth. "And there are plenty more dismal footie films where they came from." I withdraw without mentioning Best.

Film Proposal Two: Spitalfield Carrots

Me: "It's a romantic comedy about an organic stall holder who falls in love with a mysterious carrot-purchasing woman."

Crispin: "I like it. East London is very now and the carrots are a quirky idea. Do they get political? It'd be nice to have them join Reclaim the Streets and trash McDonald's."

Me: "Er, I dunno."

Crispin: "Work on it."

I'm so excited about Spitalfield Carrots, I don't even wait around to pitch Trance Killers, my club movie about two DJs who murder crowds with a deadly trance record, made from high-frequency noises.

Crispin tells me that he's willing to pitch Spitalfield Carrots to the Film Council. "Don't you think the title's a bit... off-putting?" I ask Crispin, on the steps of Soho House. "They made Rancid Aluminium, didn't they?" he says, and turns on his Prada soft-shoe.

Rancid Aluminium is the yardstick by which all things spiritual and temporal must now be judged. By universal consent, it is the worst film ever made in the UK. People who have seen it belong to an exclusive club. They cannot speak about the film, they simply shudder at its mention.

In many ways, Rancid Aluminium is beyond criticism because it is very hard, even after several viewings, to work out what the hell is going on. Rhys Ifans (the smelly bloke from Notting Hill) is drawn into a convoluted plot by the Russian mafia (jaw-dropping performances by Steven Berkoff and Keith Allen). There's a lot of running around, reminiscent of a Benny Hill sketch; some Lock, Stock posturing; and the obligatory appearance of Sadie Frost, for once not playing a character called Sadie.

The high point however, is the big-screen debut of Dani Behr, who plays the enigmatic "Charlie" with all the charm and presence of Dani Behr. She really is a name to watch for in the future.

With films like Rancid Aluminium being released, is it any wonder that the Guardian-reading cinema audience are flocking back to world cinema? Three hours of a Patagonian sheep-herder alone on a hill is far preferable to another cockney gangster movie with an "ironic" appearance from Bobby Davro.

In 30 years' time, a future Jonathan Ross will be curating cult seasons at the NFT of the very best of the worst of the Brit-flicks. Already, people have begun to hire video tapes of these films in a post-ironic way, pawing over each painful detail with relish. Brit-flicks will soon have all the obscure niche cool of Danish wrestling films from the 1950s.

There's a scene in Ben Elton's Maybe Baby which encapsulates the truth about Brit-flicks. Ewan Proclaimer, an Irvine Welsh parody, played with karaoke Scottish accent by Tom Hollander (the diminutive fiance of Saffi in Absolutely Fabulous) attacks Hugh Laurie for rejecting his script, Sick Junkies.

"Tell me, you uptight English bastard. When did you last write a script? At least I know my script is shite, but what's more, I knew it was shite before you told me it was shite. Let me tell you, pal. My shite shits on your shite."

Brit-flicks are shit-flicks because the whole process is motivated by the desire to out-dross your nearest rival. It's no way to run an industry, but somehow, it happened.

Brit films: five of the worst

1 Rancid Aluminum

A film so incomprehensible and deeply lacklustre in all departments that in The Editor's round-up of reviewers, it averaged one out of 10. Wannabe thriller with Sadie Frost and Rhys Ifans. And Dani Behr.

2 Mad Cows

Anna Friel manages to dip below the underwhelming Land Girls and Rogue Trader in a shrill and desperate "comedy" with Joanna Lumley.

3 Fever Pitch

Colin Firth was the deeply tedious Arsenal fan, Ruth Gemmell his understandably miffed on-off love interest. Duller than a George Graham offside trap.

4 Final Cut

Jude and Sadie as Jude and Sadie. Two Rays playing two Rays. It's improv, innit?

5 Up 'n' Under

A crap pub rugby team has to win a match. They do. Er, that's it.

(Jonathan Cape, £18) digested in the style of the original.
Buy it at BOL
fields.trailText: I write both to commemorate my father and to set the record straight. This will involve me in the indulgence of certain bad habits. Name dropping is one of them. But I've been indulging in this, in a way, ever since I first said, "Mart".
fields.body:
I write both to commemorate my father and to set the record straight. This will involve me in the indulgence of certain bad habits. Name dropping is one of them. But I've been indulging in this, in a way, ever since I first said, "Mart".

There will be no point-scoring, valued reader, though if you're reading this, Jules, I'd like to say that it was you who turned away from me, not I who turned away from you. So you can fuck right off for a start. And as for you, Thersites Eric, who demeaned and defiled our family after Kingsley's death, I'll deal with you and the toiling small-holders of the Fourth Estate in a 10-page appendix.

Rather, this is the journey through the unconscious, the "un" conscious, the un, of how the fledgling Osric became Hamlet, Prince of Westbourne Grove. It is here in the world of un, that murky novelist's landscape, where experience is collected, connections are made and communion is Freely given and received. Here we will find the pain schedule, the climacteric collision of the missing and the lost, the Delilahs and the Lucys, and the loves that come and go. There is no morality. What must be, must be. All we can do is rage and hurt and pay the bill.

It is the late 1970s. The gross of condoms that Kingsley gave me and Phillip have long since been used. Many times over. I am looking at a photo of a two-year-old girl, another version of myself.

"Do you think she might be mine," I asked my mother.

"Definitely."

"What shall I do?"

"Nothing."

But I didn't do nothing. I didn't see her or take an interest in her, obviously. No, I did something more profound and important. I wrote about her. In scribendo veritas. A careful reading of my novels, from the publication of Success in 1978 onwards, will reveal a stream of lost or wandering and putative or fugitive fathers. So Delilah and I were always together, our inner-selves linked in un-ness, un-needing of a corporeal presence.

The mid-90s were my lurid years, using lurid strictly according to the condensed epic poem of the Fowlers' article in the COD. A mid-life crisis is critical in a man; a man who reaches his forties without one has no concept of the continuum of being. The beginnings and the endings. And all things must end. My marriage to Antonia was ending, my teeth had prematurely resigned and Kingsley was creeping to his reluctant adieu. Only Saul, the world's other great novelist, could truly comfort.

But in the endings there are also joys. There is you, Isabel, and Delilah, who have come back to me. Immenso giubilo. I worried that you and the boys would not get on. Ridiculous. And even with no genetic barrier between me and my own mortality, there is a freedom in being orphaned. My tennis has got much, much better since Kingsley died. There. My experience is told. Now there is the living to be done.
And if you really are pressed: The digested read, digested:
Brilliantly written, highly selective, episodic portrayal of a life well-thought but only half felt.

Here we will find the pain schedule, the climacteric collision of the missing and the lost, the Delilahs and the Lucys, and the loves that come and go. There is no morality. What must be, must be. All we can do is rage and hurt and pay the bill. It is the late 1970s. The gross of condoms that Kingsley gave me and Phillip have long since been used. Many times over. I am looking at a photo of a two-year-old girl, another version of myself. "Do you think she might be mine," I asked my mother. "Definitely." "What shall I do?" "Nothing." But I didn't do nothing. I didn't see her or take an interest in her, obviously. No, I did something more profound and important. I wrote about her. In scribendo veritas. A careful reading of my novels, from the publication of Success in 1978 onwards, will reveal a stream of lost or wandering and putative or fugitive fathers. So Delilah and I were always together, our inner-selves linked in un-ness, un-needing of a corporeal presence. The mid-90s were my lurid years, using lurid strictly according to the condensed epic poem of the Fowlers' article in the COD. A mid-life crisis is critical in a man; a man who reaches his forties without one has no concept of the continuum of being. The beginnings and the endings. And all things must end. My marriage to Antonia was ending, my teeth had prematurely resigned and Kingsley was creeping to his reluctant adieu. Only Saul, the world's other great novelist, could truly comfort. But in the endings there are also joys. There is you, Isabel, and Delilah, who have come back to me. Immenso giubilo. I worried that you and the boys would not get on. Ridiculous. And even with no genetic barrier between me and my own mortality, there is a freedom in being orphaned. My tennis has got much, much better since Kingsley died. There. My experience is told. Now there is the living to be done. And if you really are pressed: The digested read, digested: Brilliantly written, highly selective, episodic portrayal of a life well-thought but only half felt.

fields.headline: Man is a Woman
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: [Antoine de Caunes] is actually an intelligent and stylish actor ...This film has buoyancy and urbane, tender charm
fields.body:
Followers of Antoine de Caunes might find it difficult to believe but, deprived of his Breetessh chooms and grotesque breast-implant models, he is actually an intelligent and stylish actor. Jean-Jacques Zilbermann's Man is a Woman stars De Caunes as Simon, a Jewish gay man devoted to cruising and partying who is promised a fortune by an exasperated uncle if he gets married. De Caunes lights on Rosalie (Elsa Zylberstein), a pretty singer of traditional Yiddish songs, strictly religious and keeping herself a virgin for her wedding night: a scene managed with a wonderfully light touch.

De Caunes plays everything without a hint of his trademark facetiousness and Zylberstein's performance as Rosalie, innocent yet aware of Simon's real longings, is very fine. This film has buoyancy and urbane, tender charm.

fields.headline: Simon Magus
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: [It] has a consistent and confident look, but there is something rather plodding about this romantic fantasy
fields.body:
Simon Magus is set in a 19th-century Silesian Jewish village and stars Noah Taylor as Simon the twitching, gibbering, leering fool and soi-disant witch - the outcast whose job when not casting spells is to empty the latrines and outhouses, carting the noisome burden around in his wheelbarrow. Simon is tempted by the devil (Ian Holm) to convert to Christianity - and in so doing becomes the unwitting tool in a plot by an anti-semitic gentile to foil a young Jew's attempts to buy valuable land by the new railway line.

Ben Hopkins's film has a consistent and confident look, but there is something rather plodding about this romantic fantasy, and for narrative resolution, it is over-reliant on a deus ex machina in the form of a kindly and bookish squire, improbably played by Rutger Hauer.
