fields.headline: The Girl on the Bridge
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Has not got much in the way of plot, but it has an insouciant, watchable quality
fields.body: Patrice Leconte's The Girl on the Bridge, shot in seductive monochrome, has an attractively nouvelle vague feel about it: the story of Adèle, played by Vanessa Paradis as the kind of waif who belongs to a bygone age: a gorgeous free- spirit, incessantly falling in love with unsuitable guys. About to throw herself despairingly into the Seine, she is detained by Gabor (Daniel Auteuil) who has a knife-throwing routine and haunts the bridge for precisely such uncaring suicides as she - to put in his act. Once together, they tour the clubs of the south of France, Adèle submitting to the compelling eroticism of having knives thrown at her by Gabor, who otherwise displays no interest other than fatherly disapproval of the guys she gets it on with. The Girl on the Bridge has not got much in the way of plot, but it has an insouciant, watchable quality.

fields.headline: Honest
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: It subscribes to the usual credulous fictions about the charm, glamour and wit of violent criminals, and leaves out these qualities in spades
fields.body:
Honest is yet another in the genre of Britpic gangster movies - will they stretch on to the crack of doom? Anyway, this new one stars Nicole and Natalie Appleton and Melanie Blatt of All Saints, and is directed by Dave Stewart, formerly of Eurythmics. Needless to say, it subscribes to the usual credulous fictions about the charm, glamour and wit of violent criminals, and leaves out these qualities in spades. Honest is set in 1968, and All Saints play three working-class East End girls, statuesque exquisites who have evidently had miraculous access to 21st-century diet, grooming, maquillage and gym regimen. Adorably feisty at all times, they do robberies - dressed as men! They apply male whiskers to their chins (from barbers'-shop floors?) and having laboriously done this, they wear masks. Who will ever know why?

However silly and implausible, it would be all right if there was the slightest hint of brio or fun in the script, written by comedy giants Dick Clement and Ian La Frenais. But there isn't, and some heavy drug stuff has landed it with an 18 certificate. Now all we need is a violent comedy gangland pic starring Chris Smith and The Corrs.

fields.headline: Stir of Echoes
fields.standfirst: An A-list player who has never made the A-list, Kevin Bacon is back in Stir of Echoes. Peter Bradshaw   celebrates
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: An efficient and entertaining ghost story... You can do a lot worse on a Friday night than this
fields.body:
Can it really be true that Kevin Bacon is just a couple of months shy of his 42nd birthday? This actor, who first came to our attention in Barry Levinson's Diner 18 years ago, has maintained effectively the same faintly overlooked presence ever since: coiled, muscular, yet open and always youthful and verging on naivety, with an agreeable, intelligent identity that suggests an existence outside the world of acting.

The classic definition of a star is someone with something missing rather than something extra and maybe Bacon has never had it missing, or not enough of it missing. Although he has always been a plausible leading player, actual stardom has always eluded him. Playing comedy could be an option for him of course: and yet he could be too subtle for the very broad neo-Jerry-Lewis style now in fashion and even the famous "Six Degrees" game is a slight on his abilities and achievements. He's not obscure enough for that to be interesting and you can play the six-removes game with anyone. (There used to be a similar game of being six handshakes away from Mao Zedong - you could win by getting within five handshakes of Edward Heath.)

So it is with something of a pang that Bacon's fans will see him bestow his presence on Stir of Echoes: an efficient and entertaining ghost story updated from an old tale by Richard Matheson, who wrote the screenplay for The Incredible Shrinking Man and the novel on which Spielberg based Duel.

Bacon plays Tom, a blue-collar Chicago guy who works for the telephone company, married with a five-year-old boy, and idly dreaming of making it as a rock musician. His wife Maggie (Kathryn Erbe) sours his mood by telling him she is pregnant again, placing his music ambitions even further out of reach and it is at this point that grouchy Tom is riled by his sister-in-law Illeana Douglas: another classic supporting player, whose jolie-laide looks condemn her to best-friend roles and making the leading lady look good.

She says he is not open to new experiences, and in her New Agey way hypnotises him, causing the initially derisive Bacon to succumb utterly and undergo a terrifying sense of communicating with the dead. And this gives him something in common with his son Jake, who communicates with the great beyond also, whispering things like: "Does it hurt being dead?"

Naturally, Stir of Echoes has elements of a Sixth Sense knock-off, especially when Bacon goes all cold and his breath condenses. But thankfully, it is not encumbered with a twist ending, and avoids all the silliness that finally sank Sixth Sense.

And the moments in which a child is menaced by a dead person are enjoyably unpleasant, especially the scene in which little Jake is trying to watch HR Pufnstuf on TV but the ghost keeps changing the channel to the horror film that he's not allowed to watch - which keeps playing even when the deeply bewildered Jake has actually pulled the plug out of the wall.

Bacon's own contact with the dead works best when it manifests itself in little glimpses of horror and desecration: the dreamed moment when a fingernail - perhaps Bacon's fingernail - is snapped off with a wince-inducing crack. And there is a clammy dream sequence in which Bacon visits the bathroom and seeing that one of his front teeth has gone completely rotten, colour of reddish mud, reaches into his mouth and after some effort pulls it out of his head together with a gout of blood. It is the most squeaming tooth scene since Richard Burton demonstrated John Hurt's utter physical abasement in the adaptation of Orwell's 1984 by pincering one of his teeth out with his finger and thumb.

Bacon himself endures all this sturdily, looking far younger than his years, and with his shirt off, his musculature has only slightly less definition than it did in Apollo 13, but still in good nick, and perfectly in line with the Abs Tyranny of modern Hollywood. Added to this is a distinctly serviceable script by director David Koepp, who allows Ileana Douglas to tell Maggie chirpily: "What you need is a young priest with smouldering good looks who can get you through all this!"

There is a workmanlike carpentry in Koepp's script and direction which satisfactorily launches moments of scariness and does not allow the narrative tension to sag or, as in The Sixth Sense, pitch into potholes of inconsistency and dullness. And Bacon is always an A-list player whose style elevates anything he's in. You can do a lot worse on a Friday night than this.

webTitle: The bank that likes to say 'Quoi?'

fields.headline: The bank that likes to say 'Quoi?'
fields.trailText: A self-employed French businessman who asked his bank to help him invest £60,000 of his savings in the stock market has ended up losing £1.9m.
fields.body:
A self-employed French businessman who asked his bank to help him invest £60,000 of his savings in the stock market has ended up losing £1.9m.

The French stock exchange watchdog yesterday opened an inquiry into the case of Gerard Pujol, whose bank, Union des Banques de Paris, is suing him for the entire debt despite the fact that it was one of its dealers who lost the money.

"I'm ruined," Mr Pujol said. "The ads say the value of your investments can fall as well as rise, but I thought I would be reasonably safe with my bank. The first I knew something was wrong was when they called me in, told me the trader concerned had been fired, and presented me with a bill for nearly £2m."

As a booming economy encourages hundreds of thousands of first-time investors to plunge gaily into a market that over the past several months has far outpaced New York's Dow Jones industrial average, more and more are discovering that if they have only a vague idea of what they are doing, their banks have even less.

"At the moment we're getting three or four cases a week of people who have lost not only their shirts but their cars and houses too," said Stéphan Alamowitch, a solicitor specialising in financial markets law, "and that's just in my firm. French banks and stockbrokers have tried to raise standards, but they're not there yet."

Mr Pujol is the most spectacular victim so far of a particularly dangerous Gallic investment practice known as règlement mensuel , or monthly settlement. Unique to France, this system allows investors to acquire shares by putting up just 20% of their market value and borrowing the rest. Profits and losses are accounted for at the end of each month when accounts must be settled.

Over a year this allowed Mr Pujol's ambitious if inept stockbroker to build up a portfolio of shares in high-performing, hi-tech companies worth £1.2m - 20 times his original input.

"Things did seem to be going rather well," he said, "but I thought the guy knew what he was doing. Then the hi-tech stocks crashed, and that was that. I'm countersuing for abuse of trust, but I don't have much hope. Banks can clearly do what they damn well like."
